However, the space in the dome alongside the entrance <b>is</b> wide <b>enough to</b> theoretically <b>carve out</b> space to <b>complete</b> a width of <b>four</b> handbreadths. <b>Rabbi Meir holds</b> that in all cases where a certain minimum area is required for a specific <i>halakha</i> to take effect and the existing area is smaller, if circumstances would theoretically allow one to carve out and create an area of the requisite size, its legal status is as if <b>one carves out</b> the space <b>to complete</b> it. Therefore, the opening is considered wide enough to require a <i>mezuza</i>. <b>And the Rabbis hold: One does not carve out</b> the space <b>to complete</b> it. Since the width of the opening is not actually four handbreadths, it is exempt from the mitzva of <i>mezuza</i>.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A synagogue, a woman’s house,</b> and <b>a house</b> jointly owned by <b>partners</b> are all <b>obligated in</b> the mitzva of <b><i>mezuza</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: That is <b>obvious;</b> why would these structures be exempt? <b>Lest you say</b> that it is written: <b>“Your house,”</b> in the masculine, <b>and not her house; “Your house,”</b> in the singular, <b>and not their house,</b> excluding a jointly owned house. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that those houses are obligated in the mitzva of <i>mezuza</i> like all others.
<b>And say</b> it is <b>indeed so</b> that a woman’s house and a jointly owned house are exempt. The Gemara rejects this possibility: Immediately following the mitzva of <i>mezuza</i> is the reward for its fulfillment, as <b>the verse states: “So that your days be numerous, as well as the days of your sons”</b> (Deuteronomy 11:21). If these structures were exempt from the mitzva, the question would arise: Do <b>these</b> men and individuals <b>require</b> long <b>life, and these,</b> meaning women and partners, <b>do not require</b> long <b>life?</b> The mitzva of <i>mezuza</i> clearly applies to all of them.
The Gemara then asks: <b>Rather, why do I</b> need the emphasis of the verse: <b>Your house,</b> if every house is obligated in the mitzva of <i>mezuza</i>? The Gemara answers: This could be understood <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rava, as Rava said:</b> Your house is interpreted to mean that the <i>mezuza</i> is placed in <b>the way that you enter</b> the house. <b>And when a person lifts</b> his foot to begin walking, <b>he lifts his right foot first.</b> Therefore, the <i>mezuza</i> is affixed on the right side of the doorway.
§ Apropos the <i>baraita</i> just cited, the Gemara cites a related <i>baraita</i> that addresses a different topic. <b>It was taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>A synagogue, a house</b> jointly owned by <b>partners, and a woman’s house become impure with</b> the impurity of <b>leprosy</b> of the house, like all other houses. The Gemara asks: That is <b>obvious;</b> why wouldn’t they become impure? The Gemara explains: <b>Lest you say</b> that it is written with regard to leprosy: <b>“And the one whom the house is his will come”</b> (Leviticus 14:35), which could be interpreted: <b>His and not hers; his and not theirs,</b> to the exclusion of a house owned by a woman or by partners. Therefore, <b>it teaches us</b> that these houses are also included in this <i>halakha</i>.
<b>And say</b> it is <b>indeed so</b> that a woman’s house and a jointly owned house are excluded from the impurity of leprosy. The Gemara responds that <b>the verse states: “In a house of the land of your possession”</b> (Leviticus 14:34). The word your is written in the plural form to teach that all houses in Eretz Yisrael are subject to this impurity. The Gemara asks: <b>Rather, why do I</b> need the emphasis of the term: <b>His,</b> if every house is subject to the impurity of leprosy? The Gemara answers that the term does not teach a <i>halakha</i> but reveals why a house might be afflicted with leprosy. The house belonging to <b>one who dedicates his house to himself</b> alone, <b>who refuses to lend his vessels</b> to others <b>and says that he does not have</b> them, will be punished. <b>The Holy One, Blessed be He, publicizes his</b> possessions for all to see <b>when</b> he is forced to <b>empty</b> them from <b>his house</b> due to leprosy. <b>This excludes</b> one <b>who lends his vessels to others;</b> his house is not afflicted with leprosy.
The Gemara raises another question: <b>And</b> with regard to a <b>synagogue, does it become impure with</b> the impurity of <b>leprosy? But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that synagogues and study halls become impure with</b> the impurity of <b>leprosy.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: And the one whom the house is his will come;</b> this is referring to a house <b>that is designated for him, excluding those</b> houses <b>that are not designated for him</b> but are public property.
The Gemara responds: This is <b>not difficult,</b> as it is the subject of a tannaitic dispute. <b>This</b> <i>baraita</i>, which states that a synagogue can become impure with the impurity of leprosy, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir; that</b> <i>baraita</i>, which states that a synagogue cannot become impure with the impurity of leprosy, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A synagogue in which there is a residence for the synagogue attendant is obligated in</b> the mitzva of <b><i>mezuza</i>,</b> as it is a dwelling. With regard to <b>a synagogue in which there is no residence, Rabbi Meir obligates</b> it in the mitzva of <i>mezuza</i>, <b>and the Rabbis exempt</b> it. Rabbi Meir deems a synagogue like a residence with regard to both a <i>mezuza</i> and its susceptibility to leprosy.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead a different resolution to the contradiction between the <i>baraitot</i> with regard to the synagogue. Both <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>and that</b> <i>baraita</i> are in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, and</b> it is <b>not difficult. This</b> <i>baraita</i>, which states that it can become impure, is referring to a synagogue <b>in which there is a place of residence; that</b> <i>baraita</i>, which states that it cannot become impure, is referring to a synagogue <b>in which there is not a place of residence.</b>
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead yet a different resolution to the contradiction between the <i>baraitot</i>: Both <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>and that</b> <i>baraita</i> are referring to synagogues <b>in which there is not a place of residence,</b>

Daf 12a

<b>and this</b> <i>baraita</i>, which states that a synagogue does not become impure, is referring to synagogues <b>in</b> large <b>cities.</b> Since those synagogues attract people from different places, the building is not the property of the local residents but that of the public. <b>And that</b> <i>baraita</i>, which states that a synagogue becomes impure, is referring to synagogues <b>in villages,</b> which belong solely to the residents of the village, and its status is like that of a house owned by partners.
The Gemara asks: <b>And do</b> the synagogues <b>in</b> large <b>cities not become ritually impure</b> with the impurity <b>of leprosy? Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that it is written: “In a house of the land of <b>your possession”</b> (Leviticus 14:34); the land of <b>your possession becomes ritually impure</b> with the impurity <b>of leprosy, and</b> the city of <b>Jerusalem does not become ritually impure</b> with the impurity <b>of leprosy,</b> since it belongs to all the Jewish people rather than to a specific tribe? <b>Rabbi Yehuda said: I heard</b> that it is <b>only the site of the Temple [<i>mikdash</i>] alone</b> that does not become ritually impure with the impurity of leprosy. It can be inferred <b>that</b> in the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, even <b>synagogues and study halls</b> in Jerusalem <b>become ritually impure</b> with the impurity <b>of leprosy, and</b> that is the case <b>even though they</b> are synagogues <b>in</b> large <b>cities.</b> The Gemara rejects this; rather, one must emend the <i>baraita</i> and <b>say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda said: I heard</b> that it is <b>only a sacred [<i>mekudash</i>] site alone.</b> That definition includes synagogues and study halls.
§ The Gemara explains the dispute in the <i>baraita</i> that was cited: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do</b> Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis <b>disagree? The first <i>tanna</i> holds: Jerusalem was not divided among the tribes</b> but belonged to all of the Jewish people, and as such it does not become ritually impure with the impurity of leprosy. <b>Rabbi Yehuda holds: Jerusalem was divided between the tribes</b> of Judah and Benjamin. Therefore, the same <i>halakhot</i> of impurity apply there as apply in all other cities in Eretz Yisrael.
The Gemara states: <b>And</b> that dispute corresponds <b>to the dispute</b> between <b>these <i>tanna’im</i>, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>What</b> part of the Temple <b>was</b> located <b>in the portion of</b> the tribe of <b>Judah?</b> It was the part including <b>the</b> entire <b>Temple Mount,</b> excluding those areas in the portion of Benjamin, <b>the chambers, and the courtyards. And what</b> part of the Temple <b>was in the portion of</b> the tribe of <b>Benjamin?</b> It was the part including <b>the Entrance Hall</b> of the Sanctuary, <b>and the Sanctuary, and the Holy of Holies. And a strip</b> of land <b>emerges</b> from <b>the portion of Judah and enters the portion of Benjamin on which the altar is built. And Benjamin the righteous would suffer</b> longing <b>to engulf it every day.</b> The tribe of Benjamin was disappointed that the strip belonging to the tribe of Judah intersected its tribal land and wanted Judah to transfer ownership so that the land with the altar would belong to Benjamin.
An allusion to this is <b>that</b> which <b>is stated</b> in Moses’ blessing to Benjamin: <b>“Ever does he protect him</b> and he rests between his shoulders” (Deuteronomy 33:12), like one who is unable to abide something stuck between his shoulders and constantly rubs it to remove it. <b>Therefore, Benjamin the righteous was privileged to serve as host [<i>ushpizekhan</i>] to the Almighty, as it is stated: “And he rests between his shoulders,”</b> alluding to the fact that the Holy of Holies was located in the territory of Benjamin. According to this <i>baraita</i>, Jerusalem was divided among the tribes.
<b>And this <i>tanna</i> holds: Jerusalem was not divided among the tribes</b> at all, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Homeowners did <b>not let</b> their <b>houses in Jerusalem because</b> the houses <b>were not</b> actually <b>theirs.</b> Residents of Jerusalem did not own their residences, as the city belonged to the entire Jewish people. <b>Rabbi Elazar bar Tzadok says: Even beds</b> were <b>not</b> rented. <b>Therefore,</b> with regard to <b>hides of consecrated animals</b> of the Festival peace-offerings, which the pilgrims to Jerusalem would give as gifts to their hosts, the hosts were not really entitled to them. This is why <b>the hosts</b> would <b>take them by force. Abaye said: Learn from it that it is customary for a guest to leave</b> his empty wine <b>jug and hides</b> from sacrificial animals and give them <b>to his host.</b>
After discussing the status of Jerusalem, the Gemara addresses the matter of synagogues in villages. The Gemara asks: <b>And do</b> the synagogues <b>in villages become impure</b> with the impurity <b>of leprosy? Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> as follows? It is written: “When you enter the land of Canaan that I give you <b>for a possession,</b> and I put the plague of leprosy in a house of the land of your possession” (Leviticus 14:34). The term: “For a possession,” means <b>until you conquer it</b> and it becomes entirely yours. However, in a case where <b>they conquered it but did not divide it among the tribes,</b> or where <b>they divided</b> it <b>among the tribes but did not distribute</b> it <b>to the patrilineal families;</b> or where <b>they distributed</b> it <b>to the patrilineal families, but every one</b> of them <b>does not recognize his</b> individual portion, <b>from where</b> is it derived that it does not become impure?
<b>The verse states: “And the one whom the house is his will come”</b> (Leviticus 14:35); one <b>whom</b> the house <b>is designated for him</b> and who is certain of his ownership, <b>excluding those</b> houses <b>which are not designated for him.</b> Apparently, the legal status of synagogues in villages is that of communal property, as the portion of each individual is not clearly identifiable, and therefore they cannot become impure. <b>Rather,</b> there is no distinction in this regard between synagogues in large cities and those in villages. And with regard to the original question, <b>it is clear as we responded initially</b> with alternative resolutions to the contradiction between the <i>baraitot</i>.
§ It was taught in the mishna: <b>And they would designate another priest</b> in the High Priest’s stead, lest a disqualification due to impurity prevent his entering the Temple on Yom Kippur. The Gemara asks: It is <b>obvious</b> that if <b>disqualification befell</b> the incumbent High Priest <b>prior to the</b> sacrifice of the <b>daily morning offering</b> on Yom Kippur, that <b>one initiates</b> the replacement by dressing him in the eight garments of the High Priest <b>with the daily morning offering,</b> which renders him acting High Priest. <b>However,</b> if <b>disqualification befell</b> the incumbent High Priest <b>after the daily morning offering, how does one initiate</b> the replacement? After the daily morning offering, the High Priest begins the Yom Kippur service clothed in the four linen garments unique to the day, which are the same as the tunic, trousers, turban, and belt of the common priest. How is it evident that he is the acting High Priest?
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said:</b> It is evident <b>by</b> means of his <b>belt.</b> The belt worn by the High Priest on Yom Kippur was made of linen, unlike that of the common priest, which was a mixture of the diverse kinds of linen and wool. The Gemara asks: <b>This</b> works out <b>well</b> according <b>to the one who said:</b> Throughout the rest of the year, <b>the belt of the High Priest,</b> which the Torah clearly states is made of a mixture of diverse kinds, <b>is</b> identical to <b>the belt of the common priest,</b> whereas on Yom Kippur, the belt is made of linen. When the replacement priest dons the linen belt he is initiated as the acting High Priest. <b>However, according to the one who said: The belt of the High Priest is not</b> identical to <b>the belt of the common priest, what can be said?</b> According to this approach, throughout the year the High Priest wears a belt of blue and purple wool and linen, while the belts of common priests are made of white linen like the rest of their clothes. Therefore, on Yom Kippur, when the High Priest dons a belt of white linen, his belt is identical to that of a common priest. If so, what initiates the replacement as acting High Priest?
<b>Abaye said:</b> Before the replacement begins serving on Yom Kippur with the four linen garments, he is initiated and promoted to the High Priesthood by <b>donning</b> the <b>eight</b> garments of the High Priest <b>and turning over</b> one of the limbs on the altar <b>with a fork,</b> thereby accelerating the burning of the daily morning offering. By performing part of the service while wearing the garments of the High Priest, he is initiated as acting High Priest. <b>And</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Huna, as Rav Huna said: A non-priest who turns over</b> part of the offering on the altar <b>with a fork is liable</b> to receive the <b>death</b> penalty because he engaged in Temple service restricted to priests. <b>And Rav Pappa said:</b>

Daf 12b

That action is unnecessary and therefore superfluous; <b>his service initiates him.</b> The replacement High Priest need not undergo any preliminary initiation. His very performance of the Yom Kippur service, which is valid only if performed by the High Priest, initiates him as acting High Priest. As proof, the Gemara states: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>all the</b> sacred <b>vessels that Moses made, their anointment</b> with oil <b>consecrates them. From that</b> point <b>forward,</b> in the generations after Moses, new vessels did not require anointment to be consecrated; rather, <b>their</b> use in Temple <b>service initiates them</b> and renders them fit for use. <b>Here, too,</b> with regard to the High Priest, <b>his service initiates him.</b>
§ Apropos the belt of the High Priest, the Gemara cites the aforementioned dispute in its entirety. <b>When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia <b>he said:</b> With regard to <b>the belt of the common priest,</b> there is a dispute between <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>and Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon. One said:</b> It was a mixture <b>of diverse kinds</b> of wool and linen, like the belt of the High Priest mentioned in the Torah. <b>And one said:</b> It was made of <b>fine linen,</b> like the rest of the garments of the common priest.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Conclude that it is Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>who said</b> that the belt of the common priest was a mixture <b>of diverse kinds, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The only</b> difference <b>between a High Priest and a common priest is</b> the <b>belt;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, says: Not even</b> the <b>belt</b> represents a difference between them. The Gemara explains: With regard to the difference between the High Priest and the common priest, <b>when</b> is there a dispute between the <i>tanna’im</i>? <b>If we say</b> that the dispute is with regard to <b>the rest of the days of the year, there are many</b> other differences between them, since <b>the High Priest serves</b> wearing <b>eight garments and the common</b> priest wears <b>four</b> garments. Therefore, that could not be the point of the dispute.
<b>Rather,</b> is it <b>not</b> that the dispute is with regard to the differences between the High Priest and the common priest on <b>Yom Kippur?</b> They agree that the belt of the High Priest on Yom Kippur is made of linen, but disagree with regard to the common priest’s belt. According to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, who says that there is a difference between the belts, the belt of the common priest must be made of a mixture of diverse kinds. According to Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, who says that there is no difference between their belts, the belt of the common priest must be made of linen, like that of the High Priest on Yom Kippur.
The Gemara rejects this proof. The Sages <b>say: No,</b> this is not a proof, as <b>actually,</b> the dispute is with regard to the differences <b>during the rest of the days of the year.</b> However, the dispute is not with regard to all the differences between the High Priest and the common priest, but rather only with regard to <b>those</b> four garments <b>common</b> to both priests: The tunic, trousers, turban, and belt. Based on this understanding that the dispute is with regard to the rest of the year, the analysis of the dispute is reversed: According to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi the belt of the High Priest is a mixture of diverse kinds and that of the common priest is made of linen, while according to Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, the belt of the common priest is a mixture of diverse kinds. Therefore, there is no definitive proof from the <i>baraita</i>.
<b>When Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia <b>he stated</b> this tradition in a clearer fashion: With regard to <b>the belt of the High Priest on Yom Kippur, everyone agrees</b> that it is made <b>of fine linen,</b> as stated in the Torah. With regard to <b>the belt of the High Priest during the rest of the days of the year, everyone agrees</b> that it is a mixture <b>of diverse kinds. They disagreed only with regard to the belt of the common priest both during the rest of the days of the year and on Yom Kippur, as Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi says: It was a mixture <b>of diverse kinds, and Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, says</b> it was made <b>of linen.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: We, too, have learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The Torah says with regard to the removal of the ashes from the altar: “And the priest shall put on his linen garment, and his linen trousers shall he put <b>upon his flesh”</b> (Leviticus 6:3). The <i>baraita</i> questions the formulation of the verse. Since at the beginning of the verse it is written: “And the priest shall put on,” for <b>what</b> purpose <b>does the verse state: “Shall he put upon,”</b> in the latter part of the verse? <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> It comes <b>to include</b> donning the <b>mitre</b> and the <b>belt for the removal of the ashes,</b> even though it is not explicitly stated in the verse. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>Rabbi Dosa says</b> that the term: Shall put on, comes <b>to include</b> the <i>halakha</i> that <b>the garments of the High Priest on Yom Kippur are fit for a common priest.</b> During the Yom Kippur service, the High Priest wears just four linen garments. Although he may not serve in those garments on Yom Kippur the following year, a common priest may serve in them during the rest of the year. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: There are two responses to</b> reject this <b>statement</b> of Rabbi Dosa. <b>One: The belt of the High Priest on Yom Kippur is not</b> the same as <b>the belt of the common priest</b> during the rest of the year. Clearly, according to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, the belt of the High Priest on Yom Kippur is made of linen, and that of the common priest during the year is a mixture of the diverse kinds of wool and linen.
<b>And furthermore,</b> there is another reason to reject the statement of Rabbi Dosa. Could it be that with regard to <b>garments that were used</b> by the High Priest to perform a service of <b>extreme sanctity,</b> the common priest <b>will use them</b> to perform a service of <b>minor sanctity? Rather,</b> according to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, for <b>what</b> purpose <b>does the verse state</b> the phrase: <b>Shall put on?</b> It comes <b>to include threadbare</b> garments and to teach that as long as they are not completely tattered, they may be worn for that service.
<b>And Rabbi Dosa follows his</b> line of <b>reasoning, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: That which is written: “And Aaron shall come into the Tent of Meeting, and shall put off the linen garments, which he put on when he went into the Sanctuary, <b>and shall leave them there”</b> (Leviticus 16:23), <b>teaches</b> that the garments worn by the High Priest on Yom Kippur <b>require interment</b> and may not be put to additional use. <b>Rabbi Dosa says:</b> It means only that the High Priest <b>may not use them</b> on <b>Yom Kippur</b> in <b>a different</b> year. According to Rabbi Dosa, they may be worn by a common priest during his service, as they do not require interment.
§ The Gemara returns to the initiation of the acting High Priest. <b>The Sages taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: If <b>a disqualification befalls</b> the High Priest <b>and they appointed another in his stead,</b> and then the cause of the disqualification of the High Priest is resolved, e.g., he was purified from impurity, the <b>original</b> High Priest <b>returns to his service.</b> With regard to the <b>second,</b> acting High Priest, <b>all the mitzvot of the High Priesthood are</b> incumbent <b>upon him.</b> He serves wearing eight garments and it is prohibited for him to let his hair grow, to rend his garments in mourning the death of a relative, to subject himself to impurity imparted by the corpse of a relative, or to marry a widow. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> The <b>original</b> priest <b>returns to his service,</b> while the <b>second is fit</b> to serve <b>neither as High Priest</b> with eight garments, because there is a different High Priest; <b>nor as a common priest</b> with four garments, as once he was elevated to a state of extreme sanctity he may not be reduced to a state of minor sanctity.
<b>Rabbi Yosei said</b> as proof for his opinion: There was <b>an incident involving</b> the priest <b>Yosef ben Elem of Tzippori,</b> who, when a reason for <b>disqualification befell a High Priest,</b> the priests <b>appointed him in his stead.</b> After the cause of the disqualification was resolved, <b>the Sages said:</b> The <b>original</b> High Priest <b>returns to his service,</b> while the <b>second is fit</b> to serve <b>neither as High Priest nor as a common priest.</b> The Gemara explains: Neither as a <b>High Priest, due to hatred,</b> jealousy and bitterness that would arise if there were two High Priests with equal standing in the Temple; nor as a <b>common priest, because</b> the principle is: <b>One elevates</b> to a higher level <b>in</b> matters of <b>sanctity and one does not downgrade.</b> Once he has served as a High Priest he cannot be restored to the position of a common priest.
<b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b>

Daf 13a

The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> that the original High Priest returns to his service, while the second is fit to serve neither as High Priest nor as a common priest. <b>And Rabbi Yosei concedes that if</b> the second priest <b>violated</b> this provision <b>and served</b> as High Priest wearing eight garments, <b>his service is valid. Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, and Rabbi Yosei conceded that if</b> the <b>original</b> High Priest <b>dies,</b> the second <b>returns to his service</b> as High Priest.
The Gemara asks: That is <b>obvious.</b> Clearly, the second priest may serve as High Priest after the first one dies without concern that their rivalry will generate hatred between them. The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say</b> that the mere knowledge that another priest is in waiting to replace him is enough to generate hatred, and <b>would be for him</b> like a woman whose husband has taken a <b>rival wife in</b> her <b>lifetime;</b> therefore, Rav <b>teaches us</b> that this is not a concern.
§ It was taught in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The Sages would <b>even designate another wife for</b> the High Priest lest his wife die. The Rabbis say: There is no concern lest his wife die, and therefore the Sages did not designate another wife for him. The Gemara asks with regard to <b>the Rabbis: Aren’t they concerned lest</b> he become impure, which is why the Sages designate a replacement High Priest? Why then, are they not concerned lest his wife die? The Gemara answers that <b>the Rabbis</b> could have <b>said to you: Impurity is common,</b> as it is not unusual for the High Priest to become impure either due to secretions from his body or from an external source. <b>Death is not common,</b> and therefore there is no concern lest his wife die.
It was taught in the mishna that <b>the Rabbis said to</b> Rabbi Yehuda: <b>If so,</b> that you are concerned lest his wife die, <b>there is no end to the matter.</b> You should also be concerned lest the second wife die, requiring designation of a third and even a fourth wife. The Gemara comments: The Rabbis <b>spoke well to Rabbi Yehuda,</b> making a good point. What can Rabbi Yehuda respond? <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> could have <b>said to you: For</b> the potential <b>death of one</b> wife, <b>we are concerned; for</b> the potential <b>death of two</b> wives, <b>we are not concerned,</b> as the likelihood of that happening is negligible. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what would <b>the Rabbis</b> respond to that contention? They would say: <b>If there is</b> reason <b>to be concerned</b> for a potential death, then <b>even for</b> the potential <b>death of two</b> wives, <b>we are concerned.</b>
The Gemara suggests: If according to <b>the Rabbis</b> there is no distinction between concern that one wife might die and concern that two wives might die, <b>let them say</b> the same with regard <b>to their own</b> opinion. Just as they designate a replacement lest the High Priest become impure, they should designate a second replacement lest the first replacement also become impure. The Gemara answers that <b>the Rabbis</b> could have <b>said to you: The High Priest is vigilant</b> in avoiding impurity. No amount of vigilance can prevent death. The Gemara asks: <b>If he is vigilant</b> in avoiding impurity, then <b>why do</b> the Sages <b>designate another priest</b> in his stead? The reason for the designation of the replacement is that <b>once we establish</b> a replacement as a <b>rival, all the more so</b> will the High Priest <b>be</b> even <b>more vigilant</b> in avoiding impurity to maintain his position.
§ The Gemara asks with regard to Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion: <b>And is designation</b> of a second wife <b>sufficient for him? The Merciful One stated</b> in the Torah: “And he shall make atonement for himself and for <b>his house”</b> (Leviticus 16:11). House means wife; <b>and this</b> designated woman <b>is not his wife</b> as they are not yet married. What purpose does designation serve if his wife dies on Yom Kippur? The Gemara answers: <b>He betroths her</b> before Yom Kippur. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> that does not solve the problem. <b>As long as he has not married her, she is not</b> yet <b>his house,</b> i.e., his wife. The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yehuda says <b>that</b> not only is a replacement wife designated, but <b>he</b> actually <b>marries her. If so,</b> another problem arises. The High Priest <b>has two houses, and the Merciful One said: “And he shall make atonement for himself and for his house”</b> (Leviticus 16:11). He atones for one house <b>and not for two houses.</b>
The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yehuda says <b>that</b> after marrying the second wife, <b>he then divorces her.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>If he divorces her, our difficulty is restored to its</b> original <b>place.</b> There is no point in designating a second wife, as if the first wife dies, the second woman is not married to him. The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> in a case <b>where</b> he marries her and <b>divorces her provisionally, as he says to her: This is your bill of divorce on condition that you die</b> on Yom Kippur. If she dies on Yom Kippur, then she was divorced retroactively and he has only one wife; if she does not die but the original wife dies, her divorce does not take effect and the second wife is married to the High Priest. In either case, the High Priest has only one wife. The Gemara asks: <b>And perhaps neither</b> she nor the original wife <b>will die, and</b> the High Priest then <b>has two houses</b> on Yom Kippur.
<b>Rather,</b> it is a case <b>where</b> the High Priest <b>said to her,</b> the woman designated: <b>This is your bill of divorce on condition that you will not die</b> on Yom Kippur. <b>If</b> she does <b>not die,</b> then <b>she is divorced</b> and he remains married to the original wife; <b>if she dies, isn’t that</b> original wife <b>alive</b> and he remains married to her alone? The Gemara asks: <b>And perhaps the</b> second one will <b>not die and her bill of divorce will be</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce,</b> meaning she is not his wife, but <b>her counterpart</b> might die, <b>leaving</b> the High Priest <b>without a wife</b> at all on Yom Kippur.
<b>Rather,</b> it is a case <b>where</b> the High Priest <b>said to her: This is your bill of divorce on condition that one of you dies.</b> If <b>this</b> one <b>dies, that</b> one <b>is alive,</b> and if <b>that</b> one <b>dies, isn’t this</b> one <b>alive?</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And perhaps neither one of them</b> will <b>die, and he will</b> then <b>have two houses.</b>
<b>And furthermore,</b> the question arises: <b>Is</b> a document <b>of that sort</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce?</b> Does a condition of that sort take effect? <b>But didn’t Rava say:</b> If a man says to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce on condition that you will not drink wine</b> for <b>all the days of my life and your life, that is not severance.</b> The bill of divorce in the Torah is called a bill of severance, meaning that for the document to be valid all connections between the husband and wife must be severed. If there is a provision in the document that maintains a permanent connection between the spouses, e.g., not to drink wine for all of her life, the document does not effect a valid divorce.
However, if one said to his wife: This is your bill of divorce on condition that you will not drink wine during <b>all the days of the life of so-and-so; that is severance.</b> Since the condition is not dependent on her and him but on the life of a third party, it is like any other condition in a divorce. Therefore, in the case of the High Priest, since the divorce takes effect only if neither of the women dies, that is a condition that maintains a relationship between the husband and wife for as long as she lives, which invalidates the divorce.
<b>Rather,</b> it is a case <b>where</b> the High Priest <b>said to</b> the second wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce on condition that your counterpart,</b> the other wife, <b>will not die. If her counterpart,</b> the first woman, <b>does not die,</b> the second woman <b>is divorced; and if</b> the first woman <b>dies, isn’t</b> the second woman <b>alive</b> and not divorced? The Gemara asks: <b>And perhaps her counterpart will die in the middle of the</b> Yom Kippur <b>service, and it will become clear</b>

Daf 13b

<b>retroactively that the bill of divorce of this</b> second woman <b>is not a</b> valid <b>bill of divorce,</b> since the first wife died. In that case, it turns out retroactively that <b>he performed</b> part of <b>the service with two houses,</b> married to two wives. <b>Rather,</b> it is a case <b>where</b> the High Priest <b>said to</b> the second wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce on condition that your counterpart dies.</b> The Gemara asks: In this case, too, <b>perhaps her counterpart</b> will <b>die and the bill of divorce of this</b> second woman <b>is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce, and</b> he will <b>remain without a house</b> at all.
<b>Rather,</b> this is a case where <b>he divorces both of them</b> provisionally, with a different stipulation to each woman. <b>To one, he says: This is your bill of divorce on condition that your counterpart will not die. And to</b> the other <b>one, he says: This is your bill of divorce on condition that you will not enter the synagogue</b> on Yom Kippur, cognizant of the fact that she can easily fulfill that condition and thereby effect her divorce. The Gemara asks: <b>And perhaps her counterpart</b> will <b>not die,</b> fulfilling the condition and effecting the divorce of one wife; <b>and she will not enter the synagogue,</b> fulfilling the condition and effecting the divorce of the other wife. In that case <b>the bill of divorce of both</b> women <b>is a</b> valid <b>bill of divorce and he remains without a wife.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> it is a case where <b>to one</b> of the women, the High Priest <b>says: This is your bill of divorce on condition that your counterpart does not die. And to</b> the other <b>one</b> of the women <b>he says: This is your bill of divorce on condition that I will enter the synagogue. If this</b> wife <b>dies, that</b> other <b>one is alive; and if that</b> other one <b>dies, this</b> one <b>is alive. What is there to say</b> in refuting this possibility? <b>Perhaps her counterpart will die in the middle of the service,</b> and it will turn out retroactively that <b>he performed</b> part of <b>the service with two houses,</b> married to two wives. <b>If he sees that she seeks,</b> i.e., she is about <b>to die, he</b> will then <b>preemptively enter the synagogue, rendering the bill of divorce of</b> the dying wife <b>a</b> valid <b>bill of divorce retroactively.</b> He will then be married to only one woman. In that way, a second wife can be designated for the High Priest without him being married to two women on Yom Kippur.
<b>Rav Asi, and some say</b> it was <b>Rav Avira, strongly objects to</b> that conclusion: <b>However, if</b> that is <b>so,</b> that from the term: His house, in the singular, one derives one wife and not two, then <b>two widows of a brother who died without a child [<i>yevamot</i>] who come from one house,</b> i.e., they were married to the same man, should <b>not be</b> obligated <b>to</b> marry his brother in <b>levirate marriage.</b> In addressing levirate marriage, the Torah says: “So shall it be done to the man that does not build his brother’s house” (Deuteronomy 25:9). One may derive from this: One house, i.e., wife, and not two. The Gemara responds that when the Torah says: “Then <b>his <i>yevama</i></b> shall go up to the gate” (Deuteronomy 25:7), “and <b>his <i>yevama</i></b> will draw nigh to him” (Deuteronomy 25:9), twice, it comes to <b>include</b> a situation where the deceased had two wives; in that case one of them is required to marry his brother in levirate marriage.
<b>Ravina, and some say</b> it was <b>Rav Sherevya, strongly objects to this:</b> It was stated above that a woman betrothed to the High Priest is not considered his house, i.e., his wife. <b>However, if</b> that is <b>so, a betrothed</b> woman whose betrothed passed away should <b>not be</b> obligated <b>to</b> marry his brother in <b>levirate marriage,</b> since the term: House, appears in that context as well. In practice, that is not the <i>halakha</i>. The Gemara answers that the Torah says: “The wife of the dead shall not be married <b>outside</b> to one not of his kin” (Deuteronomy 25:5). The superfluous term: Outside, comes <b>to include the betrothed woman.</b> Although she is technically still outside the family, the brother of the deceased must either marry her in levirate marriage or perform <i>ḥalitza</i>.
§ Apropos the death of the wife of the High Priest, the Gemara cites an additional <i>baraita</i>. <b>The Sages taught: A High Priest sacrifices</b> offerings when he is an <b>acute mourner,</b> on the day of a relative’s death, but <b>does not eat</b> from those offerings. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: The entire day.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the phrase: <b>The entire day?</b> Rava said: This phrase <b>is necessary only to bring him from his house.</b> Not only is it permitted for the High Priest to serve in the Temple when he is an acute mourner, but it is a mitzva to bring him from his house to serve in the Temple for the entire day to help ease his pain.
<b>Abaye said to him: Now,</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, we remove</b> the High Priest from the Temple when he is an acute mourner, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If a common priest <b>was standing and sacrificing</b> an offering <b>on top of the altar and heard that</b> a relative <b>of his died, he leaves his service</b> in the middle <b>and exits</b> the Temple; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei says: He completes</b> the service and then leaves. Rabbi Yehuda rules stringently in the case of a priest who is an acute mourner sacrificing an offering. Even though the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a common priest, it is reasonable to say that the same is true with regard to a High Priest as well. Rabbi Yehuda says that a High Priest who becomes an acute mourner exits the Temple, <b>and you say we bring</b> the High Priest who is an acute mourner <b>from his house</b> to serve?
<b>Rather, Rava said:</b> The initial interpretation must be rejected. <b>What</b> is the meaning of the phrase: <b>The entire day?</b>

Daf 14a

Rabbi Yehuda means <b>to say that</b> the High Priest <b>does not serve for the entire day</b> even though the Torah allows him to do so, due to a rabbinic <b>decree lest</b> he forget that he is an acute mourner and <b>eat</b> consecrated food forbidden to him. <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said to Rava: And did Rabbi Yehuda issue a decree lest he eat? But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The Sages would <b>even designate another wife for him lest his wife die? And if his wife dies,</b> he nevertheless <b>performs</b> the Temple <b>service, and Rabbi Yehuda did not issue a decree lest he eat.</b> That contradicts the other statement by Rabbi Yehuda that a High Priest may not serve for the entire day that he is an acute mourner. Rava <b>said to him: How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> in the mishna, <b>since it is Yom Kippur, when everyone does not eat, he too</b> will <b>not come to eat.</b> However, <b>here,</b> during the rest of the year, <b>when everyone eats, he too</b> will <b>come to eat.</b> Therefore, a decree was issued.
The Gemara raises a question from a different perspective: <b>And</b> in a case <b>like this,</b> would the halakhic status of <b>acute mourning take effect on him,</b> considering that <b>she is divorced?</b> According to Rabbi Yehuda, the High Priest must give his wife a provisional divorce in which case she is no longer his wife and if she dies he is no longer obligated to mourn her. The Gemara answers: <b>Although</b> the status of <b>acute mourning does not take effect on him, is he not troubled</b> over the death of his wife? Therefore, according to Rabbi Yehuda, it is appropriate to prohibit his performance of the service on that day.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> During <b>all seven days</b> of the High Priest’s sequestering before Yom Kippur, <b>he sprinkles the blood</b> of the daily burnt-offering, <b>and he burns the incense, and he removes</b> the ashes of <b>the lamps</b> of the candelabrum, <b>and he sacrifices the head and the</b> hind <b>leg</b> of the daily offering. The High Priest performs these tasks in order to grow accustomed to the services that he will perform on Yom Kippur. <b>On all the other days</b> of the year, <b>if</b> the High Priest <b>wishes to sacrifice</b> any of the offerings, <b>he sacrifices them, as the High Priest sacrifices</b> any <b>portion</b> that he chooses <b>first and takes</b> any <b>portion</b> that he chooses <b>first.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>Who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> who <b>taught</b> this mishna? <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> This mishna is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, as if</b> it were in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> it is difficult. <b>Didn’t</b> Rabbi Akiva <b>say:</b> With regard to a <b>ritually pure</b> person <b>upon whom a sprinkling</b> of purification water <b>fell, it renders him impure?</b> This is based on the enigmatic principle with regard to the water of the red heifer: It purifies the ritually impure and renders impure the ritually pure. If so, <b>how</b> can the High Priest <b>perform the</b> Temple <b>service?</b> The High Priest is sprinkled with purification water on each of the seven days of his sequestering due to the possibility that he was impure with impurity imparted by a corpse. However, it is possible that he is ritually pure. If he is ritually pure, the sprinkling will render him impure.
<b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that it is written: <b>“And the pure person will sprinkle it upon the impure person”</b> (Numbers 19:19); this emphasis that he sprinkles the water upon the impure person comes to teach that if he sprinkled <b>on the ritually impure</b> person, that person becomes <b>pure; but</b> if he sprinkled <b>on the pure</b> person, that person becomes <b>ritually impure.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva. And the Rabbis say: These matters are stated</b> to teach that it is considered sprinkling <b>only</b> if it is performed <b>on items susceptible to impurity,</b> whereas if the water was sprinkled on items not susceptible to impurity, it is not considered sprinkling.
<b>What is</b> the halakhic implication of that statement? It is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna: With regard to one who mistakenly <b>intended to sprinkle</b> purification water <b>on an animal,</b> which does not become impure when alive, <b>but</b> happened to <b>sprinkle</b> it <b>upon</b> an impure <b>person, if</b> water remains <b>on the hyssop</b> that he used to sprinkle the water, <b>he</b> should <b>repeat</b> the action and sprinkle the purification water on the person to purify him. Since the first sprinkling was onto a person, who can become impure, the water remaining on the hyssop may be reused, and it is not disqualified by improper use. However, with regard to one who <b>intended to sprinkle</b> purification water <b>on a person but</b> happened to <b>sprinkle</b> it <b>upon an animal,</b> even <b>if</b> water remains <b>on the hyssop, he</b> should <b>not repeat</b> the action. Since the first sprinkling was onto an animal, which cannot become impure, the water is disqualified by improper use, and may not be used in a second sprinkling.
The Gemara analyzes the basis of the dispute: <b>What is the reason for</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Akiva?</b> Instead of writing: And the pure person will sprinkle it upon the impure person, <b>let the Merciful One write</b> in the Torah: <b>And the pure person will sprinkle it upon him,</b> and it would be clear that it is upon the aforementioned impure person. <b>What</b> is taught by the phrase: <b>Upon the impure person? Learn from it</b> that if he sprinkled <b>on the impure</b> person, that person becomes <b>pure; but</b> if he sprinkled <b>on the pure</b> person, that person becomes <b>impure. And the Rabbis</b> say with regard to <b>that</b> phrase: <b>It comes</b> to teach that it is only considered sprinkling if it is performed <b>on items susceptible to impurity. However, here,</b> with regard to sprinkling purification water on a pure person, it is derived through an <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference that he remains ritually pure: <b>If</b> the water falls <b>on the impure</b> person, he is <b>pure;</b> if the water falls on <b>the pure</b> person, <b>all the more so</b> is it <b>not</b> clear that he remains pure?
<b>And Rabbi Akiva</b> would respond to that <i>a fortiori</i> inference: <b>That is what</b> King <b>Solomon said: “I said I would become wise, but it eludes me”</b> (Ecclesiastes 7:23). According to tradition, even Solomon in his great wisdom could not understand the contradictory nature of the sprinkling of purification water that purifies an impure person and impurifies a pure person. <b>And the Rabbis</b> ascribe Solomon’s bewilderment to a different aspect of the <i>halakha</i>: <b>The one who sprinkles</b> the water <b>and the one upon whom one sprinkles</b> the water are <b>pure; but one who touches</b> the water unrelated to sprinkling is <b>impure.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Is</b> the <b>one who sprinkles</b> the water actually <b>pure? Isn’t it written: “He who sprinkles the purification waters will wash his clothes,</b> and he who touches the purification waters will be unclean until evening” (Numbers 19:21)? The Gemara responds: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the term: <b>He who sprinkles?</b> It means: <b>He who touches. But isn’t it written: He who sprinkles? And isn’t it written</b> in the same verse: And <b>he who touches? And furthermore,</b> in that verse, <b>one who sprinkles requires washing</b> of his <b>clothes,</b> indicating a more severe level of impurity, whereas <b>one who touches does not require washing</b> of his <b>clothes.</b> Apparently, when it is written: He who sprinkles, it is not referring to one who touches.
<b>Rather,</b> the Rabbis assert: <b>What</b> is the meaning of: <b>He who sprinkles?</b> It refers to <b>one who carries</b> the purification water. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, <b>let the Merciful One write: One who carries; what is the reason</b> that <b>he who sprinkles is written</b> if the reference is to carrying? The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> use of the term sprinkling to depict carrying <b>teaches us</b> that in order to become impure from carrying purification water, one <b>must</b> carry the <b>measure</b> required for <b>sprinkling.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>This</b> works out <b>well</b> according <b>to the one who said</b> that <b>sprinkling requires a</b> minimum <b>measure</b> of water, as then the concept of a measure required for sprinkling has meaning. <b>However,</b> according <b>to the one who said</b> that <b>sprinkling does not require a</b> minimum <b>measure</b> of water, <b>what can be said?</b> There is no concept of a measure required for sprinkling. The Gemara answers: <b>Even</b> according <b>to the one who said</b> that <b>sprinkling does not require a</b> minimum <b>measure</b> of water, <b>that applies</b> only to the measure of purification water that must be sprinkled on <b>the back of the</b> impure <b>man;</b> any amount will suffice. <b>However, in the vessel</b> into which one dips the hyssop in order to sprinkle the water, a certain <b>measure</b> of water <b>is required, as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>How much</b> water should <b>be in</b> the vessel so that it <b>will be equivalent</b> to the measure required for <b>sprinkling?</b> It must be <b>equivalent</b> to the measure required <b>to dip</b>

Daf 14b

<b>the tops of the stems</b> of the hyssop branch into the water <b>and sprinkle it.</b> Apparently, even according to the one who said that there is no minimum measure of water for sprinkling there is a minimum measure of water that must be in the vessel. <b>Abaye said: Even</b> if <b>you say</b> that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> who said that the purification water impurifies the pure, the difficulty can be resolved: The High Priest <b>performs the</b> Temple <b>service</b> for <b>the entire day</b> on each of the seven days of sequestering, <b>and toward the evening</b> the priests <b>sprinkle</b> the purification water <b>upon him.</b> Even if he was pure and the sprinkling rendered him impure, he <b>immerses</b> immediately <b>and observes</b> the requirement to wait <b>until sunset,</b> at which point he is purified and prepared to serve the next day.
§ The mishna teaches that on each of the seven days the High Priest <b>burns the incense and removes</b> the ashes from <b>the lamps. Apparently, incense</b> is burned <b>first, and then the lamps</b> are cleaned. <b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from a mishna in tractate <i>Tamid</i> that discusses the lottery in which the priests performing the various tasks that constitute the morning Temple service are selected. That mishna first mentions the one <b>who was privileged</b> to be selected to perform <b>removal of the ashes from the inner altar,</b> and then <b>the one who was privileged</b> to be selected to remove the ashes from the lamps of <b>the candelabrum,</b> and only then does it deal with <b>the one who is privileged</b> to be selected to burn <b>the incense.</b> According to that mishna, removing ashes from the candelabrum precedes the burning of the incense.
<b>Rav Huna said: Who is</b> the <i>tanna</i> who <b>taught</b> the <i>mishnayot</i> in tractate <b><i>Tamid</i>? It is Rabbi Shimon Ish HaMitzpa,</b> who disagrees with the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna here. The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t we learn the opposite, as we learned</b> in the mishna in tractate <i>Tamid</i>: The priest sprinkles the blood of the daily offering on the altar. <b>He comes to the northeast corner</b> of the altar and <b>sprinkles</b> once on the <b>northeast</b> corner. From there he proceeds to the <b>southwest corner</b> and <b>sprinkles</b> once on the <b>southwest</b> corner.
<b>And it was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i> <b>concerning</b> this mishna: <b>Rabbi Shimon Ish HaMitzpa changes the</b> sprinkling of the blood of the <b>daily offering</b> relative to the sprinkling of blood of all other burnt-offerings. He agrees with the first <i>tanna</i> with regard to the first sprinkling of the blood; the priest comes to the <b>northeast</b> corner and <b>sprinkles</b> once on the <b>northeast</b> corner. However, when he proceeds to the <b>southwest</b> corner he does not sprinkle once as he would when offering a burnt-offering; rather, <b>he sprinkles</b> on the <b>west</b> side of the altar <b>and then sprinkles</b> on the <b>south</b> side. Since the disputing opinion is that of Rabbi Shimon Ish HaMitzpa, apparently the unattributed opinions in the <i>mishnayot</i> in tractate <i>Tamid</i> are not the opinions of Rabbi Shimon Ish HaMitzpa.
<b>Rather,</b> there must be a different resolution to the contradiction between the mishna here and the one in tractate <i>Tamid</i>. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> who <b>taught</b> the Yom Kippur service in <b>tractate <i>Yoma</i>? It is Rabbi Shimon Ish HaMitzpa,</b> and tractate <i>Tamid</i> is in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis who disagree with him.
The Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from one mishna in <b>tractate <i>Yoma</i> against</b> another mishna in <b>tractate <i>Yoma</i>, as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>The second lottery</b> conducted daily among the priests determined the following: <b>Who slaughters</b> the daily morning offering; <b>who sprinkles</b> its blood; <b>who removes the ashes</b> from <b>the inner altar; and who removes the ashes</b> and burnt wicks from <b>the candelabrum; and who takes the limbs</b> of the daily offering <b>up to the ramp</b> to be burned later. Following the second lottery the priests dispersed, and they later reconvened for <b>the third lottery.</b> Before the third lottery, the appointee declared: Let only those priests who are <b>new to</b> offering <b>the incense</b> come and <b>participate in the lottery</b> for the incense. Apparently, removing the ashes from the lamps of the candelabrum preceded the burning of the incense, which contradicts the mishna here.
<b>Abaye said:</b> This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> the mishna is discussing <b>the removal</b> of the ashes from <b>two lamps,</b> which is performed after the burning of the incense; <b>there,</b> the mishna of the lotteries is discussing <b>the removal</b> of the ashes from <b>five lamps,</b> which precedes the burning of the incense. As will be explained, the priest attends to five lamps first, and after a break, he attends to the final two lamps.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say that the</b> burning of the <b>incense interposes</b> between attending to the first five lamps and attending the last two? <b>But</b> when <b>Abaye related the order of the</b> daily <b>priestly functions in the name of tradition, didn’t</b> he state that it was the sprinkling of <b>the blood of the daily offering that interposed between</b> the five lamps and the two, not the burning of the incense? The Sages <b>say</b> in response: This is <b>not difficult. That</b> sequence cited by Abaye is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Abba Shaul,</b> whereas <b>this</b> sequence cited in the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One</b> should <b>not remove</b> the ashes from <b>the lamps and then burn</b> the incense; <b>rather one should burn</b> the incense <b>and then remove</b> the ashes from the lamps. <b>Abba Shaul says: One removes</b> the ashes from the lamps <b>and then burns</b> the incense. The different sources reflect the dispute cited in the <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the rationale</b> for the opinion of <b>Abba Shaul?</b> It is <b>as it is written: “Every morning when he removes the ashes from the lamps,</b> he shall burn it” (Exodus 30:7), <b>and then</b> it is written: <b>“He shall burn it”</b> (Exodus 30:8). First the lamps are cleaned, and only then is the incense burned. <b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis,</b> who hold that the incense was burned first, interpret this verse? They say: <b>What is the Merciful One saying?</b>

Daf 15a

It means: <b>At the time of</b> the <b>removal</b> of the ashes <b>you shall burn the incense,</b> and no later. <b>As, if you do not say so</b> but explain that the phrase: He shall burn the incense, at the end of the verse means after cleaning the lamps, then with regard to the burning of the <b>afternoon</b> incense, with regard to <b>which it is written: “And when Aaron lights the lamps in the afternoon he shall burn it”</b> (Exodus 30:8), in <b>this</b> case <b>too,</b> does it mean that <b>initially</b> the priest <b>lights the lamps and</b> only <b>then burns the afternoon incense? And if you say indeed,</b> that is <b>so, wasn’t</b> the following <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: “Aaron and his sons will set it in order to burn <b>from evening until morning</b> before the Lord; it shall be a statute forever throughout their generations on behalf of the children of Israel” (Exodus 27:21)?
And the <i>baraita</i> explains: <b>Give</b> the candelabrum <b>its measure</b> of oil so that <b>it will continue to burn all night from evening until morning. Alternatively,</b> the phrase: <b>From evening to morning,</b> teaches that <b>you have only this service that is valid</b> when performed <b>from evening to morning</b>. Apparently, lighting the candelabrum is the final daily Temple service and the incense is not burned after the lamps are lit. <b>Rather, what is the Merciful One saying</b> in the phrase: “And when Aaron lights the lamps in the afternoon he shall burn it.” This teaches that <b>at the time of</b> the <b>lighting</b> of the lamps <b>you shall burn the incense,</b> and no later. If so, <b>here too,</b> in the morning, <b>at the time of</b> the <b>removal</b> of the ashes <b>you shall burn the incense,</b> and no later. This is the rationale for the opinion of the Rabbis.
<b>And Abba Shaul</b> could have <b>said to you</b> in response: <b>It is different there,</b> with regard to the burning of the afternoon incense, <b>as it is written:</b> “Aaron and his sons will set <b>it</b> [<b><i>oto</i></b>] in order.” The term <i>oto</i> is exclusionary: Only in the afternoon is it critical that the lighting of the lamps be the last service performed and that it follow the burning of the incense. However, in the morning, where there is no exclusionary term, the sequence of the verse is observed: First attending to the candelabrum and then burning the incense.
<b>Rav Pappa said</b> a different resolution to the contradiction between the <i>mishnayot.</i> This is <b>not difficult,</b> because each mishna is in accordance with the opinion of a different <i>tanna</i>. <b>This</b> mishna, in which the burning of the incense is first, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis;</b> and <b>that</b> mishna, in which the lighting of the lamps is first, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Abba Shaul.</b> The Gemara questions Rav Pappa’s resolution: In accordance with the opinion of <b>which</b> <i>tanna</i> <b>is the mishna here established?</b> It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b> The sequence in the mishna where the <b>lottery</b> is discussed is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Abba Shaul.</b>
<b>Say the latter clause</b> of that mishna as follows: <b>They brought him the</b> sheep for <b>the daily</b> morning <b>offering that he slaughtered</b> by cutting most of the way through the gullet and the windpipe. <b>And</b> a <b>different</b> priest <b>completed</b> the <b>slaughter on his behalf.</b> And then <b>he entered</b> the Sanctuary <b>to burn the</b> morning <b>incense and to remove</b> the ashes from <b>the lamps</b> of the candelabrum. If so, <b>we have</b> again <b>arrived at</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> that burning the incense precedes attending to the lamps, which leads to the difficult conclusion: The <b>first clause and</b> the <b>last clause</b> of the mishna in tractate <i>Yoma</i> are in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> and the <b>middle clause</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Abba Shaul. Rav Pappa</b> could have <b>said to you: Indeed,</b> the <b>first clause and</b> the <b>last clause</b> are in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> and the <b>middle clause</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Abba Shaul.</b> Although this is not common, because these <i>mishnayot</i> are not directly juxtaposed, it is possible.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, Abaye does not say in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Pappa,</b> as he is <b>not</b> willing to <b>establish</b> the <b>first clause and</b> the <b>last clause</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> and the <b>middle clause</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Abba Shaul. However,</b> with regard to <b>Rav Pappa, what is the reason</b> that <b>he did not say</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Abaye</b> and instead prefers an uncommon and difficult resolution? Rav Pappa could have <b>said to you</b> that the resolution proposed by Abaye is difficult as well, as according to Abaye <b>in the first clause</b> of the mishna it was <b>taught</b> with regard to the <b>removal</b> of the ashes from <b>two lamps,</b> which is performed later, <b>and</b> only <b>then</b> taught the <b>removal</b> of the ashes from <b>five lamps,</b> which is performed before the ashes of the two lamps are cleared. Therefore, Rav Pappa prefers to establish that the <i>mishnayot</i> reflect a tannaitic dispute rather than to accept this reversal of the order.
<b>And Abaye</b> holds that this is not difficult and could have <b>said to you</b> that the first mishna, which describes the routine of the High Priest during his seven days of separation, teaches <b>a general directive</b> describing the services with which the High Priest must be familiarized prior to Yom Kippur, without concern for the sequence. <b>And</b> in terms of <b>the sequence, the</b> mishna <b>then teaches</b> it in the context of the actual performance of the services.
§ The Gemara cites a dispute between the Rabbis and Rabbi Shimon Ish HaMitzpa. The Gemara proceeds to analyze <b>the matter itself:</b> The priest <b>comes to the northeast corner</b> of the altar and <b>sprinkles</b> once on the <b>northeast</b> corner. From there he proceeds to the <b>southwest corner</b> and <b>sprinkles</b> once on the <b>southwest</b> corner. <b>And it was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i> <b>concerning</b> this mishna: <b>Rabbi Shimon Ish HaMitzpa changes the</b> sprinkling of the blood of the <b>daily offering</b> vis-à-vis the sprinkling of blood of all other burnt-offerings. The priest comes to the <b>northeast</b> corner and <b>sprinkles</b> once on the <b>northeast</b> corner. However, when he proceeds to the <b>southwest</b> corner, <b>he sprinkles</b> on the <b>west</b> side of the altar <b>and then sprinkles</b> on the <b>south</b> side. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the rationale</b> for the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon Ish HaMitzpa,</b> who changes the sprinkling of the blood of the daily offering vis-à-vis the sprinkling of blood of all other burnt-offerings?
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said in the name of one</b> of the Sages <b>of the school of Rabbi Yannai</b> that <b>the verse states: “And one goat as a sin-offering to the Lord; it shall be offered aside from the daily burnt-offering and its libation”</b> (Numbers 28:15). From the phrase: Beside the daily burnt-offering, it is derived that the daily offering is <b>a burnt-offering</b>, and from the juxtaposition of the sacrifice of the sin-offering to the daily offering, <b>the Merciful One said: Perform with it the procedure of a sin-offering.</b>
And <b>how</b> can <b>this</b> be accomplished? It can be accomplished by performing half of the sprinklings according to the procedure of a burnt-offering, and half according to the procedure of a sin-offering. One <b>sprinkles one</b> sprinkling <b>that is two,</b> i.e., one sprinkles the blood on the corner of the altar so that the blood is divided between the two sides, <b>in accordance with the procedure of a</b> standard <b>burnt-offering.</b> Then <b>he sprinkles two</b> sprinklings <b>that are two, in accordance with the procedure of a sin-offering.</b> The blood of a sin-offering is sprinkled in four separate actions, one on each of the four corners of the altar. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> if the objective is to have the daily offering sacrificed like a sin-offering, <b>let him sprinkle</b> the blood in a manner that will accomplish both: First, <b>two</b> sprinklings <b>that are four in accordance with the procedure of a</b> standard <b>burnt-offering, and</b> then <b>four</b> sprinklings <b>that are four in accordance with the procedure of a sin-offering.</b>
The Gemara rejects that proposal: <b>We did not find</b> a case of <b>blood that atones and</b> then <b>again atones.</b> Once the blood was sprinkled and brought atonement by following the procedure of the burnt-offering, one cannot then begin the rite of atonement of a sin-offering. The Gemara asks: <b>And did we find</b> the <b>blood</b> of an offering, <b>half of which</b> is sprinkled as <b>a sin-offering and half of which</b> is sprinkled as <b>a burnt-offering? Rather, perforce,</b> say that <b>the verse juxtaposes them</b> and commands that the blood of the daily offering be offered half as a burnt-offering and half as a sin-offering. <b>Here too, perforce,</b> say that <b>the verse juxtaposes them</b> and commands two separate sprinklings: The sprinkling of a burnt-offering followed by the sprinkling of a sin-offering.
The Gemara responds: The two suggestions are different. <b>There,</b> in the statement of Rabbi Shimon Ish HaMitzpa, there is no radical divergence from the standard burnt-offering; <b>it is merely dividing the sprinklings.</b> Instead of sprinkling the blood on the corner so that it falls on two sides of the altar, one sprinkles the blood on each of the two sides separately. In contrast, performing two independent acts of sprinkling is a radical divergence. <b>And</b> the Gemara suggests an alternative manner in which the daily offering could be offered like a sin-offering. <b>Let us sprinkle one</b> sprinkling <b>that is two below</b> the red line painted halfway up the altar, <b>in accordance with the procedure of a</b> standard <b>burnt-offering,</b> and sprinkle another <b>two sprinklings that are two above</b> the red line on the upper half of the altar <b>in accordance with the procedure of a sin-offering</b>.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>We did not find</b> a case of <b>blood half of which</b> is sprinkled <b>above</b> the red line <b>and half of which</b> is sprinkled <b>below</b> the red line. One either sprinkles all the blood on the lower half of the altar, as in the case of most offerings, or entirely on the upper half of the altar, as in the case of sin-offerings. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is there really <b>no</b> case of that sort? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: The High Priest took the blood of the bull into the Holy of Holies <b>and sprinkled from</b> the blood <b>one</b> time <b>upward and</b> then <b>seven</b> times <b>downward?</b> Apparently, the blood of an offering can be sprinkled part upward, toward the upper part of the thickness of the Ark cover, and part downward, toward the lower part of the thickness of the Ark cover.
The Gemara rejects this: That is not a case of half the blood sprinkled upward and half sprinkled downward. Instead, that sprinkling was <b>like a <i>matzlif</i>;</b> the sprinklings were not performed one above the other, but rather one beneath the other, and all were sprinkled in a row on the Ark cover. The Gemara explains: <b>What</b> is the meaning of <b>like a <i>matzlif</i>? Rav Yehuda demonstrated</b> with his hand; it means <b>like one who whips.</b> One who whips another does not strike in one place but directs one lash beneath another.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is there really <b>no</b> case of that sort? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna with regard to the sprinkling of blood on the incense altar: <b>He sprinkled seven times from</b> the blood <b>on <i>tohoro</i> of the altar. What, is it not</b> referring to the <b>middle</b> of the side <b>of the altar, as people say: Clear noon [<i>tihara</i>],</b> that <b>is the middle of the day?</b> In other words, <i>tohoro</i> refers to halfway up the altar. Now, since the blood was sprinkled on the altar seven times, inevitably some of the blood landed above the midpoint and some of it landed below the midpoint.
<b>Rabba bar Sheila said: No</b>, that is not the meaning of <i>tohoro</i>.

Daf 15b

Rather, <i>tohoro</i> means <b>on</b> top of <b>the altar itself, as it is written: “Like the very sky for purity [<i>latohar</i>]”</b> (Exodus 24:10). <i>Tohoro</i> refers to the top of the altar after the ashes of the incense are cleared and the pure gold is visible.
The Gemara returns to the opinion of Rabbi Shimon IshHaMitzpa: <b>What is different that</b> he says to <b>sprinkle</b> in accordance with the procedure of the <b>burnt-offering first and then sprinkle</b> in accordance with the procedure <b>that</b> is used for the <b>sin-offering? Let us first sprinkle</b> in accordance with the procedure <b>that</b> is used for the <b>sin-offering and then let us sprinkle</b> in accordance with the procedure <b>that</b> is used for the <b>burnt-offering.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Since</b> the daily offering <b>is a burnt-offering,</b> that procedure <b>takes precedence,</b> and it is followed by the sin-offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different that</b> he says to <b>sprinkle</b> first on the <b>northeast</b> corner of the altar <b>and</b> then on the <b>southwest</b> corner? <b>Let him sprinkle</b> first on the <b>southeast</b> corner <b>and then</b> on the <b>northwest</b> corner. The Sages <b>say:</b> That is because the blood of the <b>burnt-offering requires</b> sprinkling on the side of the altar with <b>a base,</b> as it is stated: “On the base of the altar of burnt-offering” (Leviticus 4:18) <b>and the southeast corner did not have a base.</b> Therefore, the sprinkling was performed on the northeast corner, where part of the base of the altar was located.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different that</b> he says to <b>sprinkle</b> first on the <b>northeast</b> corner of the altar <b>and</b> then on the <b>southwest</b> corner? <b>Let him sprinkle</b> first on the <b>southwest</b> corner <b>and then</b> on the <b>northeast</b> corner. The Gemara answers that it is <b>since the Master said: All turns that you turn should be only to the right.</b> With regard to certain offerings sacrificed when the priest is on the south side of the altar, he would turn <b>to the east,</b> which was to his right. Since the animal to be offered is slaughtered to the north of the altar, he <b>first</b> sprinkles blood at the corner that <b>he encounters</b> first.
<b>And from where</b> is the conclusion drawn that <b>the Merciful One says with regard to a burnt-offering to perform it</b> in accordance with <b>the procedure of a sin-offering? Perhaps it is with regard to a sin-offering</b> of the New Moon <b>that the Merciful One says to perform it</b> in accordance with <b>the procedure of a burnt-offering.</b> The Gemara responds: This can <b>not enter your mind, as it is written: “It shall be offered aside from the daily burnt-offering and its libation”</b> (Numbers 28:15). <b>What is the Merciful One saying? Cast a matter of the sin-offering upon the burnt-offering,</b> i.e., apply the procedure of the sin-offering to the sacrifice of the burnt-offering.
§ Just as the contradiction above was resolved by attributing different sources to different <i>tanna’im</i>, the Gemara cites an additional contradiction with a similar resolution. <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there: The appointee,</b> the deputy High Priest, <b>said to</b> the other priests: <b>Go out and bring a lamb from the Chamber of the Lambs,</b> where lambs awaiting sacrifice were kept after they underwent inspection and were found to be without blemish. That mishna continues: <b>The Chamber of the Lambs was</b> located <b>in the northwest corner</b> of the Hall of the Hearth in the Temple courtyard. <b>And there were four chambers there</b> in that hall. <b>One</b> was <b>the Chamber of the Lambs, and one</b> was <b>the Chamber of the Seals.</b> In the Temple, seals were dispensed as receipts to individuals who paid for sacrificial animals. The person then showed the seal to a Temple official, who supplied him with an animal. <b>And one</b> was <b>the Chamber of the Hall of the Hearth, and one</b> was <b>the chamber where the shewbread was prepared.</b>
<b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from a mishna in tractate <i>Middot</i>: <b>Four chambers were</b> open <b>into the Hall of the Hearth like small</b> semi-open <b>rooms [<i>kitoniyyot</i>] that open into a</b> central <b>hall [<i>teraklin</i>]. Two</b> of these chambers were located in the <b>sacred</b> area, in the Temple courtyard, <b>and two</b> of the chambers <b>were</b> located <b>in the non-sacred</b> area of the Temple Mount. <b>And the tops of</b> wooden <b>stakes [<i>pispasin</i>]</b> in the Hall of the Hearth <b>divided between the sacred</b> area and the <b>non-sacred</b> area to apprise the people in both areas where they were located and what conduct is required. <b>And what</b> purpose did these chambers <b>serve?</b> The <b>southwest</b> chamber <b>was the Chamber of the Sacrificial Lambs;</b>

Daf 16a

the <b>southeast</b> chamber in the Hall of the Hearth <b>was the chamber in which the shewbread was prepared.</b> The <b>northeast</b> chamber was the chamber <b>in which the Hasmoneans sequestered the altar stones that were desecrated by the gentile kings</b> when they sacrificed idolatrous offerings. The <b>northwest</b> chamber was the chamber <b>in which</b> the priests <b>descended</b> through tunnels <b>to the Hall of Immersion.</b> There is a contradiction between the sources with regard to the location of the Chamber of the Lambs. <b>Rav Huna said: Who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> who <b>taught</b> the <i>mishnayot</i> in tractate <b><i>Middot</i></b>? It is <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov,</b> who has a different opinion with regard to this matter.
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna in tractate <i>Middot</i>: The dimensions of the <b>women’s courtyard were a length of 135</b> cubits <b>by a width of 135</b> cubits, <b>and there were four chambers in its four corners. And what</b> purpose did these chambers <b>serve?</b> The <b>southeast</b> chamber <b>was the Chamber of the Nazirites, as there the nazirites cook their peace-offerings and shave their hair and cast</b> it in the fire to burn <b>beneath the pot</b> in which the peace-offering was cooked, as the Torah instructs (see Numbers 6:18). The <b>northeast</b> chamber <b>was the Chamber of the Woodshed, where blemished priests,</b> who are disqualified for any other service, <b>stand and examine the logs</b> to determine if they were infested <b>by worms, as any log in which there are worms is disqualified for</b> use <b>on the altar.</b>
The <b>northwest</b> chamber <b>was the Chamber of the Lepers,</b> where lepers would immerse for purification. With regard to the <b>southwest</b> chamber, <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov said: I forgot what</b> purpose it <b>would serve. Abba Shaul says: They would place wine and oil there</b> for the meal-offerings and libations, <b>and it was called the Chamber of the House of Oils.</b> From this mishna it may be inferred that the <i>tanna</i> who taught the <i>mishnayot</i> in tractate <i>Middot</i> is Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, as that is why the mishna finds it necessary to mention that he forgot the purpose of one of the chambers.
<b>So too, it is reasonable</b> to conclude that the <i>mishnayot</i> in tractate <i>Middot</i> are in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, as we learned</b> in a mishna there: <b>All the walls that were there</b> surrounding the Temple Mount <b>were high except for the Eastern Wall, as the priest who burns the</b> red <b>heifer stands on the Mount of Olives,</b> where the red heifer was slaughtered and burned, <b>and directs</b> his attention <b>and looks toward the entrance of the Sanctuary when</b> he <b>sprinkles the blood.</b>
The Gemara seeks the opinion according to which this would be feasible. <b>And we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>All the entrances that were there</b> in the Temple were <b>twenty cubits high and ten cubits wide. And we learned</b> in a different mishna describing the layout of the Temple: <b>Inside</b> the eastern wall of the Temple Mount was <b>a latticed gate. And we learned</b> in a different mishna: <b>Inside</b> the latticed gate was <b>the rampart,</b> which was an elevated area <b>ten cubits</b> wide. In that area <b>there were twelve stairs;</b> each <b>stair</b> was <b>half a cubit high and half a cubit deep,</b> for a total ascent of six cubits.
In addition, <b>fifteen stairs ascend from within</b> the women’s courtyard and <b>descend from the Israelite courtyard to the women’s courtyard.</b> Each <b>stair</b> was <b>half a cubit high and half a cubit deep,</b> for an additional ascent of seven and a half cubits. The total height of both staircases together was thirteen and a half cubits. <b>And we learned</b> in that mishna: The area <b>between the Entrance Hall and the altar</b> was <b>twenty-two cubits</b> wide, <b>and there were twelve stairs</b> in that area. Each <b>stair</b> was <b>half a cubit high and half a cubit deep,</b> for an additional ascent of six cubits and a total height of nineteen and a half cubits.
<b>And we learned</b> in that mishna that <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: There was</b> an additional <b>stair there</b> between the Israelite courtyard and the priests’ courtyard. That stair was <b>one cubit high, and the platform</b> on which the Levites stood <b>was placed upon it and on it</b> were <b>three stairs, each</b> with a height and depth of <b>half a cubit,</b> for a total of twenty-two cubits.
<b>Granted, if you say</b> that the <i>mishnayot</i> in tractate <i>Middot</i> are in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, that is</b> how it can be understood that <b>the entrance was concealed.</b> The threshold of the entrance to the Sanctuary was more than twenty cubits higher than the threshold of the eastern gate of the Temple Mount. One looking through the Eastern Gate would be unable to see the entrance of the Sanctuary, because the gate was only twenty cubits high. In order to provide the priest performing the red heifer ritual on the Mount of Olives with a view of the entrance to the Sanctuary, the eastern wall had to be lowered.
