And when there are many</b> priests who wish to perform that task, the privilege to do so is determined by a race: The priests <b>run and ascend on the ramp</b> leading to the top of the altar. <b>Any</b> priest <b>who precedes another</b> and reaches within <b>four cubits</b> of the top of the altar first <b>is privileged</b> to remove the ashes. <b>And if both of them were equal</b> and neither preceded the other, <b>the appointed</b> priest says to all the priests: <b>Extend</b> your <b>fingers,</b> and a lottery was performed, as will be explained.
<b>And what</b> fingers <b>do they extend</b> for the lottery? They may extend <b>one or two</b> fingers, <b>and</b> the priests <b>do not extend a thumb in the Temple.</b> The reason is that the lottery was conducted by the appointee choosing a number and counting the extended fingers of the priests standing in a circle. As the count progressed, a priest could calculate and manipulate the result in his favor by surreptitiously extending his thumb and an additional finger. Since there is separation between the thumb and the forefinger it could appear as though they belonged to two different priests, skewing the results of the lottery.
Initially, that was the procedure; however, <b>an incident</b> occurred <b>where both of them were equal</b> as they were <b>running and ascending on the ramp, and one of them shoved another and he fell and his leg was broken. And once the court saw that</b> people <b>were coming to</b> potential <b>danger, they instituted that</b> priests <b>would remove</b> ashes from <b>the altar only</b> by means <b>of a lottery. There were four lotteries there,</b> in the Temple, on a daily basis to determine the priests privileged to perform the various services, <b>and this,</b> determining which priest would remove the ashes, was <b>the first lottery.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara questions the original practice of holding a race to determine which priest would remove the ashes: <b>And what is the reason that the Sages did not initially institute a lottery for</b> the removal of the ashes as they did for other parts of the service? The Gemara answers: <b>Initially</b> they <b>thought:</b> Since it is <b>a service</b> performed <b>at night it would not be important to</b> the priests, and <b>not</b> many of them would <b>come</b> to perform it, so a lottery would be unnecessary. Then, <b>when they saw that</b> many priests <b>did</b> indeed <b>come and</b> that <b>they were coming to danger</b> by racing up the altar’s ramp, <b>they instituted a lottery.</b>
The Gemara poses a question against the assertion that nighttime Temple services did not normally require a lottery: <b>But there is</b> the burning of the <b>limbs</b> of burnt-offerings <b>and the fats</b> of other offerings, <b>which is a service</b> that is performed at <b>night, and</b> nevertheless <b>the Sages instituted a lottery</b> for that from the outset. The Gemara answers: The burning of those parts is not considered a nighttime service but <b>the end of a daytime service,</b> as the main part of the sacrificial service, the slaughtering and the sprinkling of blood, took place during the day.
The Gemara asks: If so, it could be argued that <b>this</b> service of removing the ashes is <b>also</b> not a nighttime service but <b>the start of a daytime service, as Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> If a priest has <b>sanctified his hands</b> at night by washing them <b>for the removal of the ashes, the next day,</b> i.e., after daybreak, if he remained in the confines of the Temple, <b>he need not sanctify</b> his hands again, <b>because he already sanctified</b> them <b>at the start of the service.</b> Apparently, the removal of the ashes, though performed at night, is considered the start of the next day’s service.
The Gemara responds by emending Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement: <b>Say</b> the following version of the end of Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement: <b>Because he had already sanctified</b> them <b>at the outset for service.</b> According to this formulation, Rabbi Yoḥanan did not say that the removal of the ashes is considered the start of the following day’s service. Rather, he said that although the removal of the ashes is a nighttime service, since the priest sanctified his hands before performing that service, the sanctification remains in effect for the services performed after daybreak as well, since there is no interruption between the two activities.
<b>Some say</b> that the original practice should be explained as follows: <b>Initially,</b> the Sages <b>thought</b> that <b>since there is</b> a likelihood of being <b>overcome by sleep</b> at that time of night, <b>not</b> many priests <b>would come. When they saw that they did</b> indeed <b>come and</b> that <b>they were also coming to danger, the Sages instituted a lottery</b> for this task. The Gemara asks: <b>But there is</b> the burning of the <b>limbs</b> of burnt-offerings <b>and the fats</b> of other offerings, a service for <b>which there is</b> the same likelihood of being <b>overcome by sleep,</b> and nevertheless <b>the Sages instituted a lottery</b> for that from the outset. The Gemara answers: <b>Lying down</b> to go to sleep late <b>is different from rising</b> in the middle of the night. It is not as difficult to stay up late in order to burn limbs on the altar as it is to rise before dawn to remove the ashes from the altar.
The Gemara addresses the substance of the mishna’s claim: <b>But was the ordinance</b> to assign the removal of ashes by means of a lottery <b>due to that reason</b> cited in the mishna, the matter of the dangerous incident? <b>The ordinance</b> was instituted <b>due to this reason:</b> There were other important tasks associated with the removal of the ashes that required a lottery in their own right, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The priest <b>who was privileged to</b> perform <b>the removal of the ashes was</b> also <b>privileged with laying out the arrangement of wood</b> on the altar and with placing <b>the two logs</b> that were placed on the altar each morning. Since these were inherently important tasks, the only way to assign them was through a lottery, which would also determine who removed the ashes.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Ashi said: There were two</b> separate <b>ordinances</b> instituted. <b>Initially,</b> the Sages <b>thought</b> that priests <b>would not</b> come forward to perform the task of removing the ashes. <b>Once they saw that</b> many priests <b>did come and</b> that <b>they were also coming to danger,</b> the Sages <b>instituted a lottery</b> for this task. <b>Once they established a lottery</b> for removing the ashes, the priests <b>did not come</b> anymore. <b>They said: Who says</b> the lottery <b>will fall in our favor?</b> Therefore, they did not bother to come. <b>Then</b> the Sages <b>instituted for</b> the priests that <b>whoever was privileged with</b> performing <b>the removal of the ashes would</b> also <b>be privileged with laying out the arrangement of wood</b> on the altar and with placing the <b>two logs, so that</b> the importance of all these tasks combined would ensure that the priests <b>would come and participate in the lottery.</b>
§ It was taught in the mishna that before the lottery was instituted, <b>when there were many</b> priests who sought to perform the removal of the ashes, the first priest to reach within four cubits of the top of the altar was privileged with performing the removal of the ashes. <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> It is <b>obvious to me</b> that the <b>four cubits</b> the mishna is referring to are not the four cubits adjacent to the ramp <b>on the ground,</b> because <b>we learned</b> in the mishna that the priests <b>run and ascend on the ramp,</b> and not adjacent to the ramp. It is <b>also not</b> referring to the <b>first</b> four cubits from the foot of the ramp, because <b>we learned</b> that the priests <b>run and ascend on the ramp, and only afterward</b> it says: <b>Any</b> priest <b>who precedes another</b> and reaches within four cubits of the altar first, indicating that the competition begins only once they have ascended the ramp to some extent.
It is <b>also not</b> referring to four cubits somewhere in the <b>middle,</b> between the four on the bottom and the top of the altar, because <b>the matter is not defined</b> and there is no clear indication which four cubits on the ramp are the determining cubits. In light of all this, it is <b>obvious to me</b> that the four cubits <b>we learned</b> in the mishna are referring to the four cubits <b>that are adjacent to the altar</b> itself. The priest who reaches those four cubits first is the one privileged to remove the ashes.
Rav Pappa <b>raised a dilemma</b> based on the above clarification: Are the <b>four cubits that they stated,</b> which are the four cubits adjacent to the altar, calculated <b>including the cubit of the base</b> of the altar <b>and the cubit of</b> its <b>ledge,</b> as the ramp continues and overlaps these two cubits at the top of the altar,

Daf 22b

<b>or</b> are they <b>perhaps calculated excluding the cubit of the base</b> of the altar <b>and the cubit of</b> its <b>ledge?</b> The altar’s edge can be considered to be at the end of the ramp, the point at which it meets the altar, or it can be considered the point on the ramp that is directly over the external base of the altar, which is two cubits away from the point where the ramp meets the altar. Which of these two calculations is the correct one? Rav Pappa’s question remains unanswered, and the Gemara concludes: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ It was taught in the mishna that <b>if both of them were equal</b> and neither preceded the other, <b>the appointed</b> priest <b>says</b> to all the priests: <b>Extend</b> your <b>fingers</b> [<b><i>hatzbiu</i></b>], and a lottery was performed. A <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> the meaning of the unusual term <i>hatzbiu</i>: <b>Put out your fingers for a count.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Let him count</b> the priests <b>themselves</b> directly, rather than counting their fingers. The Gemara answers: This is <b>a support for</b> a teaching of <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak, as Rabbi Yitzḥak said: It is prohibited to count Jews</b> directly, <b>even for the purposes of a mitzva, as it is written</b> concerning King Saul and his count of his soldiers: <b>“And he numbered them with <i>bezek</i>”</b> (I Samuel 11:8), meaning that he counted them through shards, one shard representing each man, rather than counting them directly.
<b>Rav Ashi strongly objects to this</b> interpretation of the verse: <b>From where</b> do you derive <b>that this</b> word <b><i>bezek</i> is a term</b> related to the verb meaning <b>to break apart,</b> so that it means shards? <b>Perhaps it is the name of a town,</b> and it means that Saul counted them in Bezek, <b>as it is written: “And they found Adoni-bezek</b> in Bezek” (Judges 1:5), which shows that Bezek is the name of a place. The Gemara answers: Indeed, the proof is not from that verse <b>but from here,</b> where it says: <b>“And Saul summoned the people and numbered them by sheep”</b> (I Samuel 15:4), meaning that Saul tallied his soldiers by having each one take a sheep and put it aside to represent him in the count.
<b>Rabbi Elazar said: Whoever counts</b> a group of <b>Jews violates a negative</b> mitzva, <b>as it is stated: “And the number of the children of Israel will be like the sand of the sea, which cannot be measured”</b> (Hosea 2:1). Rabbi Elazar interprets the verse to be saying: Which may not be measured. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> One who counts a group of Jews in fact <b>violates two negative</b> mitzvot, <b>as it is stated</b> in that verse: “Which <b>cannot be measured and cannot be counted”</b> (Hosea 2:1).
<b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yonatan raised a contradiction: It is written</b> in this verse: <b>“And the number of the children of Israel will be like the sand of the sea,”</b> suggesting that they will have a specific number, though it will be very large. On the other hand, it continues and says: <b>“Which cannot be measured and cannot be counted,”</b> which means they will not be countable at all. How can these two statements be reconciled?
It is <b>not difficult: Here,</b> in the second statement, it is referring to <b>a time when the Jewish people fulfill the will of God;</b> then they will be innumerable. <b>There,</b> in the first statement, it is referring to <b>a time when</b> the Jewish people <b>do not fulfill the will of God;</b> then they will be like the sand of the sea, having a specific number. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said</b> a different resolution <b>in the name of Abba Yosei ben Dostai:</b> It is <b>not difficult: Here,</b> in the second statement, it is referring to counting <b>by the hand of man;</b> the Jewish people will be too numerous to count by man. <b>There,</b> in the first statement, it is referring to counting <b>by the hand of God,</b> and He will find that they are like the number of the grains of the sand of the sea.
<b>Rav Nehilai bar Idi said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: Once a man is appointed as a leader of the community, he becomes wealthy.</b> This is derived from the verses cited above. <b>Initially, it is written</b> with regard to Saul: <b>“And he numbered them with <i>bezek</i>,”</b> meaning pottery shards, <b>and in the end it is written: “And he numbered them with sheep,”</b> indicating that he was able to provide enough of his own sheep to use them in counting the people. The Gemara asks: <b>But perhaps</b> the people provided these sheep <b>from their own</b> flocks. The Gemara rejects this: <b>If so, what is the novelty in the matter?</b> Why would the text tell us that the people were counted with sheep if not to illustrate incidentally the great wealth of Saul?
§ Having mentioned the verse about Saul, the Gemara proceeds to interpret more of that passage: “And Saul came to the city of Amalek <b>and he strove in the valley”</b> (I Samuel 15:5). <b>Rabbi Mani said:</b> This means that Saul strove with God, as it were, <b>concerning the matter of the valley. At the time when the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to</b> Saul: “Now <b>go and attack Amalek</b> and proscribe all that belongs to him; do not pity him, but kill men and women alike, infants and sucklings alike, oxen and sheep alike, camel and donkey alike” (I Samuel 15:3), Saul countered and <b>said: Now, if</b> on account of <b>one life</b> that is taken, in a case where a slain person’s body is found and the murderer is unknown, <b>the Torah said to bring a heifer whose neck is broken</b> to a barren valley, in the atonement ritual described in Deuteronomy 21:1–9, <b>all the more so</b> must I have pity and not take <b>all these</b> Amalekite <b>lives.</b>
<b>And</b> he further reasoned: <b>If the men have sinned,</b> in <b>what</b> way <b>have the animals sinned?</b> Why, then, should the Amalekites’ livestock be destroyed? <b>And if the adults have sinned,</b> in <b>what</b> way <b>have the children sinned? A Divine Voice</b> then <b>came forth and said to him: “Do not be overly righteous”</b> (Ecclesiastes 7:16). That is to say: Do not be more merciful than the Creator Himself, Who has commanded you to do this, for to do so would not be an indication of righteousness but of weakness. At a later time, <b>when Saul said to Doeg: “Turn around and strike down the priests,</b> and Doeg the Edomite turned around and struck down the priests, and he killed on that day eighty-five men who wore the linen ephod, and he struck Nob the city of priests by the sword, man and woman alike, infants and sucklings alike, oxen and donkeys and sheep, by the sword” (I Samuel 22:18–19), <b>a Divine Voice came forth and said to him: “Do not be overly wicked”</b> (Ecclesiastes 7:17).
Apropos Saul’s contravention of God’s command to obliterate Amalek, the Gemara observes that <b>Rav Huna said: How little does a person who has the support of his Lord have to worry or be concerned.</b> The proof for this assertion is a comparison between Saul and David. <b>Saul</b> failed <b>with one</b> single sin <b>and it was counted against him,</b> costing him the throne. <b>David,</b> however, failed <b>with two</b> sins <b>and</b> they were <b>not counted against him,</b> as he retained his position. The Gemara asks: <b>What was Saul’s one</b> sin? <b>The incident</b> with <b>Agag,</b> king of Amalek, whom Saul spared in defiance of God’s command (see I Samuel 15:9). <b>But</b> was this his sole sin? <b>There is</b> also <b>the incident of Nob, the city of priests,</b> in which Saul later slew many innocent people, as cited above. The Gemara answers: It was after <b>the incident</b> with <b>Agag,</b> and even before the incident at Nob, that God said: <b>“I regret that I have crowned Saul to be king”</b> (I Samuel 15:11).
Rav Huna stated above that <b>David</b> failed <b>with two</b> sins. <b>What were they?</b> One was the incident in which he had <b>Uriah</b> killed. The other was the matter of <b>the incitement</b> of David to conduct a census of the Jewish people (see II Samuel 24:1), which led to many deaths in a plague.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> were these his only two sins? <b>There is also the incident of Bathsheba,</b> in which he took another man’s wife as his own. The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> in that case, <b>punishment was exacted from him</b> separately, so the matter is no longer listed among his sins, <b>as it is written</b> with regard to this incident: <b>“And he shall restore the lamb fourfold”</b> (II Samuel 12:6). The lamb was a metaphor for Bathsheba, and ultimately David was indeed given a fourfold punishment for taking Bathsheba: The first <b>child</b> born to Bathsheba and David died (see II Samuel 12:13–23); David’s son <b>Amnon</b> was killed; <b>Tamar,</b> his daughter, was raped by Amnon (see II Samuel 13); <b>and</b> his son <b>Avshalom</b> rebelled against him and was ultimately killed (see II Samuel 15–18).
The Gemara asks: If sins for which David was punished separately are not counted, one could ask: <b>There, too,</b> with regard to the sin of the census, <b>he was punished</b> separately, <b>as it is written: “And the Lord sent a plague against Israel from the morning until the appointed time”</b> (II Samuel 24:15). The Gemara responds: <b>There,</b> David <b>was not punished</b> personally, <b>in his</b> own <b>body;</b> rather, the punishment was inflicted on the Jewish people.
The Gemara challenges this: <b>There, too,</b> in the incident with Bathsheba, David <b>was not punished</b> personally, <b>in his</b> own <b>body;</b> rather, it was his children who suffered punishment. The Gemara answers: That is <b>not so; he was punished</b> personally, <b>in his</b> own <b>body,</b> for that sin, as <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: David was stricken with leprosy</b> for <b>six months</b> after that incident, <b>and the Sanhedrin withdrew from him</b> in protest over his behavior, <b>and the Divine Presence</b> also <b>left him. As it is written</b> that David prayed: <b>“May those who fear You return to me, and they who know Your testimonies”</b> (Psalms 119:79). Since he prayed for the return of those who fear God and who know His testimonies, referring to the Sages of the Sanhedrin, it can be inferred that they had withdrawn from him. <b>And it is written</b> as well: <b>“Restore to me the joy of Your salvation,</b> let a vigorous spirit support me” (Psalms 51:14), where David asks for the return of the Divine Spirit, which had left him.
The Gemara asks: And didn’t David commit other sins? <b>Didn’t Rav say: David accepted a slanderous report</b> from Ziba about Mephibosheth, son of Jonathan, stating that the latter was pleased with David’s downfall? There was, in that case, this additional sin. The Gemara responds: Consequently, it is necessary to follow the approach of <b>Shmuel, who said: David did not accept a slanderous report,</b> because Ziba’s claim was true.
The Gemara continues: <b>And even</b> according <b>to Rav, who said that David accepted a slanderous report,</b> one could answer that that sin is not counted, as <b>was he not punished</b> for it? <b>As Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: At the time when David said to Mephibosheth: “I say that you and Ziba should divide the field”</b> (II Samuel 19:30), <b>a Divine Voice came forth and said to him: Rehoboam and Jeroboam will divide the kingship.</b> Because David believed Ziba’s slanderous report and awarded him half of Mephibosheth’s field, David was punished by having his kingdom divided into two. Following King Solomon’s death the Jewish people split into two kingdoms, Israel to the north and Judea to the south (see I Kings 12<b>)</b>. Therefore, David was punished for that sin too.
§ The Gemara continues its discussion of Saul and David. It is written: <b>“Saul was one year old when he began to reign”</b> (I Samuel 13:1), which cannot be understood literally, as Saul was appointed king when he was a young man. <b>Rav Huna said:</b> The verse means that when he began to reign he was <b>like a one-year–old, in that he had never tasted the taste of sin</b> but was wholly innocent and upright.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak strongly objects to this</b> interpretation of the verse, saying: You could just as well <b>say</b> that he was <b>like a one-year-old</b> in that he was always <b>filthy with mud and excrement. Rav Naḥman was shown a frightful dream</b> that night, and he understood it as a punishment for having disparaged Saul. <b>He said: I humbly submit myself to you, O bones of Saul, son of Kish,</b> and beg your forgiveness. But <b>once again he was shown a frightful dream,</b> and he understood that he had not shown enough deference in his first apology. He therefore <b>said</b> this time: <b>I humbly submit myself to you, O bones of Saul, son of Kish, king of Israel,</b> and beg your forgiveness. Subsequently, the nightmares ceased.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: Why did the kingship of the house of Saul not continue</b> on to succeeding generations? It is <b>because there was no flaw</b> in his ancestry; he was of impeccable lineage. <b>As Rabbi Yoḥanan said in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yehotzadak: One appoints a leader over the community only if he has a box</b> full <b>of creeping animals hanging behind him,</b> i.e., he has something inappropriate in his ancestry that preceded him. Why is that? It is <b>so that if he exhibits a haughty attitude toward the community, one can say to him: Turn</b> and look <b>behind you</b> and be reminded of your humble roots. This is why David’s kingdom lasted while Saul’s did not, as David descended from a family with problematic ancestry, namely Tamar (see Genesis, chapter 38) and Ruth the Moabite (see Ruth 4:18–22).
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: Why was Saul punished</b> in that he was ultimately led to commit the sins described above? <b>Because</b> at the very outset of his reign he inappropriately <b>forwent his</b> royal <b>honor, as it is stated</b> with regard to Saul’s inauguration: <b>“And some base fellows said: How can this man save us? So they disparaged him and brought him no present. But he made himself as if he did not hear”</b> (I Samuel 10:27). And it is stated immediately afterward: <b>“And Nahash the Ammonite marched up and encamped against Jabesh-gilead”</b> (I Samuel 11:1). The implication is that if Saul had forcefully assumed his throne, Nahash would not have dared to attack the people of Jabesh-gilead. In this way, his humility led to the crisis.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yehotzadak: Any Torah scholar</b>

Daf 23a

<b>who does not avenge</b> himself <b>and bear a grudge like a snake</b> when insulted <b>is not</b> considered <b>a Torah scholar</b> at all, as it is important to uphold the honor of Torah and its students by reacting harshly to insults. The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it written</b> explicitly in the Torah: <b>“You shall not take vengeance nor bear any grudge</b> against the children of your people” (Leviticus 19:18)? The Gemara responds: <b>That</b> prohibition <b>is written with regard to monetary</b> matters and not personal insults, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>What is revenge and what is bearing a grudge? Revenge</b> is illustrated by the following example: <b>One said to</b> his fellow: <b>Lend me your sickle,</b> and <b>he said: No. The next day he,</b> the one who had refused to lend the sickle, <b>said to</b> the other person: <b>Lend me your ax.</b> If he <b>said to him: I will not lend to you, just as you did not lend to me, that is revenge.</b>
<b>And what is bearing a grudge?</b> If <b>one said to</b> his fellow: <b>Lend me your ax,</b> and <b>he said: No,</b> and <b>the next day he,</b> the one who had refused to lend the ax, <b>said to</b> the other man: <b>Lend me your robe;</b> if the first one <b>said to him: Here it is,</b> as <b>I am not like you, who would not lend to me, that is bearing a grudge.</b> Although he does not respond to his friend’s inconsiderate behavior in kind, he still makes it known to his friend that he resents his inconsiderate behavior. This <i>baraita</i> shows that the prohibition relates only to monetary matters, such as borrowing and lending.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> does the prohibition against vengeance really <b>not</b> relate also to matters of <b>personal anguish</b> suffered by someone? <b>Wasn’t</b> it <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Those who are insulted but do not insult</b> others, <b>who hear themselves</b> being <b>shamed but do not respond, who act out of love</b> for God, <b>and who</b> remain <b>happy in</b> their <b>suffering, about them the verse states: “They that love Him be as the sun when it goes forth in its might”</b> (Judges 5:31). This <i>baraita</i> shows that one should forgive personal insults as well as wrongs in monetary matters.
The Gemara responds that the prohibition against taking vengeance and bearing a grudge indeed applies to cases of personal anguish; however, <b>actually,</b> the scholar may <b>keep</b> resentment <b>in his heart,</b> though he should not act on it or remind the other person of his insulting behavior. The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t Rava say:</b> With regard to <b>whoever forgoes his reckonings</b> with others for injustices done to him, the heavenly court in turn <b>forgoes</b> punishment <b>for all his sins?</b> The Gemara answers: Indeed, even a scholar who is insulted must forgive insults, but that is only in cases where his antagonist <b>has sought to appease</b> him, in which case he should allow himself to <b>be appeased</b> toward him. However, if no apology has been offered, the scholar should not forgive him, in order to uphold the honor of the Torah.
§ The mishna describes that the lottery between competing priests is conducted by the priests extending their fingers for a count. And the mishna elaborated: <b>And what</b> fingers <b>do they extend</b> for the lottery? They may extend <b>one or two</b> fingers, and the priests do not extend a thumb in the Temple. The Gemara asks: <b>Now</b> that the mishna states that the priest may extend <b>two</b> fingers, is it <b>necessary</b> to state that they may also extend <b>one</b> finger?
<b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> when the mishna speaks of extending one finger, it is referring to <b>a healthy person</b>, who has no difficulty extending just one finger without extending a second one. <b>There,</b> when the mishna mentions two fingers, it is referring to <b>a sick person,</b> for whom it is difficult to extend a single finger at a time. <b>And</b> so <b>it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>They</b> may <b>extend one</b> finger, but <b>they</b> may <b>not extend two. In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said <b>in</b> reference to <b>a healthy person; however, a sick person</b> may <b>extend even two</b> fingers. <b>And</b> the sick priests who sit or lie <b>alone,</b> separately from the other priests, <b>extend two</b> fingers, <b>but</b> their two fingers are <b>counted only as one.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> are the sick priest’s two fingers really <b>counted as only one? Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The priests may <b>not extend the third</b> finger, i.e., the middle finger, <b>or the thumb,</b> together with the index finger, <b>due to</b> concern for <b>cheaters.</b> One who sees that the count is approaching him might intentionally extend or withdraw an extra finger so that the lottery will fall on him. <b>But if he does extend the third</b> finger <b>it is counted for him.</b> This is because the third finger cannot be stretched very far from the index finger, so that it is easily recognizable that both fingers are from the same person, and this is not taken as an attempt to cheat. If he extends his <b>thumb,</b> however, <b>it is not counted for him, and moreover</b> he is punished with <b>lashes</b> administered by <b>the person in charge of the <i>pakia</i>.</b> The implication of the <i>baraita</i> is that when the third finger is extended along with the index finger, both fingers are counted.
The Gemara answers: <b>What</b> does the <i>baraita</i> mean when it says that if the priest extended his middle finger along with his index finger, <b>it is counted for him?</b> It <b>also</b> means, as stated earlier, that the two fingers are counted as <b>one.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> mentions lashes administered by the person in charge of the <i>pakia</i>. <b>What</b> is <b>a <i>pakia</i>? Rav said:</b> It is <b>a <i>madra</i>.</b> However, the meaning of that term also became unclear over time, so the Gemara asks: <b>What is a <i>madra</i>? Rav Pappa said: It is a whip [<i>matraka</i>]</b> used by <b>the Arabs, the end of which is split</b> into several strands. That is the <i>pakia</i> mentioned above, which was used for punishing the priests.
Apropos this discussion, <b>Abaye said: At first I would say</b> as follows: <b>When we learned</b> in a mishna that <b>ben Beivai was in charge of the <i>pakia</i>, I would say</b> that it means that he was in charge of producing <b>wicks, as we learned</b> in another mishna: <b>They would tear</b> [<b><i>mafkia</i></b>] strips <b>from the priests’ worn-out trousers and belts and</b> make wicks out of them, <b>with which they lit</b> the lamps for the Celebration of Drawing Water. But <b>once I heard that which is taught</b> in the previously cited <i>baraita</i>: <b>And moreover,</b> he is punished with <b>lashes</b> administered by <b>the person in charge of the <i>pakia</i>, I</b> now <b>say: What</b> is <b>a <i>pakia</i>?</b> It is <b>lashes.</b> Ben Beivai was in charge of corporal punishment in the Temple.
§ It was taught in the mishna: <b>An incident</b> occurred where <b>both of</b> the priests <b>were equal</b> as they were <b>running and ascending on the ramp,</b> and one of them shoved the other and he fell and his leg was broken. <b>The Sages taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>An incident</b> occurred where there were <b>two priests who were equal</b> as they were <b>running and ascending the ramp. One of them reached the four cubits before his colleague,</b> who then, out of anger, <b>took a knife and stabbed him in the heart.</b>
The <i>Tosefta</i> continues: <b>Rabbi Tzadok</b> then <b>stood up on the steps of the Entrance Hall</b> of the Sanctuary <b>and said: Hear</b> this, <b>my brothers of the house of Israel.</b> The verse <b>states: “If one be found slain in the land...</b> and it be not known who had smitten him; <b>then your Elders and your judges shall come forth</b> and they shall measure…and it shall be that the city which is nearest to the slain man…shall take a heifer” (Deuteronomy 21:1–3). And the Elders of that city took that heifer and broke its neck in a ritual of atonement. But what of <b>us,</b> in our situation? <b>Upon whom</b> is the obligation <b>to bring the heifer whose neck is broken?</b> Does the obligation fall <b>on the city,</b> Jerusalem, so that its Sages must bring the calf, <b>or</b> does the obligation fall <b>upon the</b> Temple <b>courtyards,</b> so that the priests must bring it? At that point <b>the entire</b> assembly of <b>people burst into tears.</b>
<b>The father of the boy,</b> i.e., the young priest who was stabbed, <b>came and found that he was</b> still <b>convulsing. He said: May</b> my son’s death <b>be an atonement for you.</b> But <b>my son is still convulsing</b> and has not yet died, and as such, <b>the knife,</b> which is in his body, <b>has not become ritually impure</b> through contact with a corpse. If you remove it promptly, it will still be pure for future use. The <i>Tosefta</i> comments: This incident comes <b>to teach you that the ritual purity of utensils</b> was <b>of more concern to them than the shedding of blood.</b> Even the boy’s father voiced more concern over the purity of the knife than over the death of his child. <b>And similarly, it says: “Furthermore, Manasseh spilled innocent blood very much, till he had filled Jerusalem from one end to another”</b> (II Kings 21:16), which shows that in his day as well people paid little attention to bloodshed.
The Gemara asks: <b>Which incident came first,</b> the one about the broken leg reported in the mishna or the one about the slain priest in the <i>Tosefta</i>? <b>If we say</b> that the incident of <b>bloodshed</b> came first, this raises a problem: <b>Now,</b> if in response to a case of <b>bloodshed they did not establish a lottery</b> but continued with the running competition, can it be that in response to an incident of a priest’s <b>leg being broken they did establish</b> a lottery? <b>Rather,</b> we must say that the case in which the priest’s <b>leg was broken</b> in the course of the race <b>came first,</b> and as the mishna states, the establishment of the lottery was in response to that incident.
The Gemara asks: If the running competition was abolished immediately after the incident of the broken leg and a lottery was instituted to replace it, <b>once they established the lottery, what were they doing</b> still running to within <b>the four cubits</b> in the incident that led to the priest’s murder? <b>Rather, actually,</b> it is necessary to return to the approach suggested earlier, <b>that</b> the case involving <b>bloodshed came first. Initially,</b> the Sages <b>thought that it was merely a random,</b> i.e., isolated, <b>event,</b> and because it was extremely unlikely for a murder to happen again they did not abolish the competition due to that incident. Then, <b>once they saw that in any event</b> the priests <b>were coming to danger,</b> as one of them was pushed and broke his leg, <b>the Sages established a lottery.</b>
The Gemara returns to the incident of the slain priest and discusses several details of it. It was related that <b>Rabbi Tzadok stood up on the steps of the Entrance Hall</b> of the Sanctuary <b>and said: Hear</b> this, <b>my brothers of the house of Israel.</b> The verse <b>states: “If one be found slain in the land,</b> etc.” But what of <b>us,</b> in our situation? <b>Upon whom</b> is the obligation <b>to bring</b> the heifer whose neck is broken? Does the obligation fall <b>upon the city,</b> Jerusalem, <b>or</b> does the obligation fall <b>upon the</b> Temple <b>courtyards?</b> The Gemara asks: Is <b>Jerusalem subject to bringing a heifer whose neck is broken? Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Ten things were said</b> about <b>Jerusalem</b> to distinguish it from all other cities in Eretz Yisrael, <b>and this is one of them:</b>

Daf 23b

Jerusalem <b>does not bring a heifer whose neck is broken.</b> The reason for this is that the <i>halakha</i> of the heifer whose neck is broken applies only to land that was apportioned to a specific tribe of the Jewish people. Jerusalem alone was not divided among the tribes, but was shared equally by the entire nation. <b>And furthermore, it is written</b> that the heifer whose neck is broken is brought when <b>“it be not known who had smitten him,” and</b> here, in the case of the slain priest, <b>it was</b> well <b>known who had smitten him. Rather,</b> one must conclude that Rabbi Tzadok invoked the <i>halakha</i> of the heifer whose neck is broken not because it actually applied in this case but only in <b>order</b> to arouse the people’s grief and <b>to increase weeping.</b>
In relating the above incident the <i>Tosefta</i> said: <b>The father of the boy came and found that he was</b> still <b>convulsing. He said: May</b> my son’s death <b>be an atonement for you.</b> But <b>my son is still alive,</b> etc. This incident comes <b>to teach you that the ritual purity of utensils</b> was <b>of more concern to them than the shedding of blood. A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: Should one conclude from this comment that <b>bloodshed had become trivialized</b> in their eyes <b>but</b> their concern for <b>purity of utensils remained where it was</b> originally, meaning that while they cared less than they should have about murder, they did not exaggerate the importance of purity of utensils; <b>or perhaps</b> their concern for <b>bloodshed remained where it was</b> originally, <b>but</b> their concern for <b>purity of vessels</b> had become too <b>strict,</b> to the extent that its importance was exaggerated beyond concern for human life?
The Gemara answers: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> an answer to the dilemma: Since the <i>Tosefta</i> <b>adduces a biblical teaching</b> from the verse, <b>“Furthermore, Manasseh spilled innocent blood,” conclude from this</b> that <b>it was bloodshed that had become trivialized, and</b> the importance of <b>purity of utensils remained where it had been.</b>
§ The Gemara returns to the mitzva of removing the ashes from the altar and associated issues. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The Torah states, after describing the removal of the ashes: <b>“And he shall put off</b> his garments, <b>and put on other garments, and carry the ashes out</b> of the camp to a clean place” (Leviticus 6:4). <b>I</b> might <b>understand</b> from here that this change of garments is a mitzva to change into a different kind of garment, <b>similar to</b> the change of garments performed on <b>Yom Kippur,</b> when the High Priest changes back and forth from gold clothes to white clothes. Here, too, the Torah requires <b>that he remove his sacred garments and put on non-sacred garments.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: To teach us otherwise, <b>the verse states: “And he shall put off his garments, and put on other garments,”</b> thereby <b>juxtaposing the garments he puts on to the garments he takes off.</b> This indicates that <b>just as there,</b> the garments he removes, i.e., those in which he had performed the mitzva of removal of the ashes, are <b>sacred garments, so too here,</b> the clothes he puts on to take the ashes out of the camp are <b>sacred garments.</b>
<b>If so, what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: Other</b> garments, which implies that the second set of garments is different from the first? It means they are <b>of lower quality than</b> the first set of garments. <b>Rabbi Eliezer says</b> a different interpretation of the words: Other garments. The verse states: “And put on <b>other</b> garments, <b>and carry</b> the ashes <b>out</b> of the camp,” in which the Hebrew juxtaposes the words “other” and “carry out.” This <b>teaches that priests with</b> physical <b>blemishes,</b> who are considered others in that they are not eligible to perform sacred tasks, <b>are eligible to carry out the ashes.</b>
The Gemara now explains the <i>baraita</i> in detail. <b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: The words: <b>Other</b> garments, teach that they are to be <b>of lower quality than</b> the garments worn during the removal of the ashes. This is <b>in accordance with</b> what <b>was taught</b> in <b>the school of Rabbi Yishmael, as it was taught</b> in <b>the school of Rabbi Yishmael: Clothes</b> worn by a servant <b>as he was cooking food for his master</b> that became soiled in the process <b>should not</b> be worn by him when <b>he pours a cup for his master,</b> which is a task that calls for the servant to present a dignified appearance. Similarly, one who performs the dirtying task of carrying out the ashes should not wear the same fine clothes worn to perform other services.
The <i>baraita</i> taught that Rabbi Eliezer derived from the word other that blemished priests are eligible for the task of carrying out the ashes, while the first <i>tanna</i> derived a different teaching from those words. The Gemara clarifies the scope of the dispute between the first <i>tanna</i> and Rabbi Eliezer. <b>Reish Lakish said: Just as</b> there is <b>a dispute</b> between Rabbi Eliezer and the first <i>tanna</i> <b>with regard to carrying</b> the ashes <b>out</b> of the camp, <b>so too, there is a dispute with regard to the removal of the ashes</b> from the altar. Rabbi Eliezer maintains that the removal of the ashes may also be performed by blemished priests, while the first <i>tanna</i> disagrees. <b>But Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The <b>dispute</b> is only <b>with regard to carrying</b> the ashes <b>out</b> of the camp, <b>but all agree that the removal</b> of the ashes <b>is a</b> bona fide Temple <b>service</b> that cannot be performed by blemished priests.
The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reason behind</b> the opinion <b>of Reish Lakish?</b> Reish Lakish could have <b>said to you: If it enters your mind</b> that the removal of the ashes <b>is a</b> bona fide Temple <b>service,</b> you are faced with the following difficulty: <b>Do you have</b> any Temple <b>service that may be performed with</b> only <b>two garments</b> rather than the full set of four vestments worn by the priests? In the Torah’s description of the garments worn to remove the ashes it says: “And the priest shall put on his linen garment, and his linen trousers shall he put on his flesh” (Leviticus 6:3).
<b>And</b> what is the explanation for <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan’s</b> opinion? In fact, the priest is required to wear all four priestly garments. <b>The Merciful One reveals</b> in the Torah that the priest must wear <b>the tunic and the trousers</b> like any other service so that one would not think that taking out the ashes may be performed in regular, non-sacred clothes. Once the Torah has made this point and mentioned these two specific garments, <b>the same is true</b> for the other two garments as well, i.e., <b>the mitre and the belt.</b>
The Gemara asks: If the Torah requires all four garments and mentions the tunic and trousers only as examples, <b>what is different about these</b> two that the Torah mentioned them in particular? The Gemara answers that these two particular garments were mentioned in order to teach certain <i>halakhot</i>. The Torah refers to the tunic as <b>“his linen garment,”</b> with the words <b>“his garment” [<i>middo</i>],</b> indicating that the tunic must conform <b>to his</b> exact <b>size [<i>middato</i>]</b> and should fit the priest perfectly. As for the words <b>“linen trousers,”</b> they come to teach <b>that which was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> as the priest gets dressed <b>no</b> garment <b>should precede the trousers? As it is stated: “And his linen trousers shall he put on his flesh,”</b> which implies that the trousers should be donned when the priest has nothing but his flesh, i.e., when he has no other garments on him yet.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>Reish Lakish,</b> who maintains that these two garments are mentioned because they are the only two that the priest wears when removing the ashes, from where does he derive these two <i>halakhot</i>? The Gemara answers: The <i>halakha</i> that <b>his</b> linen <b>garment,</b> i.e., the tunic, must be <b>according to his size</b> is derived the fact that <b>the Merciful One uses the expression “his garment,”</b> i.e., his fitted garment, in the Torah, rather than calling it by its usual name, tunic. And the <i>halakha</i> <b>that no</b> garment <b>should precede the trousers</b> when the priest dresses is <b>derived</b> from the fact that the Torah added the phrase <b>“on his flesh.”</b>
<b>Let us say</b> that the dispute between Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish is <b>parallel to</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b> As it was taught in a <i>baraita</i> that the Torah states: “And the priest shall put on his linen garment, and his linen trousers shall he put on his flesh” (Leviticus 6:3). The words “shall he put on” seem superfluous, since these same words were already stated earlier in the verse. Therefore, the Torah could have sufficed with saying: “And linen trousers <b>on his flesh.” What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “Shall he put on”?</b> This extra expression comes <b>to include</b> the donning of the <b>mitre and</b> the <b>belt,</b> which are not mentioned here explicitly, for <b>the removal</b> of the ash; this is the statement of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>Rabbi Dosa says:</b> The extra expression comes <b>to include the</b> permissibility of the <b>High Priest’s clothes</b> that he wears <b>on Yom Kippur,</b> which are linen garments identical to those of the common priest, to teach that <b>they are acceptable</b> to be used afterward by <b>common priests</b> in their service. In other words, the expression teaches that the High Priest’s garments need not be permanently retired from service after Yom Kippur, unlike the opinion of another Sage, as will be explained below.
<b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: There are two refutations</b> against Rabbi Dosa’s interpretation: <b>One</b> is that <b>the belt of</b> the <b>High Priest</b> that he wears on Yom Kippur is made only of linen and <b>is not</b> identical to <b>the belt of</b> the <b>common priest,</b> which, in Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s opinion, is made of wool and linen. Therefore, it is impossible for the High Priest’s Yom Kippur garments to be used by a common priest. <b>And furthermore,</b> with regard to <b>garments that you used</b> to perform the services of <b>the most severe sanctity,</b> i.e., the services performed by the High Priest on Yom Kippur, can it be that <b>you will</b> then <b>use them</b> to perform <b>services of lesser sanctity</b> by a common priest? <b>Instead</b> of this, a different interpretation must be said. <b>What,</b> then, is the meaning when <b>the verse states</b> the superfluous words <b>“shall he put on”?</b>

Daf 24a

The phrase comes <b>to include worn out</b> garments, teaching that as long as they have not become tattered they may be used for Temple services.
The Gemara continues with another <i>baraita</i> connected to this debate. With regard to the garments of the High Priest, the Torah states: “And Aaron shall go into the tent of meeting, and he shall take off the linen garments that he had put on when he went into the Sanctuary, <b>and shall leave them there”</b> (Leviticus 16:23). This verse <b>teaches that</b> the linen garments worn by the High Priest during the Yom Kippur service <b>require storing away,</b> i.e., they may not be used again. <b>Rabbi Dosa says:</b> They do not have to be stored away, because although they may not be used again by the High Priest on a subsequent Yom Kippur, <b>they are acceptable</b> for use <b>for a common priest. And what,</b> then, is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “And shall leave them there,”</b> which implies that they are not to be used again? It means <b>that</b> the High Priest himself <b>may not use them</b> on a <b>subsequent Yom Kippur</b> for service in the Holy of Holies; it does not mean that they may not be used at all.
The Gemara returns to the question of whether or not the removal of the ashes is considered a bona fide Temple service, requiring all four priestly garments, and whether or not this is the subject of debate between <i>tanna’im</i>. <b>What, is it not with regard to this that</b> Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Dosa <b>disagree: One Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda, who derives from the phrase “he shall wear” that all four garments are required, <b>holds</b> that the removal of the ashes <b>is a</b> bona fide <b>service; and one Sage,</b> Rabbi Dosa, who derives a different teaching from “he shall wear,” <b>holds</b> that <b>it is not a</b> bona fide <b>service,</b> and consequently only two of the four garments are required? Their dispute would therefore be identical to the dispute between Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: It is possible to say that this is <b>not</b> the subject of debate between these two <i>tanna’im</i>. Rather, <b>everyone</b> agrees that the removal of ashes <b>is</b> a bona fide Temple <b>service</b> requiring all four garments, <b>and here they disagree about</b> a different point, which is <b>this: One Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>holds</b> that <b>a</b> derivation from the <b>verse is necessary</b> to <b>include</b> the mitre and belt, which are not mentioned explicitly in the verse. <b>And one Sage,</b> Rabbi Dosa, <b>holds that</b> since the removal of the ash is a bona fide Temple service it is obvious that all four garments are required, so a derivation from <b>a verse</b> to include the other two garments <b>is not necessary.</b> Accordingly, both <i>tanna’im</i> are in agreement that the removal of ash is a bona fide service and requires all four priestly garments.
§ <b>Rabbi Avin raised a dilemma: How much</b> ash must be removed in order to fulfill the mitzva of <b>removal of the ashes? Do we derive it from the <i>teruma</i> of the tithe,</b> the portion that the Levite sets aside for the priest, in which case one hundredth of the total is separated, <b>or do we derive it from the donations</b> that were set aside from the spoils of the war with <b>Midian, where</b> one five-hundredth was taken from the spoils of war (see Numbers 31:28)? <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a teaching with regard to this dilemma. <b>As Rabbi Ḥiyya taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>it is stated here: “And he shall take up</b> the ashes” (Leviticus 6:3), <b>and it is said elsewhere,</b> with regard to a meal-offering: <b>“And he shall take up</b> a handful of the choice flour of the meal-offering” (Leviticus 6:8). <b>Just as there,</b> the amount he removes is <b>a handful</b> of flour, <b>so too, here,</b> he removes <b>a handful</b> of ash. The amount of ashes removed from the altar is therefore not a fixed percentage of the total ash.
§ <b>Rav said:</b> Although a non-priest may not perform any Temple service, <b>there are</b> only <b>four</b> Temple <b>services</b> for which <b>a non-priest is liable to</b> receive the punishment of <b>death</b> by God’s hand for doing so. They are: <b>Sprinkling</b> sacrificial blood on the altar, <b>and burning</b> incense or parts of sacrificial animals on the altar, <b>and</b> pouring out <b>the water libation</b> on the altar on the festival of <i>Sukkot</i>, <b>and</b> pouring out <b>the wine libation</b> on the altar. <b>And Levi said:</b> This is true <b>also</b> for <b>the removal of the ashes. And similarly, Levi taught in his</b> collection of <b><i>baraitot</i>: The removal of ashes</b> is <b>also</b> included among those services for which a non-priest incurs the death penalty if he performs them.
The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reason for Rav’s</b> opinion? <b>As it is written: “And you and your sons with you shall keep your priesthood in everything pertaining to the altar and to that within the veil; and you shall serve; I give you the priesthood as a service of gift; and the common man that draws near shall be put to death”</b> (Numbers 18:7). Rav interprets this verse as follows: <b>“A service of gift”</b> indicates a service that involves giving, i.e., placing something on the altar, <b>and not a service</b> that involves <b>removal</b> from the altar, to the exclusion of removing the ashes. <b>“And you shall serve [<i>va’avadtem</i>]”</b> is interpreted as referring to <b>a service that is complete [<i>avoda tamma</i>]</b> on its own, such as sprinkling the blood, <b>and not</b> a service that is not complete, i.e., <b>a service that</b> is only a preparatory step and <b>has another service after it</b> that completes its purpose, such as slaughtering the animal or collecting its blood, which are only preparatory steps leading up to the sprinkling of the blood on the altar.
<b>And</b> what is the reason for the opinion of <b>Levi?</b> Why does he include the removal of ashes? According to him, <b>the Merciful One includes</b> this service by adding <b>“in everything pertaining to the altar,”</b> which teaches that all actions performed on the altar, including the removal of ashes, are significant and are prohibited to a non-priest on pain of death. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what does <b>Rav</b> learn from the phrase “in everything pertaining to the altar”? The Gemara answers: According to him, the word “everything” in <b>that</b> phrase comes <b>to include the seven sprinklings that are</b> performed <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary, when the blood of certain offerings is sprinkled on the veil of the Holy of Holies, <b>and</b> the seven sprinklings of oil <b>of the leper,</b> which are also performed inside the Sanctuary. Rav learns from the word “everything” that if a non-priest were to perform any of these actions he would be liable to receive the death penalty, despite the fact that they are not performed on the altar.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> from where does <b>Levi</b> derive these cases? The Gemara answers: <b>He derives</b> them <b>from</b> the superfluous wording of the text. As the entire phrase <b>“pertaining</b> to the altar” is superfluous, he derives from this the inclusion of the removal of the ashes. Additionally, the expression <b>“everything pertaining”</b> implies a further inclusion, from which he derives the internal sprinklings mentioned above. <b>And</b> what does <b>Rav</b> learn from this superfluous wording? Rav does <b>not derive</b> anything particular from the distinction between the expressions <b>“pertaining</b> to the altar” and <b>“everything pertaining</b> to the altar.”
The Gemara asks about Levi’s position: <b>But say</b> that the verse should be interpreted as follows: <b>“In everything pertaining”</b> is a <b>generalization,</b> and <b>“a service of gift”</b> is a <b>specification,</b> indicating a case of <b>a generalization</b> followed by <b>a specification.</b> One of the principles of hermeneutics states that in such cases, <b>the generalization includes only what</b> is mentioned explicitly <b>in the specification.</b> Following that rule, one would conclude: <b>A service of giving,</b> i.e., placing on the altar, <b>yes,</b> this is included, but <b>a service of removal</b> is <b>not</b> included. This presents a difficulty for Levi. The Gemara responds that <b>the verse states:</b>

Daf 24b

<b>“To that within the veil; and you shall serve;</b> I give you the priesthood as a service of gift” (Numbers 18:7), indicating that it is only with regard to services that are performed <b>within the veil,</b> i.e., in the Holy of Holies, <b>that there is</b> a distinction between services, and a non-priest who performs <b>services of giving</b> there, such as sprinkling the blood inside the Holy of Holies on Yom Kippur, is subject to the death penalty, <b>but not</b> one who performs <b>services of removing</b> there, such as the removal of the censer from the Holy of Holies on Yom Kippur. <b>This</b> leads to the conclusion that when it comes to services performed <b>outside</b> of the Holy of Holies, a non-priest would be liable if he performed any service, <b>even a service of removal,</b> such as the removal of ashes from the altar.
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> it is <b>so</b> that the limitations of the verse apply only to those services performed in the Holy of Holies, one should say that the phrase: “<b>And you shall serve [<i>va’avadtem</i>],”</b> from which it is derived that one is liable only for a service that is complete [<i>avoda tamma</i>] on its own and not incomplete, should <b>also</b> be similarly limited to services performed <b>to what is within the veil.</b> In that case, the liability of the non-priest, which is limited to cases where he performs <b>a complete service and</b> does <b>not</b> apply if he performs <b>a service that</b> is only preparatory and <b>has another service after it</b> that completes its purpose, should apply only to services performed in the Holy of Holies. <b>But</b> for services performed <b>outside</b> the Holy of Holies, a non-priest should be liable <b>even</b> if it is <b>a service that</b> is incomplete and <b>has a service after it.</b>
The Gemara answers: The phrase: “<b>And you shall serve [<i>va’avadtem</i>],”</b> which begins with the conjunction <i>vav</i>, meaning: And, indicates that <b>the verse goes back and combines</b> the service performed within the veil to services performed outside of it. This teaches that with regard to this <i>halakha</i> there is no difference between a service performed outside and a service performed inside.
According to Levi, if a non-priest performs a service involving removal within the veil, i.e., in the Holy of Holies, he does not incur the death penalty, but if he performs a service involving removal outside, such as the removal of the ashes from the external altar, he is liable to the death penalty. <b>Rava raised a dilemma</b> relating to Levi’s approach: <b>What</b> would be the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a service of removal</b> performed <b>in the Sanctuary</b> chamber that is before the Holy of Holies, such as removing the burnt incense from the inner altar, or removing burnt wicks and leftover oil from the candelabrum? Do <b>we compare</b> such an act <b>to</b> a service performed <b>inside</b> the Holy of Holies, so that he would be exempt from the death penalty, <b>or</b> do <b>we compare</b> it <b>to the outer</b> service?
Rava himself <b>went back and resolved</b> the dilemma: Had the Torah said only: <b>Within</b> the veil, it would have been understood that it is referring only to actions performed in the Holy of Holies. But since the Torah says: <b>And to what is within</b> the veil, the added conjunction: And, teaches that it is referring to something else besides the Holy of Holies, i.e., the Sanctuary.
The Gemara asks: <b>However, if</b> it is <b>so</b> that a non-priest is liable for performing a service that is complete on its own that takes place in the Sanctuary, one should say that <b>a non-priest who arranges the</b> loaves on the shewbread <b>table should be liable.</b> The Gemara answers: After arranging the bread <b>there is</b> still the <b>arranging of the vessels</b> of frankincense on the table that remains to be done, so the arrangement of the bread is not a service that is complete on its own. The Gemara asks: If so, <b>a non-priest who arranges the vessels</b> of frankincense on the table <b>should be liable.</b> The Gemara rejects this: After arranging the vessels, <b>there is</b> still the <b>removal</b> of these vessels <b>and the burning</b> of their frankincense on the altar that remain to be done; therefore, arranging the vessels is not considered a service that is complete on its own.
The Gemara asks further with regard to the notion that a non-priest is liable for performing a service that is complete on its own that takes place in the Sanctuary: If so, <b>a non-priest who arranges the</b> lamps of the <b>candelabrum should be liable.</b> The Gemara rejects this: <b>There is</b> still the <b>placing of the wicks</b> in the lamps that remains to be done, so arranging the lamps is not considered a service that is complete on its own. The Gemara asks: If so, a non-priest who <b>placed a wick</b> in the candelabrum’s lamps <b>should be liable.</b> The Gemara answers: That too is not a service that is complete on its own, as <b>there is</b> still the necessity of <b>placing the oil.</b>
The Gemara asks: If so, a non-priest who <b>placed the oil should be liable.</b> The Gemara answers: That too is not a service that is complete on its own, as <b>there is</b> still the service of <b>lighting</b> that needs to be done. The Gemara asks: If so, if a non-priest <b>who lit</b> the lamps <b>should be liable.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Lighting</b> the lamps <b>is not</b> considered a bona fide Temple <b>service,</b> since in doing so nothing is done to the candelabrum itself.
The Gemara asks: <b>And is</b> kindling a fire really <b>not</b> considered a Temple service? <b>But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that it is written: <b>“And the sons of Aaron the priest shall put fire upon the altar and lay out wood in order upon the fire”</b> (Leviticus 1:7), which <b>teaches that the kindling of chips [<i>alita</i>]</b> added to keep the altar’s fire going must <b>be performed only by a proper priest and</b> that he must be wearing <b>the priestly garments?</b> This shows that kindling is considered a service. The Gemara answers: <b>Kindling</b> the <b>chips is a</b> bona fide <b>service,</b> but <b>lighting</b> the candelabrum is <b>not</b> a bona fide <b>service.</b>
The Gemara further asks: <b>However, if</b> it is <b>so</b> that a non-priest is liable for performing any service involving placing, as established above, <b>a non-priest who set up the arrangement</b> of wood on the altar <b>should be liable,</b> since that is a service involving placing. The Gemara answers: <b>There is</b> still <b>the</b> mitzva of the <b>arrangement of two logs</b> on the altar that remains to be done, so that setting up the arrangement of wood is not a service that is complete on its own. The Gemara asks: If so, a non-priest who <b>arranged the two logs should be liable.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>There is</b> still <b>the arrangement of limbs</b> of offerings on the fire that remains to be done, so placing the two logs is also not considered a service that is complete on its own.
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t Rav Asi say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: A non-priest who arranged the two pieces of wood is liable?</b> This shows that placing the two logs is a complete service and contradicts Rav’s statement that a non-priest is liable only if he performs the four services that he mentioned above. The Gemara answers: Indeed, Rav and Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>disagree on this</b> point. <b>One Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds</b> that the placement of the two logs <b>is a service that is complete</b> on its own, as the arrangement of limbs that follows is not considered a continuation of the setting up of the wood; <b>and one Sage,</b> Rav, <b>holds</b> that the placement of the two logs <b>is not</b> considered <b>a service that is complete</b> on its own, since it is followed by the arrangement of the limbs on the wood.
The Gemara returns to the disagreement between Rav and Levi and notes: <b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav,</b> and <b>it was taught</b> in a second <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Levi. It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav:</b> These are the <b>services for which a non-priest</b> who performs them <b>is liable to</b> receive the penalty of <b>death</b> by God’s hand: One who performs <b>the sprinkling of blood, whether inside</b> the Sanctuary; on the golden altar or at the veil; <b>or inside the innermost</b> chamber, the Holy of Holies, on Yom Kippur; or outside on the main altar; <b>and one who sprinkles</b> blood in the case of a <b>bird sin-offering; and one who squeezes</b> the blood of <b>a bird burnt-offering</b> on the wall of the altar <b>or burns</b> the bird on the altar; <b>and one who pours out three <i>log</i> of water</b> on the altar for the <i>Sukkot</i> water libation <b>or three <i>log</i> of wine</b> on the altar for an ordinary libation. The removal of ashes from the altar is not listed here.
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Levi:</b> These are the <b>services for which a non-priest</b> who performs them <b>is liable to</b> receive the penalty of <b>death</b> by God’s hand: <b>One who removes the ashes</b> from the altar; one who performs <b>the seven sprinklings that are</b> performed <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary <b>or</b> the sprinklings <b>of the leper; and one who raises up</b> an offering <b>onto the altar, whether it is</b> a <b>proper</b> offering <b>or</b> a <b>disqualified</b> one. In this <i>baraita</i>, the removal of ashes is listed.
§ The Gemara returns to its interpretation of the mishna. The mishna states that there were four lotteries held in the Temple every day. One of the Sages asked: <b>Why did</b> the Temple authorities <b>hold lotteries?</b> Before answering the question, the Gemara expresses astonishment at the question itself: <b>Why did they hold lotteries?</b> The reason is <b>as we said</b> clearly in the mishna: To prevent quarrels among the priests. The Gemara explains: <b>Rather,</b> this is the meaning of the question: <b>Why did they</b> assemble all the priests together and <b>hold a lottery, and once again</b> gather them together to <b>hold another lottery,</b> four times, when the priests could be gathered one time and all the necessary lotteries held at that time?
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> It was done this way <b>in order to create a commotion throughout</b> the Temple <b>courtyard,</b> as the priests would converge from all over to assemble there, <b>as it is stated: “We took sweet counsel together, in the House of God we walked with the throng”</b> (Psalms 55:15). This verse teaches that it is proper to stir up a commotion and to cause public excitement in the course of the Temple services and the preliminary steps leading up to them, such as the assignment of tasks to the priests.
The Gemara asks: <b>With what</b> garments were the priests clothed when <b>they held the lottery? Rav Naḥman said:</b> The priests were clothed in their own <b>non-sacred garments. And Rav Sheshet said:</b> The priests were dressed in the priestly <b>sacred garments.</b>
The Gemara explains the two approaches. <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> The priests were dressed in <b>non-sacred garments, because if you say</b> the lottery was to be held when they were dressed in their <b>sacred garments, there are</b> strong-<b>armed men who might act with force and perform the service</b> even if they did not win the lottery. Since they were already wearing the sacred garments, they would simply force their way into performing the service. <b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> They were wearing the <b>sacred garments, as, if you say</b> they wore their <b>non-sacred garments, due to</b> the fact that the service was so <b>beloved</b> to them, in their excitement over having been granted the privilege to perform the service, <b>it may happen</b> that <b>they would perform the service</b> immediately, forgetting to don their sacred garments, thereby disqualifying the service.
<b>Rav Naḥman said: From where do I state</b> my opinion? <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: After the lottery <b>they gave</b> the priests <b>over to the attendants, and they would take their clothes off them and they would leave only</b> their <b>trousers on them.</b>

Daf 25a

<b>What, is</b> this <b>not</b> talking <b>about those</b> priests <b>who won the lottery,</b> describing how their non-sacred garments were removed from them before they were dressed in the priestly garments? <b>Rav Huna bar Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav Sheshet said,</b> rejecting that interpretation: <b>No,</b> it is possible to explain that all the priests at the lottery were wearing sacred garments and that, on the contrary, the mishna speaks <b>about those</b> priests <b>who did not win the lottery.</b> The text describes how the sacred garments they wore during the lottery were removed from them.
The Gemara supports this latter interpretation: <b>So too, it is reasonable</b> to follow Rav Sheshet’s interpretation of the mishna. <b>As, if it were to enter your mind</b> to say that the mishna is dealing <b>with those who won the lottery</b> and describes how their non-sacred garments were removed and sacred garments put on, how would one understand the statement: <b>They would leave only their trousers on them?</b> One would have to explain that the priests subsequently donned the sacred clothes on top of the non-sacred trousers; then they would remove the non-sacred trousers and replace them with the sacred trousers. <b>But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that nothing should precede the trousers</b> when the priest dresses? <b>The verse states: “And he shall have linen trousers upon his flesh”</b> (Leviticus 16:4)? However, according to the proposed interpretation of the mishna, the priests donned the other sacred garments and put on the trousers after them.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how would <b>the other one,</b> Rav Naḥman, resolve this difficulty? He would respond that <b>this is not difficult,</b> as <b>this is what</b> the mishna <b>is teaching: While the non-sacred garments are still on them they put the sacred trousers on them, and</b> then <b>they remove</b> from them <b>the non-sacred clothes, and they left</b> them wearing <b>only the</b> sacred <b>trousers.</b> Therefore, it is possible to interpret the mishna either way.
<b>Rav Sheshet said: From where do I say</b> that the priests wore sacred garments when the lottery was held? <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The Chamber of Hewn Stone was</b> built <b>in the style of a large basilica [<i>basileki</i>]; the lottery</b> is held <b>in the east</b> of the chamber, <b>and an Elder</b> of the court <b>sits in its west</b> to provide instruction and adjudicate any doubtful cases. <b>And the priests stand in a circle in the shape of a bracelet [<i>bekholyar</i>], and the appointed</b> priest <b>comes and removes the mitre from the head of one of them, and</b> everyone thereby <b>knew that the count began from him. And if it were to enter your mind</b> to say that the priests wore <b>non-sacred garments</b> during the lottery, <b>is there</b> such a thing as <b>a mitre among</b> one’s <b>non-sacred garments?</b> This shows that the priests were wearing their sacred garments when the lottery took place.
The Gemara rejects this reasoning: <b>Yes,</b> indeed, there is such a thing as a mitre that one wears as non-sacred apparel, <b>as Rav Yehuda, and some say</b> it was <b>Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda, taught: A priest whose mother made a tunic for him,</b> to show her love for her son and her love for mitzvot, <b>may perform an individual service with it on,</b> but not communal services. Therefore, it is possible that the priests had non-sacred mitres in the style of the sacred mitres, just as they sometimes had non-sacred tunics.
Apropos the <i>baraita</i> that was just cited, <b>Abaye said: Conclude from this</b> <i>baraita</i> that <b>the Chamber of Hewn Stone</b> was built <b>half in the sacred</b> area, within the consecrated Temple grounds, <b>and half in the non-sacred</b> part of the Temple grounds. <b>And conclude from it</b> as well that the chamber <b>had two doorways, one</b> that <b>opened to the sacred</b> area of the Temple <b>and one</b> that <b>opened to the non-sacred</b> area. Abaye explains these inferences: <b>As, were it to enter your mind</b> that the Chamber of Hewn Stone stood <b>entirely in the sacred</b> area, how could one say that <b>an Elder sat in its west? Didn’t the Master say: There is no sitting</b> allowed <b>in the</b> Temple <b>courtyard except for kings of the house of David alone?</b> The Elder must therefore have been sitting in an area external to the Temple courtyard area.
<b>And if it were to enter your mind</b> to say the opposite, that the chamber stood <b>entirely in the non-sacred</b> area, how could <b>the lottery</b> be held <b>in the east? Aren’t we required</b> to fulfill the verse: <b>“In the House of God we walked with the throng”</b> (Psalms 55:15), from where it was derived earlier that it is desirable that the lotteries cause a commotion in the House of God, i.e., in the sacred area of the Temple? If the lottery were held in a non-sacred area, <b>there</b> would <b>not be</b> a fulfillment of this verse. <b>Rather,</b> one must <b>conclude from this</b> <i>baraita</i> that the chamber was situated <b>half in the sacred</b> area of the Temple <b>and half in the non-sacred</b> area.
Abaye continues: <b>And were it to enter your mind</b> that the chamber <b>had</b> just <b>one doorway, which opened to the sacred</b> area, how could the <b>Elder sit in its west? Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: <b>Chambers that are built in the non-sacred</b> area of the Temple Mount, but that <b>open up into the sacred</b> area, <b>their interior is</b> considered entirely <b>sacred,</b> despite the fact that they also occupy land outside the sacred area? <b>And if,</b> on the other hand, <b>it were to enter your mind</b> that the chamber had just one doorway, <b>which opened to the non-sacred</b> area, how could the <b>lottery</b> be held <b>in its east? Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: With regard to chambers that are <b>built in the sacred</b> area but which <b>open up into the non-sacred</b> area, the space <b>within them is</b> considered entirely <b>non-sacred,</b> despite the chambers’ location on sacred territory. <b>Rather, isn’t it</b> correct to <b>conclude from this</b> that the Chamber of Hewn Stone <b>had two doorways, one that opened up into the sacred</b> area <b>and one that opened into the non-sacred</b> area?
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The second lottery</b> conducted daily among the priests determines the following: <b>Who slaughters</b> the daily morning offering, <b>who sprinkles</b> its blood, <b>who removes the ashes</b> from <b>the inner altar, and who removes the ashes</b> and burnt wicks from <b>the candelabrum, and who takes the limbs</b> of the daily offering <b>up to the ramp</b> to be burned later.
This is how the limbs were divided before taking them up to the altar: <b>The head and the</b> right <b>leg</b> were carried by one priest, <b>and the two forelegs</b> were carried by a second priest. <b>The tail,</b> including the lower vertebrae of the spinal column and the fat tail, <b>and the</b> left <b>leg</b> were carried by a third priest. <b>And the breast and the throat</b> and some of the inner organs attached to it were carried by a fourth priest. <b>And the two flanks</b> were taken by a fifth priest, <b>and the intestines</b> by a sixth priest. <b>And the fine flour</b> of the meal-offering accompanying the daily offering was carried by a seventh priest. <b>And the</b> High Priest’s daily <b>griddle-cake offering</b> was carried by an eighth priest, <b>and the wine</b> for libation was carried by a ninth priest. Altogether <b>thirteen priests prevailed in this</b> lottery: Nine priests who carried the daily offering and its accompanying elements, and four who performed the slaughter, sprinkling, and removal of ashes from the inner altar and the candelabrum.
<b>Ben Azzai said before Rabbi Akiva in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua:</b> That was not the sequence of taking the limbs up to the ramp; rather, the order in which <b>it was sacrificed</b> was according to <b>the way it walks</b> when alive, as will be explained in the Gemara.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>When the priests performed the lottery, did they perform a lottery for</b> just <b>one service,</b> such as the slaughtering, and the other twelve tasks were divided among the priests adjacent to the chosen one; <b>or perhaps they performed a</b> separate <b>lottery for each and every service</b> of the thirteen acts listed? The Gemara answers: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from that which was taught in the mishna: <b>There were four lotteries there. And if it were to enter your mind</b> that <b>they performed a lottery</b> for <b>each and every service</b> separately, <b>there would be many</b> more than four lotteries. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> That is not a conclusive proof, because one could argue that <b>this is what</b> the mishna <b>is saying:</b> The priests <b>gathered four times for a lottery, but each</b> gathering involved <b>many lotteries</b> for many individual services.

Daf 25b

<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> When the third lottery was held to determine who would perform the burning of the incense, <b>there was no</b> separate <b>lottery</b> held for carrying <b>the coal pan,</b> although a second priest was required to rake up coals from the outer altar, carry them in a coal pan, and put them on the inner altar, where the priest assigned the task of burning the incense would then place the incense onto the coals. <b>Rather, the priest who won</b> the privilege <b>of the incense said to the one who was next to him: Be privileged along with me with</b> the task of carrying <b>the coal pan.</b> This shows that each individual service did not have its own lottery; rather, the other priests adjacent to the winner of the lottery were automatically chosen for the ancillary tasks.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>The</b> tasks of carrying the <b>coal pan and</b> burning the <b>incense are different, because</b> together <b>they are</b> considered as <b>a single service,</b> so that a single lottery determined the participants for the two tasks.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that this <i>baraita</i> was brought to derive the opposite conclusion: It was <b>specifically</b> concerning the case of carrying <b>the coal pan and</b> burning <b>the incense, which are</b> considered as two parts of <b>one</b> and the same <b>service,</b> that Rabbi Yehuda said one lottery can be used to assign the two tasks. <b>However,</b> the implication is that <b>other services,</b> which are not interrelated in this manner, <b>require a lottery</b> for each and every separate task. If Rabbi Yehuda had meant this to be a general principle, why did he mention the specific example of the coal pan and the incense?
This argument is rejected: That is not a proof that other services require their own lotteries. The reason Rabbi Yehuda mentioned this specific example is that <b>it was necessary for him</b> to teach explicitly that the coal pan and the burning of the incense do not have separate lotteries but a single, combined lottery. It might <b>have entered your mind to say that since</b> the burning of incense <b>is infrequent,</b> being performed only twice a day, unlike other offerings, which may be donated by private individuals and brought many times a day, <b>and</b> also since <b>it brings about wealth</b> for whoever performs it, as the Gemara teaches later, <b>we should institute a</b> separate <b>lottery for</b> bringing in the coal pan <b>itself,</b> as many priests wished to perform this task. Therefore, Rabbi Yehuda <b>teaches us</b> that despite this, the bringing in of the coal pan does not have its own lottery. Consequently, there is no proof either way from this <i>baraita</i>.
