As it was stated</b> in a case where one has <b>excrement on his flesh or that his hands were</b> placed <b>into a bathroom</b> that <b>Rav Huna said:</b> It is nevertheless <b>permitted to recite <i>Shema</i>. And Rav Ḥisda said:</b> It is <b>prohibited to recite <i>Shema</i></b> in those cases. The Gemara rejects this: The situations are not comparable. There is no dispute that excrement <b>in its place</b> is more severe, as in the anus <b>the filth is great</b> because it is new and malodorous. <b>And</b> if it is <b>not in its place, its filth is not great,</b> as it is dried and less malodorous. It is with regard to that situation that there is an amoraic dispute.
The Gemara proceeds to discuss a related topic. <b>The Sages taught a <i>halakha</i> with regard to a meal</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A person</b> who <b>exits</b> a meal <b>to urinate washes one</b> of <b>his hands,</b> the one that he used to brush off drops of urine, <b>and enters</b> to resume the meal. If one left, <b>spoke with another, and lingered</b> outside, he <b>washes both of his hands and enters</b> to resume the meal. Presumably, during the lengthy conversation he was distracted from maintaining the cleanliness of his hands, requiring him to wash his hands again. <b>And when one washes</b> his hands for the meal he should <b>not wash</b> them <b>outside and then enter, due to</b> the concern that doing so will arouse <b>suspicion</b> that he did not wash his hands. <b>Rather, he enters and sits in his place and washes both his hands, and returns the jug</b> of water <b>to</b> pass among <b>the guests</b> and ask if anyone requires water, to make certain that everyone is aware that he washed his hands.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said: We said</b> this principle with regard to making certain that one washes his hands in public <b>only</b> when he enters <b>to drink; however,</b> if he enters and intends <b>to eat</b> he may even <b>wash</b> his hands <b>outside and enter.</b> Why is this so? It is because <b>it is well known that he is fastidious</b> and would not handle food without cleaning urine and the like off his hands. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: And I</b> can <b>even</b> wash my hands outside when I intend only <b>to drink,</b> because <b>they know that I am fastidious</b> and that I certainly washed my hands before I entered to eat.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A person does not enter the</b> Temple <b>courtyard for the</b> Temple <b>service, even</b> if he is <b>pure, until he immerses. Five immersions and ten sanctifications</b> the <b>High Priest immerses and sanctifies</b> his hands and feet, respectively, <b>on the day</b> of Yom Kippur. <b>And all</b> of these immersions and sanctifications take place <b>in the sacred</b> area, the Temple courtyard, <b>on</b> the roof of the <b>Hall of <i>Parva</i>, except for this</b> first immersion <b>alone.</b> As that immersion is not unique to Yom Kippur, it may be performed outside the courtyard. <b>They spread a sheet of fine linen between him and the people</b> in the interest of modesty, and then the High Priest immersed and <b>sanctified his hands and feet.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>They asked ben Zoma</b> with regard to <b>this immersion: Why</b> is it a requirement for anyone who enters to perform the Temple service? <b>He said to them: Just as one who moves from</b> service in one <b>sacred</b> area <b>to</b> service in another <b>sacred</b> area, i.e., the High Priest on Yom Kippur, who moves from one service to another in the Temple courtyard and the Sanctuary; and likewise one who moves <b>from</b> service in <b>an area that</b> one who enters while impure <b>is punished by <i>karet</i>,</b> the courtyard, <b>to</b> service in another <b>area that</b> one who enters impure <b>is punished by <i>karet</i>,</b> the Sanctuary or the Holy of Holies, <b>requires immersion;</b> so too, with regard to <b>one who moves from a non-sacred</b> area <b>to a sacred</b> area, <b>and from a place that</b> one who enters while impure <b>is not punished by <i>karet</i> to a place that</b> one who enters while impure <b>is punished by <i>karet</i>, is it not right that he require immersion?</b> This first immersion was instituted for purposes of sanctity rather than purity.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says: It is an ancillary immersion,</b> which is not a mitzva, instituted <b>so that one will remember any old impurity that he</b> contracted <b>and withdraw.</b> In the course of immersion, he will remember if he was exposed to a source of seven-day impurity and will refrain from serving in the Temple.
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do</b> ben Zoma and Rabbi Yehuda, who provided two different rationales for the immersion, <b>disagree?</b>

Daf 30b

It is <b>with regard to</b> whether the Temple <b>service is desecrated</b> and disqualified if the priest failed to immerse before its performance that <b>they disagree.</b> According <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>ben Zoma,</b> this immersion is for the purpose of sanctification and is an integral part of the service; consequently, if the priest failed to immerse <b>he desecrates the service.</b> According <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda he does not desecrate</b> the <b>service,</b> because the immersion is merely a precautionary measure.
The Gemara wonders: <b>And</b> according <b>to ben Zoma, is</b> the service <b>desecrated? But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a High Priest who did not immerse and did not sanctify</b> his hands and feet <b>between</b> donning the golden <b>garments and</b> the white linen <b>garments,</b> and similarly, with regard to a High Priest who did not immerse <b>between</b> performance of one <b>service and</b> another <b>service, his service is valid.</b> However, <b>both a High Priest and a common priest who did not sanctify his hands and feet</b> at all <b>in the morning and performed the service, his service is disqualified.</b> If the High Priest’s failure to immerse between services does not desecrate the service, all the more so that failure to perform the first immersion would not desecrate the service, as ben Zoma derives the first immersion from the immersion of the High Priest. Apparently, that is not the basis of their dispute.
<b>Rather,</b> it is with regard <b>to</b> whether one who fails to immerse before service <b>stands in</b> violation of <b>a positive mitzva</b> that <b>they disagree.</b> According <b>to ben Zoma, he stands in</b> violation of a <b>positive mitzva</b> because there is a special requirement to perform this immersion for the purpose of sanctification. According to <b>Rabbi Yehuda, he does not stand in</b> violation of <b>a positive mitzva.</b>
The Gemara wonders: <b>And does Rabbi Yehuda hold</b> in accordance with <b>this</b> line of <b>reasoning? Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A leper</b> on the eighth day of his purification, after he has already immersed at the end of the seventh day, <b>immerses</b> again <b>and stands at the Gate of Nicanor</b> in the Temple to bring his purification offerings and to have the priest sprinkle the blood of the guilt-offering and the oil that accompanies his purification offerings on his thumbs and big toes to complete the purification process. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: He does not require</b> an additional <b>immersion, as he already immersed the</b> previous <b>evening.</b> Apparently, Rabbi Yehuda does not require a special immersion in the morning to remind the leper of old impurity.
The Gemara answers: In <b>that</b> case of the leper, the reason that no immersion is required in the morning is <b>as the reason was taught</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>As he already immersed the</b> previous <b>evening.</b> That immersion purified him and reminded him of any old impurity that he might have. This is in no way connected to the matter of ancillary immersion.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> the one <b>who grasps</b> this <i>baraita</i> as a contradiction to Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion, in <b>what</b> manner <b>does he grasp it?</b> The rationale for the <i>halakha</i> is explicit. The Gemara answers: <b>Because</b> the Gemara <b>wants to raise a contradiction</b> between <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i> and this <i>baraita</i>, and the question will be clarified through combination of the sources. As it was taught: Why was the chamber called <b>the Chamber of the Lepers?</b> It is <b>because the lepers immerse there. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> It was <b>not only lepers</b> that <b>they said</b> immerse there; <b>rather, all people</b> immersed there. Rabbi Yehuda states that lepers and others immersed in this chamber in the Temple, contradicting his statement in the first <i>baraita</i> that a leper does not require immersion in the Temple, as he immersed the evening before.
The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult; this</b> <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where</b> the leper <b>immersed</b> the evening before and need not immerse again; <b>that</b> <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where</b> the leper <b>did not immerse.</b> In that case, there was a special chamber where lepers could immerse. The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> it is a case <b>where</b> the leper <b>did not immerse</b> at all the previous evening, <b>he requires the sun to set</b> after his immersion to be sufficiently purified to enter the Temple. <b>Rather, both this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>and that</b> <i>baraita</i> refer to a case <b>where</b> the leper <b>immersed,</b> but <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> that requires a second immersion is in a case where he <b>was distracted</b> from his efforts to avoid impurity imparted by a corpse; <b>that</b> <i>baraita</i> that does not require a second immersion is in a case where he <b>was not distracted.</b>
The Gemara asks: If he <b>was distracted</b> from his efforts to avoid impurity imparted by a corpse, it is <b>sprinkling</b> of purification waters on <b>the third and the seventh</b> days that <b>he requires,</b> not merely immersion. <b>As Rabbi Dostai bar Matun said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Distraction</b> from efforts to avoid impurity <b>requires sprinkling</b> of purification waters on <b>the third and the seventh</b> days.
<b>Rather, both this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>and that</b> <i>baraita</i> refer to a case <b>where</b> the leper <b>was not distracted, and</b> this is <b>not difficult; this</b> <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where</b> the leper <b>immersed</b> the evening before with <b>the intention of entering the Temple; that</b> <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where</b> the leper <b>did not immerse</b> in the evening with <b>the intention of entering the Temple.</b> In that case, he requires a second immersion for purification even to enter the sacred area. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>Teach</b> the <i>baraita</i> with a slight emendation: It was <b>not lepers</b> that <b>they said</b> immerse there; <b>rather, all people</b> immersed there. Rabbi Yehuda does not qualify the statement of the Rabbis but disputes it. In his opinion, lepers do not require immersion in the morning at all.
In an alternative resolution of the contradiction between the statements of Rabbi Yehuda, <b>Ravina said:</b> In the second <i>baraita</i>, <b>Rabbi Yehuda is stating</b> his opinion <b>to them according to the statement of the Rabbis.</b> His statement does not reflect his opinion. Rather, it is a contention that he raised in the framework of his dispute with the Rabbis. According <b>to my</b> opinion, <b>a leper does not require</b> a second <b>immersion</b> to enter the Temple. However, according <b>to your</b> opinion, <b>concede to me then [<i>izi</i>] that</b> it was <b>not only lepers</b> that <b>they said</b> immerse there; <b>rather, all people</b> immersed there. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis</b> explain their opinion? It answers that there is no comparison: <b>A leper is accustomed to impurity;</b> therefore, he could overlook other impurities that he may have contracted. The immersion reminds him to purify himself for those as well. However, <b>all</b> other <b>people,</b> who <b>are not accustomed to impurity,</b> will certainly be sensitive to and conscious of any impurity that they may have encountered and do not require a special immersion.
<b>Abaye said to Rav Yosef: Let us say</b> that <b>the Rabbis, who disagree</b> with <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> with regard to immersions, <b>hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>ben Zoma,</b> who maintains that this immersion is an obligation by Torah law for anyone entering the courtyard. <b>And</b> the fact <b>that</b> the dispute in the <i>baraita</i> <b>is taught</b> with regard to a <b>leper,</b> contrary to the opinion of ben Zoma, comes <b>to convey the far-reaching</b> nature of the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda</b> that even a leper does not require immersion. <b>Or perhaps</b> fundamentally the Rabbis agree with Rabbi Yehuda; however, the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a leper is different</b> because <b>he is accustomed to impurity,</b> and that is why a second immersion was instituted for him. Rav Yosef <b>said to him: A leper is different</b> because <b>he is accustomed to impurity.</b>
<b>Abaye said to Rav Yosef:</b> According to <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who said</b> the immersion is not an actual obligation but <b>it is an ancillary immersion</b> to remind the individual of old impurity,

Daf 31a

do items that are generally considered interpositions that invalidate an immersion <b>interpose</b> in this immersion, <b>or</b> do they <b>not interpose,</b> since the immersion is only ancillary and serves as a reminder? Rav Yosef <b>said to him: All</b> ordinances <b>that the Sages instituted, they instituted parallel to Torah law.</b> Therefore, this immersion by rabbinic law has the same basic parameters as immersion by Torah law. There may be no interposition.
<b>Abaye said to Rav Yosef:</b> Is <b>partial entry,</b> when one enters a certain place with only part of his body, <b>considered entry or not?</b> Rav Yosef <b>said to him: The thumbs</b> of the leper <b>will prove</b> this point, <b>as</b> the leper reaching his thumbs into the Temple <b>constitutes partial entry, and it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A leper immerses and stands at the Gate of Nicanor,</b> indicating that immersion is required before even partial entry. <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i>; may an impure person <b>craft</b> a very <b>long knife and slaughter</b> an animal in the Temple courtyard while remaining outside the courtyard? Is it the essence of the service that requires immersion, or is it entry into the courtyard that requires immersion?
The Gemara comments: <b>Raise the dilemma</b> according <b>to ben Zoma,</b> who rules stringently with regard to immersion; and <b>raise the dilemma</b> according <b>to the Rabbis who disagree with Rabbi Yehuda</b> and do not obligate all people in this immersion. The Gemara elaborates: <b>Raise the dilemma</b> according <b>to ben Zoma:</b> Does <b>ben Zoma require</b> immersion <b>only for</b> entry <b>inside</b> the courtyard; <b>however, for</b> standing <b>outside</b> the courtyard, <b>no,</b> he does not require immersion? <b>Or perhaps</b> even for one standing outside the courtyard ben Zoma requires immersion, <b>lest he</b> inadvertently <b>come to be drawn</b> inside in the course of his service.
Similarly, <b>raise the dilemma</b> according <b>to the Rabbis, who disagree with Rabbi Yehuda:</b> How so? Do <b>the Rabbis say</b> that there is no requirement of immersion <b>only there, where he is not performing</b> any Temple <b>service; however, here, where he is performing service, no,</b> they would require immersion? <b>Or perhaps there is no difference,</b> and they would not require immersion under any circumstances. The Gemara concludes: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ It was taught in the mishna: <b>Five immersions and ten sanctifications</b> the <b>High Priest immerses</b> and sanctifies his hands and feet, respectively. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Five immersions and ten sanctifications</b> the <b>High Priest immerses and sanctifies</b> his hands and feet, respectively, <b>on the day</b> of Yom Kippur. <b>And all</b> of these immersions and sanctifications take place <b>in the sacred</b> area, the Temple courtyard, <b>in</b> the <b>Hall of <i>Parva</i>, except for</b> this <b>first</b> immersion, <b>which was in the non-sacred</b> area <b>on the roof of Gate of the Water, and</b> that gate <b>was alongside his chamber. Abaye said: Conclude from that</b> which was taught in this <i>baraita</i> that <b><i>Ein Eitam</i>,</b> the spring from which water was supplied to the Temple, was <b>twenty-three cubits higher than the ground of the Temple courtyard.</b>
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>All the entrances that were there</b> in the Temple, <b>their height is twenty cubits and their width is ten cubits, except for</b> the entrance <b>to the Entrance Hall</b> of the Sanctuary, which was twice that, i.e., forty cubits high and twenty cubits wide. <b>And it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that it is stated: <b>“And he shall wash his flesh in water”</b> (Leviticus 15:13), and it is stated in another verse: “And he shall wash all of his flesh in water”(Leviticus 15:16). This refers to water known as <b>the waters of a ritual bath.</b> The verse adds the emphasis: <b>All of his flesh,</b> to say that immersion must be <b>in water that one’s entire body enters</b> at the same time. <b>And how much</b> water <b>is it?</b> It is <b>one cubit</b> length <b>by one cubit</b> width <b>by a height of three cubits.</b> That is sufficient water to cover a person’s height. <b>And the Sages calculated</b> that the volume of <b>the waters of a ritual bath</b> that fit into that space is <b>forty <i>se’a</i>.</b>

Daf 31b

As the gate is twenty cubits high, and the immersion chamber above it is at least three additional cubits high, the water was twenty-three cubits above the ground of the courtyard. The Gemara asks: How could it be only twenty-three cubits higher? <b>Isn’t there the cubit of</b> the thickness of <b>the ceiling</b> over the gate <b>and the cubit of the</b> thickness of the <b>plaster</b> sealing of the ritual bath floor for a total of at least twenty-five cubits? The Gemara answers: With regard to <b>the Temple gates, since they were</b> constructed <b>of marble, they constructed them with minimal</b> thickness. Neither the thickness of the ceiling nor the thickness of the plaster was a cubit. The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t there that minimal</b> thickness of the ceiling and the plaster that would nevertheless total more than twenty-three cubits? The Gemara answers: Indeed; however, <b>since</b> the ceiling <b>was not</b> a whole <b>cubit he does not consider it</b> in his calculation.
§ We learned in the mishna: <b>They spread a sheet of fine linen</b> between the High Priest and the people in the interest of modesty. The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> that they specifically used a sheet <b>of fine linen?</b> The Gemara answers: It is <b>as Rav Kahana said</b> with regard to a related issue: <b>So that he will be aware that the service of the day</b> of Yom Kippur is performed <b>in fine linen garments. Here, too,</b> a linen sheet was used <b>so that he will be aware that the service of the day</b> of Yom Kippur is performed <b>in fine linen garments.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The High Priest <b>removed</b> the white garments that he was wearing, <b>descended</b> to the ritual bath, <b>and immersed. He ascended and dried himself</b> with a towel. Then <b>they brought him</b> the <b>golden garments</b> of the High Priest, <b>and he dressed</b> in the garments, and <b>he sanctified his hands and his feet. They brought him the</b> sheep for <b>the daily</b> morning <b>offering, which he slaughtered</b> by cutting most of the way through the gullet and the windpipe. <b>And a different</b> priest <b>completed</b> the <b>slaughter on his behalf</b> so that the High Priest could receive the blood in a vessel and proceed with the order of the Yom Kippur service. As soon as the slaughter was completed, the High Priest <b>received the blood</b> in a vessel <b>and sprinkled it</b> on the altar.
<b>He entered</b> the Sanctuary <b>to burn the morning incense and to remove</b> the ashes from <b>the lamps</b> of the candelabrum; <b>and</b> he left the Sanctuary and returned to the courtyard <b>to sacrifice the head and the limbs</b> of the sheep sacrificed for the daily offering <b>and the</b> High Priest’s daily <b>griddle-cake</b> offering, <b>and the wine</b> libation of the daily offering. The Mishna comments: <b>The morning incense was burned between</b> the receiving and sprinkling of the <b>blood</b> and the burning <b>of the limbs;</b> and the <b>afternoon</b> incense was burned <b>between</b> the taking of the <b>limbs</b> up to the altar and the pouring of the <b>libations</b> that accompanied the offering.
With regard to the immersion, <b>if the High Priest was old</b> and found it difficult to immerse in cold water, <b>or</b> if he was <b>delicate [<i>istenis</i>], they</b> would <b>heat hot</b> water <b>for him</b> on Yom Kippur eve <b>and place</b> it <b>into the cold</b> water of the ritual bath <b>in order to temper its chill</b> so the High Priest could immerse without discomfort.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages said</b> this matter <b>before Rav Pappa: This</b> mishna is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, as, if</b> it were in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, since he said:</b> The High Priest <b>performs two sanctifications</b> of his hands and his feet <b>upon</b> each <b>change of garments,</b> once before donning the garments and once after donning them, <b>here too,</b> in the mishna, <b>let him perform two sanctifications upon the change of garments.</b> However, the description in the mishna indicates that he removes his garments and does not sanctify his hands and feet.
<b>Rav Pappa said to them: Both</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis and</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> there is <b>one</b> sanctification <b>upon removal</b> of <b>sacred garments, and one</b> sanctification <b>upon donning</b> other sacred garments. <b>And here,</b> it is <b>with regard to this</b> issue that <b>they disagree.</b> It is written: <b>“And he shall remove</b> the linen garments that he put on when he entered the Sanctuary and leave them there. <b>And he shall wash</b> his flesh in water in a sacred place <b>and he shall put on</b> his garments” (Leviticus 16:23–24). <b>Rabbi Meir holds:</b> The Torah <b>juxtaposes removal</b> of garments <b>to donning</b> of garments for the following reason: <b>Just as</b> when <b>donning</b> the garments, <b>he dons the garments and afterward sanctifies</b> his hands and feet, <b>so too,</b> with regard to <b>removal</b> of the garments, <b>he removes</b> the garments <b>and afterward sanctifies</b> his hands and feet.
<b>And the Rabbis hold</b> that the Torah <b>juxtaposes removal</b> of garments <b>to donning</b> of garments for the following reason: <b>Just as</b> when <b>donning</b> the garments, <b>when he is dressed, he sanctifies</b> his hands and feet; <b>so too,</b> for <b>removal</b> of the garments, <b>he sanctifies</b> his hands and feet <b>when he is dressed.</b> Therefore, when he completes the service he sanctifies his hands and feet and only then removes the garments. However, the first time that the High Priest dons the priestly vestments on Yom Kippur he certainly does not require two sanctifications, since at that point he does not remove any other garments.
<b>The Sages said to Rav Pappa: And how can you say that</b> according to Rabbi Meir the first time that the High Priest dons the garments he does not require two sanctifications? <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> as follows? <b>They spread a sheet of fine linen between him and the people, and he removed</b> his garments <b>and descended and immersed,</b> and <b>he ascended and dried himself. They brought him golden garments, and he donned</b> them, <b>and he sanctified his hands and his feet. Rabbi Meir says: He removed</b> his garments <b>and sanctified his hands and his feet and descended and immersed. He ascended and dried himself. They brought him golden garments and he donned</b> them <b>and sanctified his hands and his feet.</b> Apparently, Rabbi Meir maintains that there is a special sanctification prior to donning the garments. <b>He said to them: If it was taught, it was taught.</b> I will retract my opinion, which was based on logical analysis, in favor of an explicit <i>baraita</i> that contradicts that opinion.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> according to the approach of <b>Rabbi Meir, that is how you find</b> that possibility of

Daf 32a

<b>ten sanctifications,</b> as according to his opinion each of the five immersions is accompanied by two sanctifications. <b>However,</b> according to the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> who do not require sanctification before donning the garments for the first time, only <b>nine</b> sanctifications <b>are</b> performed. The Gemara answers that <b>The Rabbis</b> could have <b>said to you:</b> With regard to <b>the final sanctification, when he removes</b> the <b>sacred garments and dons non-sacred garments, he performs it there.</b> According to the Rabbis’ opinion, he sanctifies his hands and his feet when he removes the sacred garments. Rabbi Meir holds that sanctification of his hands and feet is performed only before donning sacred garments.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> the following with regard to the verse: <b>“And Aaron shall come into the Tent of Meeting”</b> (Leviticus 16:23). <b>Why does he come</b> there? He already completed the service in the Sanctuary. <b>He comes only to remove the spoon and the coal pan</b> that he left in the Holy of Holies, <b>as the entire</b> Torah <b>portion</b> in which the Yom Kippur service is discussed <b>was stated in the order</b> in which it is performed in the Temple <b>except for this verse,</b> which should have been written after the sacrifice of the burnt-offering in the following verse. The High Priest does not remove the spoon immediately after he places it in the Holy of Holies. Rather, after placing it there, he emerges and performs certain services outside the Sanctuary and changes his garments again. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that the High Priest interrupts the inner rite of the incense to offer his ram and the people’s ram before removing the spoon and the coal pan?
<b>Rav Ḥisda said: We learned</b> as a tradition that <b>five immersions and ten sanctifications</b> the <b>High Priest immerses and sanctifies</b> his hands and feet, respectively, <b>on the day</b> of Yom Kippur; <b>and if</b> the service is performed in <b>the order</b> that appears in the Torah, <b>you find only three immersions and six sanctifications.</b> The first immersion is before sacrifice of the daily morning offering; the second is between the daily offering and the rest of the service of the day, including the removal of the spoon and the coal pan from the Holy of Holies. The High Priest immerses a third time between removal of the ladle and the coal pan from the Holy of Holies and the sacrifice of his ram and the people’s ram, which were part of the additional offering and the daily afternoon offering that follow. According to the revised sequence, the High Priest performs a service outside the Sanctuary after placing the spoon and the coal pan in the Holy of Holies, and then he reenters the Holy of Holies to remove those vessels. The High Priest immersed and changed his garments both before entering and after exiting the Holy of Holies, for a total of five immersions.
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda said: From where</b> are derived the <b>five immersions and ten sanctifications</b> that the <b>High Priest immerses and sanctifies</b> his hands and feet, respectively, <b>on the day</b> of Yom Kippur? They are derived from <b>the verse</b> that <b>states: “And Aaron shall come into the Tent of Meeting and he shall remove the linen garments</b> that he put on when he entered the Sanctuary and leave them there. <b>And he shall wash his flesh in water in a sacred place and put on his garments, and he shall go out and perform</b> his own burnt-offering and the burnt-offering of the people” (Leviticus 16:23–24). From <b>this you learned: Anyone who moves from</b> an inner <b>service,</b> in the Holy of Holies, <b>to</b> an outer <b>service,</b> and vice versa, <b>requires immersion.</b> According to the order of the services there are a total of five immersions.
<b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: From where</b> are derived the <b>five immersions and ten sanctifications</b> that the <b>High Priest immerses and sanctifies</b> his hands and feet, respectively, <b>on the day</b> of Yom Kippur? They are derived from that <b>which is stated: “He shall be dressed in a sacred linen tunic, and with linen trousers next to his flesh, and he shall be girded with a linen belt, and he shall wear a linen mitre; they are sacred garments, and he shall wash his flesh in water and then put them on”</b> (Leviticus 16:4). From <b>this you learned: Anyone who moves from</b> an inner <b>service,</b> in the Holy of Holies, <b>to</b> an outer <b>service requires immersion. And</b> the verse <b>says: “They are sacred garments”; all of the garments are equated to one another.</b> Just as the High Priest immerses when donning the linen garments, so he immerses when donning the golden garments.
<b>And they are five services:</b> The sacrifice of the <b>daily morning offering,</b> performed <b>in golden garments; the service of the day,</b> the sacrifice of the bull and the goat, which is performed <b>in white garments;</b> the sacrifice of <b>his ram</b> guilt-offering and the <b>ram of the people in golden garments.</b> After that he removes the <b>spoon and</b> the <b>coal pan</b> from the Holy of Holies <b>in white garments.</b> He emerges from the Holy of Holies and sacrifices the <b>daily afternoon offering in golden garments</b>.
<b>And from where</b> is it derived <b>that each and every immersion requires two sanctifications</b> of the hands and the feet? It is derived from <b>the verse</b> that <b>states:</b> “And Aaron shall come into the Tent of Meeting <b>and he shall remove</b> the linen garments that he put on when he entered the Sanctuary and leave them there. <b>And he shall wash</b> his flesh in water” (Leviticus 16:23–24). And it says: <b>“And he shall wash</b> his flesh in water in a sacred place <b>and put on</b> his garments” (Leviticus 16:24). This indicates that one sanctifies his hands and feet when he removes garments, and one likewise sanctifies his hands and feet when he dons garments.
<b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, says</b> that it is derived by means of an <b><i>a fortiori</i> inference: Just as in a place where</b> the Torah <b>does not require immersion,</b> i.e., for a priest before he enters the Temple to perform service, it nevertheless <b>requires sanctification</b> of the hands and feet; <b>in a place where</b> the Torah <b>requires immersion</b> for all changes of garments, i.e., on Yom Kippur, <b>is it not right that it requires sanctification</b> of the hands and feet?
<b>If</b> based on that inference the suggestion arises: <b>Just as there,</b> in the case of a priest entering to perform the Temple service, only <b>one sanctification</b> is required, <b>so too here,</b> on Yom Kippur, only <b>one sanctification</b> should be required for the changes of garments throughout all the services of the day. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And Aaron shall come into the Tent of Meeting and he shall remove the linen garments that he put on”</b> (Leviticus 16:23). <b>What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “That he put on”? Does a person remove</b> any garments <b>other</b> than those <b>that he put on? Rather,</b> this phrase comes <b>to equate removal</b> of garments <b>to donning</b> of garments: <b>Just as donning</b> garments <b>requires sanctification, so too, removal</b> of garments <b>requires sanctification.</b>
The Gemara explains the position of Rabbi Yehuda that was mentioned earlier. <b>Rabbi Yehuda said: From where</b> are derived the <b>five immersions and ten sanctifications</b> that the <b>High Priest immerses and sanctifies</b> his hands and feet, respectively, <b>on the day</b> of Yom Kippur? They are derived from <b>the verse</b> that <b>states: “And Aaron shall come into the Tent of Meeting</b> and he shall remove the linen garments that he put on when he entered the Sanctuary and leave them there. <b>And he shall wash his flesh in water in a sacred place”</b> (Leviticus 16:23–24). From <b>this you learned: Anyone who moves from</b> an inner <b>service,</b> in the Holy of Holies, <b>to</b> an outer <b>service,</b> and vice versa, <b>requires immersion.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> proof that the High Priest requires immersion when he changes <b>from white garments to golden garments;</b> however, <b>from where</b> is it derived that he requires immersion when he changes <b>from golden garments to white garments?</b>

Daf 32b

<b>The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught</b> that it is derived by means of an <b><i>a fortiori</i> inference: Just as</b> before donning <b>golden garments, with which</b> the High <b>Priest does not enter the innermost sanctum,</b> the Holy of Holies, the High Priest <b>requires immersion,</b> before donning <b>white garments, with which</b> the High <b>Priest enters the innermost sanctum, is it not right that</b> the High Priest <b>require immersion?</b> The Gemara asks: The <i>a fortiori</i> inference <b>can be refuted: What</b> is the comparison <b>to golden garments, as</b> the <b>atonement</b> that <b>they</b> effect <b>is extensive?</b> The High Priest serves in the golden garments throughout the year atoning for the sins of the Jewish people; he wears the white garments on just one Yom Kippur. Therefore, it is reasonable that before donning them, the High Priest would require immersion. <b>Rather, it is derived</b> from the verse cited by <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi.
The Gemara analyzes an additional clause from the <i>baraita</i> cited above. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: From where</b> are derived the <b>five immersions and ten sanctifications</b> that the <b>High Priest immerses and sanctifies</b> his hands and feet, respectively, <b>on the day</b> of Yom Kippur? They are derived from <b>the verse</b> that <b>states: “He shall be dressed in a sacred linen tunic</b>, and with linen trousers next to his flesh, and he shall be girded with a linen belt, and he shall wear a linen mitre; they are sacred garments, and he shall wash his flesh in water and then put them on” (Leviticus 16:4). From <b>this you learned: Anyone who moves from</b> an inner <b>service,</b> in the Holy of Holies, <b>to</b> an outer <b>service,</b> and vice versa, <b>requires immersion.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> proof that the High Priest requires immersion when he changes <b>from golden garments to white garments;</b> however, <b>from where</b> is it derived that he requires immersion when he changes <b>from white garments to golden garments?</b>
<b>The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught</b> that it is derived by means of an <b><i>a fortiori</i> inference: Just as</b> before donning <b>white garments,</b> with regard to <b>which</b> the <b>atonement</b> that <b>they</b> effect <b>is minimal</b> as the priest wears them only on one Yom Kippur, <b>immersion is required,</b> before donning <b>golden garments,</b> with regard to <b>which</b> the <b>atonement</b> that <b>they</b> effect <b>is extensive</b> throughout the year, <b>is it not right that immersion should be required?</b>
The Gemara asks: The <i>a fortiori</i> inference <b>can be refuted: What</b> is the comparison <b>to white garments, as he enters with them to the innermost sanctum?</b> As the High Priest does not enter the Holy of Holies with the golden garments, apparently the sanctity of the white garments is greater. The Gemara comments: The source for the requirement to immerse when changing from white garments to golden garments <b>is that which is taught</b> later in the <i>baraita</i>: The verse <b>states: “They are sacred garments, and he shall wash his flesh in water and then put them on”</b> (Leviticus 16:4), meaning immersion is required before donning all sacred garments.
<b>And they are five services:</b> The sacrifice of the <b>daily morning offering,</b> performed <b>in golden garments; the service of the day,</b> the bull and the goat, which is performed <b>in white garments;</b> the sacrifice of <b>his ram</b> guilt-offering and the <b>ram of the people,</b> performed <b>in golden garments.</b> After that the High Priest places the <b>spoon and the coal pan</b> into the Holy of Holies <b>in white garments.</b> He emerges from the Holy of Holies and sacrifices the <b>daily afternoon offering in golden garments</b> and then removes the spoon and the coal pan in white garments.
<b>And from where</b> is it derived <b>that each and every immersion requires two sanctifications</b> of the hands and the feet? It is derived from <b>the verse</b> that <b>states:</b> “And Aaron shall come into the Tent of Meeting <b>and he shall remove</b> the linen garments that he put on when he entered the Sanctuary and leave them there. <b>And he shall wash</b> his flesh in water” (Leviticus 16:23–24). And it says: <b>“And he shall wash</b> his flesh in water in a sacred place <b>and put on</b> his garments” (Leviticus 16:24). The Gemara asks: <b>That is written</b> with regard <b>to immersion.</b> The washing mentioned in this verse is not sanctification of the hands and feet but rather immersion. The Gemara answers: <b>If it is not a matter</b> relating <b>to immersion, which is derived from</b> the phrase: <b>“They are sacred garments”</b> (Leviticus 16:4), indicating that every change of clothes requires immersion, then <b>render it a matter</b> relating <b>to sanctification.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And let the Merciful One write</b> the obligation <b>in</b> the <b>language of sanctification</b> of the hands and feet rather than the language of immersion. The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> language comes to <b>teach us that</b> in this case, the legal status of <b>immersion is like</b> that of <b>sanctification. Just as sanctification</b> of the hands and feet is performed <b>in a sacred area,</b> as the basin used for sanctification is situated in the courtyard, <b>so too,</b> the <b>immersion</b> before donning garments must be performed <b>in a sacred area,</b> not outside the Temple.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who derives immersion before donning the golden garments from this verse and does not derive anything from the phrase: They are sacred garments, <b>from where does he</b> derive the obligation to perform <b>sanctification</b> of the hands and feet? The Gemara answers: <b>He derives it</b> as an <i>a fortiori</i> inference <b>from</b> the inference of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon:</b> In a place that the Torah does not require immersion it nevertheless requires sanctification of the hands and feet; therefore, in a place that the Torah requires immersion for all changes of garments, is it not right that it requires sanctification of the hands and feet?
<b>Rav Ḥisda said: That</b> statement of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi with regard to immersion and sanctification <b>is</b> an original opinion <b>to the exclusion of</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir</b> with regard to sanctification, <b>and to the exclusion of</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis. It is to the exclusion of</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, as the Rabbis said</b> that <b>he sanctifies</b> his hands and feet when <b>he is dressed, and</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: He sanctifies</b> them <b>when he undresses. And it is to the exclusion of</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, as Rabbi Meir said:</b> With regard to <b>this last sanctification</b> that he performs after each immersion, <b>he sanctifies</b> his hands and feet <b>when he is dressed. And</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: He sanctifies</b> them <b>when he undresses.</b>
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: Everyone agrees with regard to the second sanctification that one dresses, and afterward sanctifies</b> his hands and feet. <b>What</b> is <b>the reason</b> for this? It is <b>as the verse states: “Or when they approach the altar</b> to serve, to burn an offering by fire to God, they shall wash their hands and feet so that they do not die” (Exodus 30:20–21). This teaches that the priest who is obligated to sanctify his hands and feet is one who is <b>lacking only</b> the element of <b>approach</b> to the altar to begin performing the service, to the <b>exclusion of that</b> priest who has not yet donned the priestly vestments, <b>who is lacking</b> both the element of <b>donning</b> priestly vestments and the element of <b>approach</b> to the altar. Sanctification of the hands and feet prior to the service is performed when he is already dressed.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son</b> of <b>Rava, said to Rav Ashi: Neither does Rav Ḥisda,</b> who said that according to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi the priest performs the two sanctifications before donning the garments, <b>agree with Rav Aḥa,</b> who said that according to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi the sanctification is done after donning the garments; <b>nor does Rav Aḥa,</b> who said that according to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi the sanctification must be performed directly prior to the service, <b>agree with Rav Ḥisda,</b> who said that according to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi the two sanctifications are performed before donning the garments. <b>As, if</b> they <b>do</b> agree, according <b>to Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>there are fifteen sanctifications.</b> For each change of garments he would require three sanctifications: One when he undresses, one prior to dressing, and one after he is dressed.
§ It was taught in the mishna: <b>They brought him the</b> sheep for <b>the daily</b> morning <b>offering, which he slaughtered [<i>keratzo</i>].</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of <b><i>keratzo</i>? Ulla said: It is a term</b> meaning <b>killing. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: What is the verse</b> that indicates this meaning? It is stated: <b>“Egypt is a very fair heifer, but the <i>keretz</i> out of north is come, it is come”</b> (Jeremiah 46:20). The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> may it be <b>inferred</b> that <i>keretz</i> means killing? The Gemara explains: It is <b>as translated by Rav Yosef: Egypt is a fair kingdom, but murderous nations will come upon it from the north.</b> The Gemara asks: When he <b>slaughtered</b> the sheep, <b>to what extent</b> did he do so? <b>Ulla said:</b> He slaughtered the animal <b>with</b> a cut through <b>the majority of</b> each of the <b>two</b> organs, the windpipe and the gullet, which is sufficient to render the animal ritually slaughtered.
<b>And similarly, Rav Yoḥanan said: With the majority of</b> each of the <b>two</b> organs. <b>And Reish Lakish also held: With the majority of</b> each of the <b>two</b> organs. This is indeed Reish Lakish’s opinion, <b>as Reish Lakish said: Once we learned</b> in the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual slaughter that <b>the majority of one</b> organ is <b>like the whole, why was</b> it necessary that <b>we</b> also <b>learn</b> there that in order for the slaughter to be valid it requires <b>the majority of one</b> organ <b>in a bird and the majority</b> of each of <b>two</b> organs <b>in an animal?</b> That is clear based on the principle that one organ is required in a bird and two in an animal. Rather, <b>since we learned: They brought him the</b> sheep for <b>the daily</b> morning <b>offering, which he slaughtered</b> by cutting most of the way through the gullet and the windpipe, <b>and a different</b> priest <b>completed</b> the <b>slaughter on his behalf</b> so that the High Priest could receive the blood in a vessel, and the High Priest <b>received the blood</b> in a vessel <b>and sprinkled it</b> on the altar; one <b>might</b> have thought that if the other priest <b>did not complete</b> cutting through the two organs, the slaughter <b>would be invalid.</b>
The Gemara asks: How is it possible that one <b>might</b> have thought that if the other priest <b>did not complete</b> cutting through the two organs, the slaughter <b>would be invalid? If</b> that is <b>so,</b> the completion of the slaughter <b>is</b> a Temple <b>service</b> performed by <b>another</b> on Yom Kippur. <b>And it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>All Yom Kippur services are valid only</b> if performed <b>by</b> the High Priest. The Gemara answers that <b>this is what</b> Reish Lakish <b>is saying:</b> Clearly, there is no requirement by Torah law to complete the slaughter of the two organs. One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>it would be invalid by rabbinic law;</b>

Daf 33a

<b>therefore, we learned</b> again: <b>The majority of one</b> organ <b>in a bird and the majority</b> of each of <b>two</b> organs <b>in an animal,</b> to teach that slaughtering the majority of each of the signs is sufficient. The Gemara asks: <b>And since there is not even an invalidation by rabbinic law, why do I</b> need another priest <b>to finish</b> cutting the organs? Why not suffice with the High Priest’s slaughter of the majority of each of the two organs? The Gemara answers: It is nevertheless a <b>mitzva to complete</b> the slaughter <i>ab initio</i> to cause the blood to flow more freely.
§ <b>Abaye arranged the sequence</b> of the daily services in the Temple <b>based on tradition and in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Abba Shaul:</b> Setting up the <b>large arrangement</b> of wood on the altar on which the offerings were burned <b>precedes</b> the <b>second arrangement</b> of wood. This second arrangement was arranged separately near the southwest corner of the altar, and twice every day priests raked coals from it and placed them on the inner altar in order to burn the <b>incense.</b> The <b>second arrangement for</b> the <b>incense precedes setting up</b> the <b>two logs of wood</b> above the large arrangement to fulfill the mitzva of bringing wood. <b>And</b> the <b>setting up of</b> the <b>two logs of wood precedes the removal of ashes</b> from <b>the inner altar. And the removal of ashes</b> from <b>the inner altar precedes the removal of ashes from five</b> of the seven <b>lamps</b> of the candelabrum.
<b>And removal of ashes from five lamps precedes</b> the slaughter and the receiving and sprinkling of the <b>blood of the daily</b> morning <b>offering.</b> The sprinkling of the <b>blood of the daily offering precedes the removal of ashes from</b> the <b>two</b> remaining <b>lamps</b> of the candelabrum. <b>And the removal of ashes from two lamps precedes</b> the burning of the <b>incense.</b> The burning of the <b>incense</b> on the inner altar <b>precedes</b> the burning of the <b>limbs</b> of the daily offering on the outer altar. The burning of the <b>limbs</b> precedes the sacrifice of the <b>meal-offering</b> which accompanies the daily offering. The sacrifice of the <b>meal-offering</b> precedes the sacrifice of the High Priest’s daily <b>griddle-cake</b> offering, half of which he sacrificed in the morning and half in the afternoon. <b>And the griddle-cake</b> offering precedes the pouring of the <b>libations</b> of the daily offering.
<b>And</b> the <b>libations</b> precede the sacrifice of the <b>additional offerings</b> on days when the additional offerings are sacrificed. <b>And</b> the <b>additional offerings</b> precede the <b>vessels</b> of frankincense that are offered on Shabbat. <b>And</b> the <b>vessels</b> precede the sacrifice of the <b>daily afternoon offering, as it is stated:</b> “And he shall lay out the burnt-offering on it, <b>and burn on it the fat parts of</b> the <b>peace-offerings”</b> (Leviticus 6:5). The term <b>on it,</b> means <b>complete</b> sacrifice of <b>all other offerings,</b> i.e., after the daily morning offering rather than after the daily afternoon offering. In all cases, the daily afternoon offering is the final offering sacrificed.
The Gemara proceeds to analyze the items listed by Abaye and seeks biblical or logical sources for each. <b>The Master said:</b> Setting up <b>the large arrangement</b> of wood on the altar on which the offerings were burned <b>precedes the second arrangement</b> of wood <b>for incense.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> do <b>we</b> derive this? The Gemara answers: <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “The burnt-offering <b>itself shall go up on its bonfire upon the altar all night”</b> (Leviticus 6:2); <b>this is</b> referring to the <b>large arrangement</b> of wood. <b>“And the fire of the altar shall be kept burning on it”</b> (Leviticus 6:2); <b>this is</b> referring to the <b>second arrangement</b> of wood near the corner of the altar, from which coals are taken for the <b>incense.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> perhaps <b>I should reverse</b> them and say that the first verse refers to the arrangement of wood for the incense, and the second verse refers to the large arrangement of wood. The Gemara answers: It is <b>reasonable</b> that the <b>large arrangement</b> of wood takes <b>precedence, as</b> the <b>atonement</b> that <b>it</b> effects <b>is extensive.</b> All of the offerings are sacrificed on the large pile, not just the incense.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>On the contrary,</b> the <b>second arrangement</b> takes <b>precedence, as</b> unlike the large arrangement in which offerings are burned exclusively on the outer altar, coals <b>from it are taken inside</b> the Sanctuary. The Gemara answers: <b>Even so,</b> the contention that the <b>atonement</b> that <b>it</b> effects <b>is extensive</b> takes <b>precedence. And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>If one does not find wood for the second arrangement, wouldn’t he take</b> coals <b>from the large arrangement into</b> the Sanctuary to burn the incense? There is no fundamental obligation to bring coals from a special arrangement, and the second arrangement is only an addition to the large arrangement on which all the offerings are burned.
Abaye continued and said that the <b>second arrangement for incense precedes the setting up of the two logs.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> do <b>we</b> derive this? <b>As it is written: “And the priest shall burn wood upon it in the morning, in the morning”</b> (Leviticus 6:5); there is an obligation to place new logs upon the large arrangement. The term <b>upon it</b> underscores that the wood is placed only on the large arrangement, <b>and not on the other</b> arrangement from which coals are taken for the incense. From the fact that this exclusionary term is necessary, it can be derived <b>by inference</b> that there <b>is another</b> pile on the altar, meaning that when the new logs are placed on the altar, the two arrangements are already there.
The Gemara asks: <b>But this</b> term: <b>Upon it, is needed for its own sake,</b> to teach the obligation to place the logs on the altar; therefore, how can the timing of their placement be derived from that term? The Gemara answers: The term: <b>Upon it, is written twice</b> in that verse: “And the priest shall burn wood upon it in the morning, in the morning, and he shall place the burnt-offering upon it.” From one instance of this term the fundamental obligation to place the logs is derived, and from the other instance the order of their placement is derived.
Abaye continued: <b>The setting up of the two logs precedes the removal of ashes</b> from <b>the inner altar. Although here,</b> with regard to the two logs, <b>it is written: In the morning, in the morning,</b> meaning that the priest must arise early in the morning to perform this act, <b>and here,</b> with regard to removal of the ashes from the inner altar, <b>it is</b> also <b>written: “In the morning, in the morning”</b> (Exodus 30:7), <b>even so,</b> an action that <b>facilitates</b> another service takes <b>precedence.</b> Therefore, setting up the logs, from which coals are taken, facilitating the burning of the incense, precedes removal of ashes from the inner altar. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the act that <b>facilitates?</b> It is the placement of the <b>two logs. But didn’t you say</b> that <b>the two logs go to the large arrangement</b> of wood and not to the arrangement of wood from which the coals are taken for the incense? These logs in no way facilitate the burning of the incense.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said:</b> The reference is to the <b>category of wood.</b> Although these logs do not facilitate the burning of the incense, wood facilitates its burning, and the two logs are wood. Therefore, they take precedence. <b>Ravina said</b> a different reason: <b>Since he began</b> with the service of setting up the <b>arrangement, he completes it</b> by placing two logs. Only then he moves on to perform a different service. <b>Rav Ashi said: If one does not find wood for the second arrangement, won’t he take</b> coals <b>from the large arrangement into</b> the Sanctuary to burn the incense? This demonstrates that there are circumstances in which placing the logs facilitates the burning of the incense. Therefore, it takes precedence.
Abaye continued: <b>And removal of ashes</b> from <b>the inner altar precedes the removal of ashes from five</b> of the seven <b>lamps</b> of the candelabrum. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>Abaye said: I learned</b> this <b>through tradition;</b> however, <b>I do not know the rationale</b> behind it. <b>And Rava said:</b> The reason is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Reish Lakish, as Reish Lakish said: One may not forego</b> performance <b>of</b> any of <b>the mitzvot</b> in order to perform another mitzva.

Daf 33b

<b>And when</b> he <b>enters the Sanctuary</b> it is <b>the altar</b> that <b>he encounters first,</b> before reaching the candelabrum; therefore, he performs the service of the altar before removing the ashes from the lamps, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The <b>table</b> stood <b>in the north</b> of the Sanctuary, <b>removed two and a half cubits from the wall. And</b> the <b>candelabrum</b> stood <b>in the south</b> of the Sanctuary, <b>removed two and a half cubits from the wall. The altar was centered and standing in the middle</b> of the Sanctuary, <b>removed a bit outward.</b> Therefore, one encounters the altar first. The Gemara questions the essence of the matter: <b>And let us stand</b> the altar <b>alongside</b> the table and the candelabrum; why was it removed outward? The Gemara answers: It is <b>because it is written: “And the candelabrum opposite the table”</b> (Exodus 26:35); <b>we require that they are visible to each other.</b> Were the altar aligned with the table and the candelabrum, it would interpose between them.
<b>Rava said: Conclude from</b> the statement <b>of Reish Lakish</b> that one may not forego performance of any of the mitzvot, that it is <b>prohibited to forego</b> donning the phylacteries <b>of the arm</b> in order to don the <b>phylacteries</b> of the head, as when donning phylacteries, one encounters the arm first. <b>How does he conduct</b> himself? He proceeds <b>from</b> the phylacteries <b>of the arm</b> to the <b>phylacteries</b> of the head.
§ Abaye continued: <b>And removal of ashes from five lamps precedes</b> the slaughter and the receiving and sprinkling of the <b>blood</b> of <b>the daily</b> morning <b>offering.</b> The sprinkling of <b>the blood of the daily offering precedes the removal of ashes from</b> the <b>two</b> remaining <b>lamps</b> of the candelabrum. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>Abaye said:</b> Take <b>that</b> phrase: <b>In the morning, in the morning,</b> written with regard to <b>the two logs, which is unnecessary</b> to establish the time for performance of that service, as its precedence was explained due to its association with the arrangement of wood. And <b>cast</b> that extraneous phrase <b>to here,</b> and apply it to other elements of the morning service. If the phrase is superfluous in its context, apply it elsewhere where a <i>halakha</i> can be derived. <b>Cast one</b> term: In the morning, and apply it <b>to removal of ashes from five lamps</b> so <b>that it</b> will <b>precede the blood of the daily offering. And cast one</b> term: In the morning, and apply it <b>to the blood of the daily offering,</b> so <b>that it</b> will <b>precede the removal of ashes from</b> the <b>two</b> additional <b>lamps.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Cast one</b> term: In the morning, and apply it <b>to removal of ashes from five lamps</b> so <b>that it</b> will <b>precede the blood of the daily offering, as here,</b> there are <b>three</b> instances of: In the morning; two instances are written explicitly with regard to removal of ashes from the lamps (see Exodus 30:7) and one is written with regard to the two logs. <b>And here,</b> with regard to the blood of the daily offering, there are <b>two</b> instances of the phrase; one explicit mention in the text (see Exodus 29:39) and one written with regard to the two logs.
<b>And cast one</b> term: In the morning, <b>to the blood of the daily offering</b> so <b>that it</b> will <b>precede the removal of ashes from</b> the <b>two</b> additional <b>lamps. Although here,</b> with regard to removal of ashes from the lamps, there are <b>two</b> instances of the phrase: In the morning, <b>and here,</b> with regard to the blood of the daily offering, there are <b>two</b> instances of the phrase: In the morning, one written and one cast from the portion of two logs, the blood of the daily offering takes precedence because an act that <b>effects atonement,</b> the sprinkling of blood, takes <b>precedence.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said to Abaye: And say</b> instead, <b>cast one</b> of the extraneous phrases: In the morning, and apply it <b>to</b> the <b>removal of ashes</b> from <b>the inner altar,</b> so <b>that it</b> will <b>precede the blood of the daily offering, as here</b> there are <b>three</b> instances of the phrase <b>and there</b> there are <b>two. And cast one</b> of the extraneous phrases: In the morning, and apply it <b>to the blood of the daily offering</b> so <b>that it</b> will <b>precede the removal of ashes from five lamps,</b> and say that <b>although here</b> there are <b>two</b> instances of the phrase: In the morning, <b>and here</b> there are <b>two</b> instances of the phrase: In the morning, still an act that <b>effects atonement,</b> the sprinkling of blood, takes <b>precedence.</b> Abaye dismisses this question by saying: <b>If</b> the blood of the daily offering precedes the removal of ashes from five lamps, <b>with what will you demarcate</b> between the removal of ashes from five lamps and the removal of ashes from two lamps?
<b>That</b> works out <b>well</b> according to the opinion of <b>Reish Lakish,</b> who <b>said: Why does</b> the priest <b>remove the ashes from</b> five lamps of the candelabrum <b>and</b> then <b>return and remove the ashes from</b> two lamps of the candelabrum rather than arrange all seven lamps at once? It is <b>in order to enliven</b> those present in the <b>entire</b> Temple <b>courtyard,</b> since people are coming and going to fulfill this mitzva with great ceremony. It works out <b>well</b> according to the opinion of Reish Lakish, because he says there is no need for any other service to demarcate between removal of ashes from five lamps and removal of ashes from two.
<b>However,</b> according to <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan, who said</b> the following based on the verse: “And Aaron shall burn upon it incense of sweet spices; in the morning, in the morning, when he removes the ashes from the lamps” (Exodus 30:7); take the term <b>in the morning, in the morning,</b> and <b>divide</b> the service of removal of ashes from the lamps <b>into two mornings,</b> i.e., into two parts, by performing a service in between, <b>what can be said?</b> According to Rabbi Yoḥanan, since the result would be that there is no service demarcating between the five lamps and the two lamps, there is no alternative to interpreting the matter in accordance with the explanation of Abaye.
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi</b> with regard to the basis for Abaye’s argument: <b>Is this</b> term: <b>In the morning, in the morning,</b> written with regard to the two <b>logs</b> actually <b>superfluous</b> and therefore available to have other matters derived from it? <b>Isn’t it necessary</b> to teach <b>its own</b> basic <i>halakha</i>, <b>as the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah: <b>Have it precede the second arrangement</b> of wood, from which coals are taken <b>for the incense?</b> Rav Ashi <b>said to him: And did we not establish</b> that it is written: <b>Upon it,</b> underscoring the fact that wood is placed only on the large arrangement <b>and not on the other</b> arrangement from which coals are taken for the incense? From the fact that this exclusionary term is necessary, it can be derived <b>by inference</b> that there <b>is another</b> pile on the altar, meaning that when the new logs are placed on the altar, the two arrangements are already there.
The Gemara asks with regard to the sequence in which the priest removes the ashes from the lamps: <b>What is different that he performs the removal of ashes from five lamps first? Let us perform the removal of ashes from two lamps first.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Since he begins</b> the service <b>with them, he performs</b> the service on <b>a majority of the</b> lamps. The Gemara asks: If so, <b>let him perform</b> the service on <b>six</b> lamps. The Gemara responds that <b>the verse states: “When he removes the ashes from the lamps, he shall burn it”</b> (Exodus 30:7), <b>and lamps is</b> plural, meaning <b>no fewer than two.</b> Apparently, removal of ashes from lamps must be performed on a minimum of two lamps.
Abaye continued: <b>And the removal of ashes from two lamps precedes</b> the burning of the <b>incense, as the verse</b> first <b>states: “When he removes the ashes from the lamps,” and then</b> states: <b>“He shall burn it.”</b> The removal of the ashes precedes the burning of the incense.
Abaye continued: <b>And</b> the burning of the <b>incense</b> on the inner altar <b>precedes</b> the burning of the <b>limbs</b> of the daily offering on the outer altar, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Let the matter with regard to which it is stated: In the morning, in the morning,</b> i.e., the burning of the incense, <b>precede the matter with regard to which only one: In the morning, is stated,</b> i.e., the daily morning offering, in the verse: “You shall offer one lamb in the morning” (Exodus 29:39).
Abaye continued: The burning of <b>the limbs</b> precedes the sacrifice of the <b>meal-offering</b> that accompanies the daily offering, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that there</b> may <b>be no item</b> placed on the arrangement of wood <b>prior to the daily morning offering?</b>

Daf 34a

<b>The verse states:</b> “And the priest shall burn wood upon it in the morning, in the morning, <b>and he shall place the burnt-offering upon it”</b> (Leviticus 6:5), <b>and Rava said:</b> The verse could have simply said: And he shall place upon it, indicating that everything sacrificed on the altar is placed upon it; but instead, the verse states: “And he shall place <b>the burnt-offering</b> upon it,” to teach that <b>it ascends</b> the altar <b>first.</b>
Abaye continued: The sacrifice of the <b>meal-offering</b> precedes the sacrifice of the High Priest’s daily <b>griddle-cake</b> offering, half of which he sacrifices in the morning and half in the afternoon, as the verse states: “To bring offerings by fire to the Lord, burnt-offerings, meal-offerings, sacrifices, and libations, on each day what is proper to it” (Leviticus 23:37). Since the Torah states <b>burnt-offerings and meal-offerings,</b> apparently the daily burnt-offering precedes the meal-offering. And since the meal-offering is part of the burnt-offering sacrifice, it precedes the griddle-cake offering, which is a meal-offering unrelated to the burnt-offering.
Abaye continued: <b>And the griddle-cake</b> offering precedes the pouring of the <b>libations</b> of the daily offering. This is because it is in the <b>category</b> of <b>meal-offering.</b> Since it has been established that the meal-offering that accompanies the daily offering is sacrificed after the daily offering, all meal-offerings are sacrificed after the daily-offering prior to any other service.
Abaye continued: <b>And</b> the <b>libations</b> precede the sacrifice of the <b>additional offerings,</b> as it is written: <b>Offerings and libations,</b> from which it is derived that the libations are brought immediately after the daily offering, before any other offering is sacrificed. <b>And the additional offerings</b> precede <b>the vessels</b> of frankincense that are brought on Shabbat. The Gemara asks: <b>But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The vessels</b> of frankincense <b>precede the additional offerings?</b> The Gemara answers: This <b>is</b> the subject of a dispute between the <b><i>tanna’im</i></b> Rabbi Yishmael and Rabbi Akiva (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 58a).
<b>Abaye said:</b> It is <b>reasonable</b> that the sequence should be <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the one who said the additional offerings</b> precede <b>the vessels</b> of frankincense, as <b>didn’t you say</b> that the repetition of the term: <b>In the morning, in the morning,</b> comes <b>to prioritize</b> the daily offering? <b>Here too,</b> repetition within the clause: “He shall arrange them <b>on</b> Shabbat <b>day, on</b> Shabbat <b>day”</b> (Leviticus 24:8), with regard to the vessels of frankincense, comes to <b>postpone</b> that service until the peak of the day.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the rationale</b> for the opinion <b>of the one who said:</b> The <b>vessels</b> of frankincense <b>precede the additional offerings?</b> The Gemara explains: By means of a verbal analogy <b>he derives: Statute,</b> written with regard to the vessels of frankincense: “A statute for all time” (Leviticus 24:9), <b>from: Statute,</b> written with regard to the <b>griddle-cake</b> offering: “A statute for all time” (Leviticus 6:15). Just as the griddle-cake offering precedes the additional offerings, so too, the vessels of frankincense precede the additional offerings.
The Gemara asks: <b>If he derived it from there, let him derive the entire matter from there,</b> and let the vessels of frankincense be burned immediately after the griddle-cake offering; why are the libations offered between them? The Gemara answers: It is <b>to that</b> end that the verse: “He shall arrange them <b>on</b> Shabbat <b>day, on</b> Shabbat <b>day,”</b> with regard to the vessels of frankincense, <b>is effective, to postpone</b> their offering until later.
§ After analyzing Abaye’s tradition with regard to the sequence of the daily service, the Gemara returns to analyzing the passage in the mishna: <b>The morning incense was burned between</b> the receiving and sprinkling of the <b>blood</b> and the burning <b>of the limbs.</b> The Gemara asks: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is the mishna? <b>If</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> elsewhere (15a), the mishna <b>should</b> say that the incense was burned <b>between</b> the sprinkling of the <b>blood and</b> the removal of the ashes from the <b>lamps. If</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Abba Shaul,</b> the mishna <b>should</b> say that the incense was burned <b>between</b> the removal of the ashes from the <b>lamps and</b> the burning <b>of</b> the <b>limbs.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>Actually,</b> the mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, but</b> the mishna <b>is not speaking of the sequence</b> of the entire service. The mishna states that the incense was burned between the sprinkling of the blood and the burning of the limbs of the daily offering, although other services were performed then as well, including the removal of ashes from the lamps.
The mishna continues: The <b>afternoon</b> incense was burned <b>between</b> the taking of the <b>limbs</b> up to the altar and the pouring of its <b>libations.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that the <b>verse states:</b> “And the other lamb you shall present in the afternoon, <b>as the meal-offering in the morning and its libation, you shall present it,</b> an offering made by fire, of a sweet fragrance unto the Lord” (Numbers 28:8). <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>the morning meal-offering incense precedes libations, so too here,</b> in the afternoon, <b>incense precedes the libations.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> so, <b>just as there,</b> in the morning, <b>incense</b> even <b>precedes limbs, so too here,</b> in the afternoon, <b>incense</b> should <b>precede limbs.</b> The Gemara rejects this: <b>Is it written: As the limbs in the morning? As the meal-offering in the morning, is written,</b> indicating with regard to the daily afternoon offering that it is <b>like the meal-offering in the morning, and not like the</b> burning of the <b>limbs of the morning.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that it is written: <b>“And its libation shall be a quarter-<i>hin</i></b> for the one lamb, in the sacred area it shall be poured as an offering of strong drink unto the Lord” (Numbers 28:7). The Sages understand this verse as referring to the daily afternoon offering; therefore, <b>one will derive</b> the manner and order <b>of</b> the daily <b>morning</b> offering <b>from</b> the manner and order <b>of</b> the daily <b>afternoon</b> offering. Just as libations are required for the daily afternoon offering, so too, they are required for the daily morning offering.

Daf 34b

<b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> The daily <b>afternoon</b> offering is derived <b>from that of the morning.</b> The phrase: “The one lamb,” refers to the lamb of the daily morning offering, and the daily afternoon offering is derived from it.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> according to the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> who hold that <b>this</b> verse <b>is written</b> with regard to the daily <b>afternoon</b> offering based on the preceding verses, they can explain that the daily morning offering is derived from the daily afternoon offering. <b>However, what is the rationale</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, who holds that the afternoon offering is derived from the morning offering? <b>Rabba bar Ulla said</b> that <b>the verse states: “For the one lamb.” Which is the lamb with regard to which it is</b> previously <b>stated: One? You must say: That is</b> the lamb of the <b>daily morning offering</b> (see Exodus 29:39).
<b>And</b> according to <b>the Rabbis, what</b> is the meaning of the term: <b>One?</b> It means the <b>special</b> lamb <b>that is</b> one <b>in his flock.</b> The lamb for the daily offering should be of the highest quality. <br><b>And</b> from where does <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi derive that principle? The Gemara answers that in his opinion, the principle <b>is derived</b> from that which is written: “And <b>all the choicest of your</b> vow-offerings” (Deuteronomy 12:11). One is required to fulfill his vow by offering the animal of the highest quality. <br><b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis</b> interpret this verse? They interpret that <b>one</b> verse refers to the requirement to bring the animal of the highest quality for <b>obligatory</b> offerings and <b>one</b> verse refers to the requirement to bring the animal of the highest quality for gift-offerings. <b>And</b> both verses are <b>necessary,</b> as otherwise it would not have been clear that this requirement applies to both. On the one hand, one might think it is only with regard to obligatory offerings that the animal of the highest quality must be sacrificed. On the other hand, one might think it is only with regard to a gift-offering that the animal of the highest quality must be sacrificed, as if it is not of the highest quality, it is better not to sacrifice it at all.
§ The mishna continues: <b>If the High Priest was old or delicate,</b> they would heat hot water for him on Yom Kippur eve and place it into the cold water of the ritual bath in order to temper its chill. <b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda said: They would heat blocks of iron on Yom Kippur eve and cast them into the cold</b> water of the ritual bath <b>to temper its chill.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> by doing so, <b>doesn’t he harden</b> the iron, which is a labor prohibited on Yom Kippur? <b>Rav Beivai said:</b> The temperature of the blocks of iron <b>did not reach</b> the <b>hardening</b> point. <b>Abaye said: Even</b> if <b>you say that</b> the temperature of the iron <b>reached</b> the <b>hardening</b> point, the fact that the iron hardened when he placed it in the water is <b>an unintentional act,</b> which is <b>permitted.</b> His intention was to temper the chill of the water, not to harden the iron.
<b>And did Abaye</b> actually <b>say that</b> an unintentional act is permitted? <b>But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that it is written: “And on the eighth day the <b>flesh of his foreskin</b> shall be circumcised<b>”</b> (Leviticus 12:3), from which it is derived that <b>one</b> may <b>cut</b> the foreskin and circumcise the baby <b>even if there is a white spot</b> of leprosy <b>there?</b> He may do so even though the Torah prohibits excising a white spot of leprosy. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yoshiya. And we discussed</b> this matter: <b>Why do I</b> need <b>a verse</b> to permit it? His intention is not to excise the leprosy but to fulfill the mitzva of circumcision. <b>And Abaye said:</b> The statement of Rabbi Yoshiya is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who <b>said</b> that performing <b>an unintentional act is prohibited.</b> Therefore, a special verse is necessary to permit circumcision in that case. Apparently, Abaye holds that Rabbi Yehuda prohibits even unintentional acts. Why, then, does he explain that Rabbi Yehuda permits placing blocks of iron into the water if his intention is not to harden the iron?
The Gemara answers: When Abaye said that Rabbi Yehuda prohibits unintentional acts, <b>that applies only to</b> actions prohibited by Torah law that appear in <b>the whole Torah in its entirety. However, here, hardening</b> the blocks of iron is not a labor prohibited by Torah law but is prohibited <b>by rabbinic law,</b> as a decree intended to enhance the character of Shabbat as a day of rest. Rabbi Yehuda concedes that unintentional performance of prohibitions by rabbinic law is permitted.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>They brought</b> the High Priest to immerse a second time in the <b>Hall of <i>Parva</i>,</b> which <b>was in the sacred</b> area, the Temple courtyard. <b>They spread a sheet of fine linen between him and the people</b> in the interest of modesty. <b>And he sanctified his hands and his feet and removed</b> his garments. <b>Rabbi Meir says</b> that this was the sequence: He first <b>removed</b> his garments and then <b>he sanctified his hands and his feet. He descended and immersed</b> a second time. <b>He ascended and dried himself.</b> And <b>they</b> immediately <b>brought him</b> the <b>white garments,</b> in which <b>he dressed, and he sanctified his hands and his feet.</b>
<b>In the morning he would wear</b> linen garments <b>from</b> the Egyptian city of <b>Pelusium worth twelve <i>maneh</i>,</b> 1,200 dinars or <i>zuz</i>. These garments were very expensive due to their high quality. And <b>in the afternoon</b> he wore linen garments <b>from India,</b> which were slightly less expensive, <b>worth eight hundred <i>zuz</i>.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: In the morning he would wear</b> garments <b>worth eighteen <i>maneh</i>, and in the afternoon</b> he would wear garments <b>worth twelve <i>maneh</i>.</b> In <b>total,</b> the clothes were worth <b>thirty <i>maneh</i>. These</b> sums for the garments came <b>from the community, and if</b> the High Priest <b>wished to add</b> money to purchase even finer garments, <b>he</b> would <b>add</b> funding of his own.

Daf 35a

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>What is</b> the meaning of the name <b><i>Parva</i>? Rav Yosef said: <i>Parva</i></b> is the name of a Persian <b>sorcerer,</b> whose name is associated with the chamber due to a particular incident.
§ It was stated in the mishna: <b>They spread</b> there <b>a sheet of fine linen.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> that the sheet that they spread was made of <b>fine linen? Rav Kahana said:</b> It was <b>so that</b> the High Priest <b>will be aware</b> and remember <b>that the service of the day</b> is performed <b>in fine linen.</b>
§ The mishna continues: <b>In the morning, he would wear</b> garments <b>worth eighteen</b> <i>maneh</i>, and in the afternoon he would wear garments worth twelve <i>maneh</i>. In total, the clothes were worth thirty <i>maneh</i>. The Gemara expresses surprise at the total in the mishna: <b>Does the <i>tanna</i> come to tell us the tally</b> that eighteen and twelve equal thirty? The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> comes to <b>teach us that</b> one may <b>not fashion</b> garments worth <b>less than</b> the total of <b>these</b> morning and afternoon garments. The Gemara elaborates: <b>If one decreases</b> the value <b>of these</b> morning garments, and <b>raises</b> the value <b>of those</b> afternoon garments, <b>we have no</b> problem <b>with it.</b> One can distribute the total of thirty <i>maneh</i> between the two sets of garments in any manner that he chooses.
The Gemara comments: <b>However, everyone,</b> both Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis, <b>agrees that</b> the clothes of the <b>morning are superior</b> and must be more valuable than those of the afternoon. <b>From where do we</b> derive this? <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Ilai, said</b> that with regard to the linen garments donned by the High Priest in the morning, <b>the verse states:</b> “He shall be dressed in a sacred <b>linen</b> tunic, and with <b>linen</b> trousers next to his flesh, and he shall be girded with a <b>linen</b> belt, and he shall wear <b>a linen</b> mitre” (Leviticus 16:4). From the fact that the verse repeats the term linen four times it is derived that the <b>choicest linen</b> should be used for this purpose.

Daf 35b

<b>The Gemara raises an objection.</b> It is stated: “And it shall be that when they enter in at the gates of the inner court, they shall be clothed with linen garments; and no wool shall come upon them, while they minister in the gates of the inner court, and within” (Ezekiel 44:17). This verse is referring to the Yom Kippur service, as during the year the High Priest performed the service in eight priestly vestments made partially of wool.
