<b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that a prohibition exists <b>during the burning</b> of the incense; <b>from where</b> do I derive that the prohibition applies also <b>during the presentations of the</b> bull’s <b>blood</b> in the Holy of Holies? <b>The verse states: “When he goes in to make atonement,”</b> and atonement is achieved through the presentations of blood. <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that a prohibition exists from the time of <b>his entrance</b> into the Holy of Holies; <b>from where</b> is it derived that the prohibition remains in force until <b>his exit? The verse states: “Until he comes out.”</b>
The <i>baraita</i> concludes by expounding the final part of the verse: <b>“And have made atonement for himself, and for his household, and for all the assembly of Israel”</b> (Leviticus 16:17). This teaches that <b>his atonement precedes the atonement of his household; the atonement of his household precedes that atonement of his brethren, the priests; the atonement of his brethren, the priests, precedes the atonement of the entire community of Israel.</b>
The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i>: <b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that a prohibition exists <b>during the burning</b> of the incense. From <b>where</b> in the verse could this have <b>been inferred? Rava said, and similarly Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Avdimi said, and similarly Rabbi Elazar said:</b> The conclusion of that <b>verse states: “And have made atonement for himself, and for his household, and for all the assembly of Israel.” Which</b> act of <b>atonement is the same for him, and for his household, and for his brethren, the priests, and for the entire community of Israel? You must say this is the burning of the incense.</b>
Does <b>incense effect atonement?</b> The Torah mentions the concept of atonement only with regard to offerings. <b>Yes, as Rabbi Ḥananya teaches</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>We learned of the incense that it effects atonement,</b> as <b>it is stated: “And he put on the incense and made atonement for the people”</b> (Numbers 17:12). <b>And the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: For what does incense effect atonement? For slander.</b> And why is that? <b>Let something that</b> is done <b>in secret,</b> i.e., the incense, which is burned in seclusion within the Sanctuary, <b>come and effect atonement for an act done in secret,</b> i.e., slander, which is generally said in private.
<b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there: They remove</b> themselves <b>from</b> the area <b>between the Entrance Hall and the altar during the burning</b> of the incense. <b>Rabbi Elazar said: They taught</b> that this is true <b>only during the burning</b> of the incense <b>of the Sanctuary, but during the burning</b> of the incense <b>in the innermost</b> chamber, i.e., the Holy of Holies, people are required to <b>remove</b> themselves only <b>from the Sanctuary. They do not need to remove themselves</b> from the area <b>between the Entrance Hall and the altar.</b>
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava raised an objection</b> to Rabbi Elazar’s opinion from a <i>baraita</i>, <b>and some say it unattributed: Rabbi Yosei says: Just as they remove</b> themselves <b>from</b> the area <b>between the Entrance Hall and the altar during the burning</b> of the incense, <b>they similarly remove</b> themselves <b>during the</b> blood <b>presentations of the bull of the anointed priest,</b> i.e., of the High Priest, which he brings if he issues an erroneous halakhic ruling and acts upon it; and also during the blood presentations <b>of the bull for an unwitting</b> communal <b>sin</b> brought if the Sanhedrin issues an erroneous halakhic ruling and the community acts upon it; and also during the blood presentations <b>of the goats of idol worship</b> brought for an inadvertent communal transgression of idol worship.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: If so, <b>what higher standard is</b> applicable <b>to the Sanctuary relative to</b> the area <b>between the Entrance Hall and the altar? Only that</b> those <b>in the Sanctuary remove</b> themselves <b>both during the</b> incense <b>burning and also</b> during the blood presentations, which is <b>not during the</b> incense <b>burning.</b> Those who are in the area <b>between the Entrance Hall and the altar remove</b> themselves <b>only during the</b> incense <b>burning</b> but not during the blood presentations.
The Gemara explains the challenge: <b>In any case,</b> it is evident from the <i>baraita</i> that <b>during the</b> incense <b>burning they do remove</b> themselves. <b>What, is it not</b> referring to <b>during the burning</b> of the incense <b>of the innermost</b> chamber, i.e., the Holy of Holies? This would contradict Rabbi Elazar’s opinion.
The Gemara defends his opinion: <b>No,</b> it is referring to <b>during the burning of the</b> incense <b>of the Sanctuary.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> how can the <i>baraita</i> say: <b>What higher standard</b> is applicable to the Sanctuary? This implies that it is superior only with respect to one higher standard. <b>Are there not more? Surely, there is this higher standard, that whereas</b> the people <b>in the Sanctuary remove</b> themselves <b>both during its own,</b> i.e., the Sanctuary’s, incense <b>burning and during the</b> incense <b>burning of the innermost</b> chamber, i.e., the Holy of Holies, <b>but in</b> the area <b>between the Entrance Hall and the altar they remove</b> themselves <b>only during the burning</b> of the incense <b>of the Sanctuary.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>This is</b> in fact what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is teaching:</b> It is teaching <b>only that</b> those <b>in the Sanctuary remove</b> themselves <b>both during the burning</b> of the incense <b>and also</b> during the blood presentations, which is <b>not during the burning</b> of the incense; <b>from</b> the area <b>between the Entrance Hall and the altar they do not remove</b> themselves,

Daf 44b

<b>except during</b> the <b>burning</b> of the incense.
<b>But there is</b> also <b>this higher standard, that whereas from the Sanctuary they remove</b> themselves <b>both during its own sanctification,</b> i.e., the blood presentations in the Sanctuary, <b>and during the sanctification of the innermost</b> chamber, i.e., the Holy of Holies, <b>but from</b> the area <b>between the Entrance Hall and the altar, they remove</b> themselves <b>only during the sanctification of the Sanctuary. Rava said:</b> Indeed, there are numerous distinctions, but the <i>baraita</i> teaches only one because all the distinctions fit into <b>one category of removal.</b>
The Gemara continues to analyze the <i>baraita</i>: <b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: Just as they remove themselves from the area between the Entrance Hall and the altar during the burning of the incense, <b>they similarly remove</b> themselves <b>during the</b> blood <b>presentations of the bull of the anointed priest; of the bull for an unwitting</b> communal <b>sin; and of the goats of idol worship. From where do we</b> derive this? <b>Rabbi Pedat said:</b> It is derived by a verbal analogy between the word <b>atonement</b> said in connection with those offerings and the word <b>atonement from</b> the prohibition on <b>Yom Kippur.</b>
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Ahava said: Learn from this</b> that there is a prohibition in the area between the Entrance Hall and the altar. The <b>higher standards</b> applied to the various areas in the Temple are defined <b>by Torah law, and</b> the Sages <b>learned them</b> as a tradition.
<b>As if it could enter your mind</b> that these standards are defined <b>by rabbinic law, what is different</b> about the area <b>between the Entrance Hall and the altar</b> that the prohibition applies only there? <b>Perhaps</b> other priests would accidentally <b>happen to enter</b> the Sanctuary while incense is burning there. But if that is the reason, then the rabbinic decree should require that <b>they remove</b> themselves <b>also from the entire Temple courtyard,</b> since <b>perhaps they</b> would accidentally <b>happen to enter.</b> The fact that the prohibition does not extend to the Temple courtyard suggests that the standards are defined by Torah law.
The Gemara rejects Rav Aḥa bar Ahava’s reasoning: The prohibition could indeed be rabbinic. Nevertheless, it is reasonable to limit it to the area <b>between the Entrance Hall and the altar,</b> as follows: <b>Since there is nothing that separates it</b> from the Sanctuary, the distinction between the two areas <b>is not conspicuous,</b> and therefore people may err and enter. But with regard to the <b>Temple courtyard, since there is the outer altar that separates</b> the rest of the Temple courtyard from the Sanctuary, the distinction between the areas <b>is conspicuous,</b> and therefore there is no need to extend the prohibition throughout the Temple courtyard.
<b>Rava said: Learn from this</b> fact that there is a rabbinic prohibition in the area between the Entrance Hall and the altar. <b>The sanctity of the Entrance Hall</b> and the sanctity of the <b>Sanctuary is one matter,</b> i.e., there they share the same sanctity, and therefore the Torah prohibition applies to the Entrance Hall as well. <b>For if it could enter your mind</b> to say that <b>these</b> areas <b>have two</b> distinct levels <b>of sanctity,</b> it would emerge that the prohibition to be in the <b>Entrance Hall is itself</b> a rabbinic <b>decree. But will we arise and issue</b> one <b>decree to</b> prevent violation of another <b>decree</b> by prohibiting being present in the area between the Entrance Hall and the altar, lest one enter the Entrance Hall itself?
The Gemara rejects Rava’s reasoning: <b>No,</b> this would not be a case of issuing one decree to prevent violation of another decree, because <b>the Entrance Hall and the</b> area <b>between the Entrance Hall and the altar</b> share <b>one sanctity.</b> Consequently, any prohibition applied to one will certainly also apply to the other. However, <b>the Sanctuary and the Entrance Hall have two</b> distinct <b>sanctities.</b>
§ The mishna states: <b>On every</b> other <b>day,</b> a priest <b>would scoop up</b> the coals with a coal pan made <b>of silver and pour</b> the coals from there <b>into</b> a coal pan <b>of gold.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> the gold pan was not used to scoop the coals? The Gemara answers: Because <b>the Torah spared the money of the Jewish people.</b> Since the pan is worn away with use, it is preferable to use a less expensive silver pan.
§ The mishna continues: <b>But</b> on <b>this day,</b> on Yom Kippur, the High Priest <b>scoops up with</b> a coal pan <b>of gold, and with</b> that coal pan, <b>he would bring</b> the coals <b>into</b> the Holy of Holies. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that on Yom Kippur only one pan is used? <b>Due to the weakness</b> of the <b>High Priest.</b> He has to perform the entire service by himself while fasting; using only one pan minimizes his exertion.
§ The mishna states: <b>On every</b> other <b>day,</b> a priest scoops up the coals with a coal pan <b>of four <i>kav</i></b> and pours the coals into a coal pan of three <i>kav</i>. Rabbi Yosei says: On every other day, a priest scoops with a coal pan of a <i>se’a</i>, which is six <i>kav</i>, and then pours the coals into a coal pan of three <i>kav</i>. <b>It was taught</b> in a mishna (<i>Tamid</i> 33a): As he poured from a pan of four <i>kav</i> to a pan of three <i>kav</i>, <b>a <i>kav</i> of coals became scattered, and he swept them into the canal</b> that passed through the Temple and ran to the Kidron brook.
It <b>was taught</b> in <b>one</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>A <i>kav</i></b> of coals was scattered. <b>And it was taught in another</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>Two <i>kav</i></b> were scattered. The Gemara comments: <b>Granted, this</b> <i>baraita</i>, which <b>teaches that</b> a single <b><i>kav</i></b> was scattered, is understandable. It is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> the first <i>tanna</i> of the mishna, who maintain that coals are poured from a coal pan of four <i>kav</i> to one of three. <b>But that</b> <i>baraita</i>, which <b>teaches</b> that <b>two <i>kav</i></b> of coals were scattered, in accordance <b>with whose</b> opinion is it? <b>It is not</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis and not</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei.</b> According to Rabbi Yosei, three <i>kav</i> of coals would have been scattered.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said: It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, says: With</b> a coal pan <b>of two <i>kav</i> he would bring</b> the coals <b>into</b> the Holy of Holies. If one accepts the opinion of the Rabbis that the coals were scooped with a coal pan of four <i>kav</i>, two <i>kav</i> were scattered.
<b>Rav Ashi said: You can even say</b> that this <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, and this is what he is saying: On every</b> other <b>day,</b> a priest <b>scooped with</b> a coal pan <b>of a desert <i>se’a</i>, which</b> is five Jerusalem <i>kav</i>, <b>and</b> then <b>he poured</b> the coals <b>into a coal pan of three Jerusalem <i>kav</i>.</b> Therefore, two <i>kav</i> would be scattered.
§ The mishna states: <b>On every</b> other <b>day,</b> the coal pan <b>was heavy, but</b> on <b>this day</b> it was <b>light. It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>On every</b> other <b>day its side was thick but</b> on <b>this day</b> it was <b>soft</b> and thin. <b>On every</b> other <b>day</b> its handle <b>was short but</b> on <b>this day it was long. What is the reason? So that the arm of the High Priest could assist him</b> in carrying the coal pan, i.e., he could support the coal pan by resting it against his arm rather than bear the entire weight in his hand.
It was <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>On every</b> other <b>day it did not have a ring, but</b> on <b>this day it has a ring</b> on the end of the handle, which clatters against it and makes a noise in fulfillment of the verse “And the sound thereof shall be heard when he goes in to the Sanctuary” (Exodus 28:35); this is <b>the statement of the son of the Deputy.</b>
§ The mishna states: <b>On every</b> other <b>day, it was</b> of <b>greenish gold</b> but on this day it was of a red gold. <b>Rav Ḥisda said: There are seven</b> types <b>of gold</b> mentioned in the Bible: <b>Gold, and good gold, and gold of Ophir</b> (I Kings 10:11), <b>and glistering gold</b> (I Kings 10:18), <b>and <i>shaḥut</i> gold</b> (I Kings 10:17), <b>and closed gold</b> (I Kings 10:21), <b>and <i>parvayim</i> gold</b> (II Chronicles 3:6). The Gemara explains the reason for these names: There is a distinction between <b>gold and good gold, as it is written</b> in the verse: <b>“And the gold of that land is good”</b> (Genesis 2:12), which indicates the existence of gold of a higher quality. <b>Gold of Ophir</b> is gold <b>that comes from Ophir. Glistering [<i>mufaz</i>] gold</b> is so named

Daf 45a

<b>because it resembles the luster of pearls [<i>paz</i>]</b> in the way it glistens. <b><i>Shaḥut</i> gold</b> is named as such <b>because</b> it is very malleable and <b>is spun like thread [<i>shenitve keḥut</i>].</b> <i>Shaḥut</i> is a contraction of the words <i>shenitve keḥut</i>. <b>Closed gold</b> is so called <b>because when</b> a shop <b>opens</b> to sell it, <b>all the</b> other <b>shops close,</b> as no one is interested in purchasing any other type of gold. <b><i>Parvayim</i> gold</b> is so called <b>because</b> its redness <b>resembles the blood of bulls [<i>parim</i>].</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said: There are</b> in fact only <b>five</b> types of gold, the last five in Rav Ḥisda’s list. Gold and good gold are not independent categories; rather, <b>each and every one</b> of the types of gold has two varieties: Regular <b>gold and</b> a superior variety called <b>good gold. That was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to <i>parvayim</i> gold: <b>On every</b> other <b>day</b> the coal pan was made <b>of greenish gold, but</b> on <b>this day</b> it was made of <b>a red</b> gold, <b>and this is the <i>parvayim</i> gold which resembles the blood of bulls.</b>
§ The mishna states: <b>On every</b> other <b>day,</b> a priest <b>sacrificed a <i>peras</i>,</b> half of a <i>maneh</i>, of incense <b>in the morning,</b> and a <i>peras</i> in the afternoon, but on this day the High Priest adds an additional handful of incense and burns it in the Holy of Holies. <b>On every</b> other <b>day,</b> the incense <b>was</b> ground <b>fine</b> as prescribed by the Torah, <b>but</b> on <b>this day it was superfine. The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the incense on Yom Kippur that it is <b>“finely ground</b> aromatic incense” (Leviticus 16:12). <b>What</b> does the <b>verse</b> mean to <b>teach</b> by this? <b>Has it not already been stated: “And you shall grind some of it finely”</b> (Exodus 30:36)? <b>Rather, it teaches</b> that on Yom Kippur the incense has to be <b>superfine.</b>
§ The mishna states: <b>On every</b> other <b>day, priests ascend on the eastern side of the ramp.</b> A <i>baraita</i> explains the reason for this: <b>As the Master said: All the turns that you turn should be only to the right,</b> which, after ascending the altar, means one will turn <b>to the east</b> and will mean one will circulate the altar in a counter-clockwise fashion. When they descended, they again turned to the right, which is to the west of the ramp.
§ The mishna continues: <b>But</b> on <b>this day</b> the priests <b>ascend in the middle</b> of the ramp <b>and descend in the middle. What is the reason? Due to the eminence</b> of the <b>High Priest</b> he should not walk on the side but in the middle.
§ We learned in the mishna that <b>every</b> other <b>day the High Priest sanctifies his hands and his feet from the laver</b> like the other priests, and on this day he sanctifies them from the golden flask. <b>What is the reason? Due to the eminence</b> of the <b>High Priest.</b>
§ The mishna states: <b>On every</b> other <b>day, there were four arrangements</b> of wood <b>there,</b> upon the altar, but on this day there were five. <b>The Sages taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>On every</b> other <b>day there were two arrangements</b> of wood on the altar, <b>but</b> on <b>this day</b> there were <b>three: One,</b> the <b>large arrangement; and one,</b> the <b>second arrangement</b> for coals <b>for the incense; and one,</b> the additional arrangement of wood, <b>which they add on that day</b> for the incense that is burned in the Holy of Holies. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei says: On every</b> other <b>day</b> there were <b>three</b> arrangements, <b>but</b> on <b>this day</b> there were <b>four: One, the large arrangement; and one,</b> the <b>second arrangement for the incense; and one, for the upkeep of the fire,</b> so that if the fire of the large arrangement begins to die down, wood from this arrangement may be added to it to raise the flames; <b>and one,</b> the additional arrangement of wood <b>that they add on that day</b> for the incense that is burned in the Holy of Holies.
<b>Rabbi Meir says: On every</b> other <b>day there were four</b> arrangements of wood on the altar <b>but</b> on <b>this day</b> there were <b>five: One,</b> the <b>large arrangement; and one,</b> the <b>second arrangement for the incense; and one, for the upkeep of the fire;</b> and <b>one, for</b> burning <b>the limbs and fats that were not</b> fully <b>consumed</b> on the altar <b>the</b> previous <b>evening; and one,</b> the additional arrangement of wood <b>that they add on that day</b> for the incense that is burned in the Holy of Holies.
The Gemara analyzes the different opinions: <b>At any rate, everyone has</b> at least <b>two</b> arrangements in their calculations. <b>From where do we</b> derive this? <b>The verse states: “It is the burnt-offering on the flame on the altar all night”</b> (Leviticus 6:2); <b>this</b> is referring to <b>the large arrangement.</b> It states further: <b>“And the fire of the altar shall be kept burning thereby”</b> (Leviticus 6:2), <b>this</b> additional mention of a fire is referring to <b>the second arrangement,</b> which is <b>for the incense. And from where does Rabbi Yosei</b> learn about the additional arrangement <b>for the upkeep of the fire? He derives it</b> from the verse: <b>“And the fire upon the altar shall be kept burning thereby”</b> (Leviticus 6:5), which mentions fire for the third time.
<b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who holds that normally there are only two arrangements, explain this third mention of a fire? <b>That</b> additional mention <b>comes to</b> teach about <b>the kindling</b> of the <b>thin wood chips,</b> which were used to ignite the fires on the altar, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda would say: From where</b> is it derived <b>that the kindling of the wood chips should</b> be done <b>only at the top of the altar,</b> rather than setting them alight at the bottom of the altar and carrying them up? <b>The verse states: “And the fire upon the altar shall be kept burning thereby”</b> (Leviticus 6:5), which indicates that the fire that is brought there has to be lit on the altar itself. <b>Rabbi Yosei said: From where</b> is it derived <b>that an arrangement for the upkeep of the fire is made? The verse states: “And the fire upon the altar shall be kept burning thereby”</b> (Leviticus 6:5).
<b>And from where</b> does <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> derive that the <b>kindling of the wood chips</b> should be at the top of the altar? <b>He derives it from the</b> same <b>place</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon derives it. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“And the sons of Aaron the priest shall put fire upon the altar”</b> (Leviticus 1:7), which <b>teaches about the kindling of</b> the <b>wood chips that it may be</b> done <b>only by a fit priest and</b> one who is robed <b>in</b> the priestly <b>vestments of service;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Shimon said to him:</b> There is no need for a verse to teach that a priest must kindle the chips, <b>for could it enter your mind that a non-priest could approach the altar? Rather,</b> this verse <b>teaches</b> about the <b>kindling of the wood chips, that they may be lit only at the top of the altar.</b>
<b>And</b> what would <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> respond to Rabbi Shimon’s reasoning? <b>If</b> this <i>halakha</i> was derived <b>from there, I would have said</b> a non-priest could light the fire on the altar by <b>standing on the ground</b> below <b>and using a bellows</b> to fan the flames on the top of the altar. Therefore, this verse <b>teaches us</b> that in all circumstances the person kindling the fire must be a priest.
<b>And from where does Rabbi Meir</b> learn about an additional arrangement for the <b>limbs and the fats that were not</b> fully <b>consumed</b> on the altar <b>the</b> previous <b>evening? He derives it</b> from the phrase <b>“and the fire.”</b> The apparently superfluous word “and” alludes to the existence of an additional arrangement. <b>And the Rabbis,</b> i.e., Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Yehuda, who disagree, <b>do not expound</b> the word <b>“and.”</b>
<b>And</b> according to <b>the Rabbis, what do they do with the limbs and the fats that were not</b> fully <b>consumed</b> on the altar <b>the</b> previous <b>evening?</b> Where are they burned? A priest <b>returns them to the large arrangement,</b> where the process of their burning is completed. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived that <b>for limbs and fats that were not</b> fully <b>consumed</b> on the altar <b>the</b> previous <b>evening,</b>

Daf 45b

<b>that they are arranged upon the altar, and if</b> the space on the altar <b>cannot hold them, that they are arranged upon the ramp or upon the ledge</b> that protrudes from the altar, <b>until the large arrangement is made</b> the following day <b>and</b> then <b>they are arranged</b> upon it? <b>The verse states: “That which the fire will consume of the burnt-offering, on the altar”</b> (Leviticus 6:3). This is taken to mean that those items that the fire already consumed are once again placed upon the altar.
<b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Meir</b> expound this verse? He derives from it that if <b>parts of a burnt-offering</b> that were already partially <b>consumed</b> on the altar fell off the altar, <b>you should return them</b> to continue burning; <b>but you do not return incense</b> that was <b>consumed</b> and fell off of the inner incense altar. <b>As Rabbi Ḥananya bar Minyomi from the school of Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“That which the fire will consume of the burnt-offering on the altar”</b> (Leviticus 6:3). This teaches that if <b>parts of a burnt-offering</b> that were partially <b>consumed</b> fell off the altar, <b>you should return them; but you do not return incense</b> that was partially <b>consumed</b> and fell off the altar.
<b>At any rate, everyone</b> assumes there is an additional arrangement of wood <b>that they add on that day,</b> i.e., Yom Kippur, for the incense that is burned in the Holy of Holies. <b>From where</b> do <b>they</b> derive this? <b>They derive it</b> from the verse <b>“And the fire</b> upon the altar” (Leviticus 6:5). The apparently superfluous words “and the” allude to an additional fire. <b>And even one who does not</b> generally <b>expound</b> the word <b>“and” does expound</b> the phrase <b>“and the.”</b>
The Gemara notes that there is an additional mention of the altar fire, which has not yet been explained: The phrase <b>“a perpetual fire”</b>(Leviticus 6:6), <b>for what</b> <i>halakha</i> does it <b>come</b> to teach? <b>It is required for</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>that was taught</b> in the following <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“A perpetual fire shall be kept burning on the altar, it shall not go out”</b> (Leviticus 6:6). This <b>teaches about the second arrangement</b> of wood to produce coals <b>for</b> the <b>incense, that it is</b> set up <b>only on the outer altar.</b>
<b>From where</b> is it derived that coals of <b>fire</b> that are taken with <b>a coal pan</b> for the incense on Yom Kippur <b>and</b> for the fire <b>for</b> lighting <b>the candelabrum</b> must also be from the outer altar? <b>It is a logical derivation. “Fire” is stated with regard to the</b> daily <b>incense</b> offering, <b>and “fire” is stated with regard to the</b> incense <b>coal pan and the candelabrum. Just as there,</b> in the case of the daily incense offering, the fire is taken from <b>upon the outer altar, so too</b> here, in the case of the incense coal pan and the candelabrum, the fire should be taken from <b>upon the outer altar.</b>
If the matter is derived through reasoning, it is also possible to posit an alternative argument: <b>Or,</b> alternatively, one could <b>go this way. “Fire” is stated with regard to the</b> daily <b>incense</b> offering, <b>and “fire” is stated with regard to the</b> incense <b>coal pan and the candelabrum. Just as there,</b> in the case of the daily incense offering, the fire is taken from a place <b>near to it,</b> i.e., the outer altar, <b>so too,</b> in the case of the incense <b>coal pan and the candelabrum,</b> the fire should be taken from a place <b>near to it,</b> i.e., the inner altar.
Since there are two equally logical derivations, a verse is required to teach the <i>halakha</i>. <b>The verse states: “A perpetual fire shall be kept burning on the altar, it shall not go out”</b> (Leviticus 6:6). The <b>“perpetual fire” that I told you,</b> i.e., the fire of the candelabrum, about which the Torah states “a lamp to burn continually” (Exodus 27:20), <b>should</b> be lit <b>only</b> from a fire that is <b>upon the top of the outer altar.</b>
<b>We</b> have therefore <b>learned</b> the source for the <b>fire for</b> the <b>candelabrum. From where</b> do we derive the same <i>halakha</i> for the <b>fire for the</b> incense <b>coal pan</b> on Yom Kippur? <b>It is a logical derivation. “Fire” is stated with regard to</b> the incense <b>coal pan</b> on Yom Kippur, <b>and “fire” is stated with regard to</b> the <b>candelabrum. Just as there,</b> in the case of the candelabrum, the fire is taken from <b>upon the outer altar, so too, here,</b> in the case of the incense coal pan, the fire should be taken from <b>upon the outer altar.</b>
If the matter is derived through reasoning, it is also possible to posit an alternative argument: <b>Or,</b> alternatively, one could <b>go this way: “Fire” is stated with regard to the</b> daily <b>incense</b> offering, <b>and “fire” is stated with regard to the</b> incense <b>coal pan</b> on Yom Kippur. <b>Just as there,</b> in the case of the daily incense offering, the fire is taken from a place <b>near to it,</b> i.e., the outer altar, <b>so too, here,</b> in the case of fire for the incense coal pan, the fire should be taken from a place <b>near to it,</b> i.e., the inner altar.
Since there are two equally logical derivations, a verse is required to teach the <i>halakha</i>: <b>The verse states: “And he shall take a pan full of coals of fire from upon the altar from before the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 16:12). The description of the altar being “from before the Lord” suggests it is not entirely before the Lord. <b>Which altar</b> is only <b>partially before the Lord, but not all of it is before the Lord,</b> i.e., part of it lies directly parallel to the Sanctuary, but part of it does not? <b>You must say</b> that <b>this is the outer altar.</b> Only the western side of it lies parallel to the entrance to the Sanctuary. In contrast, the inner altar is entirely within the Sanctuary and so is considered entirely before the Lord.
<b>And it is necessary to write “from upon the altar” and it is necessary to write “from before God” because if the Merciful One had written</b> only <b>“from upon the altar” I would have said: What altar</b> is the verse referring to? The <b>inner altar.</b> Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes “from before God.” And if the Merciful One had written</b> only <b>“from before God,” I would have said</b> it means <b>specifically from</b> the part of the altar that lies <b>before God,</b> i.e., from the northwestern corner, which lies directly parallel to the entrance of the Sanctuary;

Daf 46a

<b>but from this side or from that side</b> of the altar, both of which are not directly in front of the Sanctuary’s entrance, I would <b>say</b> that <b>no,</b> the fire may not be taken from there. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> to write both terms in order to teach this <i>halakha</i>.
<b>Rabbi Elazar said in the name of bar Kappara: Rabbi Meir would say:</b> With regard to <b>limbs of a burnt-offering that remained</b> on the altar from the previous night and which were not fully consumed, <b>one should make a separate arrangement</b> of wood <b>for them and arrange them</b> upon it to be burned. <b>And</b> this is done <b>even on Shabbat.</b>
<b>What is</b> bar Kappara <b>teaching us</b> when he informs us that Rabbi Meir requires a separate arrangement to be made? Surely, <b>we</b> already <b>learned</b> this in the mishna that cites Rabbi Meir as saying: <b>On every</b> other <b>day, there were four arrangements</b> of wood <b>there,</b> upon the altar. The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Avin said:</b> Bar Kappara’s teaching <b>is needed only</b> in order to teach the requirement to set up a fourth arrangement, even though it is only for limbs of <b>disqualified</b> offerings. As certain disqualifications apply only <i>ab initio</i>, if the offering is nevertheless brought upon the altar it should not then be removed. Bar Kappara teaches that Rabbi Meir’s ruling applies in the event that limbs of such an offering were not fully consumed.
The Gemara qualifies this: <b>But</b> this applies <b>specifically</b> when <b>the fire has</b> already <b>taken hold of them</b> and they have begun to burn. <b>But</b> if <b>the fire</b> has not yet <b>taken hold of them, no,</b> a separate arrangement is not made in order to burn them.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> a different version of this qualification: <b>Both</b> with regard to the limbs of <b>valid</b> offerings <b>and</b> of <b>disqualified</b> offerings, <b>if the fire has</b> already <b>taken hold of them</b> and they have begun to burn, <b>yes,</b> a separate arrangement is made to burn them, <b>but if</b> the fire did not take hold of them, <b>no,</b> a separate arrangement is not made in order to burn them.
Bar Kappara concluded: <b>And</b> this is done <b>even on Shabbat.</b> But surely, <b>we</b> already <b>learned</b> this in the mishna that cites Rabbi Meir as saying: <b>But</b> on <b>this day,</b> on Yom Kippur, there are <b>five.</b> This means that the arrangement for burning any remaining limbs is made also on Yom Kippur, despite the fact that all the Shabbat prohibitions apply.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said:</b> Nevertheless, bar Kappara’s teaching <b>is necessary,</b> for <b>it could enter your mind to say</b> that <b>this applies</b> only <b>when Yom Kippur occurs after Shabbat,</b> i.e., on Sunday. Perhaps only in such a case is a separate arrangement made, based on the accepted law <b>that</b> leftover <b>fats of Shabbat</b> offerings <b>are sacrificed</b> and burned <b>on Yom Kippur. However,</b> if Yom Kippur occurs <b>in the middle of the week,</b> then perhaps <b>no,</b> a separate arrangement is not made in order to burn them. Therefore, bar Kappara <b>teaches us</b> that Rabbi Meir’s ruling applies in all cases.
<b>Rava said: Who is this that does not care about his flour,</b> i.e., he does not truly care about what he says and speaks imprecisely? <b>Did we</b> not <b>learn</b> in the mishna: <b>On every</b> other <b>day.</b> This clearly implies that Rabbi Meir’s ruling applies equally to all days of the week. As such, Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov’s justification for bar Kappara’s teaching is already implied in Rabbi Meir’s words in the mishna. The Gemara comments: Indeed, it is <b>difficult.</b>
The Gemara comments: Both Rava and bar Kappara hold that a separate arrangement is made even on Shabbat. This <b>disagrees with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Huna, who said: The beginning</b> of the sacrificial service of the daily offering, i.e., its slaughter, the sprinkling of its blood, and its burning <b>overrides</b> Shabbat; <b>the end</b> of its service, i.e., the burning of its sacrificial parts, <b>does not override</b> Shabbat.
The Gemara analyzes Rav Huna’s statement: Returning to <b>the</b> matter <b>itself: Rav Huna said: The beginning</b> of the sacrificial service of the <b>daily offering overrides</b> a <i>halakha</i>, whereas <b>the end</b> of its service <b>does not override</b> a <i>halakha</i>.
Previously, the Gemara assumed that Rav Huna was discussing the possibility that the sacrifice of the daily offering overrides Shabbat. The Gemara now clarifies if this was his intention: <b>What</b> is meant by saying that the end of its service <b>does not override</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> Although the end of its service <b>does override Shabbat, it does not override</b> the <i>halakha</i> that it should not be brought in a state of <b>ritual impurity.</b> This is true although the beginning of the sacrificial service of the daily offering may, if necessary, be brought in a state of ritual impurity. <b>And Rabba said:</b> The end of its service <b>overrides</b> only the <i>halakha</i> that it should not be brought in a state of <b>ritual impurity, but it does not override Shabbat.</b>
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rabba: <b>It</b> poses <b>a difficulty to your</b> opinion, <b>and it</b> poses <b>a difficulty to</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Ḥisda. It</b> is <b>difficult to your opinion</b> as follows: <b>What is different</b> about the prohibition of bringing an offering in a state of <b>ritual impurity</b> that the daily offering overrides it? <b>Because it is written</b> with regard to the daily offering <b>“in its season”</b> (Numbers 28:2), to emphasize that it should be brought under all circumstances, even if that means that it will be brought <b>in</b> a state of <b>ritual impurity.</b> But, by that logic, the daily offering should <b>also</b> override <b>Shabbat.</b> Because the term <b>“in its season”</b> emphasizes that it should be brought under all circumstances, this means <b>even on Shabbat.</b>
<b>And it</b> is <b>difficult to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Ḥisda: What is different</b> about <b>Shabbat</b> that the daily offering overrides it? <b>Because it is written “in its season,”</b> to emphasize that it should be brought under all circumstances, <b>even on Shabbat.</b> But by that logic, the daily offering should <b>also</b> override the prohibition of bringing an offering in a state of <b>ritual impurity.</b> Because the term <b>“in its season”</b> emphasizes that it should be brought under all circumstances, this means <b>even in</b> a state of <b>ritual impurity.</b>
Rabba <b>said to him: It</b> is <b>not difficult to my</b> opinion <b>and it does not</b> pose <b>a difficulty to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Ḥisda. It</b> is <b>not difficult to my</b> opinion, because I hold that <b>the end of</b> its sacrificial rite <b>is like its beginning.</b>

Daf 46b

Therefore, with regard to overriding the prohibition to bring an offering in a state of <b>ritual impurity,</b> since <b>the beginning</b> of the sacrifice of the daily offering <b>is fit to override</b> the prohibition of offering it in a state of <b>ritual impurity,</b> so too, <b>its end also overrides</b> the prohibition. However, in the case of <b>Shabbat, the beginning</b> of a daily offering of the weekday <b>is not fit to override</b> Shabbat, since by definition it must be brought on its appropriate day. Therefore, <b>its end also does not override</b> Shabbat in the event that limbs remain from Friday’s daily offering.
And it is also <b>not difficult to the</b> opinion of <b>Rav Ḥisda,</b> because <b>he does not hold</b> that <b>its end is like its beginning.</b> Rather, he has the following reasoning: The prohibitions of <b>Shabbat</b> are not merely overridden <b>in</b> the case of <b>a communal</b> offering, but they are actually <b>permitted,</b> such that there is no need to try to avoid performing the necessary labors when sacrificing it. Therefore, <b>its end also overrides</b> Shabbat.
However, in the case of the prohibition to bring an offering in a state of <b>ritual impurity, which is</b> merely <b>overridden in</b> the case of <b>a communal</b> offering, it is preferable to avoid doing so. Therefore, <b>the beginning of</b> its sacrifice, i.e., its slaughter and the sprinkling of its blood, and its burning, <b>which is the essential</b> stage that provides <b>atonement, overrides</b> the prohibition and should be done even in a state of ritual impurity. However, <b>its end,</b> i.e., the burning of the sacrificial parts, <b>which is not the essential</b> stage that provides <b>atonement, does not override</b> the prohibitions.
The Torah prohibits the fire on the altar to be extinguished: “A perpetual fire shall be kept burning on the altar, it shall not go out” (Leviticus 6:6). With regard to this prohibition, an amoraic dispute <b>was stated:</b> With regard to <b>one who extinguishes the fire of</b> the coals that are taken with <b>the coal pan</b> for the incense on Yom Kippur <b>or</b> the fire <b>of</b> the coals that are taken in order to light <b>the candelabrum, Abaye said: He is liable. Rava said: He is not liable.</b>
The Gemara elaborates on the dispute: In a case <b>where one extinguished</b> a coal while still standing <b>upon the top of the altar, everyone agrees that he is liable.</b> This is because the verse explicitly is referring to extinguishing a flame “upon the altar.” <b>When they disagree,</b> it is in a case <b>where he brought</b> the coals <b>down to ground</b> level <b>and extinguished</b> a coal there. <b>Abaye said: He is liable,</b> since it is still considered <b>fire of the altar. Rava said: He is not liable,</b> because <b>once it has been removed</b> from the altar <b>it is</b> considered <b>removed</b> and no longer part of the altar’s fire. Therefore, the prohibition does not apply to it.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, with regard to <b>this</b> ruling <b>that Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said: One who takes down a coal from upon the altar and extinguishes it is liable, in accordance with whose</b> opinion is he ruling? Could he possibly be ruling <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Abaye?</b> Certainly not. In disputes between Abaye and Rava, the <i>halakha</i> follows Rava.
The Gemara explains: <b>You can even say</b> his ruling <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rava</b> by making the following distinction: <b>There,</b> in the ruling of Rav Naḥman, the coal <b>was not removed to fulfill its mitzva.</b> Therefore, it is still considered to be part of the fire of the altar and the prohibition still applies. Whereas, <b>here,</b> in the dispute between Abaye and Rava, this is a case of coal that <b>was removed to fulfill its mitzva.</b> Therefore, it is associated with its mitzva and no longer considered the fire of the altar.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> a different version of the dispute:
In a case <b>where he brought</b> the coals <b>down to the ground and extinguished</b> a coal there, <b>everyone agrees that he is not liable. When they disagree</b> it is in a case <b>where one extinguished</b> a coal while still standing <b>upon the top of the altar. Abaye said: He is liable,</b> since it is still considered <b>fire of the altar. Rava said: He is not liable,</b> because <b>once it has been removed</b> from the altar <b>it is</b> considered <b>removed</b> and no longer part of the altar’s fire. Therefore, the prohibition does not apply to it.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, with regard to <b>this</b> ruling <b>that Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said: He who takes down a coal from upon the altar and extinguishes it is liable, in accordance with whose</b> opinion is his ruling? It would appear that it is <b>neither in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Abaye, nor in accordance</b> with the opinion of <b>Rava.</b> The Gemara explains: You can even say that his ruling is in accordance with the opinion of Rava by making the following distinction: <b>There,</b> in the ruling of Rav Naḥman, the coal <b>was not removed to fulfill its mitzva;</b> it is therefore still considered to be part of the fire of the altar and the prohibition applies. Whereas, <b>here,</b> in the dispute between Abaye and Rava, this is a case of coal that <b>was removed to fulfill its mitzva,</b> and it is therefore associated with its mitzva and no longer considered the fire of the altar.

Daf 47a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>They brought out the spoon and the coal pan</b> to the High Priest so he may perform the service of the incense. <b>He scoops his handfuls</b> from the incense <b>and places it into the spoon. The</b> High Priest with <b>large</b> hands fills the spoon with incense in an amount <b>corresponding to the large</b> size of his hands, <b>and the</b> High Priest with <b>small</b> hands fills the spoon with incense in an amount <b>corresponding to the small</b> size of his hands. <b>And this was the measure</b> of the spoon, i.e., it was made to correspond to the size of his hands. <b>He took the coal pan in his right</b> hand <b>and the spoon in his left</b> hand.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara expresses surprise at the statement of the mishna. In an earlier mishna, the <i>tanna</i> already <b>taught</b> that the High Priest must bring the <b>coal pan: He takes a coal pan and ascends to the top of the altar and rakes and descends.</b> Why does the <i>tanna</i> mention the taking of the coal pan again? The Gemara explains: <b>There</b> the mishna deals with the <b>coal pan of</b> burning <b>coals, and here</b> the mishna is referring to the <b>coal pan of incense,</b> which he would later scoop out. <b>As it was</b> explicitly <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>They brought out an empty spoon for him from the chamber of vessels, and a coal pan heaped with incense from the Chamber of the House of Avtinas.</b>
§ The mishna taught: <b>He scoops his handfuls</b> from the incense <b>and places it into the spoon. The</b> High Priest with <b>large</b> hands fills the spoon with incense <b>corresponding to the large</b> size of his hands, <b>and</b> the High Priest with <b>small</b> hands fills the spoon <b>corresponding to the small</b> size of his hands, <b>and this was the measure</b> of the spoon, according to the size of his hands. The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need <b>a spoon on Yom Kippur?</b> After all, <b>the Merciful One states:</b> “And he shall take a coal pan full of coals of fire from off the altar from before the Lord, and <b>his hands full</b> of sweet incense beaten small <b>and bring</b> it within the veil” (Leviticus 16:12). This verse suggests that the handfuls are brought by hand rather than in a vessel.
The Gemara answers: The High Priest uses a spoon <b>because it is impossible</b> to perform the service otherwise. The Gemara elaborates: <b>As what should we do? Let him bring in</b> the coal pan <b>and then bring in</b> the incense? <b>The Merciful One states one</b> act of <b>bringing</b> for the coals and the incense, <b>and not two</b> acts of <b>bringing.</b>
Instead, <b>let him take</b> the <b>incense by his handfuls and place</b> the <b>coal pan on top of</b> his two handfuls <b>and enter,</b> carrying it all in one go. This suggestion is also impractical, as <b>when he arrives there,</b> in the Holy of Holies, <b>what should he do?</b> How can the High Priest put down the coal pan where it is? <b>Let him take</b> the <b>coal pan in his teeth and lower</b> it. <b>Now, before a king of flesh and blood one would not do so,</b> as it is disrespectful. <b>All the more so,</b> one would not act in this manner <b>before the King of kings, the Holy One, Blessed be He.</b>
The Gemara concludes: <b>Therefore, it is impossible</b> for the High Priest to behave in another way, <b>and since it is impossible</b> to act in any other manner, <b>he acts as we find</b> with regard to the sacrifices of the <b>princes</b> during the dedication of the Tabernacle. On that occasion, the princes brought spoons filled with incense: “One golden spoon of ten shekels full of incense” (Numbers 7:14).
§ The mishna taught that the High Priest <b>took the coal pan in his right</b> hand <b>and the spoon in his left</b> hand. The Gemara questions this arrangement by citing a well-known maxim: <b>The native is on the ground and the stranger is in the heavens;</b> i.e., this is the opposite of what one would expect. The main component of the mitzva is the incense, while the coal pan is required only for burning the incense. Consequently, the High priest should carry the spoon, which contains the main component of the service, in his right hand, and the accessory in his left hand.
The Gemara explains: The service is performed in this manner for reasons of comfort, as <b>this</b> coal pan is <b>greater</b> in weight, since it holds the coals, <b>and that</b> spoon of incense weighs <b>less. And even when the two of them are equal,</b> when the spoon contains three <i>kav</i> of incense <b>like the action of Rabbi Yishmael ben Kimḥit,</b> who could hold several <i>kav</i> in his exceptionally large hands, nevertheless, <b>this</b> coal pan <b>is hot</b> and must be held carefully in the right hand, <b>and that</b> spoon of incense <b>is cold</b> and is easily carried in the left.
§ Since the Gemara has mentioned Rabbi Yishmael ben Kimḥit, it discusses him further. <b>They said about Rabbi Yishmael ben Kimḥit</b> that his hands were so large <b>that he would scoop</b> up <b>four <i>kav</i>,</b> which he would hold <b>by his handfuls, and say: All the women selected</b> the best they could for their children, <b>but the selection of my mother rose to the roof,</b> i.e., my mother chose the best. Rabbi Yishmael ben Kimḥit is referring to himself, as he matured to a great height and stature. <b>Some say</b> he was referring to his mother’s selection <b>of flour, in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Rabba bar Yonatan. As Rabba bar Yonatan said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yeḥiel said: Flour is beneficial</b> and healthy <b>for the sick.</b> Since his mother ate this flour when she was pregnant with him, her son grew heartily.
<b>And some say</b> this reference to selection is a euphemism for semen, <b>in accordance with</b> a statement of <b>Rabbi Abbahu, as Rabbi Abbahu raised a contradiction</b> between two verses. <b>It is written: “For You have girded me</b> [<b><i>vatazreni</i></b>] <b>with strength for battle”</b> (II Samuel 22:40), <b>and it is written</b> in a parallel verse: <b>“Who girds me</b> [<b><i>hame’azreni</i>] with strength”</b> (Psalms 18:33). What is the difference between these two expressions? <b>David said before the Holy One, Blessed be He: Master of the Universe: You selected me [<i>zeritani</i>]</b> with the best drop of semen that my mother absorbed, with which, <b>You fashioned me [<i>zeraztani</i>]</b> within her. This accounts for the variant forms of this expression.
The Gemara continues to discuss Rabbi Yishmael ben Kimḥit. <b>They said about Rabbi Yishmael ben Kimḥit: Once he was talking to a certain Arab in the market</b> on Yom Kippur, <b>and a drop</b> of saliva <b>sprayed from</b> the Arab’s <b>mouth onto the clothes</b> of Rabbi Yishmael, who was the High Priest at the time. This spittle rendered him ritually impure by rabbinic law, like the ritual impurity of a <i>zav</i>, preventing him from serving in the Temple. <b>And his brother Yeshevav entered and served</b> as High Priest on that day <b>in his stead. And,</b> consequently, <b>their mother saw two</b> of her sons serving as <b>High Priests on a single day.</b>
<b>And they further said about Rabbi Yishmael ben Kimḥit: Once he went out and talked to a certain officer [<i>hegmon</i>] in the market, and a drop of saliva sprayed from</b> the officer’s <b>mouth onto the clothes</b> of Rabbi Yishmael, <b>and his brother Yosef entered and served</b> as High Priest <b>in his stead. And,</b> again, <b>their mother saw two</b> of her sons serving as <b>High Priests on a single day.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Kimḥit had seven sons, and they all served</b> in the office <b>of the High Priesthood,</b> as High Priests or as his substitute. <b>The Sages said to her: What</b> good deeds <b>did you perform to merit this? She said to them: In all my days, the beams of my house never saw the braids of my hair,</b> as she was extremely modest and was strict about covering her hair even inside her own house. <b>They said to her: Many</b> women <b>did so and did not succeed</b> to such a degree; you must have been granted a special gift from God.
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> “And he shall take up from it <b>his handful,</b> of the fine flour of the meal-offering, and of its oil” (Leviticus 6:8). This verse teaches <b>that he should not measure an amount for the handful</b> of a meal-offering with a utensil, but he should separate it directly by hand. <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> as to whether the High Priest may <b>measure an amount for the handful</b> of incense? Must the incense also be scooped by hand?
The Gemara explains the two sides of the dilemma: Perhaps <b>there,</b> in the case of the handful of a meal-offering, <b>it</b> is different, <b>as it is written “in his handful,”</b> which indicates that he must use his hand rather than a vessel. <b>However here, where it is not written: In his hands, but “and his hands full of sweet incense beaten small”</b> (Leviticus 16:12), perhaps this teaches that the handfuls of incense need <b>not</b> be taken directly by hand, and the High Priest may use a vessel to scoop out the required amount. <b>Or perhaps</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>is derived</b> by means of a verbal analogy between <b>“full”</b> and <b>“full,” from “his handful,”</b> which is stated regarding the meal-offering. If this verbal analogy is accepted, the High Priest may likewise scoop the incense only by hand.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> an answer from the mishna: <b>And this was the measure</b> of the spoon. <b>What, is it not</b> correct to infer from the mishna <b>that</b> although the required measure is a handful, the High Priest is not obligated to scoop with his hand, and <b>if he wanted to measure a different amount, he</b> may <b>measure</b> the incense with a vessel? The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>No, this is</b> what the mishna <b>said;</b> this is what it means: <b>And so too,</b> the High Priest <b>would return and scoop</b> the incense <b>inside</b> the Holy of Holies in precisely the same manner.
The Gemara asks: If so, I can <b>learn from this</b> that the High Priest <b>scoops</b> the incense, <b>and again scoops.</b> That is, after scooping once, the High Priest repeats the action and scoops again in the Holy of Holies. This issue is subject to a dispute in the Gemara below.
The Gemara rejects this claim: No; <b>perhaps</b> the mishna indeed means <b>that if he wanted to measure a different amount, he</b> may <b>measure</b> the incense with a vessel. The language of the mishna does not conclusively prove which interpretation is correct, and it is possible that the Gemara’s previous inference from the mishna is accurate. Consequently, the issue of whether or not the High Priest scoops incense a second time in the Holy of Holies cannot be considered resolved. <b>Alternatively,</b> the mishna may mean <b>that</b> the High Priest must <b>take neither less nor more,</b> and therefore this statement has no bearing on the dispute with regard to his scooping.
§ <b>The Sages taught: “His handfuls”</b> (Leviticus 2:2). I <b>might</b> have thought it should <b>be overflowing</b> from the handful, and therefore <b>the verse states: “His handful”</b> (Leviticus 6:8), which indicates a precise amount. <b>If</b> the <i>halakha</i> is based solely on the phrase <b>“his handful,”</b> I <b>might</b> have thought the priest may pinch a small amount <b>even with</b> just <b>his fingertips,</b> not with his entire finger. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “His handfuls”</b> (Leviticus 2:2), meaning <b>as people</b> usually <b>take a handful,</b> i.e., with their whole hand. <b>How</b> should he perform this service? <b>He scoops</b> by closing <b>his three fingers over the palm of his hand, and takes a handful</b> from the flour of the meal-offering.

Daf 47b

<b>And in</b> a case of a meal-offering prepared in <b>a pan and</b> with regard <b>to</b> a meal-offering prepared in <b>a deep container,</b> when the flour was fried before being scooped and was therefore hard, the priest <b>smooths with his thumb</b> any flour that was overflowing <b>above</b> his handful, <b>and with his little finger</b> he smooths the flour that was pushing out <b>below. And this</b> precise taking of a handful of a meal-offering <b>is</b> the most <b>difficult</b> sacrificial <b>rite in the Temple.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>This one</b> is the hardest rite, <b>and no other? But there is pinching,</b> which is also considered extremely difficult, <b>and there is taking</b> the <b>handful</b> of incense, another complex rite. <b>Rather, this</b> taking of a handful of a meal-offering <b>is</b> one <b>of</b> the most <b>difficult rites in the Temple.</b>
§ <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Uza’a raised a dilemma: What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the flour that remains <b>between</b> the fingers <b>of his handfuls?</b> Is this flour considered to be part of his handful, or is it considered part of the remainder of the meal-offering? The Gemara elaborates: <b>Rav Pappa said</b> that with regard to the flour <b>that is on the inside,</b> toward the hand, <b>do not raise the dilemma, as it</b> is <b>certainly</b> part of <b>the handful.</b> Likewise, with regard to the flour <b>that is on the outside, do not raise the dilemma, as it</b> is <b>certainly</b> part of the <b>remainder</b> of the flour, like the rest of the meal-offering.
Rather, <b>let the dilemma be raised</b> with regard to the flour <b>between</b> the inside and the outside. <b>What is</b> the status of this flour? <b>Rav Yoḥanan said: Yehoshua ben Uza’a then resolved</b> his own dilemma: The flour that is <b>between is doubtful,</b> and should be treated as questionable in status.
The Gemara asks: <b>How does one perform</b> the Temple service in this doubtful case? <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said:</b> The priest <b>first burns the handful by itself, and then</b> he burns the flour that was <b>between. For if you say</b> that he should <b>first</b> burn the flour that was <b>between, perhaps they are remainders, and they are</b> therefore considered like <b>remainders that became reduced between taking the handful and burning,</b> as the priest has taken flour from the remainders of the meal-offering. <b>And the Master said:</b> With regard to <b>remainders that became reduced between taking the handful and the burning, one</b> may <b>not burn the handful on their</b> account.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> that there is uncertainty as to whether or not this flour is considered part of the remainder of the meal-offering, <b>now too,</b> if the priest burns the in-between flour after burning the handful, one should <b>apply here</b> the principle: <b>Whatever is partly</b> burned <b>in</b> the <b>fire</b> of the altar <b>is subject to</b> the prohibition <b>do not burn.</b> This principle states that if part of an item is burned on the altar, one who burns any other part of it, which is not designated for burning, has violated a prohibition. In this case, if the in-between flour is considered part of the remainder of the meal-offering, the priest who burns it transgresses that prohibition.
<b>Rav Yehuda, son of Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi, said that</b> the priest does not burn the flour as part of the meal-offering but <b>burns it for the purpose of wood.</b> In other words, he does not burn the flour as part of an offering but merely as fuel for the altar, which is permitted <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> “But they shall not come up <b>for a sweet savor</b> on the altar” (Leviticus 2:12). This verse indicates that <b>you</b> may <b>not bring up</b> leaven and honey as a “sweet savor,” an offering. <b>However, you</b> may <b>bring up</b> leaven and honey and other materials <b>for the purpose of wood.</b>
The Gemara asks: It works out <b>well according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, but according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who reject Rabbi Eliezer’s <i>halakha</i>, <b>what can be said? Rav Mari said:</b> The solution is <b>that fat</b> priests <b>take</b> the <b>handfuls</b> of meal-offerings, as their fleshy fingers press against everything between them, and therefore no flour remains between the fingers. The Gemara states: <b>Now that you have arrived at this</b> conclusion, according to <b>Rabbi Eliezer as well,</b> it is appropriate <b>that fat</b> priests should <b>take</b> the <b>handfuls <i>ab initio</i>,</b> to avoid a situation of doubt.
§ <b><i>Bein habeinayim</i>, <i>pashat</i>, <i>umaḥatz</i>, <i>ufizer</i>, <i>veḥishev</i>, <i>baḥafinat</i>, <i>ḥaveiro</i>:</b> This is <b>a mnemonic</b> for the ensuing questions of Rav Pappa. <b>Rav Pappa raised a dilemma: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <b>in-between</b> incense <b>of his handfuls?</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is his dilemma? If he derives</b> the verbal analogy between <b>“full”</b> and <b>“full”</b> from his handfuls <b>there,</b> the case of the meal-offering handful, <b>this</b> case <b>is</b> the same as <b>that</b> one, and therefore the incense between his fingers is invalid. If Rav Pappa does not accept this verbal analogy, what is the basis of his dilemma?
The Gemara explains that <b>Rav Pappa raised the dilemma</b> as follows: When the verse states: “And <b>his hands full</b> of sweet incense beaten small, <b>and bring</b> it within the veil” (Leviticus 16:12), does it mean that <b>we</b> merely <b>require</b> him to bring his handfuls, and <b>that is</b> fulfilled here, as in practice the High Priest brought full handfuls? <b>Or perhaps we require</b> that he must fulfill the following two commands in a similar manner: <b>“And he shall take…and he shall bring”</b> (Leviticus 16:12)? In other words, just as he must have the intention to take the incense, so too, he must intend to bring all of it. <b>And that</b> requirement <b>is not</b> fulfilled here, as he did not intend to bring the extra incense between his fingers. No answer was found for this question, and the Gemara concludes: <b>Let it stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> It is <b>obvious to me</b> that the act of <b>his handfuls</b> of a meal-offering should be performed <i>ab initio</i> in the manner that <b>people</b> usually <b>take a handful,</b> with their fingertips pointed downward. However, <b>Rav Pappa raised a dilemma: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if <b>he took a handful with his fingertips,</b> i.e., if he first put his palm into the vessel and filled his palm with flour by extending his fingers and drawing them in? Does this invalidate the taking of the handful or not?
Furthermore, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if he took the handful with the back of his hand placed <b>downward</b> in the vessel, and with his fingers collected the flour <b>upward</b> into his palm? Lastly, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if he took the flour <b>from the sides,</b> by passing the back of his hand to and fro over the flour in the vessel with his fingers spread apart, so that the flour collects in his palm? As no answers were found for these dilemmas, the Gemara states: <b>Let it stand</b> unresolved.
Likewise, <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> It is <b>obvious to me</b> that when the Torah states: <b>“His hands full”</b> (Leviticus 16:12), it means in the manner that <b>people</b> usually <b>fill their hands,</b> by placing the backs of their hands into the vessel and bringing their hands together. However, <b>Rav Pappa raised a dilemma: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if the High Priest <b>scooped a handful with his fingertips?</b> Again, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if he took a handful <b>from downward</b> to <b>upward? What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if he took a handful <b>from the side?</b> And <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if <b>he scooped a handful with this</b> hand <b>and with this</b> hand <b>and brought them together?</b> These questions are not answered either, and the Gemara states: <b>Let it stand</b> unresolved.
§ Another <b>dilemma</b> was <b>raised</b> by

Daf 48a

<b>Rav Pappa: What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> in a case where <b>he stuck the handful</b> of flour <b>onto the side of the vessel?</b> After the flour of a meal-offering has been separated, it must be placed in a vessel for burning, an action that sanctifies the flour. Rav Pappa inquires as to what the <i>halakha</i> is if the priest places the flour on the sides, instead of on the bottom of the vessel. The Gemara clarifies the two sides of the dilemma: Do <b>we require</b> the handful to be <b>inside the vessel, and that is</b> the case here? <b>Or perhaps we require</b> the handful to be <b>placed properly inside</b> the vessel, <b>and that is not</b> fulfilled in this instance. No answer is found for this question, and the Gemara concludes: <b>Let it stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Mar bar Rav Ashi raised</b> a similar <b>dilemma: What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> if the priest <b>overturned the vessel and stuck</b> the <b>handful to</b> an indentation in <b>the underside of the vessel?</b> Do <b>we require</b> the handful to be <b>inside</b> the vessel, <b>and that</b> requirement <b>is</b> fulfilled here; <b>or perhaps we require</b> it to be <b>placed properly</b> in the vessel, <b>and that is not</b> the case here? With regard to this question as well, the Gemara states: <b>Let it stand</b> unresolved.
§ <b>Rav Pappa raised a dilemma:</b> Should <b>the handfuls to which</b> the Sages <b>referred</b> be <b>smoothed</b> over <b>or</b> slightly <b>overflowing? Rabbi Abba said to Rav Ashi: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> an explicit statement in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The handfuls to which</b> the Sages <b>referred</b> should be <b>neither smoothed</b> over <b>nor overflowing, but full,</b> without any flour spilling out.
§ <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there,</b> in <i>Zevaḥim</i> 32a: If <b>the blood</b> of the sacrificial animal <b>spilled on the floor</b> instead of being collected directly into a vessel, <b>and</b> a priest <b>collected it</b> from there into a vessel, <b>it is disqualified,</b> as it was not collected properly. Conversely, if the blood spilled <b>from the vessel onto the floor,</b> after it was collected properly, <b>and</b> a priest <b>collected it</b> and put it back in the vessel, <b>it is valid.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>As the Sages taught</b> in a halakhic midrash: <b>“And</b> the anointed priest <b>shall take from the blood of the bull”</b> (Leviticus 4:5); this means that the priest shall take <b>from the blood of the soul,</b> i.e., the bull’s blood that flows from the place of slaughter as the animal dies, <b>and not from the blood of the skin,</b> which bleeds out when the skin is cut before the slaughter, <b>nor from the blood squeezed</b> from an animal after the initial spurt.
The <i>baraita</i> interprets the phrase <b>“from the blood of the bull,”</b> as though these words were written in a different order: <b>Blood from the bull,</b> i.e., the priest shall <b>receive it</b> directly. <b>For if it should enter your mind</b> that the letter <i>mem</i>, which means “from” in the phrase <b>“from the blood of the bull,”</b> is limiting <b>and</b> indicates that <b>even</b> if the priest received <b>some of the blood,</b> his action is acceptable, <b>didn’t Rav Yehuda say: He who receives</b> the blood <b>must receive all of the blood of</b> the <b>bull, as it is stated: “And all the blood of the bull he shall pour out on the base of the altar”</b> (Leviticus 4:7)? This verse emphasizes that the priest must pour all of the bull’s blood, which is possible only if he has collected all of it.
<b>Rather, learn from this</b> that <b>what is</b> the meaning of the phrase: <b>“From the blood of the bull”?</b> It means that the priest must <b>receive</b> the <b>blood</b> directly <b>from the bull. And</b> this Sage <b>maintains</b> that the Sages <b>subtract and add and interpret homiletically,</b> i.e., one may take a letter from one word, insert it into a second word, and explain the phrase in that manner.
§ <b>Rav Pappa raised a dilemma</b> based on the above ruling: <b>What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> if <b>the incense from his handfuls scattered?</b> Is <b>his hand considered like the neck of the animal, and</b> the incense is <b>disqualified? Or perhaps</b> his hand <b>is considered like a vessel used in the Temple service, and</b> if the incense fell from his hand <b>it is not disqualified.</b> No answer was found for this question either, and the Gemara again concludes: <b>Let it stand</b> unresolved.
§ <b>Rav Pappa raised</b> another <b>dilemma: What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> if the High Priest <b>thought</b> a disqualifying thought <b>during the taking of the handful of the incense,</b> e.g., if he intended to burn it after its appropriate time? Does this thought invalidate the rite or not? <b>Do we say</b> that this <i>halakha</i> <b>is derived</b> by means of a verbal analogy of <b>“handfuls”</b> and <b>“handfuls,” from</b> the case of <b>a meal-offering,</b> as follows: <b>Just as there,</b> with regard to the meal-offering, <b>thought is effective</b> to invalidate <b>it, so too</b> here, with regard to taking a handful of incense, <b>thought is effective</b> to invalidate <b>it? Or</b> should the two cases <b>not</b> be compared?
<b>Rav Shimi bar Ashi said to Rav Pappa: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to your dilemma: <b>Rabbi Akiva added the handful</b> of fine flour <b>and the incense, and the frankincense, and the coals</b> that are collected in a vessel, to the ruling of the Sages <b>that if one who immersed himself during the day touched part of them, he disqualifies all of them.</b> Due to the respect in which sacred objects are held, these objects are treated as one solid unit. This is so despite the fact that its parts are not really attached to each other but are separate small segments and therefore, logically, one who immersed himself during the day should disqualify only those parts of the item with which he came into direct contact.
The Gemara explains: <b>It enters your mind</b> that <b>from</b> the fact that <b>one who immersed himself during the day disqualifies</b> these items by touch, therefore <b>leaving</b> them after their permitted time <b>likewise disqualifies</b> them; <b>and from</b> the fact that <b>leaving</b> them after their time <b>disqualifies</b> them, therefore <b>thought likewise disqualifies</b> them. Consequently, as incense is similar to flour with regard to ritual impurity, it is also disqualified by the priest’s improper thought.
§ <b>Rav Pappa raised</b> another <b>dilemma:</b>

Daf 48b

<b>What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> if he <b>thought</b> invalidating thoughts during <b>the raking of the coals?</b> Does this thought invalidate the incense? The Gemara elaborates: The question here is whether <b>actions that facilitate</b> the performance of <b>a mitzva are considered like the mitzva</b> itself. If so, merely raking the coals, which facilitates the mitzva of the incense, is like burning the incense itself; therefore, an improper thought would disqualify the incense. <b>Or</b> perhaps actions that facilitate the performance of a mitzva are <b>not</b> considered part of the mitzva itself. No answer was found for this question either, and the Gemara once again concludes: <b>Let it stand</b> unresolved.
§ The Sages <b>raised a dilemma before Rav Sheshet: What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>carrying</b> the blood in one’s <b>left</b> hand? Is this action valid, or is carrying, like receiving and sprinkling the blood, an act that must be performed with the right hand? Rav Sheshet <b>said to them: We</b> already <b>learned it;</b> there is an answer to this question from the mishna: <b>He took the coal pan in his right</b> hand <b>and the spoon in his left</b> hand. This proves that although the spoon is carried in the left hand to the place of the service, the rite is valid.
The Gemara asks: <b>And let us resolve</b> this dilemma <b>for them from that which we learned</b> in a mishna: The priest who is privileged to carry the head and the leg of the daily offering to the ramp carried <b>the right leg</b> in his <b>left</b> hand, <b>with its</b> entire <b>hide</b> facing <b>outward</b> and the place of the slaughter on the neck facing the priest. This mishna also proves that carrying with the left hand is acceptable.
The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>If</b> the proof is <b>from there, I would have said: That applies</b> only to a type of <b>carrying that does not invalidate atonement,</b> as even if the limbs are not carried up to the altar, atonement is nevertheless achieved through the sprinkling of the blood. The rite is valid even if the limbs of the daily offering are not burned at all. <b>However, with regard to</b> the type of <b>carrying that does invalidate atonement,</b> e.g., carrying the blood to the altar, <b>no,</b> perhaps it must be done specifically with the right hand. Rav Sheshet therefore <b>teaches us</b> from the mishna that although carrying the spoon is necessary for the mitzva, the rite is nevertheless valid if it is carried in the left hand.

Daf 49a

The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: With regard <b>to receiving, carrying, or sprinkling</b> blood, if <b>a non-priest, a mourner</b> on his first day of mourning, <b>a drunk</b> priest, <b>and a blemished</b> priest, performed the rite, it is <b>disqualified. And likewise</b> if the priest was <b>sitting, and likewise</b> if he performed one of these rites with his <b>left</b> hand, it is <b>disqualified.</b> This statement contradicts the ruling of Rav Sheshet. The Gemara concludes: This is indeed <b>a conclusive refutation,</b> and Rav Sheshet’s opinion is rejected.
The Gemara asks: <b>But wasn’t Rav Sheshet</b> the <b>one who objected</b> on the basis of this very <i>baraita</i>? <b>As Rav Sheshet said to the interpreter of Rav Ḥisda: Raise the</b> following <b>dilemma before Rav Ḥisda: What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>carrying</b> the blood performed <b>by a non-priest? He said to him:</b> It is <b>valid, and a verse supports me: “And they slaughtered the Paschal offering and the priests sprinkled with their hand, and the Levites flayed”</b> (II Chronicles 35:11). This verse indicates that the priests took the blood from the hands of the Levites, from which it can be inferred that the Levites carried the blood from the place of slaughtering to the place of sprinkling.
<b>And Rav Sheshet objected</b> based on the aforementioned <i>baraita</i>: With regard <b>to receiving, carrying, or sprinkling</b> blood, if <b>a non-priest, a mourner</b> on his first day of mourning, <b>a drunk</b> priest, <b>and a blemished</b> priest, performed the rite, it is <b>disqualified.</b> This statement proves that carrying cannot be performed by a non-priest. Since Rav Sheshet himself cited this <i>baraita</i> in his objection, he was certainly familiar with it. How, then, could he issue a ruling in contradiction to the <i>baraita</i>?
The Gemara explains: <b>After</b> Rav Sheshet <b>heard</b> the <i>baraita</i> that was cited against his opinion, <b>he objected</b> to the ruling of Rav Ḥisda from that same <i>baraita</i>. At first Rav Sheshet was unaware of the <i>baraita</i>, which is why he ruled against it, but when he learned it, he relied upon it to object to Rav Ḥisda’s statement. The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t Rav Ḥisda cite a verse</b> in support of his opinion? How can a <i>baraita</i> contradict a verse? The Gemara answers: The verse does not mean that the Levites walked with the blood, but rather <b>that they acted like benches</b> and merely stood holding the bowls of blood in their hands.
§ The Gemara returns to the issue of appropriate methods for taking handfuls of incense. <b>Rav Pappa raised a dilemma: What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a case where <b>another</b> priest <b>scooped and placed</b> the incense <b>into the hands</b> of the High Priest? The Gemara clarifies the two sides of the question: Do <b>we require: “His full hands,” and that is</b> fulfilled here, as in practice the High Priest has a handful of incense? <b>Or perhaps we require</b> that the High Priest must fulfill the mitzvot: <b>“And he shall take…and he shall bring”</b> (Leviticus 16:12), <b>and that is not</b> the case here, as the High Priest did not scoop and take the incense himself? This question was also left unanswered, and the Gemara concludes: <b>Let it stand</b> unresolved.
§ <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi raised a dilemma:</b> If the High Priest <b>scooped and died, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the possibility <b>that another</b> High Priest may replace him and <b>enter with his handful?</b> May the second priest enter the Holy of Holies with the incense that the first priest scooped, or must he start from the beginning of the process? <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said</b> to his students in excitement: <b>Come and see</b> that Sages from a later generation were able to ask a difficult question on par with <b>the question of the earlier</b> generations. Even I, Rabbi Ḥanina, asked this same question, which was posed by my elder, Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi.
The Gemara analyzes this comment: <b>Is that to say that Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi</b> was <b>older</b> than Rabbi Ḥanina, which is why Rabbi Ḥanina referred to him as an early Sage? <b>But didn’t Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi say: Rabbi Ḥanina permitted me to drink cress juice on Shabbat</b> for medicinal purposes. Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi’s deference to Rabbi Ḥanina shows that Rabbi Ḥanina was older than him.
Since it has been raised, the Gemara addresses the issue of cress juice on Shabbat: Did Rabbi Ḥanina permit him <b>to drink</b> cress juice? It is <b>obvious</b> that it is permitted to drink this juice; why would it be prohibited? <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>All</b> types of <b>food</b> that healthy people eat <b>may be eaten by people</b> even <b>for medicinal</b> purposes, and one may likewise <b>drink all drinks</b> for medicinal purposes, as the Sages did not include these in their decree against taking medicine on Shabbat.
<b>Rather, Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi’s</b> question was: Is it permitted <b>to grind and drink cress on Shabbat?</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances? If</b> it involves a situation <b>where there is danger</b> to life, and this is the prescribed cure, <b>it is</b> certainly <b>permitted; and if</b> it is a case <b>where there is no danger,</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> as labor on Shabbat. The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> the question concerns a case <b>where there is</b> a life-threatening <b>danger, and this is the dilemma that he raised before him: Does</b> this drink <b>heal,</b> which would mean <b>that</b> it is appropriate <b>to violate Shabbat for it, or</b> does it <b>not heal, and</b> therefore one should <b>not violate Shabbat for it?</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> if this was not a halakhic question but a medical one, <b>what is different</b> about this question that led him to ask it specifically of <b>Rabbi Ḥanina?</b> The Gemara explains: Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi asked Rabbi Ḥanina <b>because he is an expert in medicines, as Rabbi Ḥanina said: No man ever consulted me about a wound</b> inflicted by a <b>white mule and recovered.</b> This shows that people came to Rabbi Ḥanina for medical advice.
The Gemara expresses surprise at this claim: <b>But we see that</b> people who are kicked by mules <b>do survive.</b> The Gemara answers that instead it should <b>say:</b> No man ever consulted me about a wound of this kind <b>and</b> the wound <b>survives,</b> i.e., the wound never heals. The Gemara challenges this statement as well: <b>But we see that</b> it <b>does heal.</b> The Gemara responds: <b>We say</b> that the wound will never heal only <b>when</b> the mules <b>are red and the tops of their legs are white.</b>
The Gemara returns to its previous question. <b>In any event,</b> one can <b>learn from this</b> discussion <b>that Rabbi Ḥanina</b> was <b>older</b> than Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi.
