<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara comments with regard to the wording of the mishna: It does <b>not teach: After</b> the Ark <b>was buried, but: After</b> it <b>was taken.</b> If so, <b>we learned</b> this mishna <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the one who said</b> that <b>the Ark was exiled to Babylonia</b> and was not buried in its place, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: The Ark was exiled to Babylonia, as it is stated: “And at the turn of the year King Nebuchadnezzar sent and brought him to Babylonia, along with the precious vessels of the House of the Lord”</b> (II Chronicles 36:10). These precious vessels must include the Ark.
Likewise, <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai says: The Ark was exiled to Babylonia, as it is stated:</b> “Behold, the days come that all that is in your house, and that which your fathers have stored until this day, shall be carried to Babylonia; <b>nothing [<i>davar</i>] shall be left, says the Lord”</b> (Isaiah 39:6). <b>These are the Ten Commandments [<i>dibrot</i>] that are inside it;</b> they too shall not be left behind.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Lakish says: The Ark was buried in its place, as it is stated: “And the ends of the staves were seen from the sacred place before the partition, but they could not be seen without; and they are there to this day”</b> (I Kings 8:8). The expression “to this day” means forever, as the text might be read at any time. This teaches that the Ark is hidden in its place.
The Gemara comments: And <b>this</b> opinion that the Ark was exiled to Babylonia <b>disagrees with</b> that <b>of Ulla, as Ulla said: Rabbi Matya ben Ḥarash asked Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai in Rome: And since Rabbi Eliezer taught us once and twice,</b> i.e., from two separate verses, that <b>the Ark was exiled to Babylonia.</b> The Gemara interrupts its citation of Rabbi Matya ben Ḥarash’s question to identify these two verses. <b>The first</b> verse is <b>that which we said: “And brought him to Babylonia, along with the precious vessels of the House of the Lord.” What is the second</b> verse? Rabbi Eliezer said: <b>As it is written: “And gone from the daughter of Zion is</b>

Daf 54a

<b>all her splendor”</b> (Lamentations 1:6). <b>What is</b> the meaning of: <b>“All her splendor [<i>hadara</i>]”?</b> It means: <b>Her chamber [<i>ḥadra</i>],</b> i.e., something that was hidden within the innermost chambers, namely the Ark. <b>You,</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai, <b>what do you say</b> in response to this? <b>He said to him: As I say, the Ark was buried in its place</b> and not exiled, <b>as it is stated: “And the staves were so long</b> that the ends of the staves were seen from the sacred place before the partition, but they could not be seen without; and they are there to this day” (I Kings 8:8).
<b>Rabba said to Ulla: From where</b> in this verse may it <b>be inferred</b> that the Ark was buried in its place? Ulla replied that the source is <b>as it is written: “And they are there to this day,”</b> which is referring to any day when one might read this sentence, i.e., forever. Rabba objected to this explanation: <b>And</b> is it the case that <b>anywhere that it is written “to this day” it</b> means <b>forever,</b> as opposed to the time when the verse was written? <b>But isn’t it written: “And the children of Benjamin did not drive out the Jebusites who inhabited Jerusalem; but the Jebusites dwelt with the children of Benjamin in Jerusalem, to this day”</b> (Judges 1:21)? <b>So too here,</b> let us say <b>that</b> the Jebusites <b>were not exiled</b> from Jerusalem.
<b>But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: No person passed through</b> the land of <b>Judea</b> for <b>fifty-two years</b> after the destruction of the Temple by Nebuchadnezzar, <b>as it is stated: “I will raise crying and wailing for the mountains, and a lamentation for the pastures of the wilderness, for they have been burned, with no person passing through. And they do not hear the sound of the cattle; from the bird of the heavens to the beast [<i>behema</i>], all have fled and gone”</b> (Jeremiah 9:9). <b><i>Behema</i>,</b> spelled <i>beit</i>, <i>heh</i>, <i>mem</i>, <i>heh</i>, <b>has a numerical value of fifty-two,</b> alluding to the fact that no one passed through the land for fifty-two years.
<b>And it was taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> For <b>seven years</b> a curse of <b>brimstone and salt endured in Eretz Yisrael,</b> rendering it unfit for human habitation. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: What is the rationale of Rabbi Yosei;</b> from where does he learn this? It is <b>derived from</b> a verbal analogy between <b>“covenant”</b> and <b>“covenant.” It is written here: “And he shall make a firm covenant with many for one week”</b> (Daniel 9:27), i.e., seven years. <b>And it is written there:</b> “And that its entire land is brimstone and salt…<b>They shall say: Because they forsook the covenant of the Lord, the God of their fathers”</b> (Deuteronomy 29:22; 24). Evidently, the Jebusites must have been exiled from Jerusalem, which proves that the phrase “to this day” does not always mean forever.
Ulla <b>said to him: Here,</b> with regard to the Ark, <b>it is written:</b> “And they are <b>there”;</b> whereas <b>there,</b> in the verse that deals with the Jebusites, <b>it is not written. And anywhere that “there” is written</b> with the phrase “to this day” <b>it</b> means <b>forever.</b> The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from the following verse: <b>“And some of them, even of the sons of Simeon, five hundred men, went to Mount Seir having for their captains Pelatiah and Neariah and Rephaiah and Uzziel, the sons of Ishi. And they smote the remnant of the Amalekites who escaped, and dwelt there to this day”</b> (I Chronicles 4:42–43).
The Gemara explains its objection: <b>But Sennacherib, king of Assyria,</b> had <b>already come, and</b> through his policy of forced population transfer <b>he had scrambled all</b> the nations of <b>the lands, as it is stated</b> in reference to Sennacherib: <b>“And I have removed the bounds of the peoples, and have robbed their treasures”</b> (Isaiah 10:13). This indicates that the children of Simeon were also exiled, despite the fact that the verse states: “There to this day.” The Gemara concludes: Indeed, this is <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of Ulla’s statement.
<b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that a Sage <b>taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>And the Rabbis say</b> that the <b>Ark</b> of the Covenant <b>was buried in the Chamber of the Woodshed. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: We, too, have learned</b> in a mishna: There was <b>an incident involving a certain priest who was occupied</b> with various matters, <b>and he saw a floor</b> tile in the woodshed that was <b>different from the others.</b> One of the marble floor tiles was higher than the rest, suggesting it had been lifted out and replaced. <b>He came and informed his friend</b> of the uneven tile, <b>but was unable to finish his report</b> and provide the exact location of the tile <b>before his soul departed</b> from his body. <b>And</b> consequently <b>they knew definitively that the Ark was buried there,</b> but its location was meant to be kept secret.
The Gemara asks: <b>What was he doing,</b> that priest who noticed the misplaced tile? <b>Rabbi Ḥelbo said: He was occupied with his axe,</b> i.e., he was banging the floor with his axe. He thereby discovered an empty space under a tile, which he guessed was the opening of a tunnel. <b>The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: Two blemished priests were sorting wormy wood when the axe of one of them dropped and fell there,</b> into the hole in the floor. Blemished priests were appointed to inspect the wood for worms, as these logs were unfit for use on the altar. <b>And fire burst out and consumed</b> that priest, so the exact location remains unknown.
§ <b>Rabbi Yehuda raised a contradiction. It is written: “The ends of the staves were seen,” and it is written</b> in that same verse: <b>“But they could not be seen without”</b> (I Kings 8:8). <b>How</b> can one reconcile this contradiction? <b>They were seen and</b> yet <b>not seen,</b> i.e., the staves were partially visible. <b>This was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“The ends of the staves were seen”;</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>they did not move from their position</b> and did not protrude at all. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And the staves were so long.”</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>they ripped through the curtain and emerged</b> on the other side; therefore, <b>the verse states: “They could not be seen without.”</b>
<b>How</b> is this so? The staves of the Ark <b>pushed and protruded and stuck out against the curtain</b> toward the outside, <b>and appeared like the two breasts of a woman</b> pushing against her clothes. <b>As it is stated: “My beloved is to me like a bundle of myrrh, that lies between my breasts”</b> (Song of Songs 1:13). For this reason the Ark of the Covenant, where the Divine Presence rests, is positioned so that its staves protrude through the curtain, like the breasts of a woman.
Continuing the previous discussion, <b>Rav Ketina said: When the Jewish people would ascend for</b> one of the pilgrimage <b>Festivals,</b> the priests would <b>roll up the curtain for them and show them the cherubs, which were clinging to one another, and say to them: See how you are beloved before God, like the love of a male and female.</b> The two cherubs symbolize the Holy One, Blessed be He, and the Jewish people.
<b>Rav Ḥisda raised an objection:</b> How could the priests allow the people to see this? After all, it is stated with regard to the Tabernacle: <b>“But they shall not go in to see the sacred objects as they are being covered,</b> lest they die” (Numbers 4:20), <b>and Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: When the vessels were put into their containers</b> for transport, it was prohibited even for the Levites to look at them. The prohibition against viewing the vessels should be even more severe when they are fixed in their sacred place within the Temple. How could they be publicly displayed?
<b>Rav Naḥman said</b> in answer: This is <b>analogous to a bride; as long as she is</b> engaged but still <b>in her father’s house, she is modest</b> in the presence <b>of her husband.</b> However, <b>once she</b> is married and <b>comes to her father-in-law’s house</b> to live with her husband, <b>she is no longer modest</b> in the presence <b>of her husband.</b> Likewise, in the wilderness, when the Divine Presence did not dwell in a permanent place, it was prohibited to see the sacred objects. By contrast, all were allowed to see the sacred objects in their permanent place in the Temple.
<b>Rav Ḥana bar Rav Ketina raised an objection</b> from the aforementioned mishna: There was <b>an incident involving a certain priest who was occupied</b> and discovered the place where the Ark was hidden, and he subsequently died before he could reveal its location. Since he was prevented from seeing the Ark, it was evidently prohibited to see the sacred objects even after the Temple was built. Rav Naḥman <b>said to him:</b> This is not difficult, as <b>you are speaking</b> of when <b>she was divorced.</b> Since the Jewish people were exiled after the destruction of the First Temple, they are compared to a woman divorced from her husband, <b>and when</b> a woman is <b>divorced she returns to her original beloved</b> but reserved state. She is once again modest and does not reveal herself. Likewise, the Divine Presence will remain hidden until the glory of the First Temple is restored.
The Gemara poses a question concerning Rav Ketina’s statement: <b>With what are we dealing</b> here; in what circumstance did the priests roll up the curtain to show everyone the cherubs? <b>If we say</b> this is referring <b>to</b> the <b>First Temple, was there a curtain</b> between the Sanctuary and the Holy of Holies? In the First Temple, there was a wall there. <b>Rather,</b> we will say this is referring <b>to</b> the <b>Second Temple;</b> but <b>were there cherubs</b> there? Since there was no Ark, it follows that there were no cherubs on it. The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> Rav Ketina is referring <b>to</b> the <b>First Temple, and what is the curtain</b> that he mentioned? It is <b>the curtain of the gates.</b> For all of the Jewish people to be able to see, they had to raise the curtains hanging on all the gates.
<b>As Rabbi Zeira said</b> that <b>Rav said: There were thirteen curtains in the</b> Second <b>Temple: Seven opposite,</b> i.e., on the inside of, <b>seven gates; two</b> additional ones within the Temple, <b>one</b> of which was <b>at the entrance to the Sanctuary and</b> the other <b>one</b> of which was <b>at the entrance to the Entrance Hall. Two</b> additional curtains were <b>within the partition,</b> in the Holy of Holies in place of the one-cubit partition, <b>and two corresponding to them</b> were above <b>in the upper chamber.</b> Above the Holy of Holies, there was another level in the same layout as the one below, and a curtain was affixed there, too, as no one climbed up to the higher chamber above the Holy of Holies without a pressing need. These curtains were most likely hanging in the First Temple as well.
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: Actually,</b> Rav Ketina’s statement is referring <b>to</b> the <b>Second Temple:</b> There was a curtain at the entrance of the Holy of Holies, <b>and</b> indeed <b>there were images of cherubs there,</b> i.e., drawn or engraved pictures of the cherubs on the walls. <b>As it is written: “And he carved all the walls of the house round about with carved figures of cherubs and palm trees and open flowers,</b> within and without” (I Kings 6:29), and it is further stated: <b>“And he overlaid them with gold fitted upon the graven work”</b> (I Kings 6:35), which teaches that in addition to the cherubs within the sacred place, other cherubs were drawn on the walls.
<b>And it is written: “According to the space of each with <i>loyot</i>”</b> (I Kings 7:36). The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of: <b>“According to the space of each with <i>loyot</i>”? Rabba bar Rav Sheila said:</b>

Daf 54b

It means <b>like a man</b> joined and <b>clinging to his <i>livaya</i>,</b> his partner, i.e., his wife. In other words, the cherubs appeared to be embracing one another. <b>Reish Lakish said: When gentiles</b> destroyed the Second Temple and <b>entered the Sanctuary, they saw</b> these drawings of <b>cherubs clinging to one another.</b> They peeled them from the wall, <b>took them out to the market, and said: These Jews, whose blessing is a blessing and whose curse is a curse,</b> due to their great fear of God, should <b>they be occupied with such matters,</b> making images of this kind? <b>They immediately debased</b> and destroyed <b>them, as it is stated: “All who honored her debase her because they have seen her nakedness”</b> (Lamentations 1:8).
§ The mishna taught that a stone sat in the Holy of Holies <b>and it was called</b> the <b>foundation [<i>shetiyya</i>]</b> rock. A Sage <b>taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: Why was it called <i>shetiyya</i>? It is <b>because the world was created [<i>hushtat</i>] from it.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>We learned</b> the mishna <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the one who said</b> that <b>the world was created from Zion. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: The world was created from its center, as it is stated: “When the dust runs into a mass, and the clods cleave fast together”</b> (Job 38:38). The world was created by adding matter to the center, like the formation of clumps of earth.
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> The <b>world was created from the sides, as it is stated: “For He said to the snow: Become the earth, likewise to the shower of rain, and to the showers of His mighty rain”</b> (Job 37:6). This verse indicates that the rains fell from all sides, which led to the creation of the earth. <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa said: The Holy One, Blessed be He, cast a stone into the sea, from which the world was created, as it is stated: “Upon what were its foundations fastened; or who laid its cornerstone?”</b> (Job 38:6).
<b>And the Rabbis say:</b> The world <b>was created from Zion, as it is stated: “A Psalm of Asaph. God, the Lord God</b> has spoken and called the earth, from the rising of the sun to its place of setting” (Psalms 50:1), <b>and it states: “Out of Zion, the perfection of beauty,</b> God has shined forth” (Psalms 50:2). The mishna is taught in accordance with this last opinion.
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer the Great says: “These are the generations of the heaven and the earth when they were created, on the day that the Lord God made earth and heaven”</b> (Genesis 2:4) means that the <b>generations of the heavens,</b> i.e., all things found in the heavens, <b>were created from the heavens,</b> while the <b>generations of the earth were created from the earth.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say: Both these and those were created from Zion, as it is stated: “A Psalm of Asaph. God, the Lord God has spoken and called the earth, from the rising of the sun to its place of setting,” and it says: “Out of Zion, the perfection of beauty, God has shined forth,”</b> i.e., <b>from</b> Zion <b>the beauty of the world was perfected,</b> which includes both the generations of the heavens and the generations of the earth.
§ The mishna taught that the High Priest <b>took the blood</b> of the bull <b>from</b> the one <b>who was stirring it</b> so it would not coagulate, <b>and he entered</b> and sprinkled it like one who whips. The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of: <b>Like one who whips? Rav Yehuda demonstrated</b> the action with his hand,

Daf 55a

<b>like one who lashes with a whip</b> on the back of another and who occasionally strikes lower down. A Sage <b>taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>When</b> the High Priest <b>sprinkles</b> the blood, <b>he does not sprinkle on</b> the top of <b>the Ark cover; rather,</b> he does so <b>against the thickness of the Ark cover. When he sprinkles</b> once <b>upward, he turns his hand</b> so that the back of his hand faces <b>downward,</b> and he then sprinkles upward. <b>And when he sprinkles</b> seven times <b>downward, he turns his hand</b> so its back is <b>upward.</b> However, he does not sprinkle on the Ark cover or below it, so that the blood does not actually come into contact with it.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters,</b> that the sprinklings do not actually touch the Ark cover, derived? <b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said</b> that <b>Rabbi Zeira said: The verse states</b> with regard to the goat sacrificed as a sin-offering: “And he shall do with its blood as he did with the blood of the bull, <b>and sprinkle it upon the Ark cover and before the Ark cover”</b> (Leviticus 16:15). The verse should <b>not say downward,</b> i.e., “before the Ark cover,” with regard <b>to the goat, as</b> this <b>is unnecessary;</b> this requirement <b>is derived from</b> the term <b>downward</b> in connection <b>with</b> the <b>bull.</b>
Since the rite performed with the blood of the goat is compared to the rite of the blood of the bull, <b>why is</b> the requirement that the High Priest must sprinkle downward <b>stated</b> twice? It is <b>to juxtapose</b> the phrase <b>“upon</b> the Ark cover” <b>to “before</b> the Ark cover”; <b>just as “before”</b> means <b>that</b> it is <b>not</b> actually <b>on</b> the Ark cover but merely in front of it, <b>so too, “upon”</b> means <b>that</b> it is <b>not</b> actually <b>on</b> the Ark cover but in front of it, and the High Priest simply turns his hand upward.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>On the contrary,</b> the verse should <b>not say upward,</b> i.e., “before the Ark cover,” with regard <b>to the bull, as</b> this <b>is unnecessary;</b> it <b>is derived from</b> the term <b>upward</b> stated in connection <b>to</b> the <b>goat.</b> Since the verse equates the two rituals, <b>why does it state</b> the upward sprinkling of the blood of the bull? It is <b>to juxtapose</b> the phrase <b>“before</b> the Ark cover,” stated with regard to the bull, <b>to “upon</b> the Ark cover,” stated with regard to the goat; <b>just as “upon”</b> stated by the goat means <b>actually upon,</b> as indicated by the literal meaning of the verse, <b>so too, “before”</b> means <b>actually upon</b> it, i.e., the blood of the goat should touch the thickness of the Ark cover.
The Gemara expresses surprise at this suggestion: <b>What is this</b> comparison? <b>Granted, if you say</b> that <b>downward</b> stated with regard <b>to the goat</b> is mentioned <b>to juxtapose it to upward</b> stated with regard <b>to the bull, one needs</b> the phrase “upon the Ark cover,” which deals with the blood of the bull, <b>for that which the school of Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov taught. As the school of Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov taught: “Upon [<i>al penei</i>] the Ark cover to the east”</b> (Leviticus 16:14); <b>this forms an analogy</b> that applies to the entire Torah: <b>Any place where it is stated “face [<i>penei</i>],”</b> it is referring to <b>nothing other</b> than the <b>eastern</b> side. <b>However, if you say,</b> as suggested by the question, that <b>upward</b> with regard <b>to the bull</b> is mentioned <b>to juxtapose</b> it to “upward” stated with regard to the goat, <b>for what purpose does downward</b> stated with regard <b>to the goat come;</b> what do we learn from this phrase? Rather, the first interpretation of the verse must be correct.
§ <b>The Sages taught: “And sprinkle it upon the Ark cover and before the Ark cover”</b> (Leviticus 16:15). <b>We</b> have thereby <b>learned how many</b> times the High Priest must sprinkle <b>upward for the goat,</b> that is, <b>one</b> sprinkling, as it states: “And sprinkle.” However, with regard to the sprinkling <b>downward for the goat,</b> before the Ark cover, <b>I do not know how many</b> times he must sprinkle.
<b>I</b> therefore <b>derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> from the verses. <b>It states</b> that <b>blood</b> is sprinkled <b>downward</b> in the case <b>of the bull, and it states</b> that <b>blood</b> is sprinkled <b>downward</b> in the case <b>of the goat. Just as</b> the blood that he sprinkles <b>downward</b> in the case <b>of the bull</b> consists of <b>seven</b> sprinklings, as the verse explicitly states: “And before the Ark cover he shall sprinkle seven times” (Leviticus 16:14), <b>so too,</b> the sprinkling of the blood <b>downward</b> in the case <b>of the goat</b> is performed <b>seven</b> times.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Or</b> one can <b>go</b> and reason <b>this way: It states</b> that <b>blood</b> is sprinkled <b>upward</b> in the case <b>of the goat, and</b> likewise <b>it states</b> that <b>blood</b> is sprinkled <b>downward</b> in the case <b>of the goat. Just as</b> with regard to sprinkling <b>upward</b> in the case <b>of the goat</b> there is <b>one</b> sprinkling, <b>so too,</b> with regard to sprinkling <b>downward</b> in the case <b>of the goat</b> there is only <b>one</b> sprinkling. The Gemara comments: <b>Let us see what</b> case this <b>resembles: One derives</b> an act performed <b>downward</b> from another act that is <b>downward, and one does not derive</b> an act performed <b>downward from an upward</b> act.
The Gemara retorts: <b>On the contrary, one derives</b> one aspect of <b>a matter from</b> another aspect of <b>that</b> same <b>matter,</b> i.e., one should infer the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the blood of the goat from another <i>halakha</i> involving that same blood, <b>and one does not derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>that matter from</b> an external <b>matter.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And he shall do with its blood as he did with the blood of the bull”</b> (Leviticus 16:15). <b>As</b> there is <b>no</b> need for <b>the verse to state: “As he did,”</b> because the whole process is explicitly stated a second time, <b>what</b> then is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “As he did”?</b> It comes to teach <b>that all his actions should be alike,</b> down to every detail. Consequently, <b>just as</b> the sprinklings <b>downward</b> in the case <b>of the bull</b> are <b>seven, so too,</b> the sprinklings <b>downward</b> in the case <b>of the goat</b> are <b>seven.</b>
<b>We have</b> thereby <b>learned how many</b> sprinklings are performed <b>downward</b> in the case <b>of the bull and by the goat: Seven.</b> However, <b>I do not know how many</b> times the High Priest must sprinkle <b>upward</b> in the case <b>of the bull. And I</b> therefore <b>derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> as follows: <b>It states</b> that <b>blood</b> is sprinkled <b>upward</b> in the case <b>of the goat, and it states</b> that <b>blood</b> is sprinkled <b>upward</b> in the case <b>of the bull. Just as</b> with regard to the sprinkling <b>upward</b> in the case <b>of the goat</b> he sprinkles <b>one</b> time, as stated explicitly, <b>so too,</b> in the case <b>of the bull</b> he sprinkles <b>upward one</b> time.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Or</b> one can <b>go</b> and reason <b>this way: It is stated</b> that <b>blood</b> is sprinkled <b>downward</b> in the case <b>of the bull, and</b> likewise <b>it is stated</b> that <b>blood</b> is sprinkled <b>upward</b> in the case <b>of the bull. Just as</b> with regard to sprinkling <b>downward</b> in the case <b>of the bull</b> there are <b>seven</b> sprinklings, <b>so too,</b> with regard to sprinkling <b>upward</b> in the case <b>of the bull</b> there should be <b>seven</b> sprinklings. The Gemara comments: <b>Let us see what</b> case this <b>resembles: One derives</b> an act performed <b>upward</b> from another act that is performed <b>upward, and one does not derive</b> an act performed <b>upward from a downward</b> act.
The Gemara retorts: <b>On the contrary, one derives</b> one aspect of <b>a matter from</b> another aspect of <b>that</b> same <b>matter, and one does not derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>that matter from</b> an external <b>matter.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And he shall do with its blood as he did.” As</b> there is <b>no</b> need for <b>the verse to state: “As he did,”</b> because the whole process is explicitly stated a second time, <b>what</b> then is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “As he did”?</b> It comes to teach <b>that all his actions should be alike: Just as</b> the sprinklings <b>downward</b> in the case <b>of the bull</b> are <b>seven, so too,</b> the sprinklings <b>downward</b> in the case <b>of the goat</b> are <b>seven; and just as</b> the sprinkling <b>upward</b> in the case <b>of the goat</b> is <b>one, so too,</b> the sprinkling <b>upward</b> in the case <b>of the bull</b> is <b>one.</b>
§ The mishna states that the High Priest counted: <b>One; one and one; one and two. The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that when sprinkling, the High Priest counted: <b>One; one and one; one and two; one and three; one and four; one and five; one and six; one and seven.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that he counted: <b>One; one and one; two and one; three and one; four and one; five and one; six and one; seven and one.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>They do not disagree</b> about the matter itself that the High Priest sprinkles once upward and seven times downward. Rather, this <b>Sage</b> rules <b>in accordance with</b> the norm <b>in his place, and</b> this <b>Sage</b> rules <b>in accordance with</b> the norm <b>in his place.</b> In one place they counted the smaller number first, while in the other place they would count the larger number first.
The Gemara asks: <b>In any case, everyone,</b> both Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda, agrees that <b>the first sprinkling</b> upward <b>must be counted</b> together <b>with each and every one</b> of the subsequent sprinklings. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? Why can’t the High Priest count the downward sprinklings separately? The Sages debated this matter. <b>Rabbi Elazar said:</b> The reason is so <b>that he does not err in the sprinklings.</b> If the High Priest were to count downward without including the first upward sprinkling, he might mistakenly think that his calculation includes the first sprinkling, which would lead him to add another one.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that the reason is that <b>the verse states:</b> “And he shall sprinkle it with his finger upon the Ark cover, <b>and before the Ark cover he shall sprinkle”</b> (Leviticus 16:14). <b>As</b> there is <b>no</b> need for <b>the verse to state: He shall sprinkle”</b> again, <b>what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “He shall sprinkle”?</b> This <b>teaches</b> with regard <b>to the first sprinkling that it must be counted with each and every</b> subsequent <b>one,</b> i.e., he must mention the first sprinkling every time.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between</b> these two explanations? The Gemara answers: The practical difference <b>between them</b> concerns a case <b>where he did not count</b> the first sprinkling <b>and did not err.</b> That is acceptable according to the opinion of Rabbi Elazar, whereas according to Rabbi Yoḥanan the High Priest acted incorrectly, as it is a mitzva to count the first one.
§ The mishna taught that the High Priest <b>emerged and placed</b> the bowl with the remaining blood of the bull <b>on the golden pedestal in the Sanctuary,</b> and later he placed the goat’s blood on a second pedestal, whereas according to Rabbi Yehuda there was only one pedestal. The Gemara comments: <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Shekalim</i> 6:6) that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: There were no</b> collection <b>horns for obligatory nests,</b> i.e., the pairs of pigeons or turtledoves brought as sin- and burnt-offerings by women after childbirth or other individuals, <b>due to the</b> concern of <b>mixtures.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of the phrase: <b>Due to a mixture? Rav Yosef said:</b> It means <b>due to</b> the possible <b>mixture of obligatory</b> nests <b>with free-will</b> ones. There was concern lest the priests mix the money given for obligatory nests, which are sacrificed as a sin-offering and a burnt-offering, with the money for free-will nests, which are sacrificed as a pair of burnt-offerings. Mixing the funds in this way would disqualify the birds. <b>Abaye said to him: And let us prepare two</b> collection horns <b>and write on them which is</b> the container <b>for obligatory</b> offerings <b>and which is</b> the one for <b>free-will</b> offerings. The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b>

Daf 55b

<b>does not accept</b> that one may rely on <b>writing</b> in a situation where an error is possible. <b>As we learned</b> in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: There was only one pedestal</b> in the Temple on which to place the blood. <b>What is the reason</b> that they did <b>not</b> place <b>two</b> pedestals there? The reason is <b>because</b> the pedestals might be <b>exchanged</b> for one another, and he might take the goat’s blood instead of that of the bull. <b>But</b> in that case, <b>let us place two</b> pedestals <b>and write on them which</b> one <b>is for the bull and which is for the goat. Rather,</b> it is clear that <b>Rabbi Yehuda does not accept</b> that one may rely on <b>writing</b> in a situation where error is possible.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> against this conclusion: <b>There were thirteen</b> collection <b>horns in the Temple, and they were</b> each <b>inscribed</b> with different names. On one container was written: <b>New shekels.</b> In this horn they placed shekels that were donated at the correct time that year. <b>And</b> on another horn the phrase <b>old shekels</b> was written, referring to coins from the past year that did not reach the Temple during the allotted period. On the other horns, the following phrases were written: <b>Nests,</b> for obligatory offerings consisting of pairs of pigeons or turtledoves; <b>young birds for burnt-offerings; wood,</b> for anyone who wished to donate wood; <b>frankincense; and gold for the Ark cover. And</b> there were <b>six</b> additional boxes designated <b>for</b> communal <b>free-will offerings</b> of all kinds.
The Gemara explains: <b>New shekels, these are</b> the <b>shekels of each and every year</b> that arrive on time; <b>old shekels,</b> these are for <b>one who did not donate a shekel the previous year,</b> who must <b>donate the next year; nests, these are the turtledoves</b> brought as offerings; <b>young birds for burnt-offerings, these are pigeons; and all these</b> birds <b>are burnt-offerings;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b> Rabbi Yehuda maintains that there was no container for nests of obligatory sin-offerings and burnt-offerings, due to the potential mixture between the two. In any case, this shows that Rabbi Yehuda does rely on inscriptions written on containers, which contradicts the above claim that he does not rely on writing in these situations.
<b>When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia <b>he said: They say in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, that this is a rabbinic <b>decree due to</b> the possible presence in the mixture of <b>a sin-offering whose owners have died.</b> Since a sin-offering of this kind must be left to die, if one of the donors of the coins in the sin-offering horn passes away, his funds cannot be used. The Gemara asks: <b>And are we concerned</b> about the possible death of a donor? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>one who sends his sin-offering from overseas, they sacrifice it</b> for him <b>on the presumption that he is alive,</b> although he might have died in the meantime. This shows that the possibility of death is not taken into account.
<b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Yehuda’s concern is <b>due to a sin-offering whose owner has certainly died,</b> lest it be confirmed that one of the people who donated money for a sin-offering bird has indeed died. The Gemara asks: Even so, this can be rectified, as <b>let us select four <i>zuz</i>,</b> the price of such an offering, <b>and throw them into the water</b> to be destroyed. It may be said that the money removed from the box was the money for the sin-offering whose owner died, <b>and these</b> other coins <b>will be permitted.</b> It will be clarified retroactively that these coins were designated for that purpose. The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Yehuda does not accept</b> the rule of retroactive <b>clarification.</b> In his opinion, one cannot issue a designation after the fact. Consequently, he rejects this solution.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that this is indeed Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion? <b>If we say</b> it is derived <b>from that which we learned</b> in the following mishna, there is a difficulty. The mishna states: With regard to <b>one who buys wine from among the Samaritans,</b> who do not tithe their produce properly, <b>on Shabbat eve at nightfall</b> and has no time to separate the tithe before Shabbat and to place the separated portions in distinct locations, he may <b>arise and say: Two <i>log</i></b> of the one hundred <i>log</i> present here, <b>which I will separate in the future,</b> after Shabbat, <b>shall be</b> the <b><i>teruma</i></b> <i>gedola</i> given to a priest, as the Sages mandated that one-fiftieth of one’s produce constitutes an average measure of <i>teruma</i>;

Daf 56a

<b>ten</b> <i>log</i> that I will later separate shall be the <b>first tithe;</b> and another tenth from the rest, which equals <b>nine</b> <i>log</i> of the remaining ninety, shall be <b>second tithe. And he redeems</b> the second tithe with money that he will later take to Jerusalem, <b>and he</b> may then <b>immediately drink</b> the wine. After Shabbat, when he removes portions from the mixture and places them in vessels, they are retroactively designated as <i>terumot</i> and tithes. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>

Daf 56b

<b>Rabbi Yehuda, Rabbi Yosei, and Rabbi Shimon prohibit</b> this practice. <b>Apparently,</b> Rabbi Yehuda maintains that <b>there is no</b> retroactive <b>clarification.</b>
The Gemara explains the difficulty: <b>From where</b> do you reach this conclusion? <b>Perhaps it is different there, as the reason is taught:</b> The Rabbis <b>said to Rabbi Meir: Do you not concede</b> that <b>the jug might split open</b> before he removes the portions of <i>terumot</i> and tithes from the mixture, causing all the wine to spill out? <b>And he</b> will then <b>be found drinking untithed</b> wine <b>retroactively.</b> Therefore, he cannot rely on separation that has not yet occurred. <b>And he said to them:</b> Although there will be a problem <b>if it splits open,</b> there is no cause to be concerned for this contingency in advance. Since this reasoning is based on the possibility that the jug might break, there is no proof from here that Rabbi Yehuda rejects the principle of retroactive clarification.
<b>Rather,</b> the proof that Rabbi Yehuda does not accept the principle of retroactive clarification is <b>from</b> a <i>baraita</i> the Sage <b>Ayo taught. As Ayo taught</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: A person cannot stipulate conditions about two matters at once,</b> e. g., one cannot establish a joining of Shabbat boundaries [<i>eiruv</i>] in each of two different directions on Friday afternoon while making the following stipulation: If tomorrow, on Shabbat, two Sages arrive from two different directions, I will decide then which of the two lecturers I prefer to hear at that point in time, which will determine which <i>eiruv</i> is in effect.
<b>Rather,</b> he may say that <b>if the Sage comes to the east, his <i>eiruv</i> is to the east,</b> and if the Sage comes <b>to the west, his <i>eiruv</i> is to the west. However,</b> he may <b>not</b> say that if one Sage comes <b>from here, and</b> another Sage comes <b>from there,</b> he will go wherever he wishes, in either direction.
<b>And we discussed</b> this passage in the Gemara and asked: <b>What is different</b> about a case in which one stipulated that if Sages came <b>from here and from there</b> that he may go to whichever side he chooses, such that his <i>eiruv</i> is <b>not</b> effective? Apparently, Rabbi Yehuda maintains <b>that there is no</b> retroactive <b>clarification,</b> i.e., this person cannot claim after the fact that the place where he walked is designated as the place that he initially intended for his <i>eiruv</i>.
However, according to this principle, when an individual establishes an <i>eiruv</i> <b>to the east and</b> to <b>the west</b> for the anticipated arrival of a single Sage, one should <b>also</b> invoke the principle that <b>there is no</b> retroactive <b>clarification.</b> Why does Rabbi Yehuda agree that if one anticipates the arrival of a single Sage and stipulates that if he comes to the east his <i>eiruv</i> will be to the east, the <i>eiruv</i> is valid?
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> This is not a true case of retroactive clarification, <b>as the Sage had already come</b> by twilight, but the one who established the <i>eiruv</i> did not yet know at which side of the town the Sage had arrived. Therefore, at the time the <i>eiruv</i> establishes his Shabbat residence, it is clear which <i>eiruv</i> he wants, although he himself will become aware of that only later. In this case, Rabbi Yehuda agrees that the <i>eiruv</i> is valid, but he nonetheless maintains in general that there is no retroactive clarification. This accounts for Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion that there was no container for nests of obligatory sin-offerings and burnt-offerings, as he maintains that there is no solution for the possible mixture of the different coins.
The Gemara asks: <b>And now that we have said</b> and proven that <b>according to Rabbi Yehuda there is no</b> retroactive <b>clarification,</b> nevertheless <b>he is of</b> the opinion that one may rely on <b>writing,</b> as proven from the <i>halakha</i> of the collection horns. If so, on <b>Yom Kippur as well, let us place two</b> pedestals <b>and write on them</b> which one is for the blood of the bull and which is for the blood of the goat.
The Gemara answers: The reason they did not place two pedestals with writing on them is <b>due to the High Priest’s weakness.</b> Since he is fasting during the entire day’s service, the writing will <b>not</b> be <b>on his mind;</b> he will pay no attention to it and might become confused. <b>As, if you do not say so,</b> that there is concern for the High Priest’s weakness, even <b>without writing</b> he should <b>also</b> not err, as <b>this</b> bowl in which he collects the bull’s blood <b>is</b> relatively <b>large and this</b> one for the goat’s blood <b>is small.</b>
<b>And if you say</b> that <b>he does not collect all</b> the bull’s blood but only some of it, so that the bowls are of equal size, <b>didn’t Rav Yehuda say: One who slaughters</b> the bull <b>must receive all of the blood of</b> the <b>bull, as it is stated: “And all the blood of the bull he shall pour out on the base of the altar”</b> (Leviticus 4:7).
<b>And if you say</b> that <b>perhaps some of</b> the bull’s blood <b>might spill,</b> yielding equal amounts of blood, there should still be no mistake, as <b>this</b> blood, that of the goat, is <b>white</b> and bright compared to the blood of the bull, <b>and this</b> blood of the bull <b>is red</b> and darker than the other. <b>Rather,</b> the reason must be that <b>due to the High Priest’s weakness,</b> these differences will <b>not</b> be <b>on his mind. Here, too,</b> the writing will not help, as <b>due to the High Priest’s weakness</b> the inscriptions will <b>not</b> be <b>on his mind.</b>
§ The Gemara relates: <b>A certain person descended</b> to lead the prayer service on Yom Kippur <b>before Rava</b>. He included the order of the High Priest’s Yom Kippur service in his prayer, and <b>he recited:</b> The High Priest then <b>emerged</b> from the Holy of Holies <b>and placed</b> the bowl <b>on the second golden pedestal in the Sanctuary; he took the blood of the bull</b> from the pedestal <b>and placed the blood of the goat</b> in its place.
Rava <b>said to him:</b> This is problematic, as <b>one</b> statement is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, and</b> the other <b>one</b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b> According to the Rabbis, each of these bowls sat on its own pedestal in the Sanctuary, whereas Rabbi Yehuda maintains that the High Priest must first lift up the container with the blood of the bull and then put down that of the goat. <b>Rather,</b> you should <b>recite</b> the entire order of the service entirely in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis: <b>He placed the blood of the goat</b> on its designated pedestal <b>and took the blood of the bull</b> from the second stand.
§ The mishna taught: <b>And</b> the High Priest <b>sprinkled from</b> the blood of the bull <b>on the curtain opposite the Ark from outside</b> the Holy of Holies. <b>The Sages taught:</b> “And he shall make atonement for the sacred place because of the impurities of the children of Israel, and because of their transgressions, even all their sins; <b>and so shall he do for the Tent of Meeting</b> that dwells with them in the midst of their impurity” (Leviticus 16:16). <b>What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states</b> this? <b>Just as he sprinkles in the innermost sanctum,</b> the Holy of Holies, <b>so he sprinkles in the Sanctuary,</b> the Tent of Meeting, toward the curtain.
Furthermore: <b>Just as</b> in <b>the innermost sanctum</b> he sprinkles <b>once upward and seven</b> times <b>downward from the blood of the bull, so he sprinkles in the Sanctuary. And just as</b> in <b>the innermost sanctum</b> he sprinkles <b>once upward and seven</b> times <b>downward from the blood of the goat, so he sprinkles in the Sanctuary.</b> The last part of the verse: <b>“That dwells with them in the midst of their impurity,”</b> teaches that <b>even when</b> the Jewish people <b>are impure, the Divine Presence is with them.</b>
With regard to this verse, the Gemara relates: <b>A certain Sadducee said to Rabbi Ḥanina:</b>

Daf 57a

<b>Now you are certainly impure, as it is written</b> about the Jewish people: <b>“Her impurity was in her skirts”</b> (Lamentations 1:9), and the Divine Presence does not dwell upon the Jews when they are impure. Rabbi Ḥanina <b>said to him: Come</b> and <b>see what is written about</b> the Jewish people: <b>“That dwells with them in the midst of their impurity”</b> (Leviticus 16:16). This indicates that <b>even when they are impure, the Divine Presence dwells among them.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to the aforementioned <i>halakha</i>. It was stated above that the comparison to the goat teaches that the High Priest sprinkles the bull’s blood once upward; and the seven downward sprinklings of the goat’s blood are derived from the rite of the blood of the bull. Subsequently, the order of sprinkling toward the curtain in the Sanctuary is again derived by means of a similar comparison. The Gemara asks: <b>And does a matter derived by juxtaposition,</b> i.e., a <i>halakha</i> not written explicitly in the Torah but learned by means of a comparison, <b>again teach by juxtaposition?</b> There is a general principle that a <i>halakha</i> derived by juxtaposition with regard to offerings cannot subsequently teach another <i>halakha</i> by juxtaposition.
The Gemara answers that the first juxtaposition was not a proper inference by verbal analogy, as <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> that the High Priest must sprinkle once upward and seven times downward <b>is</b> derived both <b>from that</b> juxtaposition <b>and something else</b> as well. Since the basic requirement that he must sprinkle upward and downward for the bull and the goat is stated explicitly in both cases, and the comparison was necessary only to teach the precise number of sprinklings, this inference <b>is not</b> considered <b>a juxtaposition</b> to the extent that one cannot derive further comparisons from it.
The Gemara continues to question this explanation: <b>It works out well according to the one who said</b> that a juxtaposition that is also inferred from something else <b>is not</b> considered <b>a juxtaposition</b> in this regard; <b>but according to the one who says</b> that this too <b>is</b> called <b>a juxtaposition, what can be said?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>It is</b> the <b>locations that are derived from one another.</b> The <i>halakha</i> of the blood of the bull was not derived from that of the goat, nor the <i>halakha</i> of sprinkling the bull’s blood outside the curtain from that of sprinkling the bull’s blood inside. Instead, the first comparison equates the sprinkling of the bull’s blood and the goat’s blood, while the second comparison equates the locations, i.e., he sprinkles outside the curtain in the same manner that he sprinkles inside. Consequently, the two juxtapositions are not connected to each other, which means that there is no problem of a <i>halakha</i> derived by juxtaposition itself teaching by juxtaposition.
<b>If you wish, say</b> instead a different resolution: The sprinkling <b>outside is derived from</b> the sprinkling <b>inside all at once,</b> i.e., the juxtaposition includes not only the blood of the bull and the goat, but also the manners of sprinkling the blood inside and outside. There are not two comparisons here, one derived from the other, but a single, complex juxtaposition.
§ A Sage <b>taught: When</b> the High Priest <b>sprinkles</b> the blood, <b>he does not</b> actually <b>sprinkle on the curtain but opposite the curtain. Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, said: I saw</b> the curtain <b>in Rome.</b> After a miracle was performed on his behalf and he healed the daughter of the Roman emperor, Rabbi Elazar was permitted to view the ruler’s treasures and take whatever he wanted. He saw the Temple vessels that the Romans captured, including the curtain. Rabbi Elazar continued: <b>And on</b> the curtain <b>were several drops of blood from the bull and the goat of Yom Kippur.</b> This shows that the blood was actually sprinkled on the curtain.
The Gemara questions this conclusion: <b>But</b> how can Rabbi Elazar be sure that these drops of blood were from the bull and goat of Yom Kippur? <b>Perhaps</b> they <b>were</b> from the <b>bull for an unwitting communal sin</b> or <b>the goats for</b> a sin of <b>idolatry,</b> both of whose blood is also sprinkled on the curtain.
The Gemara explains <b>that he saw that these</b> sprinklings of blood <b>were performed in their order,</b> one drop after another, a sequence that is followed only in the Yom Kippur service. <b>And we also learned</b> in a mishna about <b>a case like this with regard to</b> the <b>bull for an unwitting communal sin: When he sprinkles,</b> the blood <b>would not touch the curtain, but if it did touch, it touched,</b> and this did not invalidate the service.
<b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, said: I saw</b> the curtain <b>in Rome, and there were several drops of blood on it from</b> the <b>bull for an unwitting communal sin and</b> the <b>goats for</b> a sin of <b>idolatry.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> how could he identify the source of the blood; <b>perhaps they</b> were <b>from the bull and goat of Yom Kippur?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>He saw that they were performed not in their order</b> and inferred that they must be sprinklings from communal sin-offerings, which are not presented in a sequence.
The Gemara asks a question: What should the High Priest do if <b>the blood</b> of the bull <b>became mixed with the blood</b> of the goat before he finished all the sprinklings? <b>Rava said:</b> He should <b>present</b> from the mixture <b>once upward and seven</b> times <b>downward, and that counts toward</b> both <b>this</b> one <b>and that</b> one, as he has sprinkled from both of them.
<b>They said this</b> answer <b>before Rabbi Yirmeya</b> in Eretz Yisrael, whereupon <b>he said: Foolish Babylonians! Because they live in a dark,</b> low <b>land, they speak darkened <i>halakhot</i>,</b> devoid of logic. If this solution is followed, when the High Priest sprinkles the mixture of bull and goat blood, <b>he</b> thereby <b>presents</b> the <b>upward</b> sprinklings <b>of the goat before</b> he sprinkles the <b>downward</b> presentations of the <b>bull; and the Torah said: “And when he has finished atoning for the sacred place”</b> (Leviticus 16:20), which teaches: <b>He finishes the blood of the bull</b> by sprinkling upward and downward, <b>and</b> only <b>afterward he finishes the blood of the goat.</b>
<b>Rather, Rabbi Yirmeya said</b> that the High Priest proceeds as follows: <b>He presents once upward and seven</b> times <b>downward for the purpose of</b> sprinkling the blood of <b>the bull,</b> as the blood of the bull is in this mixture. <b>And he again presents once upward and seven</b> times <b>downward for the purpose of</b> sprinkling the blood of <b>the goat.</b> Although the blood is mixed together and by sprinkling for the purpose of the bull’s blood he also sprinkles some of the goat’s blood, since he has only the bull’s blood in mind it is as though he did not sprinkle the blood of the goat at all.
The Gemara asks another question: What should the High Priest do if <b>the blood</b> of the bull <b>became mixed with the blood</b> of the goat <b>during the final presentations</b> that he performs in the Sanctuary? <b>Rav Pappa,</b> who was sitting <b>before Rava, thought to say: He presents seven</b> times <b>downward for the purpose of the bull and for the purpose of the goat, and he again presents once upward for the purpose of the goat.</b>
<b>Rava said to him: Until now they called us</b> Babylonians merely <b>foolish, and now</b> they will call us the <b>foolish of the foolish, as</b> they will say that <b>we teach them and</b> yet <b>they do not learn.</b> In response to your statement one could simply repeat Rabbi Yirmeya’s previous argument: <b>But he presents downward</b> sprinklings <b>for the goat before</b> the <b>upward</b> sprinklings <b>for the goat, and the Torah said: Present upward and then downward.</b>

Daf 57b

<b>Rather, Rava said: He presents downward seven</b> times <b>for the purpose of the bull, and he again presents upward once and downward seven</b> times <b>for the purpose of the goat.</b>
The Gemara asks another question: What if the <b>cups became mixed,</b> i.e., if the bowl containing the blood of the bull was confused with that of the blood of the goat? The Gemara explains: <b>He presents</b> blood from one cup by sprinkling upward once and downward seven times, <b>and he again presents</b> a second set of sprinklings from the second cup.
<b>And he again presents</b> another set of sprinklings, again from the first cup, which amounts to a total of <b>three times.</b> In this manner, he fulfills the obligation no matter which cup was which. If the first cup was that of the bull’s blood and the second was that of the goat, he fulfilled his obligation with the first and second sprinklings. If the first cup contained the blood of the goat, he performed the sprinkling of the goat’s blood before that of the bull, which means his first set of sprinklings are discounted. Consequently, when he sprinkled from the second cup, which contains the bull’s blood, and a third time from the cup of the goat’s blood, he fulfilled his obligation with the second and third sets of sprinklings.
The Gemara asks yet another question: <b>If</b> only <b>part of</b> the <b>blood became mixed</b> together <b>and part of the blood did not become mixed,</b> e.g., if some of the blood spilled and became mixed in a third vessel, the solution is <b>obvious: When he presents, he presents from the</b> blood of <b>certain</b> identity.
<b>However,</b> one could still ask a question with regard to this case: What is the status of the mixed blood in <b>the other</b> vessel or vessels? <b>Are they</b> considered the <b>remainder</b> of the blood, <b>and</b> the remainder of the blood <b>goes to the base</b> of the altar like the remainder of all blood of sin-offerings? <b>Or perhaps</b> this mixture of blood <b>is rejected,</b> as the blood from this vessel was not used for the first sprinklings, <b>and</b> therefore the two types of blood are spilled and <b>go to the canal</b> beneath the altar, which rinses all the dirt from the courtyard into the Kidron River.
<b>Rav Pappa said: Even according to the one who says</b> that <b>one cup renders its counterpart a remainder,</b> i.e., if a one collected blood in two cups, the blood in the second cup is considered the remainder of the first cup, <b>this applies</b> only in a case <b>where he could present</b> blood from the second cup <b>if he wanted</b> to, i.e., if both cups were filled with blood from the offering. <b>However,</b> in <b>this</b> case, <b>as</b> the blood in this vessel could <b>not be presented</b> even <b>if he wanted</b> to, it does <b>not</b> become a remainder, and it is therefore certainly rejected.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said to Rav Pappa: On the contrary, even according to the one who says</b> that when blood is collected in two cups <b>one cup renders</b> the blood of <b>its counterpart rejected, that applies</b> only when <b>he rejects</b> the second cup <b>with</b> his own <b>hands,</b> i.e., by means of a direct act. <b>However,</b> in a case <b>where he does not reject it with</b> his own <b>hands,</b> as no act of rejection was performed but rather the blood became a remainder by itself, the blood is <b>not</b> rejected.
<b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the verse <b>above, it says:</b> “And the priest shall take of the blood of the sin-offering with his finger, and put it upon the corners of the altar of the burnt-offering, <b>and he shall pour its blood</b> out at the base of the altar of burnt-offering” (Leviticus 4:25). <b>And</b> in the verse <b>below it says:</b> “And the priest shall take of its blood with his finger, and put it upon the corners of the altar of burnt-offering, <b>and he shall pour all its blood</b> out at the base of the altar” (Leviticus 4:30). The second verse adds the word “all.”
The <i>baraita</i> explains: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>with regard to a sin-offering that</b> if <b>one collected its blood in four cups and presented</b> blood from each of them by sprinkling <b>once from this</b> cup <b>and once from that</b> cup until he has sprinkled four times, once from each cup, <b>that</b> the leftover blood in <b>all</b> the cups <b>is poured</b> out as remainders <b>on the base</b> of the altar? <b>The verse states: “And he shall pour all its blood.”</b>
One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>even</b> if <b>he presented four presentations from one of them,</b> all the rest should be spilled on the base of the altar as remainder; therefore, <b>the verse states: “And he shall pour its blood.”</b> This indicates that not all the blood, but only <b>that</b> blood in the bowl from which blood was sprinkled on the altar, <b>is poured on the base</b> as a remainder, <b>and the</b> rest of the cups of blood <b>are poured into the canal. Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Shimon, says: From where</b> is it derived <b>with regard to a sin-offering that if one collected its blood in four cups and presented four presentations from one of them, that they are all poured at the base</b> of the altar? <b>The verse states: “And he shall pour all its blood.”</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Shimon,</b> isn’t <b>it</b> also <b>written: “And he shall pour its blood”?</b> How does he explain this difference between the verses? <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> When the Torah states “its blood,” it comes <b>to exclude</b> the <b>remainders that are in the throat of</b> the <b>animal.</b> If more blood comes out of the throat after the collection of the blood, that blood is certainly not poured on the base of the altar but is swept into the canal of the Temple.
§ The mishna states that after the High Priest sprinkled the blood toward the curtain <b>he poured the blood of the bull into the blood of the goat.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>We learned</b> this mishna <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the one who said</b> that the High Priest <b>mixes</b> the two types of blood before placing them <b>on the corners</b> of the inner altar, and he does not present each one separately. <b>As it was stated:</b> The later <i>tanna’im</i>, <b>Rabbi Yoshiya and Rabbi Yonatan,</b> debated this issue. <b>One</b> of them <b>said:</b> The High Priest <b>mixes</b> the blood for the purpose of placing the blood on the altar’s corners, <b>and one</b> of them <b>said: He does not mix</b> the blood.
The Gemara comments: <b>Conclude</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoshiya was</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>who said</b> that the High Priest <b>mixes</b> the blood. In general, he maintains that whenever a verse mentions two matters, <b>although</b> the term: <b>Together, is not written</b> explicitly, <b>it is considered as though</b> the term: <b>Together, is</b> indeed <b>written.</b> In other words, two items that appear in the same verse are treated as combined unless expressly stated otherwise. By contrast, Rabbi Yonatan maintains that even if two matters are mentioned together they are treated separately unless the verse uses the term: Together. In this case, the verse states: “And he shall take of the blood of the bull and of the blood of the goat” (Leviticus 16:18). Therefore, Rabbi Yoshiya rules that the High Priest must place the two sets of blood together.
The Gemara rejects this contention. <b>Even</b> if <b>you say</b> that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yonatan,</b> it remains possible to explain its ruling, since <b>it is different here, as it is written “once”</b> (Exodus 30:10), which indicates that there must be one act of sprinkling and not two. Consequently, the High Priest must mix the blood to ensure that there is only one presentation.
The Gemara comments: <b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>contrary to our response,</b> but in accordance with the initial assumption: “And he shall go out to the altar that is before the Lord, and make atonement for it; <b>and he shall take of the blood of the bull and of the blood of the goat,</b> and put it on the corners of the altar round about” (Leviticus 16:18). This verse teaches <b>that</b> the blood of the bull and the goat should <b>be mixed.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yoshiya.</b>

Daf 58a

<b>Rabbi Yonatan says:</b> He presents <b>from this</b> one, the bull’s blood, <b>by itself, and</b> he presents <b>from that</b> one, the goat’s blood, <b>by itself</b> and does not mix them. <b>Rabbi Yoshiya said to him: But wasn’t it already stated:</b> “And Aaron shall make atonement upon its corners <b>once</b> a year; with the blood of the sin-offering of atonement” (Exodus 30:10), which indicates that the High Priest does not present twice?
<b>Rabbi Yonatan said to him: But wasn’t it already stated: “Of the blood of the bull and of the blood of the goat”</b> (Leviticus 16:18), which teaches that each set of sprinklings must be performed by itself? <b>If so, why is “once” stated?</b> This verse comes <b>to tell you</b> that he must perform the rite <b>once and not</b> perform <b>two</b> sets of sprinklings <b>from the blood of the bull;</b> and likewise he must perform the rite <b>once and not</b> perform <b>two</b> sets of sprinklings <b>from the blood of the goat.</b> From the blood of each of the animals, the High Priest presents only one set of sprinklings. This shows that Rabbi Yoshiya and Rabbi Yonatan indeed disagree with regard to this issue.
<b>It was taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>“And he shall take of the blood of the bull and of the blood of the goat”</b> (Leviticus 16:18). This verse teaches <b>that</b> the blood of the bull and the goat <b>should be mixed together.</b> Do <b>you say that they should be mixed together, or perhaps that is not</b> the case; rather, he presents <b>from this</b> blood <b>by itself and from that by itself?</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Once.”</b> The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> this <b>unattributed</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoshiya,</b> who said the two sets of blood are mixed, as stated in the mishna.
§ It was taught in the mishna that after the High Priest poured the bull’s blood into the goat’s blood, <b>he placed</b> the blood <b>from the full</b> bowl <b>into the empty</b> bowl, to mix the blood well. <b>Rami bar Ḥama raised a dilemma before Rav Ḥisda: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if <b>he placed</b> one <b>bowl inside</b> a second <b>bowl and collected the blood in</b> the inner bowl? Does one <b>type</b> of object mingled <b>with</b> another of <b>its</b> own <b>type interpose,</b> which would mean that the priest has not collected the blood himself, as the outer bowl interposed between him and the vessel? <b>Or</b> perhaps an object of one type <b>does not interpose</b> for another object of the same type, and therefore the two bowls are considered one object.
Rav Ḥisda <b>said to him: We</b> have already <b>learned</b> the answer to this question in the mishna: <b>He placed</b> the blood <b>from the full</b> bowl <b>into the empty</b> bowl. <b>What, is it not</b> correct to infer from this statement that <b>he inserted</b> the <b>full bowl into</b> the <b>empty bowl?</b>
Rami bar Ḥama responded: <b>No,</b> it means that <b>he poured</b> the <b>full bowl into</b> an <b>empty bowl.</b> Rav Ḥisda said to him: But this statement is unnecessary, <b>as</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna already <b>taught</b> the requirement to pour from one vessel into another in the <b>first</b> clause: <b>He poured the blood of the bull into the blood of the goat.</b> The subsequent phrase: He placed the full into the empty, must therefore refer to the placement of one vessel inside another. Rami bar Ḥama responded: No, it means that he pours the blood from the full bowl into the empty bowl a second time <b>in order to mix them very well.</b> To this end, he pours from one vessel into the other before again pouring the mixture back into the first vessel, thereby mixing them thoroughly.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a solution to this question: If a priest performed the Temple service while he <b>was standing on top of a vessel, or on the foot of another</b> priest, his service <b>is disqualified,</b> as the priest must stand directly on the floor of the Temple. The fact that the foot of another person is considered an interposition proves that one type serves as an interposition with regard to another object of the same type. The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>A foot is different, as he cannot nullify it.</b> The foot of another person cannot be considered nullified with respect to the priest’s foot, but in the case of a vessel it is possible to say that one vessel is nullified in favor of another vessel.
<b>Some say</b> that Rami bar Ḥama did not refer to the issue of interposition at all. Rather, <b>this is</b> the <b>dilemma he raised before</b> Rav Ḥisda: <b>Is</b> placing one vessel inside another vessel a proper <b>manner of service; or is this not</b> a proper <b>manner of service,</b> and if one does so his service is disqualified? The Gemara answers: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that <b>which the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> “And they shall take <b>all the service vessels, with which they serve in the Sanctuary”</b> (Numbers 4:12). This verse is referring to <b>two vessels and one service,</b> which indicates that this is a proper manner of service.
§ <b>Rami bar Ḥama raised</b> another <b>dilemma before Rav Ḥisda</b> along the same lines: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if <b>he placed bast,</b> the material that grows around palm trees, <b>inside the bowl, and collected the blood in</b> the bowl through the bast, such that the blood seeps through into the bowl? Does one <b>type</b> of object mixed <b>with</b> another <b>not</b> of <b>its</b> own <b>type interpose; or</b> perhaps <b>it does not interpose?</b> Could one say that <b>since the blood seeps</b> through, it therefore <b>does not interpose? Or perhaps</b> this case is <b>no different,</b> and as there is a foreign object in the vessel it is considered an interposition even if the blood seeps through.
Rav Ḥisda <b>said to him</b> in response: <b>We</b> already <b>learned</b> this matter with regard to sanctifying the purification waters, i.e., the water mixed with ashes of the red heifer. If a sponge was placed inside the container of water, the water in the sponge is disqualified and the priest may not sprinkle with it. How should he proceed? <b>He sprinkles</b> from the water <b>and continues until he reaches the sponge.</b> This shows that the presence of the sponge in the water container is not considered an interposition for the water in the container, despite the fact that it itself is unfit for the service. Rami bar Ḥama replied: This is no proof. <b>Water is different, as it is thin</b> and therefore it certainly seeps through the sponge and reaches the bowl; whereas the thicker blood will perhaps not seep into the fiber.
<b>Some say</b> that <b>this is how</b> Rav Ḥisda <b>resolved</b> the problem of placing the bast in the bowl <b>for</b> Rami bar Ḥama: In the case <b>of the blood it is valid,</b> as blood passes through, and the bast does not obstruct it. However, in the case <b>of the handful</b> of a meal-offering, which must be sanctified in a vessel immediately after the handful is taken, if he put bast in a vessel and placed the handful on top of it, <b>it is disqualified.</b> The reason is that the handful of a meal-offering consists of dough, which does not pass through the bast, and it is therefore considered a proper interposition.

Daf 58b

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> It is stated: <b>“And he shall go out to the altar that is before the Lord</b>, and make atonement for it; and he shall take of the blood of the bull, and of the blood of the goat, and place it upon the corners of the altar round about” (Leviticus 16:18). <b>This</b> altar <b>is the golden altar,</b> since the outer altar is not before the Lord in the Sanctuary. <b>He began to cleanse</b> the altar, sprinkling the blood <b>downward. From where does he begin?</b> He begins <b>from the northeast corner,</b> and proceeds to the <b>northwest</b> corner, and then to the <b>southwest</b> corner, and finally to the <b>southeast</b> corner. A way to remember this is: At the <b>place</b> where <b>he begins</b> sprinkling the blood <b>for a sin-offering</b> sacrificed <b>on the outer altar,</b> the southeast corner, <b>there he finishes</b> sprinkling the blood <b>on the inner altar.</b>
<b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The priest would not circle the altar; rather, <b>he stood in</b> one <b>place and sprinkled</b> the blood from there. Since the altar was only one square cubit, he could sprinkle the blood on all four corners without moving.
<b>And on all the corners he would present</b> the blood <b>from below upward, except for that</b> corner <b>that was</b> directly <b>before him,</b> on <b>which he would present</b> the blood <b>from above downward. He sprinkled</b> blood <b>on</b> the <b>pure</b> gold <b>of the altar seven times</b> after clearing away the ashes. <b>And he would pour the remainder of the blood on the western base of the outer altar.</b> On a related topic, the mishna teaches that <b>he would pour</b> the remaining blood of an offering, after it was sprinkled, <b>on the outer altar, on its southern base. These</b> remainders of blood from the outer altar <b>and those</b> remainders of blood from the inner altar are <b>mixed in the canal</b> beneath the altar <b>and flow out</b> with the water used to rinse the area <b>to the Kidron River.</b> This water was <b>sold to gardeners for</b> use as <b>fertilizer.</b> The gardeners paid for this water and thereby redeemed it from its sanctity. Failure to do so would render them guilty of <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught: “And he shall go out to the altar”</b> (Leviticus 16:18). <b>What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states</b> this? Upon his exit, after sprinkling toward the curtain, the High Priest must necessarily reach the golden altar. <b>Rabbi Neḥemya said:</b> It is <b>because we find with regard to the bull brought for</b> a violation of <b>all the mitzvot,</b> i.e., the bull that must be brought in the event that the community errs with regard to any of the mitzvot, which is called the bull for an unwitting communal sin, <b>that when the priest sprinkles</b> toward the curtain <b>he stands past the altar and sprinkles</b> back <b>toward the curtain;</b> therefore, one <b>might</b> have thought <b>that here, too,</b> the rite should be performed in <b>the same</b> manner.
Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And he shall go out to the altar.” Where was he</b> before? He was <b>on the inner side of the altar,</b> i.e., the western side, close to the curtain, when he sprinkled, not on the outer side of the altar.
<b>It was taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: With regard to the bull for an unwitting communal sin the verse states: “And he shall sprinkle seven times <b>before the Lord</b> in front of the curtain” (Leviticus 4:17). <b>What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states:</b> Before the Lord? <b>Rabbi Neḥemya said:</b> It is <b>because we find with regard to the bull and the goat of Yom Kippur that when he sprinkles</b> the High <b>Priest stands on the inner side of the altar,</b> close to the curtain, <b>and sprinkles toward the curtain;</b> therefore, one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>here, too,</b> in the case of the bull for an unwitting communal sin, it should be <b>the same</b> rite.
Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And the priest shall put the blood upon the corners of the <b>altar of sweet incense before the Lord, which is in the Tent of Meeting”</b> (Leviticus 4:7). This verse teaches that the <b>altar</b> is <b>before the Lord, but the priest is not before the Lord. How so?</b> The priest <b>stands on the outer side of the altar and sprinkles.</b>
§ The mishna taught: <b>He began to cleanse</b> the altar, sprinkling the blood <b>downward. The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>He began to cleanse downward. From where would he begin?</b> He would begin <b>from the southeast corner</b> of the altar, and from there he would turn to the <b>southwest</b> corner, onward to the <b>northwest</b> corner, and finally to the <b>northeast</b> corner. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva. Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says:</b> He began <b>from the northeast corner,</b> from which he turned to the <b>northwest</b> corner, then to the <b>southwest</b> corner, and finished at the <b>southeast</b> corner.
The Gemara notes: The place where the High Priest <b>begins</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili,</b> i.e., the northeast corner, <b>there</b> is where <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> says he <b>ends;</b> and the place where the High Priest <b>begins</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> the southeast corner, <b>there</b> is where <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili</b> says he <b>ends.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Everyone</b> agrees, <b>in any case,</b> that <b>he does not perform</b> the service <b>at the corner that he encounters first.</b> Since the High Priest approaches the altar from the west side, the first corner he encounters is located on the west side. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>Shmuel said:</b> The reason is <b>that the verse states: “And he shall go out to the altar,”</b> which indicates that he does not begin <b>until he goes out from</b> the sacred area beyond the <b>entire</b> area of the <b>altar.</b> At this stage, he is no longer on the western side of the altar but on its eastern side.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, let him go around via the right.</b> Since the High Priest is standing at the eastern side of the altar facing the west, the corner on his right is the northeast one. <b>Let us say</b> that <b>they disagree with regard to</b> the opinion <b>of Rami bar Yeḥezkel.</b>
<b>As Rami bar Yeḥezkel said:</b> A verse describes <b>the sea,</b> the basin <b>that Solomon built,</b> in the following terms: <b>“It stood upon twelve oxen, three looking toward the north, and three looking toward the west, and three looking toward the south, and three looking toward the east; and the sea was set upon them above, and all their hinder parts were inward”</b> (II Chronicles 4:4). From the direction in which the text lists the groups of oxen under the basin, <b>you learn that all turns that you turn should be only to the right</b> and <b>to the east</b> side. Let us say that <b>this Sage,</b> Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, <b>is of</b> the opinion that the ruling is in accordance with the opinion <b>of Rami bar Yeḥezkel, and this Sage,</b> Rabbi Akiva, <b>is of</b> the opinion that the ruling is <b>not</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rami bar Yeḥezkel.</b>
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>No, everyone is of</b> the opinion that the ruling is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rami bar Yeḥezkel, but here they disagree with regard to this</b> matter: <b>One Sage,</b> Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, <b>holds: We derive</b> the order of the rite <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary <b>from</b> the manner of the sprinkling on the <b>outside:</b> Just as the priest sprinkles on the corners of the outer altar in that order, he sprinkles similarly on the inner altar. <b>And one Sage,</b> Rabbi Akiva, <b>holds: We do not derive</b> the order of the rite <b>inside</b> of the Sanctuary <b>from</b> the rite performed <b>outside.</b>
§ The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, although he does not derive</b> the <b>inside from</b> the <b>outside,</b> nevertheless <b>if</b> the High Priest <b>wants, let him perform</b> the rite in <b>this</b> manner, and <b>if he wants, let him perform</b> the rite in <b>that</b> manner. Why must he begin specifically at the southeast corner? The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> could have <b>said to you:</b> Indeed, <b>by right he should begin</b> sprinkling <b>by that corner</b> of the altar <b>that he reaches first, as Reish Lakish said: One does not pass on</b> an opportunity to perform <b>mitzvot.</b> If one has the chance to perform a mitzva, he should not put it off for later but should do it immediately.
<b>And why does he not do</b> so; why does the High Priest not begin the sprinkling on one of the western corners? This is <b>due to</b> that <b>which is written: “He shall go out to the altar,”</b> meaning that he does not begin <b>until he goes out from</b> the area of the <b>entire altar. And since he presents</b> the blood <b>at that corner</b> on the outside of the altar, <b>he then comes to that corner</b> on the west side <b>where he should have presented</b> the blood <b>first.</b>

Daf 59a

<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>If we hold</b> that the <b>encircling</b> is performed <b>by foot,</b> i.e., the priest walks around the inner altar, <b>everyone agrees that we learn</b> the method of sprinkling <b>inside</b> from the sprinkling <b>outside. And here they disagree about this</b> matter: <b>One Sage,</b> Rabbi Akiva, <b>holds</b> that the priest stands in his place and sprinkles on all the corners from there, which means his <b>encircling</b> is performed <b>by hand; and one Sage,</b> Rabbi Yosei, <b>holds</b> that the <b>encircling</b> is done <b>by foot.</b>
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>Everyone</b> agrees that <b>the encircling</b> was performed <b>by hand, and here they disagree about this</b> matter: <b>One Sage,</b> Rabbi Yosei, <b>holds</b> that <b>we derive</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of an encircling performed by <b>hand from</b> those of an encircling by <b>foot,</b> and therefore the ritual of the inner altar is the same as that of the outer altar. <b>And one Sage,</b> Rabbi Akiva, <b>holds that we do not derive</b> the encircling performed by hand from the encircling done by foot.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>And does Rabbi Yosei HaGelili hold</b> that <b>the encircling</b> is performed <b>by hand? But from</b> the fact <b>that it is taught</b> in <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: He stood in</b> one <b>place and sprinkled</b> the blood from there, it can be learned <b>by inference</b> that <b>the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> whom the Gemara identified as Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, <b>does not maintain</b> that the rite is performed in this manner. <b>Rather, it is clear as we originally answered,</b> that <b>one Sage,</b> Rabbi Akiva, <b>holds</b> that the <b>encircling</b> is performed <b>by hand; and one Sage,</b> Rabbi Yosei, <b>holds</b> that the <b>encircling</b> is performed <b>by foot.</b>
