<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>they disagree about this</b> matter: <b>One Sage,</b> Rabbi Akiva, <b>holds</b> that the <b>perimeter of</b> the <b>inner altar is like the perimeter of</b> the <b>outer altar, and one Sage,</b> Rabbi Yosei, <b>holds</b> that the <b>entire inner altar stands in place of one corner of</b> the <b>outer altar.</b> Since the entire inner altar is only one cubit by one cubit, like a single corner of the outer altar, the <i>halakhot</i> of the outer altar are not relevant to the inner altar.
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yishmael said: Two High Priests remained from</b> the days of <b>the First Temple. This one says: I encircled by hand</b> and sprinkled, and I did not encircle the perimeter of the inner altar by foot. <b>And that one says: I encircled by foot. This one gave a reason for his statement, and that one gave a reason for his statement.</b>
<b>The one</b> who said that he encircled by foot <b>gave</b> the following <b>reason for his statement: The perimeter of the inner altar</b> is <b>like the perimeter of the outer altar,</b> which is encircled by foot for sprinkling. <b>And the one</b> who said that he encircled by hand <b>gave</b> the following <b>reason for his statement:</b> The <b>entire inner altar stands in place of one corner of</b> the <b>outer</b> altar. Just as for one corner of the outer altar, the priest sprinkles the blood by hand, the same applies to the entire inner altar.
§ It was taught in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: He stood in</b> one <b>place and sprinkled</b> the blood from there. The Gemara asks: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is <b>the mishna?</b> The Gemara answers: The mishna <b>is</b> taught in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who explained Rabbi Eliezer’s ruling in the following manner. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, later <i>tanna’im</i> disagreed with regard to the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer. <b>Rabbi Meir says</b> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says</b> as follows: <b>He stood in</b> one <b>place and sprinkled, and on all</b> of the corners <b>he presented</b> the blood <b>from above downward,</b> so as not to drip blood down the sleeve of his garment, <b>except for that</b> corner <b>on the diagonal [<i>alakhson</i>]</b> across from him. Since it was difficult for him to sprinkle on that corner from top to bottom, <b>he sprinkled from below upward.</b>
Conversely, <b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: He stood in</b> one <b>place and sprinkled, and on all of</b> the corners <b>he sprinkled from below upward,</b> as it is more convenient to sprinkle in that manner, <b>except for that one which was directly before him, on which he would present from above downward.</b> The reason is <b>so as not to dirty his garments</b> with blood. If he sprinkled on the corner next to him from below upward, the blood might fall on his clothes, and he would have to change garments, as dirty priestly garments may not be worn for the Temple service.
§ The mishna taught: <b>He sprinkled</b> blood <b>on</b> the <b>pure</b> gold <b>[<i>tohoro</i>] of the altar.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the term <b><i>tohoro</i>? Rabba bar Rav Sheila said:</b> It means <b>half</b> of the <b>altar, as people</b> commonly <b>say: <i>Tehar tihara</i>,</b> the light of noon shines <b>and it is the middle of the day.</b> Here, too, <i>tohoro</i> of the altar means half the altar, i.e., he sprinkled on the midpoint of the altar wall.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection: When he sprinkles</b> on the inner altar, <b>he sprinkles neither on top of the ash nor on top of the coals; rather, he rakes</b> and removes <b>the coals to both sides and sprinkles.</b> This indicates that this sprinkling was performed on top of the altar, not on its side. <b>Rather, Rabba bar Rav Sheila</b> retracted his previous interpretation and said: On <i>tohoro</i> of the altar means <b>on the exposed</b> area <b>of</b> the <b>altar, as it is written: “And the like of the very heaven for clearness [<i>letohar</i>]”</b> (Exodus 24:10), which shows that <i>tohar</i> is an expression of clarity.
§ <b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Ḥananya says:</b> The priest <b>presents</b> seven sprinklings <b>on the north side</b> of the altar, and <b>Rabbi Yosei says: He presents</b> them <b>on the south side.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle do <b>they disagree?</b> The Gemara explains: <b>One Sage,</b> Ḥananya, <b>holds</b> that <b>the entrance</b> was <b>positioned in the south,</b> and therefore the High Priest begins the sprinklings from that side. <b>And one Sage,</b> Rabbi Yosei, <b>holds</b> that <b>the entrance</b> was <b>positioned in the north,</b> and he therefore begins to sprinkle on the altar from the north side.
The Gemara comments: <b>Everyone</b> agrees <b>in any case</b> that in the place <b>where he finishes the presentations</b> of the <b>corners, that</b> is <b>where he places</b> the blood <b>on</b> the altar’s <b>top.</b> They disagree only about the location of the final presentation, whether it is on the south or the north side. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this agreement? The Gemara answers that <b>the verse states:</b> “And he shall sprinkle of the blood upon it with his finger seven times, <b>and cleanse it and sanctify it”</b> (Leviticus 16:19), which indicates that the <b>place he sanctified</b> by sprinkling blood, the corner of the altar where he sprinkled last, <b>there he shall</b> also begin to <b>cleanse</b> and sprinkle on top.
§ The mishna taught: <b>And he would pour the remainder of the blood on the western base of the outer altar.</b> The Gemara explains: The reason is <b>that the verse states</b> with regard to the sin-offering bull of the High Priest during the rest of the year: <b>“And he shall pour out all the blood of the bull</b> at the base of the altar of burnt-offering, which is at the door of the Tent of Meeting” (Leviticus 4:7), <b>and when he goes out</b> from the Sanctuary to pour the remainder of the blood, <b>he first reaches that</b> western side of the base of the altar.
§ The mishna further taught: <b>And he would pour</b> the remaining blood after the blood of an offering was sprinkled <b>on the outer altar, on its southern base. The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“The base of the altar”</b> (Leviticus 4:30), which is mentioned with regard to pouring the remainder of the blood of an individual offering, <b>is the southern base.</b> Do <b>you say</b> it is <b>the southern base? Or perhaps that is not</b> the case, but <b>rather</b> it is <b>the western base?</b>
<b>You said: Let his descent from the ramp</b> of the outer altar after sprinkling blood from the sin-offerings <b>be derived from his exit from the Sanctuary</b> with the remaining blood in his hand: <b>Just as</b> upon <b>his exit from the Sanctuary</b> he pours the remainder of the blood <b>on</b> the side <b>closest to him, and which is that, it is the western base; so too,</b> upon <b>his descent from the ramp</b> of the outer altar after sprinkling blood from a sin-offering, he pours the blood <b>on</b> the side <b>closest to him, and which is that? It is the southern base,</b> as when he descends from the ramp he turns to the right, i.e., the east, which means the southern base is the one closest to him.
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yishmael says:</b> Both <b>this and that,</b> the blood of an inner sin-offering and that of an outer sin-offering, were spilled at <b>the western base</b> of the altar. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai says:</b> Both <b>this and that</b> blood were spilled at <b>the southern base.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, Rabbi Yishmael maintains</b> that the <i>halakha</i> of outer sin-offerings, which is <b>not clarified</b> in the Torah, <b>is derived from</b> the inner sin-offerings, whose <i>halakha</i> is <b>explicit:</b> Just as the remains of the inner sprinklings are poured at the western base, so too, the remains of the outer sprinklings are poured at the western base.
<b>However,</b> with regard to <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai, what is the reason</b> that he holds that both sets of remainders of blood are spilled at the southern base? <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai <b>maintains</b> that the <b>entrance</b> of the Sanctuary <b>is positioned at the south</b> side of the altar, i.e., the altar is not located in the middle of the courtyard but to the north. Consequently, the southern base of the altar is closest to the High Priest’s exit from the Sanctuary.
<b>The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught</b> a different version of his opinion, which they learned <b>in the school of Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai:</b> Both <b>this and that,</b> the blood of an inner sin-offering and that of an outer sin-offering, were presented at <b>the southern base.</b> According to this version, Rabbi Yishmael changed his opinion and agreed with Rabbi Shimon. The Gemara comments: <b>And your mnemonic</b> to remember the shift in opinion is: <b>The men pulled the man,</b> i.e., the majority overruled the individual. In this case, the numerous students of Rabbi Shimon convinced the individual Sage, Rabbi Yishmael, to accept their ruling.
§ It was taught in the mishna: <b>These</b> remainders of blood from the outer altar <b>and those</b> remainders of blood from the inner altar are <b>mixed in the canal</b> beneath the altar <b>and flow out</b> with the water used to rinse the area to the Kidron River, where they are sold to gardeners. Any blood that was not redeemed was subject to the prohibition against misuse of consecrated property. <b>The Sages taught:</b> One who takes these remainders without redeeming them <b>misuses</b> property consecrated in the Temple <b>by</b> unlawfully using <b>blood,</b> which is consecrated and is Temple property. It is prohibited to use consecrated objects for mundane purposes, and one who does so is committing the sin of misusing consecrated property. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Shimon. And the Rabbis say:</b> One does <b>not misuse</b> consecrated property <b>by</b> benefiting from <b>these</b> remainders of the blood of offerings.

Daf 59b

The Gemara comments: The Rabbis <b>disagree only with regard to</b> misuse of consecrated property that applies <b>by rabbinic law,</b> as it was the Sages who prohibited the use of blood; <b>however,</b> everyone agrees that <b>by Torah law</b> one does <b>not misuse</b> consecrated property <b>by</b> benefiting from <b>these</b> remainders of blood. Clearly, the Temple treasurers would not have sold it to gardeners <i>ab initio</i> had the Torah prohibited the use of this blood (<i>Tosafot</i>).
The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters,</b> that there is no misuse for blood, derived? <b>Ulla said</b> that <b>the verse states:</b> “For the life of the flesh is in the blood, and I have given it <b>to you</b> upon the altar to make atonement for your souls” (Leviticus 17:11). “To you” indicates that <b>it shall be yours.</b> It is not the property of the Temple; rather, it belongs to all of the Jewish people. <b>The school</b> of <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> likewise <b>taught</b> that the phrase <b>“to make atonement”</b> teaches that God says: <b>I gave it for atonement and not for</b> the prohibition against <b>misuse</b> of consecrated objects.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that this <i>halakha</i> is derived from a different phrase. <b>The verse states:</b> “For <b>it is</b> the blood that makes atonement by reason of the life” (Leviticus 17:11), which indicates that it retains the same status <b>before atonement as after atonement: Just as after atonement</b> it is <b>not subject to</b> the prohibition against <b>misuse</b> of consecrated objects, as the mitzva has been performed, <b>so too, before atonement it is not subject to misuse</b> of consecrated objects. As the Gemara states below, there is a general principle that once the mitzva involving a certain object has been performed, the object is no longer subject to misuse of consecrated objects.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if the status of blood before atonement is compared to its status after atonement, one can <b>say</b> the opposite: <b>Just as before atonement it is subject to misuse</b> of consecrated objects, <b>so too, after atonement it is subject to misuse</b> of consecrated objects. The Gemara rejects this contention: This cannot be the case, as there is a general principle: <b>There is nothing whose mitzva has been performed that is</b> still <b>subject to misuse</b> of consecrated property. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is there <b>no</b> such case? <b>But there is</b> the instance of the <b>removal of the ashes</b> of offerings burned on the altar. These ashes require burial, and yet any benefit derived from them is misuse of consecrated property, despite the fact that their mitzva has already been performed.

Daf 60a

The Gemara answers: The reason is <b>because</b> the mitzva of <b>the removal of the ashes and the priestly vestments,</b> the four white garments worn by the High Priest on Yom Kippur, are both subject to the special <i>halakha</i> that misuse of consecrated objects applies to them even after their mitzva has been performed. Consequently, they are <b>two verses that come as one,</b> i.e., they share a unique <i>halakha</i> not found elsewhere. <b>And</b> there is a principle: <b>Any two verses that come as one do not teach,</b> i.e., an analogy may not be derived from these two similar cases. Instead, they are considered exceptional instances that cannot serve as models for other cases.
The Gemara raises a further difficulty: <b>This</b> works out <b>well</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, who say</b> that the verse: “And he shall take off the linen garments, which he wore when he went into the sacred place, <b>and shall leave them there”</b> (Leviticus 16:23), <b>teaches that</b> the four white garments worn by the High Priest on Yom Kippur are not fit for further use, and <b>they require interment.</b>
<b>However,</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Dosa, who said</b> that these <b>priestly vestments are fit for a common priest</b> and do not require interment, one does not misuse consecrated property by using them, and therefore <b>what is there to say?</b> In his opinion, the <i>halakha</i> of misuse of consecrated objects after the performance of a mitzva applies only to the removal of ashes from the altar, not to the priestly vestments, which means it is stated in only a single case. Why, then, does this case not serve as a model for other instances in the Torah?
The Gemara responds: The reason is <b>because</b> the cases of the <b>removal of the ashes and the heifer whose neck is broken are two verses that come as one,</b> as it is prohibited to derive benefit from either of them even after their mitzva is completed, <b>and any two verses that come as one do not teach</b> their common feature to other cases. The heifer whose neck is broken is a ritual performed when a murder victim’s body is found outside a town, and it is not known who caused his death.
The Gemara challenges this reply from a different angle: <b>It works out well according to the one who said</b> that two verses that come as one <b>do not teach</b> their common feature to other cases, <b>but according to the one who says that two verses that come as one</b> do <b>teach</b> with regard to other cases, <b>what is there to say?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Two exclusions are written</b> in these two cases, which indicate that this <i>halakha</i> applies to them alone. With respect to the removal of ashes, it states: <b>“And he shall put it”</b> (Leviticus 6:3), implying “it” and nothing else. With regard to the heifer whose neck is broken, it is written: <b>“Whose neck was broken”</b> (Deuteronomy 21:6), which teaches that this <i>halakha</i> applies solely to this case.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> if this <i>halakha</i> is derived from those two cases, <b>why do I</b> need <b>these three verses</b> stated <b>with regard to blood,</b> from which it is derived that the prohibition against misuse of consecrated objects does not apply to the remainder of blood that flows to the Kidron River? The reference is to the three phrases singled out above from the verse: “I have given it to you upon the altar to make atonement for your souls, for it is the blood that makes atonement by reason of the life” (Leviticus 17:11).
The Gemara answers: <b>One</b> of those phrases comes <b>to exclude</b> the blood from the prohibition of <b><i>notar</i>,</b> offerings that remain after the time when they may be eaten has expired. If one ate leftover blood, he is not punished with <i>karet</i>, as generally incurred by one who consumes <i>notar</i>. Rather, he is liable only for violating the prohibition against eating blood. <b>And one</b> phrase comes <b>to exclude</b> it <b>from</b> the prohibition against <b>misuse</b> of consecrated objects, <b>and one</b> other phrase comes <b>to exclude</b> it <b>from ritual impurity.</b> If one ate this blood in a state of ritual impurity, he is liable only for the transgression of eating blood, but not on account of eating consecrated food while ritually impure.
<b>However, no verse is required to exclude</b> this blood <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> an offering disqualified by improper intention, because this is already derived from another source, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>any</b> offering <b>that has</b> another rite that <b>permits it,</b> e.g., an offering that is permitted by the sprinkling of blood or by means of a second offering, <b>one is liable to</b> receive <i>karet</i> if he eats it after it is rendered <b><i>piggul</i>.</b> This is the case <b>whether</b> the other rite permits it <b>for human</b> consumption <b>or whether</b> it enables the offering to be sacrificed <b>on the altar.</b> However, the permitting factor itself is not subject to <i>piggul</i>. Consequently, <i>piggul</i> does not apply to <b>blood itself,</b> as it renders the offering <b>permitted</b> for human consumption or for the altar.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Each action</b> performed in the context of the service <b>of Yom Kippur stated</b> in the mishna, as in the Torah, is listed <b>in order. If</b> the High Priest <b>performed</b> one of the <b>actions before another, he has done nothing.</b> If <b>he performed</b> the sprinkling of <b>the blood of the goat before</b> the sprinkling of <b>the blood of the bull, he</b> must <b>repeat</b> the action <b>and sprinkle the blood of the goat after</b> sprinkling <b>the blood of the bull,</b> so that the actions are performed in the proper order. <b>And if the blood spills before he completed the presentations that</b> were sprinkled <b>inside</b> the Holy of Holies, <b>he</b> must slaughter another bull or goat, and <b>bring other blood, and</b> then <b>repeat</b> all the services <b>from the beginning inside</b> the Holy of Holies.
<b>And similarly,</b> if the blood spills before he finishes the presentations <b>in the Sanctuary,</b> he must begin the service in the Sanctuary from the beginning, <b>and likewise</b> with regard to the sprinkling of blood <b>on the golden altar. Since they are each</b> acts of <b>atonement in and of themselves,</b> there is no need to repeat the service of the entire day from the beginning. Rather, he need only repeat the specific element that he failed to complete. <b>Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon say: From the place that he interrupted</b> that particular service, when the blood spilled, <b>there he resumes</b> performance of that service. In their opinion, each individual sprinkling in each of these services is an act in and of itself, and there is no need to repeat what he has already done.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught: Each action</b> performed in the context of the service <b>of Yom Kippur stated</b> in the Torah is listed <b>in order. If</b> the High Priest <b>performed</b> one of the <b>actions before another, he has done nothing. Rabbi Yehuda said: When</b> does this apply? It applies <b>to those actions performed in white garments inside</b> the Sanctuary, e.g., burning the incense and sprinkling the blood, which are the essential services of the day. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>those actions performed in white garments outside,</b> such as the lottery and the confession, <b>if he performed</b> one <b>action before another, what he did is done</b> and he need not repeat the rite.
In contrast, <b>Rabbi Neḥemya says: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said,</b> that the order is indispensable? It is said with regard <b>to actions performed in white garments, whether inside or outside</b> the Sanctuary. <b>However,</b> with regard <b>to</b> those <b>actions performed in golden garments outside</b> the Sanctuary, the regular Temple service and additional services, if the order was altered, <b>what he did is done. Rabbi Yoḥanan said: And both of them,</b> Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Neḥemya, <b>derived</b> their opinions <b>from one verse: “And this shall be an everlasting statute to you,</b> to make atonement for the children of Israel for all their sins <b>once a year”</b> (Leviticus 16:34).

Daf 60b

<b>Rabbi Yehuda maintains</b> that this is referring to the <b>place where atonement is achieved once a year,</b> namely the Holy of Holies. In his opinion, the order of actions is indispensable for the services performed in the Holy of Holies. <b>And Rabbi Neḥemya maintains</b> that the verse is referring to <b>the actions through which atonement is achieved once a year,</b> meaning both the place and the garments. Consequently, in the opinion of Rabbi Neḥemya, the order for all actions performed in white clothes is indispensable.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say</b> that according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> the word <b>place</b> is <b>written?</b> The verse merely states “once a year,” which apparently is referring to the order of the service in general but not to a specific place. <b>Rather,</b> the Gemara retracts the previous explanation in favor of the following: <b>This is the reasoning of Rabbi Yehuda: It is written: “This”</b> (Leviticus 16:34), which is a term of restriction and limitation, <b>and it is written: “Once</b> a year” (Leviticus 16:34), another term of restriction. <b>One</b> restriction comes <b>to exclude</b> actions performed <b>in</b> the <b>white garments outside</b> the Sanctuary, meaning that they are not indispensable; <b>and one</b> restriction comes <b>to exclude</b> actions performed <b>in</b> the <b>gold garments.</b>
<b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Neḥemya</b> interpret these two restricting expressions? In his opinion, <b>one</b> of the restrictions comes <b>to exclude</b> actions performed in the <b>gold garments, and one</b> restriction comes <b>to exclude</b> the <b>remainders</b> of blood that are poured at the base of the altar, meaning <b>that</b> these <b>are not indispensable.</b> If the High Priest performed a service that is supposed to come after the spilling of the blood too early, the service is valid, despite the fact that the spilling of the blood is performed in white garments. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what does <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> maintain with regard to the remainders of blood? The Gemara answers: In his opinion, <b>if</b> the other actions performed outside are <b>indispensable,</b> this too is <b>indispensable; and if</b> the other acts performed outside are <b>not indispensable,</b> the remainders are <b>not indispensable</b> either. The pouring of the remainders of blood is no different from the sprinkling of blood in this regard.
In proof that Rabbi Yehuda maintains that pouring the remainders of blood is no different from the sprinkling of blood, the Gemara cites a <i>baraita</i> that is referring to a case where the pouring of the remainders of the blood is entirely omitted. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“And when he has finished atoning for the sacred place”</b> (Leviticus 16:20). This verse indicates that <b>if he performed the atonement, he has finished</b> the order of the service; <b>and if he did not perform the atonement, he has not finished.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva. Rabbi Yehuda said to him: Why do we not say</b> that <b>if he finished</b> sprinkling all the blood, <b>he has performed atonement; and if he did not finish, he has not performed atonement?</b> This would indicate <b>that if one of the presentations is lacking</b> it is as though <b>he did nothing.</b>
<b>And we say</b> in this regard: <b>What</b> is the practical difference <b>between them? Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi</b> debated this point. <b>One</b> of them <b>said: There is</b> a difference <b>between them</b> with regard to <b>the source from which they derive their interpretation,</b> i.e., there is no halakhic difference between them but only a dispute as to how to interpret the verses. <b>And</b> the other <b>one said: There is</b> a difference <b>between them</b> with respect to whether pouring the <b>remainders</b> of blood at the base of the altar is <b>indispensable</b> to the atonement. According to Rabbi Akiva, it is not indispensable, whereas Rabbi Yehuda maintains that it is indispensable.
The Gemara asks: <b>And did Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> actually <b>say this,</b> that in Rabbi Neḥemya’s opinion pouring the remainders of blood is not indispensable? <b>But didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> himself <b>say</b> in tractate <i>Zevaḥim</i> (111a): <b>Rabbi Neḥemya taught in accordance with the statement of the one who said that</b> the <b>remainders</b> of blood <b>are indispensable?</b> The Gemara comments: Indeed, this is <b>difficult.</b>
§ <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said:</b> With regard to <b>incense that</b> the High Priest <b>scooped before the slaughtering of the bull,</b> it is as though <b>he did nothing.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>In accordance with</b> whose opinion is this statement? <b>It is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda. As, if</b> you say it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, didn’t</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>say</b> that <b>when it is written “statute”</b> (Leviticus 16:34), a term that indicates that no details may be altered, <b>it is written</b> with regard <b>to actions performed in white garments within</b> the Sanctuary, whereas scooping incense is done outside?
The Gemara rejects this claim: <b>Even</b> if <b>you say</b> that Rabbi Ḥanina holds in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> it is possible that in his opinion scooping the incense <b>for the purpose of</b> it being taken <b>inside is considered like</b> an action actually performed <b>inside.</b> The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna that <b>if the blood spills before</b> the High Priest <b>completed the presentations that</b> were sprinkled <b>inside</b> the Holy of Holies, <b>he</b> must slaughter another bull or goat, <b>bring other blood, and</b> then <b>sprinkle again from the beginning inside. And if it is so,</b> that an action performed outside the Sanctuary for the purpose of a service inside the Sanctuary is considered like an action actually performed inside, merely slaughtering the bull and sprinkling the blood again should be insufficient. Instead, the mishna <b>should have said</b> that <b>he must return and scoop</b> the incense anew. The fact that the mishna did not say this proves that the order of scooping the incense is not indispensable.

Daf 61a

The Gemara answers that this is no proof, as <b>he is not dealing with the incense.</b> In practice, the High Priest must indeed go back and scoop new incense after slaughtering the bull. The mishna did not mention this detail because it is discussing the issue of the sprinkling of blood, not the incense service.
§ <b>Ulla said:</b> With regard to <b>a goat that he slaughtered before presentation of the blood of the bull,</b> it is as though <b>he did nothing.</b> The Gemara asks: But <b>we learned</b> in the mishna that if <b>he performed</b> the sprinkling of <b>the blood of the goat before</b> the sprinkling of <b>the blood of the bull, he</b> must <b>repeat</b> the action <b>and sprinkle the blood of the goat after</b> sprinkling <b>the blood of the bull. And if it is so</b> that Ulla is correct, the mishna <b>should have said</b> that <b>he must return and slaughter</b> another bull. The Gemara answers: <b>Ulla interpreted</b> the mishna as referring only <b>to the presentations in the Sanctuary</b> that were performed out of order. However, it is essential that the presentations in the Holy of Holies must be performed before the slaughter of the goat. <b>And likewise, Rabbi Afes said</b> that the mishna is referring <b>to the presentations in the Sanctuary.</b>
§ The mishna states: <b>And similarly in the Sanctuary, and likewise on the golden altar,</b> if the blood spills he must go back and begin that cycle of sprinklings afresh. <b>The Sages taught:</b> “And he shall make atonement for the most sacred place, and he shall make atonement for the Tent of Meeting and for the altar; and he shall make atonement for the priests and for all the people of the assembly” (Leviticus 16:33). <b>“And he shall make atonement for the most sacred place,” this is the innermost sanctum,</b> the Holy of Holies; <b>“the Tent of Meeting,” this is the Sanctuary; “altar”</b> is meant <b>as per its plain meaning; “he shall make atonement,” is</b> referring to the second mention of this phrase in the verse, <b>these are the courtyards.</b>
<b>“The priests”</b> is meant <b>as per its plain meaning; “people of the assembly,” these are the Israelites; “he shall make atonement,” these are the Levites,</b> who also gain atonement. <b>They are all equated</b> in this verse <b>in</b> that they achieve <b>one atonement</b> in this verse, which indicates <b>that they all achieve atonement through the scapegoat</b> for all <b>other transgressions,</b> apart from the ritual impurity of the Temple and consecrated objects, i.e., entering the Temple or eating consecrated food while ritually impure. The bull presented inside atones only for the priests, while the goats atone solely for Israelites. Only the scapegoat atones equally for all Jews. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shimon says: Just as the blood of the goat presented inside atones for Israelites</b> who sinned <b>with the ritual impurity of the Temple and its consecrated objects, so too, the blood of the</b> High Priest’s <b>bull atones for the priests</b> who sinned <b>with the ritual impurity of the Temple and its consecrated objects. And just as the confession over the scapegoat atones for Israelites with regard to all other transgressions, so too, the confession over the bull atones for the priests with regard to all other transgressions,</b> and therefore the priests do not require atonement through the scapegoat.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i>: “And when he has finished atoning for the sacred place, and the Tent of Meeting, and the altar, he shall present the live goat” (Leviticus 16:20). <b>“And when he has finished atoning for the sacred place,” this is</b> the sprinklings in <b>the innermost sanctum,</b> the Holy of Holies; <b>“Tent of Meeting,” this is the</b> sprinklings toward the curtain in the <b>Sanctuary; “altar,” as per its plain meaning.</b> This <b>teaches that they each</b> constitute <b>a separate atonement unto themselves,</b> i.e., each one of these actions achieves a distinct atonement. If a disqualification occurs in any of the atoning actions, he must return to the beginning of that action.
<b>From here</b> the Sages <b>stated:</b> If the High Priest <b>presented some of the presentations inside</b> the Holy of Holies <b>and</b> then <b>the blood spilled, he brings other blood and begins from the start of the presentations inside. Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon say:</b> He need not start the cycle of sprinklings again; rather, <b>he begins only from the place where he stopped.</b> If <b>he finished the presentations inside and</b> then <b>the blood spilled, he brings other blood and starts at the beginning of the presentations in the Sanctuary.</b> However, he does not begin the presentations inside anew, as he has already sprinkled all the required blood inside, and that stage of the service is complete.
If <b>he presented some of the presentations in the Sanctuary and the blood spilled, he brings other blood and begins</b> again <b>from the start in the Sanctuary,</b> as he has not yet completed all the sprinklings in the Sanctuary. <b>Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon say: He begins only from the place where he stopped.</b>
If <b>he finished the presentations in the Sanctuary and the blood spilled, he brings other blood and begins at the start of the presentations at the altar,</b> as he has already achieved the atonement of the sprinklings in the Sanctuary. If <b>he presented some of the presentations at the altar and the blood spilled, he brings other blood and begins at the start of the presentations at the altar,</b> as the atonement of the altar has yet not been completed. In this case, too, <b>Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon say</b> that <b>he begins from the place where he stopped.</b> If <b>he finished the presentations at the altar and the blood spilled</b> before he poured the remainder of the blood at the base of the outer altar, <b>everyone agrees</b> that the remainders <b>are not indispensable,</b> and he need not slaughter another offering for this mitzva.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: And both of them,</b> meaning the first <i>tanna</i>, i.e., Rabbi Meir, the accepted author of unattributed <i>mishnayot</i>, Rabbi Elazar, and Rabbi Shimon, <b>derived</b> their opinions <b>from one verse:</b> “And Aaron shall make atonement upon its corners once a year; <b>with the blood of the sin-offering of atonement once a year</b> he shall make atonement for it throughout your generations; it is most sacred to the Lord” (Exodus 30:10).
Rabbi Yoḥanan elaborates: <b>Rabbi Meir holds</b> that God said: <b>I said to you</b> to bring <b>one sin-offering and not two sin-offerings.</b> In other words, the High Priest may not sprinkle the blood of two offerings on the inner altar. Consequently, if the blood of the sin-offering spilled in the middle of the rite, he may not complete the presentation with the blood of another animal; rather, he must slaughter new offerings so that he can present all the sprinklings at the altar from one sin-offering. <b>Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon hold</b> that God said: <b>I said to you</b> to perform <b>one sprinkling and not two sprinklings.</b> If he already sprinkled once, the High Priest need not sprinkle again, and if the blood spilled in the middle, the rite is completed with the blood of another offering.
§ <b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: Rabbi Ya’akov differentiated for me</b> with respect <b>to <i>lugin</i>.</b> In other words, Rabbi Ya’akov said that although Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon disagree with Rabbi Meir with respect to the sprinkling on Yom Kippur, maintaining that the High Priest restarts from where he stopped, if some of the oil from the <i>log</i> used for purifying the leper spills in the middle of the sprinkling, these <i>tanna’im</i> do not disagree that the priest must start that rite afresh.
The Gemara expresses surprise at this claim: <b>And</b> do they <b>not</b> disagree with regard to this issue as well? <b>But wasn’t it taught</b> explicitly in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>he presented some of the presentations</b> of oil <b>that</b> he sprinkles <b>inside</b> the Temple <b>and the <i>log</i> spilled, he brings another <i>log</i> and begins from the start of the presentations in the Sanctuary;</b> and <b>Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon say: He begins from the place where he stopped.</b>
Likewise, if <b>he finished the presentations in the Sanctuary and the <i>log</i> spilled, he brings another <i>log</i> and begins from the start of the presentations</b> that he puts on <b>the thumbs</b> of the leper. If <b>he put some of the presentations on</b> the leper’s <b>thumbs and the <i>log</i> spilled, he brings another <i>log</i> and begins from the start of the presentations on</b> his <b>thumbs. Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon say: He begins from the place where he stopped.</b> If <b>he finished the presentations on his thumbs and the <i>log</i> spilled, everyone agrees</b> that <b>the presentations on the head are not indispensable.</b> This <i>baraita</i> proves that Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon also disagree with Rabbi Meir with regard to the purifying oil of the leper.
The Gemara answers: Rather, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s statement must be amended, as one should <b>say: Rabbi Ya’akov taught me</b> this dispute <b>with regard to <i>lugin</i>.</b> Just as there is a dispute with regard to spilled blood during the presentations on Yom Kippur, Rabbi Ya’akov taught that a similar dispute applies to the leper’s <i>log</i> of oil.
The Gemara analyzes this issue: <b>The Master said</b> above that everyone agrees that the <b>presentations of</b> oil placed on <b>the head</b> of the leper <b>are not indispensable.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>If we say</b> it is <b>because it is written: “And the rest of the oil</b> that is in the priest’s hand he shall put upon the head of him that is to be purified, to make atonement for him before the Lord” (Leviticus 14:29), which indicates that this presentation involves only the rest of the oil and is therefore not an essential element of atonement, <b>however, if</b> that is <b>so,</b> consider the verse: <b>“But the rest of the meal-offering</b> shall be for Aharon and his sons; it is one of the sacred offerings of the Lord by fire” (Leviticus 2:3). Should we say, <b>so too, that they are not indispensable?</b> This cannot be the case, as the <i>halakha</i> is that if the remnants of the meal-offering are lost before the handful is burnt, the owner of the offering must bring another handful.
The Gemara answers: <b>It is different there,</b> with regard to the leper’s <i>log</i> of oil, <b>as it is written</b> earlier: <b>“And of the rest</b> of the oil that is in his hand, the priest shall put upon the tip of the right ear of him that is to be purified, and upon the thumb of his right hand, and upon the big toe of his right foot” (Leviticus 14:17), and it is also written: <b>“And of the rest</b> of the oil that is in the priest’s hand, he shall put upon the head of him that is to be purified” (Leviticus 14:18). This shows that the presentation on the head is performed only with the remainder of the oil, and therefore this action is certainly not indispensable.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b>

Daf 61b

With regard to <b>a leper’s guilt-offering that was slaughtered not for its own sake</b> but for the purpose of a burnt-offering or peace-offering, <b>we have arrived at the dispute between Rabbi Meir</b> on the one hand <b>and Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon</b> on the other hand. Rabbi Yoḥanan clarifies his statement: According to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who said</b> that in the case of a service that was not completed <b>he brings another</b> animal <b>and starts from the beginning, here too,</b> in the case of the leper’s guilt-offering, <b>he brings another</b> animal <b>and slaughters</b> it, as Rabbi Meir maintains that a service that has not been completed is considered as though it had not been performed at all.
<b>And</b> according to the opinion <b>of Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon, who say</b> that <b>he begins from the place where he stopped, here he has no remedy.</b> According to their opinion, a service that has not been completed properly remains valid. In this case, once he has slaughtered the animal he cannot bring a second guilt-offering, as the verse states: “And offer it for a guilt-offering” (Leviticus 14:12), and not two guilt-offerings.
<b>Rav Ḥisda strongly objects to this: But isn’t it written:</b> “And offer <b>it</b> for a guilt-offering” (Leviticus 14:12), which indicates that he must offer that same guilt-offering he waved earlier, and if he does not do so the rite is invalid? If so, even according to the opinion of Rabbi Meir, he cannot use another offering. The Gemara comments: Indeed, this is <b>difficult</b> for Rabbi Yoḥanan.
Even so, it <b>was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> With regard to <b>a leper’s guilt-offering that</b> the priest <b>slaughtered not for its own sake, or</b> if the priest <b>did not put some of its blood on</b> the leper’s <b>thumbs, this</b> guilt-offering <b>is raised</b> and sacrificed <b>on the altar and requires libations</b> as though it were valid. <b>And</b> yet the leper <b>must</b> bring <b>another guilt-offering to make him eligible,</b> i.e., pure of his leprosy. Evidently, there is an opinion that he may offer another guilt-offering, which apparently contradicts the opinion of Rav Ḥisda that everyone agrees that he cannot use another offering. <b>And Rav Ḥisda</b> could have <b>said to you: What</b> is the meaning of the term: <b>Must,</b> stated here? It means that <b>he must</b> do so, <b>but</b> since it is impossible <b>he has no remedy.</b>
The Gemara expresses surprise at this contention: <b>But would a <i>tanna</i> teach: Must,</b> when he means that <b>he has no remedy?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, and</b> indeed <b>it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to a totally <b>bald nazirite,</b> who cannot shave his hair with a razor as required, <b>Beit Shammai say: He must</b> perform the act of <b>the passing of a razor</b> anyway, <b>and Beit Hillel say: He need not</b> perform the act of <b>the passing of a razor. And Rabbi Avina said</b> that <b>when Beit Shammai say: Must,</b> they mean <b>he must</b> do so, but since it is impossible, <b>he has no remedy.</b>
The Gemara comments: And Rabbi Avina, in his interpretation of this matter, <b>disagrees with Rabbi Pedat. As Rabbi Pedat said: Beit Shammai and Rabbi Elazar said the same thing,</b> i.e., they have the same opinion in this regard. The opinion of <b>Beit Shammai</b> is <b>that which we said,</b> that a bald nazirite must pass a razor over his head. The opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar</b> is <b>as it was taught</b> in a mishna: A leper who <b>has no thumb or big toe</b> on which to sprinkle can <b>never</b> attain <b>ritual purity. Rabbi Elazar says:</b> The priest <b>puts it on the spot</b> where the thumb was, <b>and</b> he thereby <b>fulfills</b> his obligation. <b>Rabbi Shimon says: If he put it on the left</b> hand or foot, <b>he has fulfilled</b> his obligation. According to Rabbi Pedat, Rabbi Elazar and Beit Shammai both maintain that even if the rite cannot be performed in the precise manner, one fulfills his obligation regardless.
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> “And the priest <b>shall take of the blood of the guilt-offering,</b> and the priest shall put it upon the tip of the right ear of him who is to be purified, and upon the thumb of his right hand, and upon the big toe of his right foot” (Leviticus 14:14). One <b>might</b> have thought that he should take it <b>in a vessel;</b> therefore, <b>the verse states: “And put.” Just as putting</b> means <b>with the priest’s own</b> body, <b>so too, taking</b> means <b>with the priest’s own</b> body.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>even</b> with regard to the blood of the leper’s guilt-offering that he presents <b>on the altar,</b> like the blood of other guilt-offerings, it is <b>so</b> that he collects the blood in his hand rather than with a vessel. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “For as the sin-offering is, so is the guilt-offering”</b> (Leviticus 14:13): <b>Just as a sin-offering requires a vessel</b> for collection of its blood, <b>so too,</b> the blood of <b>a guilt-offering requires</b> collection in <b>a vessel. And you find that you</b> must <b>say: The leper’s guilt-offering</b> requires <b>two priests</b> to <b>collect its blood; one</b> collects <b>by hand, and</b> the other <b>one</b> collects <b>in a vessel. The one who collected in a vessel comes to the altar</b> and sprinkles some of the blood on it, <b>and the one who collected by hand comes to the leper</b> and sprinkles some of the blood on him.
§ <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there: And all</b> of the animals whose blood was spilled, as stated in the mishna, <b>render ritually impure the garments</b> of those who are occupied with burning them. If a bull or goat was slaughtered, but their blood spilled after one stage of atonement, and another animal is brought to complete the sprinkling, the first animal is burned, an action that renders ritually impure the garments of the individuals who perform the burning. <b>And</b> each of <b>these</b> first animals <b>is burned in the place of the ashes,</b> in accordance with the <i>halakha</i> of inner sin-offerings. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon. And the Rabbis say: They do not render</b> the <b>garments impure and they are not burned in the place of the ashes, except for the last</b> animal, <b>since</b> the <b>atonement is completed with it.</b>
<b>Rava inquired before Rav Naḥman: How many goats does he send away?</b> If the blood of the goat presented inside is spilled, the High Priest must bring an additional pair of goats and perform a new lottery. This might even happen several times, which would mean that one goat is offered on the altar while several goats are designated for sending away. What should be done with those goats? <b>He said to him: Does he send away his flock?</b> In other words, the Torah said to send only one goat, not an entire flock. Rava <b>said to him:</b>

Daf 62a

<b>And does he burn his flock?</b> The Torah obligated him to burn only one goat, and yet there are times when he must burn several, as stated in the mishna. Rabbi Naḥman retorts: <b>Is it comparable? There,</b> with respect to burning the goats, <b>it is not written: “It,”</b> which would restrict the burning to only one animal, whereas <b>here,</b> with regard to the scapegoat, <b>it is written: “It,”</b> which indicates that one animal alone is sent away. The objection has been refuted and indeed only one scapegoat is used.
§ <b>It was stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> disagreed about the following issue. <b>Rav Pappi said in the name of Rava: He sends the first</b> goat; <b>and Rav Shimi said in the name of Rava: He sends the last</b> of them. The Gemara analyzes the matter: <b>Granted,</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rav Shimi bar Ashi in the name of Rava, who said</b> that <b>he sends the last</b> of them, it works out well, as <b>he</b> probably <b>holds</b> as stated above, that the last goat is used, <b>since</b> the <b>atonement is completed with it. However,</b> with regard to <b>Rav Pappi in the name of Rava, what does he hold?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>He holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> who said that when several identical items are available for a mitzva, the <b>mitzva is</b> performed <b>with the first</b> of them.
The Gemara asks: To <b>which</b> of the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> is this referring? From which of Rabbi Yosei’s statements is this conclusion derived? <b>If we say</b> it is the statement of <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> with regard to <b>containers,</b> this is problematic. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna that <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> There were <b>three containers of three <i>se’a</i> each, with which they collect the donation from the chamber.</b> Every year the money donated to the Temple by the people in the month of Adar was placed in a special chamber. The treasurers subsequently filled three containers with these coins and used the funds to purchase the communal offerings, e.g., the daily offerings and the additional offerings for Festivals. <b>And</b> the letters <b><i>alef</i>, <i>beit</i>, <i>gimmel</i> were written on the</b> containers.
<b>And it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei said: Why were</b> the letters <b><i>alef</i>, <i>beit</i>, <i>gimmel</i> written on them?</b> It was <b>to ascertain</b> from <b>which of them the donation was collected first,</b> so that they could <b>bring</b> the money <b>from it first, as</b> the <b>mitzva is</b> to use the coins <b>of the first</b> container. This apparently proves that according to the opinion of Rabbi Yosei, it is a mitzva to use the first item.
The Gemara responds: This is no proof, as <b>perhaps at the time when the first</b> container <b>was fit to be used, the last was not</b> yet <b>fit to be used.</b> When the first container was brought it was fit and designated for the offerings, whereas the coins in the second container had not yet been collected, and therefore the coins in the first container must be used first as they were sanctified first. Here, however, the scapegoat is consecrated only when its pair is sacrificed, and therefore the two cases are dissimilar.
<b>Rather,</b> the principle that one uses the first item is derived from the statement of <b>Rabbi Yosei with regard to the Paschal offering, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who separated</b> a sheep for <b>his Paschal offering and</b> the sheep <b>was lost, and he separated another</b> sheep <b>in its stead, and afterward the first</b> sheep <b>was found, and they both stand</b> before him, <b>he sacrifices whichever of them he wants;</b> this is <b>the statement of the Rabbis. Rabbi Yosei says:</b> The <b>mitzva</b> is performed <b>with the first</b> sheep. <b>And if the second was</b> of <b>superior</b> quality <b>to it, he brings</b> the second sheep. This proves that according to Rabbi Yosei, if there are two animals equally fit for an offering, one brings the animal that was chosen first.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The mitzva of the two Yom Kippur goats,</b> the goat sacrificed to God and the goat sent to Azazel that are brought as a pair, <b>is</b> as follows, <i>ab initio</i>: <b>That they will both be identical in appearance,</b> i.e., color, <b>and in height, and in monetary value, and their acquisition</b> must be <b>as one,</b> i.e., they must be purchased together. <b>And even if they are not identical,</b> nevertheless, <b>they are valid.</b> And similarly, if <b>he acquired one today and one tomorrow, they are valid.</b>
If <b>one</b> of the goats <b>died, if it died before</b> the High Priest <b>drew the lots, he</b> immediately <b>takes a counterpart for the second,</b> since neither has yet been designated. <b>And if it died after</b> the High Priest <b>drew the lots, he brings another pair</b> of goats <b>and draws lots over them from the start.</b>
After that lottery <b>he utters</b> a stipulation: <b>If</b> the one to be sacrificed <b>to God died, that</b> goat <b>upon which the lot for God</b> was drawn in the second lottery <b>shall stand in its stead; and if</b> the one to be sent <b>to Azazel died, that</b> goat <b>upon which the lot for Azazel</b> was drawn <b>shall stand in its stead. And the second,</b> superfluous goat, i.e., in the case where a new pair of goats was brought, <b>should graze until it becomes unfit,</b> at which point <b>it will be sold, and the money</b> received from <b>its</b> sale <b>will go toward</b> the purchase of <b>a</b> public <b>gift-offering.</b> Although for individual sin-offerings in similar circumstances there is no remedy and it is left to die, that is not the case here, <b>as a communal sin-offering</b> is <b>not</b> left <b>to die.</b> On the other hand, <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> In this <b>it should</b> be left to <b>die.</b>
<b>And furthermore, Rabbi Yehuda said:</b> If <b>the blood</b> of the goat sacrificed to God <b>spilled</b> before it was sprinkled, <b>the scapegoat</b> is left <b>to die.</b> Similarly, <b>if the scapegoat dies, the blood</b> of the goat sacrificed to God <b>should be spilled,</b> and two other goats are brought and lots are drawn.

Daf 62b

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught:</b> It states: <b>“He shall take two goats”</b> (Leviticus 16:5). The <b>minimum</b> number indicated by a plural term, as the word <b>goats</b> is here, is <b>two.</b> If so, <b>what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: Two?</b> It teaches <b>that the two should be identical.</b> And <b>from where</b> do we derive that <b>even if the two</b> goats <b>are not identical</b> they are nevertheless <b>valid? The verses state</b> and repeat the word <b>goat, goat</b> (Leviticus 16:9–10) <b>to amplify</b> and indicate that the goats are valid even if they are not identical.
The Gemara asks: <b>The reason</b> is specifically <b>because the Merciful One</b> in the Torah <b>amplified</b> and thereby indicated that the goats are valid even if they are not identical. <b>Doesn’t this</b> indicate that if <b>the Merciful One did not amplify, I would have said</b> the goats are <b>disqualified? From where do we</b> derive that the goats are <b>prevented</b> from being sacrificed if they are not identical? The principle with regard to sacrificial offerings is that if the Torah indicates a requirement only once, it is a mitzva <i>ab initio</i>, and if the Torah repeats the requirement, it is considered indispensable in order for the offering to be valid.
The Gemara answers: It could <b>enter your mind to say</b> that since the word <b>two, two, two, is written</b> three times in the relevant passage, the repetition indicates that the goats are disqualified if they are not identical. Therefore, the Torah had to indicate that the goats are valid even if they are not identical.
The Gemara asks: <b>And now that the Merciful One has amplified</b> by repeating the word <b>goat, goat, why do I</b> need the threefold repetition of <b>two, two, two?</b> The Gemara answers that it teaches how the mitzva should be performed <i>ab initio</i>: <b>One</b> of the terms indicates that the goats should be identical <b>in appearance, one</b> indicates they should be identical <b>in height, and one</b> indicates they should be identical <b>in monetary value.</b>
The Gemara comments that <b>this was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>with regard to</b> the <b>lambs</b> brought by a <b>leper,</b> based upon the verse: <b>“He shall take two lambs”</b> (Leviticus 14:10). The <b>minimum</b> number of <b>lambs,</b> which is a plural term, is <b>two.</b> If so, <b>what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states “two”?</b> It teaches <b>that the two should be identical.</b> And <b>from where</b> do we derive <b>that even if the two</b> lambs <b>are not identical</b> they are nevertheless <b>valid? The verses state: Lamb, lamb,</b> repetitively, <b>to amplify</b> and indicate that the lambs are valid even if they are not identical.
The Gemara asks: <b>The reason</b> is specifically <b>because the Merciful One</b> in the Torah <b>amplified</b> and thereby indicated that the lambs are valid even if they are not identical. <b>Doesn’t this</b> indicate that if <b>the Merciful One did not amplify, I would have said</b> the lambs are <b>disqualified? From where do we</b> derive that the lambs are <b>prevented</b> from being sacrificed if they are not identical? The Gemara answers: It could <b>enter your mind to say</b> that since <b>it is written:</b> “This <b>shall be</b> the law of the leper” (Leviticus 14:2), the verse indicates that every detail stated in this context is indispensable. Therefore, it was necessary for the Torah to indicate that the lambs are valid even if they are not identical.
The Gemara asks: <b>And now that the Merciful One has amplified</b> by repeating the word <b>lamb, lamb, why do I</b> need the phrase “this <b>shall be”?</b> The Gemara answers: This phrase applies <b>to the rest of the</b> <i>halakhot</i> that <b>are</b> included in the atonement ritual <b>of the leper,</b> which are indispensable.
The Gemara comments: <b>And we also learned similarly with regard to</b> the birds used for the purification of <b>a leper.</b> The verse states that the priest should take “two <b>birds”</b> (Leviticus 14:4), and the <b>minimum</b> number indicated by the plural term <b>birds</b> is <b>two. What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: Two?</b> It indicates <b>that the two</b> birds <b>should be identical. And from where</b> do we derive <b>that even if they are not identical</b> they are <b>valid? The verses state: Bird, bird</b> (Leviticus 14:5–6), repetitively, to <b>amplify.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>The reason</b> is specifically <b>because the Merciful One</b> in the Torah <b>amplified</b> and thereby indicated that the birds are valid even if they are not identical. <b>Doesn’t this</b> indicate that if <b>the Merciful One did not amplify,</b> I would have said the birds are <b>disqualified? From where do we</b> derive that the birds are <b>prevented</b> from being used if they are not identical? The Gemara answers: It could <b>enter your mind to say</b> that since <b>it is written:</b> “This <b>shall be</b> the law of the leper,” the verse indicates that every detail stated in this context is indispensable. Therefore, it was necessary for the Torah to indicate that the birds are valid even if they are not identical.
The Gemara asks: <b>And now that the Merciful One has amplified</b> by repeating the word <b>bird, why do I</b> need the phrase “this <b>shall be”?</b> The Gemara answers: This phrase applies <b>to the rest of the</b> <i>halakhot</i> that <b>are</b> included in the atonement ritual <b>of the leper,</b> which are indispensable.
The Gemara suggests: <b>If so,</b> this line of reasoning should be applied to the <b>daily offerings as well. Let us say</b> that when the verse states: “Two <b>lambs</b> of the first year, day by day, continually” (Exodus 29:38), the <b>minimum</b> number indicated by the word <b>lambs is two. What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states “two”?</b> It indicates <b>that the two</b> lambs <b>should be identical. And from where</b> do we derive <b>that even if the two are not identical they are valid? The verse states</b> the word <b>lamb, lamb</b> (Exodus 29:39), repetitively, to <b>amplify.</b> Let us learn from here that in order <b>to</b> fulfill <b>the mitzva</b> in the preferred manner, <b>we also require</b> that the two lambs used for the daily offering be identical.
The Gemara responds: <b>That</b> verse <b>is needed for that which was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“Two</b> lambs of the first year, <b>day by day”</b> (Exodus 29:38), indicates that the lambs must be slaughtered <b>opposite the</b> location of the sun at that time of <b>day.</b>
The Gemara asks: Do <b>you say</b> it means <b>opposite the</b> location of the sun at that time of <b>day, or</b> does it <b>only</b> mean to say that two lambs must be sacrificed for the <b>obligation of</b> each <b>day?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>When it states: “One lamb you shall offer in the morning, and the other lamb you shall offer in the afternoon”</b> (Numbers 28:4), <b>the obligation of</b> each <b>day is stated</b> explicitly. <b>And how do I uphold</b> the verse: <b>“Two</b> lambs of the first year, <b>day by day”?</b> It teaches that the lambs must be slaughtered <b>opposite the</b> location of the sun at that time of <b>day.</b>
<b>How</b> is this done in actuality? The <b>daily offering of</b> the <b>morning was slaughtered</b> in the Temple courtyard <b>opposite</b> the <b>northwest corner</b> of the altar, <b>on</b> the <b>second ring,</b> across from the sun, which rises in the east. <b>And</b> the daily offering <b>of</b> the <b>afternoon was slaughtered opposite</b> the <b>northeast corner</b> of the altar, <b>on</b> the <b>second ring,</b> across the sun, which is located in the west in the afternoon.
The Gemara comments: When the Torah states: “Two lambs” (Numbers 28:9) with regard to the <b>additional offerings</b> brought on <b>Shabbat,</b> the word two, which is unnecessary, <b>certainly</b> indicates <b>that the two should be identical</b> <i>ab initio</i>.
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> If the High Priest <b>slaughtered the two Yom Kippur goats outside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>when he had not yet drawn lots</b> to determine which of <b>them</b> is to be sacrificed to God and which is to be sent to Azazel, <b>he is liable</b> to receive the punishment of <i>karet</i> <b>for both of them,</b> as they are both fit for use as an offering. If he slaughtered them <b>after he drew lots</b> for <b>them, he is liable</b> for slaughtering the goat designated <b>for God,</b> which is a sacrificial offering, <b>and he is exempt for</b> slaughtering the goat designated <b>for Azazel,</b> as it is not a sacrificial offering.
The Gemara clarifies the meaning of this <i>baraita</i>. With regard to the statement that if he slaughtered the goats <b>when he had not yet drawn lots, he is liable for both of them,</b> the Gemara asks: <b>For what are they fit?</b> Before the lots are drawn, neither goat is fit for use as an offering. The Gemara answers that <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> He is liable <b>since they are fit</b> to be used <b>as the goat</b> whose sacrificial rites are <b>performed outside.</b> These two goats are fit for use as the additional offerings of Yom Kippur, whose sacrificial rites are performed outside of the Sanctuary, in the Temple courtyard. Therefore, the goats have the status of sacrificial offerings.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about <b>the goat</b> whose sacrificial rites are <b>performed inside</b> the Sanctuary, i.e., the goat selected to be sacrificed as a sin-offering, for which the goats are <b>not</b> valid because <b>they lack the lottery? They are also unfit</b> to be used <b>as the goat</b> whose rites are <b>performed outside</b> the Sanctuary, <b>as they lack the service of the day.</b> The entire Yom Kippur service must be performed in the proper sequence, and several steps have to be executed before the additional offerings are sacrificed, including the sprinkling of the bull’s and goat’s blood, and the burning of the handful of incense. Since the additional offerings cannot yet be sacrificed, the goats cannot be considered fit for these offerings, and one should not be liable to receive <i>karet</i> for slaughtering the goats outside the Temple courtyard.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Ḥisda holds</b> that an offering is <b>not</b> considered to be <b>lacking time</b> if it is to be brought on <b>that day.</b> An offering is considered lacking time, and therefore unfit, if it is supposed to be brought on a different day. However, if it is the proper day but the right moment has not yet arrived, the offering is considered valid. On the other hand, before the High Priest draws lots to determine which of the goats will be sacrificed to God and which sent to Azazel, even though it is the proper day, the goats are not yet considered valid offerings because there is a necessary action that the High Priest must take with regard to the goat itself before it can be brought as an offering.
<b>Ravina said: Now that Rav Ḥisda said</b> that although the drawing of lots is external to the animals themselves, an animal <b>lacking the lottery is comparable to</b> an animal <b>lacking an action</b> and is not yet considered a valid offering, a statement can be made with regard to <b>that which Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: Peace-offerings that one slaughtered</b> in the Temple <b>before the doors of the Sanctuary were opened are disqualified,</b> as <b>it is stated</b> with regard to peace-offerings: <b>“And he shall slaughter it at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting”</b> (Leviticus 3:2), which teaches that it must be slaughtered <b>when</b> the entrance <b>is open</b> and serves as an actual entrance, <b>but not when it is locked.</b> As long as the entrance to the Tent of Meeting, or in the Temple the doors to the Sanctuary, remain closed, one may not sacrifice the peace-offerings, and if they are sacrificed, they are disqualified.

Daf 63a

Based on Rav Ḥisda’s statement, if <b>he slaughtered them outside</b> the Temple <b>before the doors of the Sanctuary were opened he is exempt. What is the reason? Lacking</b> the <b>opening</b> of the doors <b>is comparable to lacking an action.</b> Therefore, the offering was not yet fit to be sacrificed in the Temple, and when he slaughtered it outside, despite doing so with the intention that it is a sacrificial offering, he is not considered to have violated the prohibition against sacrificing an offering outside the Temple.
Rav Ḥisda stated above that since the Yom Kippur goats could be used for the additional offerings, one is liable for slaughtering them outside the Temple. The Gemara asks: <b>Does Rav Ḥisda accept</b> the principle: <b>Since</b> a particular situation could come to be in the future, it is viewed as though it existed already in the present?
<b>And didn’t Rav Ḥisda say:</b> If one <b>slaughtered a Paschal lamb outside</b> the Temple <b>during the rest of the days of the year</b> other than Passover eve, if he slaughtered it <b>for its own sake,</b> i.e., as a Paschal lamb, <b>he is exempt,</b> since at that time it is not fit to be sacrificed as a Paschal lamb. If he sacrificed it <b>not for its own sake</b> but rather as a peace-offering, <b>he is liable.</b> A Paschal lamb that is slaughtered as a peace-offering on any day of the year other than Passover eve is considered a valid peace-offering. Therefore, it has the status of an offering that is fit to be sacrificed in the Temple, and he is liable for slaughtering it outside the Temple.
The Gemara comments: <b>The reason</b> he is liable is because he specifically slaughtered it <b>not for its own sake. However,</b> if he slaughtered it <b>without specifying</b> what offering he had in mind, <b>it is</b> considered to have been slaughtered <b>for its own sake and he is exempt. But why</b> is he exempt? <b>Let us say: Since it is fit</b> to be sacrificed <b>within</b> the Temple <b>not for its own sake,</b> i.e., as a peace-offering, it should be considered as though he slaughtered it as a peace-offering outside the Temple, and he should be liable.
The Gemara responds: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> with regard to the Paschal lamb, it <b>requires</b> explicit <b>uprooting</b> from the status of a Paschal lamb in order to be considered a peace-offering. Therefore, if he did not specify his intent, it is still considered a Paschal lamb, which is not fit to be sacrificed. <b>These</b> Yom Kippur goats <b>do not require uprooting</b> from their previous status. The Yom Kippur goats have the status of a sin-offering and the goats sacrificed as part of the additional offerings of the day are also considered sin-offerings. Therefore, one who slaughters them outside the Temple is liable, as they are fit to be sacrificed at that time as sin-offerings, even without the principle: Since, etc.
<b>Rabba bar Shimi taught these</b> two <i>halakhot</i>, cited above in the name of Rav Ḥisda, <b>in</b> the name of <b>Rabba, and he</b> found <b>a difficulty between</b> one statement of <b>Rabba</b> and another statement of <b>Rabba. And he resolved</b> the apparent contradiction <b>as we resolved</b> it.
§ <b>When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yirmeya said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> said: If one <b>slaughtered a Paschal lamb outside</b> the Temple <b>during the rest of the days of the year, whether</b> he slaughtered it <b>for its own sake,</b> as a Paschal lamb, <b>or not for its own sake,</b> as a peace-offering, <b>he is exempt.</b>
<b>Rav Dimi said: I said this <i>halakha</i> before Rabbi Yirmeya</b> and asked him: <b>Granted,</b> when he slaughters it outside the Temple <b>for its own sake</b> he is exempt, <b>because it is not fit</b> to be brought as a Paschal lamb at that time, and one is liable for slaughtering an offering outside the Temple only if it was fit to be sacrificed in the Temple. <b>However,</b> if he slaughters it <b>not for its own sake, why</b> is he exempt? <b>Isn’t it fit</b> to be sacrificed <b>not for its own sake</b> as a peace-offering <b>inside</b> the Temple?
<b>And</b> Rabbi Yirmeya <b>said to me</b> in response: <b>Uprooting</b> an offering’s designation <b>outside</b> the Temple <b>is not called uprooting.</b> Since he slaughtered it outside, the status of the offering does not change from that of a Paschal lamb to that of a peace-offering, despite his intention to this effect.
<b>When Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he said</b> a different version of the statement that <b>Rabbi Yirmeya said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> said: If one <b>slaughtered a Paschal lamb outside</b> the Temple <b>during the rest of the days of the year, whether</b> he slaughtered it <b>for its own sake or not for its own sake, he is liable.</b>
The Gemara expresses surprise: Is he liable <b>even</b> if he slaughtered it <b>for its own sake? Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna in tractate <i>Zevaḥim</i> that one is exempt for sacrificing an offering that was not yet fit for sacrifice because it was <b>lacking time?</b> This is so <b>whether</b> it <b>itself</b> was lacking time, such as if it was less than eight days old, <b>or</b> it was lacking time <b>due to</b> its <b>owners.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>And what is</b> an offering that is <b>lacking time due to</b> its <b>owners? A <i>zav</i>, a <i>zava</i>, a woman after childbirth, and a leper,</b> who sacrificed their offerings before the appropriate time. A <i>zav</i>, a <i>zava</i>, and a leper bring their offerings after counting seven days; a woman after childbirth brings hers when her purification period is complete.
Any of these people <b>who sacrificed their sin-offering and,</b> in the case of lepers, <b>their guilt-offering outside</b> the Temple <b>are exempt.</b> Since they would not fulfill their obligations to bring these offerings if they would sacrifice them in the Temple, and the offerings are unfit to be brought as voluntary offerings, because sin-offerings and guilt-offerings are not brought as voluntary offerings, one who slaughters them outside the Temple is not liable. However, if they sacrifice <b>their burnt-offerings and peace-offerings outside</b> the Temple, <b>they are liable.</b> This is because these offerings could be valid as voluntary offerings if they were sacrificed in the Temple.
<b>And Rav Ḥilkiya bar Tovi said: They only taught</b> that one is exempt for the guilt-offering when it is slaughtered <b>for its own sake, but</b> if it is slaughtered <b>not for its own sake, he is liable,</b> because a guilt-offering slaughtered in the Temple not for its own sake is valid.
The Gemara considers this: If he slaughtered it <b>for its own sake, in any event he is exempt. Why? Let us say: Since they are fit</b> to be sacrificed <b>inside</b> the Temple <b>not for their own sake,</b> he should be liable for sacrificing them outside. The Gemara responds: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> the guilt-offering <b>requires</b> explicit <b>uprooting</b> of its designation in order to be valid. <b>Here, a Paschal lamb during the rest of the days of the year is</b> considered <b>a peace-offering,</b> even if its status is not explicitly uprooted.
The Gemara continues to discuss the case of a Paschal lamb that was slaughtered outside the Temple during the rest of the year, and not for its own sake. <b>Rav Ashi taught: He is liable, as we stated. Rav Yirmeya of Difti taught: He is exempt.</b> Rav Yirmeya <b>held</b> that <b>a Paschal lamb during the rest of the days of the year requires uprooting</b> of its previous designation, <b>and uprooting</b> an offering’s designation <b>outside</b> the Temple <b>is not called uprooting. And this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>disagrees with</b> the statement <b>of Rav Ḥilkiya bar Tovi,</b> who held that uprooting an offering’s designation outside the Temple is considered an effective uprooting of that designation.
§ <b>The Master said:</b> If he slaughtered the two Yom Kippur goats outside the Temple <b>after he drew lots</b> to determine which of <b>them</b> is to be sacrificed to God and which is sent to Azazel, <b>he is liable for</b> slaughtering the one designated <b>for God, and exempt for</b> the one designated to be sent <b>to Azazel.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> based upon the verses: <b>“Any man of the house of Israel who shall slaughter a bull, or a lamb, or a goat in the camp, or who slaughters it outside the camp, and has not brought it to the entrance to the Tent of Meeting to present it as an offering to the Lord</b> before the tabernacle of the Lord, blood shall be imputed to that man; he has shed blood; and that man shall be cut off from among his people” (Leviticus 17:3–4).

Daf 63b

<b>If</b> it would have mentioned just the word <b>offering, I</b> would <b>derive</b> that one is liable <b>even</b> for slaughtering animals <b>consecrated for Temple maintenance</b> outside the Temple, <b>which are</b> also <b>called offering, as it is stated: “And we have brought the Lord’s offering,</b> what every man has found: Articles of gold, armlets, and bracelets, rings, earrings, and pendants” (Numbers 31:50). Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And has not brought it to the entrance to the Tent of Meeting”</b> (Leviticus 17:4), to teach that with regard to <b>any</b> animal <b>fit</b> to be sacrificed within <b>the entrance to the Tent of Meeting</b> or the Temple, <b>one is liable for</b> slaughtering <b>it outside</b> the Temple. Conversely, with regard to <b>any</b> animal <b>that is not fit</b> to be sacrificed within <b>the entrance to the Tent of Meeting, one is not liable for</b> slaughtering <b>it outside</b> the Temple.
Furthermore: <b>I</b> might <b>exclude these</b> animals consecrated for Temple maintenance, <b>which are not fit</b> to be sacrificed within <b>the entrance to the Tent of Meeting</b> because they are blemished, <b>and I will not exclude the heifer of a purification offering and</b> the <b>scapegoat, which are fit to come to the entrance to the Tent of Meeting.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states “to the Lord”</b> to indicate that one is liable only for <b>those</b> animals <b>that are designated exclusively for God</b> as offerings. <b>These,</b> the heifer of a purification offering and the scapegoat, <b>are excluded, as they are not designated exclusively for God</b> as sacrificial offerings but are used for some other purpose.
The Gemara asks about this halakhic midrash: <b>Does</b> the expression <b>“to the Lord”</b> come <b>to exclude?</b> The Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> based upon the verse: “When a bull, or a lamb, or a goat, is born it shall be seven days under its mother; but from the eighth day on <b>it may be accepted as an offering by fire to the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 22:27). An offering by fire to the Lord: <b>These are</b> offerings <b>by fire,</b> which are sacrificed on the altar and which may not be sacrificed before their proper time.
<b>From where</b> do we derive <b>that he may not consecrate</b> an animal when it is <b>lacking time,</b> i.e., before the eighth day? <b>The verse states: An offering,</b> which indicates that it should not be designated as an offering before the eighth day. The expression: <b>To the Lord</b> comes <b>to include the scapegoat,</b> which is also brought for the sake of God. In other words, the expression: To the Lord, not only does not exclude the scapegoat from the category of offerings, but specifically includes it in this category.
<b>Rava said</b> that this can be resolved as follows: <b>There</b> the expression is understood <b>in the context of the verse and here</b> it is understood <b>in the context of the verse. There,</b> with regard to consecrated animals slaughtered outside the Temple, <b>where</b> the phrase: <b>To the entrance,</b> in that same verse comes <b>to include</b> other offerings, the phrase: <b>To the Lord</b> necessarily comes <b>to exclude.</b> Conversely, <b>here,</b> with regard to consecrating animals before the proper time, <b>where</b> the phrase: Offering <b>by fire</b> comes <b>to exclude,</b> the phrase: <b>To the Lord</b> comes <b>to include.</b>
Once the contradiction has been reconciled, the Gemara challenges the reasoning of the argument. <b>The reason</b> the scapegoat may not be consecrated before it is eight days old <b>is because the Merciful One</b> specifically <b>included</b> it among the other offerings. <b>But had it not included</b> it <b>I would have said: The scapegoat</b> may be <b>consecrated</b> even <b>when</b> it is <b>lacking time.</b> However, this is difficult: <b>Isn’t</b> it true that <b>the lottery establishes</b> as the goat that is sacrificed to God, <b>only</b> one that is <b>fit</b> to be sacrificed <b>to God?</b> Since it is not known in advance which goat will be designated for this purpose, both goats must be eight days old and thereby fit to be sacrificed to God.
<b>Rav Yosef said:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is</b> the opinion of <b>Ḥanan the Egyptian, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Ḥanan the Egyptian says: Even</b> if the goat sacrificed to God has already been slaughtered and its <b>blood</b> has been collected <b>in the cup,</b> if the scapegoat dies, <b>he brings</b> another goat as <b>a counterpart and pairs it with</b> the goat that has already been slaughtered. Since in this case the priest need not draw new lots and the second goat is immediately designated to be sent to Azazel, it was necessary to teach that this goat must not be lacking time.
The Gemara presents a challenge with regard to this answer. <b>Say that you heard Ḥanan the Egyptian</b> say <b>that he does not</b> hold that if the scapegoat dies, the blood of the other goat is <b>rejected. Did you</b> also <b>hear him</b> say <b>that he does not</b> require a new <b>lottery</b> for the second goat? <b>Perhaps</b> he meant that one <b>brings</b> two new goats <b>and draws lots,</b> and whichever is designated to be sent to Azazel is the counterpart to the goat that was already slaughtered.
The Gemara presents another explanation of why it was necessary for the Torah to indicate that the scapegoat must not be lacking time. <b>Rather, Rav Yosef said:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this? It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>If one of</b> the goats <b>dies, he brings another</b> goat in its place <b>without a lottery;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Shimon.</b> Therefore, if the scapegoat would die, another goat would be designated as the scapegoat without a lottery, and it was necessary for the Torah to indicate that this goat had to be eight days old.
<b>Ravina said</b> that it is possible to answer according to all opinions. The derivation was necessary in a case <b>where</b> the scapegoat <b>became blemished</b> after the lottery <b>and they redeemed it with another.</b> In that situation, all agree that the new scapegoat does not need to be designated through a lottery, because the status of the original scapegoat was transferred to its replacement.
