Furthermore, with regard to the manna: The <b>students of Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai asked him: Why didn’t the manna fall for the Jewish people</b> just <b>once a year</b> to take care of all their needs, instead of coming down every day? <b>He said to them: I will give you a parable: To what does this matter compare? To a king of flesh and blood who has</b> only <b>one son. He granted him</b> an allowance for <b>food once a year and</b> the son <b>greeted his father only once a year,</b> when it was time for him to receive his allowance. So <b>he arose and granted him his food every day, and</b> his son <b>visited him every day.</b>
<b>So too,</b> in the case of <b>the Jewish people, someone who had four or five children would be worried and say: Perhaps the manna will not fall tomorrow and we will all die of starvation. Consequently, everyone directed their hearts to their Father in heaven</b> every day. The manna that fell each day was sufficient only for that day, so that all of the Jewish people would pray to God for food for the next day.
<b>Alternatively,</b> they received manna daily <b>so that they would</b> be able to <b>eat it while it was hot</b> and fresh. <b>Alternatively,</b> they received manna daily <b>due to</b> the hardship of <b>carrying on the journey.</b> They did not stay in the same place all those years, and it would have been difficult for them to carry the manna from one place to another. Therefore, the manna fell wherever they went.
§ It is told: <b>Rabbi Tarfon, and Rabbi Yishmael, and the Elders were sitting and discussing the passage about the manna and Rabbi Elazar HaModa’i was sitting among them. Rabbi Elazar HaModa’i responded and said: The manna that fell for the Jewish people was sixty cubits high. Rabbi Tarfon said to him: Moda’i, how long will you collect words and bring upon us</b> teachings that have no basis?
<b>He said to him: Rabbi, I am interpreting a verse.</b> How so? It states about the Flood: <b>“Fifteen cubits above did the waters prevail; and the mountains were covered”</b> (Genesis 7:20). <b>Is it possible that it would be fifteen cubits</b> high <b>from a valley, fifteen</b> cubits <b>from the plain,</b> and <b>fifteen</b> cubits <b>from the mountains? Did the water stand as though in layers,</b> conforming to the height of the land below it? <b>Furthermore, how could the Ark travel</b> over water that was at different levels? <b>Rather: “On the same day were all the fountains of the great deep broken up”</b> (Genesis 7:11), <b>until the water</b> rose and <b>was level with the mountains. Afterward,</b> the verse states that <b>“fifteen cubits above did the waters prevail.”</b>
Rabbi Elazar HaModa’i continues: <b>But which attribute is greater, the attribute of goodness or the attribute of retribution? One must say the attribute of goodness</b> is greater <b>than the attribute of retribution. With regard to the attribute of retribution,</b> in the case of the Flood, the verse <b>states: “And the windows of heaven were opened”</b> (Genesis 7:11), which indicates that there were only windows. Whereas, <b>with regard to the attribute of goodness,</b> in the case of the manna, the verse <b>states: “He commanded the skies above, and opened the doors of heaven, and rained down manna upon them to eat and gave them heavenly grain”</b> (Psalms 78:23–24).
Based on this, the Gemara calculates: The area of <b>how many windows are in a door? Four.</b> A door is equivalent to four windows in size. One adds another <b>four</b> for the second door, as the verse uses the plural “doors,” which implies that there were two doors. <b>This equals</b> the area of <b>eight</b> windows. If the depth of water in the Flood is based on the phrase “windows of heaven,” implying two windows, then the manna fell at a rate four times that of the water of the Flood. Since the water of the Flood reached a depth of fifteen cubits, <b>it turns out that the manna that fell for the Jewish people was sixty cubits high,</b> i.e., four times as high.
Similarly, <b>it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Isi ben Yehuda said: The manna that fell for the Jewish people would accumulate and ascend until all the kings of the East and West could see it, as it is stated: “You prepared a table before me in the presence of my enemies;</b> you anointed my head with oil; <b>my cup runs over”</b> (Psalms 23:5). God prepared food for the Jewish people, so that their enemies would see their greatness over the world. <b>“My cup runs over [<i>revaya</i>]”; Abaye said: We learn from this that the cup of David in the next world holds 221 <i>log</i>, since it is stated: “My cup runs over,”</b> and the word <b><i>revaya</i> has that numerical value.</b>
The Gemara asks how Rabbi Elazar HaModa’i can compare the depth of the Flood waters with the amount of manna that fell in the desert: <b>This is not similar,</b> and the calculation is inaccurate. <b>There,</b> in the case of the Flood, the water rose fifteen cubits in <b>forty days;</b> but <b>here,</b> in the case of the manna, it took only <b>one hour</b> every day to fall. Conversely, <b>there</b> the Flood was <b>for everyone</b> and covered the whole world; whereas <b>here</b> the manna <b>was for the Jewish people alone. And there</b> would be <b>much more</b> manna <b>for them</b> than sixty cubits, which is the measurement put forth by Rabbi Elazar HaModa’i. The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Elazar HaModa’i derived “opening”</b> in the verse: “He commanded the skies above, and opened the doors of heaven” (Psalms 78:23), from <b>“opening”</b> in the verse: “And the windows of heaven were opened” (Genesis 7:11). He used a verbal analogy that teaches that the skies opened in both instances in the same way.
§ The mishna taught that as per the five prohibited activities on Yom Kippur it is <b>prohibited</b> to engage <b>in eating</b> and in drinking, and in bathing, and in smearing the body with oil, and in wearing shoes, and in conjugal relations. The Gemara asks: <b>These five afflictions</b> of Yom Kippur, to <b>what</b> do they <b>correspond?</b> Where is the Torah source or allusion to them? <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> They are based on <b>the five</b> times that the <b>afflictions</b> of Yom Kippur are mentioned <b>in the Torah.</b> It is stated: (1) <b>“And on the tenth</b> of this seventh month you shall have a holy convocation, and you shall afflict your souls” (Numbers 29:7); (2) <b>“But on the tenth</b> of this seventh month is the day of atonement, it shall be a holy convocation for you and you shall afflict your souls” (Leviticus 23:27); (3) “It shall be for you <b>a Shabbat of solemn rest,</b> and you shall afflict your souls (Leviticus 23:32); (4) <b>“It is a Shabbat of solemn rest [<i>shabbaton</i>]</b> for you, and you shall afflict your souls” (Leviticus 16:31); (5) <b>“And it shall be</b> a statute <b>for you</b> forever, in the seventh month on the tenth of the month, you shall afflict your souls” (Leviticus 16:29).
The Gemara asks: <b>Are these five</b> the only afflictions? <b>We learn</b> in the mishna that there are <b>six:</b> Eating, drinking, bathing, smearing oil, conjugal relations, and wearing shoes. The Gemara answers: <b>Drinking is included in</b> the prohibition of <b>eating;</b> both together are considered a single affliction. <b>As Reish Lakish said: From where do we derive that drinking is included in</b> the concept of <b>eating? As it is stated: “And you shall eat before the Lord your God,</b> in the place where He shall choose to cause His name to dwell there, <b>the tithe of your grain,</b> of <b>your wine [<i>tirosh</i>], and</b> of <b>your oil”</b> (Deuteronomy 14:23). <b><i>Tirosh</i> is wine,</b> yet the verse <b>calls</b> the drinking of wine eating with the phrase <b>“and you shall eat,”</b> meaning that eating also refers to drinking.
The Gemara rejects this answer: <b>From where</b> do you draw this conclusion? <b>Perhaps</b> the wine <b>was eaten as <i>anigron</i>,</b> a sauce made of oil, beet juice, and garum mixed with wine. As <b>Rabba bar Shmuel said: <i>Anigron</i></b> is <b>beet juice</b> and wine mixed together. <b><i>Akhsigron</i></b> is <b>water that comes from boiled vegetables</b> that have wine mixed into them. The vegetables are mixed with the wine and eaten. It is possible for wine to literally be eaten. Therefore, the verse does not prove that drinking is included in eating.
<b>Rather, Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: From here</b> there is a proof as the verse states: <b>“And you shall spend that money on all that your soul desires, on oxen, or on sheep, or on wine, or on strong drink [<i>sheikhar</i>]</b> or whatever your soul desires, and you shall eat” (Deuteronomy 14:26). <b>Strong drink is a drink, but the Merciful One calls</b> its consumption eating, in the phrase <b>“and you shall eat.”</b>
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>From where</b> do you draw this conclusion? <b>Perhaps here too it was eaten as <i>anigron</i>?</b> The Gemara rejects this: Here that answer is insufficient because the verse <b>writes “strong drink [<i>sheikhar</i>],”</b> meaning <b>something</b> that <b>intoxicates.</b> Beverages that generally intoxicate do not do so when they are in a mixture. The Gemara asks: <b>Perhaps</b> <i>sheikhar</i> does not refer to wine but to a food that causes intoxication, such as <b>a sweet dried fig from Keilah. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: A priest who <b>ate a sweet dried fig from Keilah or drank honey or milk,</b> thereby becoming intoxicated, <b>and entered the Temple</b> to serve

Daf 76b

<b>is liable</b> for violating the prohibition: “Drink no wine nor strong drink [<i>sheikhar</i>]” (Leviticus 10:9). Consequently, the term <i>sheikhar</i> in the text can be understood here as the sweet dried fig.
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara rejects this and states: <b>It is derived</b> through a verbal analogy of <b>“<i>sheikhar</i>”</b> and <b>“<i>sheikhar</i>”</b> stated in the verses <b>of</b> the <b>nazirite</b> (Numbers 6:3). <b>Just as there,</b> in the case of the nazirite, <i>sheikhar</i> means strong <b>wine, so too, here,</b> it means strong <b>wine</b> and not sweet dried figs.
The Gemara returns to the meaning of the word <i>tirosh</i>: <b>Is <i>tirosh</i> wine? Isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One</b> who <b>vows</b> not to benefit <b>from <i>tirosh</i> is not allowed sweet foods,</b> e.g., sweet fruits, <b>but is allowed wine.</b> Therefore, <i>tirosh</i> is not wine but sweet food. The Gemara rejects this: <b>And is</b> <i>tirosh</i> <b>not wine? But isn’t it written: “<i>Tirosh</i> shall make the young women flourish [<i>yenovev</i>]”</b> (Zechariah 9:17). The word <i>yenovev</i> comes from the word <i>niv</i>, speech. Consequently, <i>tirosh</i> is a food that tempts the heart and mouth of the drinker, even of virgins, who are modest and reticent. Since sweet foods do not have this effect, <i>tirosh</i> must be wine. The Gemara replies: This is not a proof, since we could explain it otherwise: <b>Something that comes from <i>tirosh</i>,</b> such as wine, <b>causes virgins to come forth;</b> <i>tirosh</i> itself means sweet grapes. Perhaps wine is called <i>tirosh</i> only by extension because it is made from <i>tirosh</i>.
The Gemara challenges this: <b>But isn’t it written: “And your vats shall overflow with <i>tirosh</i>”</b> (Proverbs 3:10). This description implies that <i>tirosh</i> is wine rather than sweet grapes. The Gemara answers: This too is not a proof that <i>tirosh</i> means wine. We could say that <b>the vats shall overflow with something that comes from <i>tirosh</i>,</b> i.e., wine; yet <i>tirosh</i> itself means sweet fruits.
The Gemara objects: <b>But it is written: “Harlotry, and wine, and <i>tirosh</i> take away the heart”</b> (Hosea 4:11). Since <i>tirosh</i> leads the heart astray, it is clear that it is wine. Therefore, the Gemara accepts that <i>tirosh</i> means wine. <b>Rather, according to everyone,</b> the word <b><i>tirosh</i></b> in the Bible refers to <b>wine, but vows follow colloquial language.</b> During the time of the Mishna, <i>tirosh</i> meant sweet fruits; the term included grapes but not wine. When dealing with vows, the intention of the speaker is what must be determined, but no inference can be drawn from colloquial language to the biblical definition of the word.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> if so, <b>why does</b> the Bible <b>call</b> it <b>wine</b> and <b>why does it call it <i>tirosh</i>?</b> The Gemara explains: <b>“Wine”</b> suggests <b>that it brings lament to the world</b> because drunkenness causes most sins. There is a phonetic resemblance between the <i>yayin</i>, wine, and <i>ta’aniya va’aniya</i>, sorrow and howling, which Rashi (on Job 2:5) explains as lament. <b>“<i>Tirosh</i>”</b> shows <b>that those who indulge in it become poor [<i>rash</i>].</b>
<b>Rav Kahana raised a contradiction: It is written</b> as <b><i>tirash</i> but we read it <i>tirosh</i>.</b> This should be understood as follows: If <b>one merits</b> and drinks appropriately, <b>he is made a head [<i>rosh</i>];</b> if <b>one does not merit</b> and does not drink appropriately, <b>he is made poor [<i>rash</i>].</b> The Gemara comments: <b>This is the same as</b> what <b>Rava</b> said, as <b>Rava raised a contradiction: It is written:</b> “And wine that <b>makes glad [<i>yishamaḥ</i>]</b> the heart of man” (Psalms 104:15) with a <i>shin</i>, but <b>we read it <i>yisamaḥ</i></b> with a <i>sin</i>. This teaches: <b>If one merits,</b> wine <b>makes him happy [<i>same’aḥ</i>]; if one does not merit,</b> it <b>makes him confounded [<i>shamem</i>]. This is</b> the same as <b>what Rava said: Wine and good scents make me wise,</b> meaning that wine benefits one who deserves it.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that abstaining from <b>bathing and smearing</b> oil on oneself <b>is called affliction?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>As it is written “I ate no pleasant bread, neither did meat nor wine enter my mouth, neither did I anoint myself at all”</b> (Daniel 10:3). The Gemara explains the verse: <b>What</b> is the meaning of <b>“I ate no pleasant bread”? Rav Yehuda, son of Rav Shmuel bar Sheilat, said: He did not eat even bread</b> made from <b>refined wheat;</b> he ate only wheat mixed with bran.
The Gemara continues to show that abstaining from smearing oil on oneself is considered an affliction: <b>And from where do we</b> derive that abstaining from the activities that Daniel describes is <b>considered affliction? As it is written: “Then he said to me: Fear not, Daniel, for from the first day that you set your heart to understand and to afflict yourself before your God, your words were heard, and I have come due to your words”</b> (Daniel 10:12). <b>“For you are greatly loved”</b> (Daniel 9:23).
<b>We have found</b> proof that abstaining from <b>smearing</b> oil on oneself is considered affliction; <b>from where do we</b> derive that abstaining from <b>bathing</b> is also called affliction? <b>Rav Zutra, son of Rabbi Toviya, said: The verse states: “And it came into his innards like water, and like oil into his bones”</b> (Psalms 109:18). This means that the water with which one bathes and the oil with which one smears himself are absorbed into the body. Just as abstaining from smearing oil is considered an affliction, so too, abstaining from bathing is considered an affliction. The Gemara objects: <b>But say</b> that “came into his innards like water” is referring to <b>drinking</b> rather than smearing oil. The Gemara rejects this: <b>It is similar</b> to <b>oil. Just as</b> the <b>oil</b> described in the verse is smeared <b>from outside</b> the body and not drunk, <b>so too,</b> the <b>water</b> mentioned in the verse is used for bathing <b>from the outside.</b> It is not drunk.
The Gemara asks: <b>But the <i>tanna</i> took</b> the <b>opposite</b> meaning, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>From where do we derive that smearing</b> oil <b>is like drinking on Yom Kippur? Although there is no</b> explicit <b>proof of the matter</b> from the Bible, <b>there is an allusion to the matter</b> from the verse, <b>as it is stated: “And it came into his innards like water, and like oil into his bones”</b> (Psalms 109:18), meaning that oil on the body is like water within it. Therefore, the phrase “and it came into his innards like water” is referring to the act of drinking water. <b>Rather, Rav Ashi said: Bathing is derived from the same verse</b> cited above, <b>as it is written: “Neither did I anoint myself at all”</b> (Daniel 10:3). This teaches that Daniel did not do any anointing, including bathing. Consequently, the same source prohibits both of these activities.
Apropos the verses from Daniel, the Gemara asks: <b>What</b> did the angel mean when he said to Daniel: <b>“And I have come due to your words”</b> (Daniel 10:12)? From this, it seems that the angel was able to come only because of Daniel. The Gemara answers: <b>This is as it is written: “And there stood before them seventy men of the Elders of the house of Israel, and Jaazaniah, son of Shaphan, standing in the midst of them, each man with his censer in his hand, and a thick cloud of incense went up”</b> (Ezekiel 8:11). Ezekiel saw the Elders of the house of Israel worshipping foreign gods. <b>“And the form of a hand was put forth, and I was taken by a lock of my head; and a spirit lifted me up between the earth and the heaven, and brought me in the visions of God to Jerusalem, to the door of the gate of the inner court that faces northward where</b>

Daf 77a

<b>there was the seat of the image of jealousy, which provokes jealousy”</b> (Ezekiel 8:3). <b>“And he brought me into the inner court of the Lord’s House, and behold at the opening of the Entrance Hall</b> of the Sanctuary <b>of God, between the porch and the altar were about twenty-five men with their backs toward the Temple of the Lord, and their faces toward the east, and they worshipped the sun toward the east”</b> (Ezekiel 8:16). The Gemara explains: <b>From the fact that it is stated “and their faces toward the east,” is it not clear that their backs were to the Sanctuary,</b> which is in the west? <b>Rather, what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states “their backs toward the Temple of the Lord”? This teaches that they would uncover</b> themselves <b>and defecate downward,</b> toward the Divine Presence. The verse used a euphemism to refrain from vulgar language.
<b>The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Michael,</b> the ministering angel of the Jewish people: <b>Michael, your nation has sinned</b> (see Daniel 10:21). <b>He replied: Master of the Universe,</b> may <b>it be enough for the good</b> people <b>among them</b> to save them from destruction. <b>He said to him: I will burn them and the good among them</b> because the good do not rebuke the wicked. <b>Immediately,</b> God spoke to Gabriel: <b>“He spoke to the man clothed in linen and said: Go in between the wheelwork and beneath the cherub, and fill your hands with coals of fire from between the cherubs, and scatter them over the city; and he came before my eyes”</b> (Ezekiel 10:2). <b>Immediately: “And the cherub stretched out his hand from between the cherubs into the fire that was between the cherubs, and took and put it into the hands of him that was clothed in linen, who took it and went out”</b> (Ezekiel 10:7).
<b>Rav Ḥana bar Bizna said</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon Ḥasida said: If it were not for the fact that the embers cooled</b> as they were passed <b>from the hand of the cherub to the hand of Gabriel,</b> instead of Gabriel taking the embers directly himself as he had been told, <b>not a remnant or a refugee of the enemies of the Jewish people,</b> a euphemism for the Jewish people themselves, <b>would have survived.</b> The cooling of the embers limited the punishment.
The Gemara continues. <b>And it is written: “And behold, the man clothed in linen with the slate by his side, reported the matter saying: I have done as You have commanded me”</b> (Ezekiel 9:11). <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: At that moment, they cast out Gabriel from behind the curtain [<i>pargod</i>],</b> where the inner angels reside, <b>and they struck him with sixty blows [<i>pulsei</i>] of fire. They said to him: If you did not do it, you did not do it; if you did do it, why did you not do it according to what you were commanded</b> but deviated from what you were instructed to do? <b>Moreover,</b> after <b>you already did it, do you not have</b> knowledge of the principle: <b>One should not deliver</b> a report <b>about destruction?</b> If one is sent on a mission of destruction, he should not deliver a detailed report of its success but should only hint at it.
<b>They</b> then <b>brought Dubiel, the ministering angel of the Persians and put him in the place of [<i>baḥarikei</i>]</b> Gabriel <b>and he served for twenty-one days. As it is written: “But the prince of the kingdom of Persia stood opposed to me for twenty-one days, but, lo, Michael, one of the chief princes, came to help me and I remained there beside the kings of Persia”</b> (Daniel 10:13). Corresponding to those twenty-one days, <b>they gave him,</b> the ministering angel of Persia, <b>twenty-one kings</b> who ruled and <b>the seaport</b> of <b>Mashhig.</b>
The ministering angel of the Persians <b>said: Write for me that the Jews</b> must pay <b>taxes [<i>akarga</i>]</b> to the Persians. <b>They wrote it for him</b> as he asked. He said: <b>Write for me that the Sages</b> must pay <b>taxes. They wrote</b> this <b>for him. When they wanted to sign</b> the documents, <b>Gabriel stood from behind the curtain and said: “It is vain for you who rise early who sit up late to eat the bread of sorrow, for He gives His beloved sleep”</b> (Psalms 127:2). <b>What</b> does <b>“for He gives His beloved sleep”</b> mean? <b>Rav Yitzḥak said: These are the wives of Torah scholars who disturb</b> their <b>sleep in this world</b> by staying up waiting for their husbands, who rise early and return late from learning Torah, <b>and</b> they thereby <b>merit the World-to-Come.</b> Gabriel asked: Is this the reward they deserve, to pay more taxes? <b>They did not listen to</b> Gabriel.
<b>He said before Him: Master of the Universe, if all the wise men of other nations were placed on one side of the scale, and Daniel the beloved man were on the other side, would he not outweigh them? The Holy One, Blessed be He, said: Who is the one who teaches the virtue of My children? They said to Him: Master of the Universe,</b> it is <b>Gabriel. He said to them: Let him come</b> from behind the partition, as it <b>is stated: “And I have come due to your words”</b> (Daniel 10:12), meaning that Gabriel was permitted to enter from behind the partition because he mentioned Daniel’s name. <b>God</b> then <b>said</b> to the other angels: <b>Let him ascend. They brought him up.</b>
<b>He came</b> and <b>found Dubiel</b> the ministering angel of the Persians <b>holding the letter in his hand.</b> Gabriel <b>wanted to take</b> the letter <b>from him,</b> but Dubiel <b>swallowed it. Some say the letter was written, but it was not signed. Some say it was also signed,</b> but <b>when he swallowed it,</b> the signature <b>was erased.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>This is</b> why, <b>in the kingdom of Persia, there are</b> those <b>who pay taxes and there are</b> those <b>who do not pay taxes,</b> as the decree was not finalized. It also states there: <b>“And when I depart from him, the prince of Greece comes”</b> (Daniel 10:20). Gabriel <b>screamed and screamed</b> that the kings of Greece should not rule over the Jews, <b>but no one listened to him.</b>
§ The Gemara returns to the issue of whether refraining from bathing is considered affliction. <b>If you wish, say</b> instead: The fact <b>that bathing is considered affliction, from where do we</b> derive this? <b>As it is written: “And to Ebiathar the priest the king said: Get to Anatoth to your fields, for you are deserving of death. But I will not put you to death today, because you carried the Ark of the Lord God before David my father, and because you have been afflicted in all that my father was afflicted”</b> (I Kings 2:26). <b>And it is written with regard to David: “For they said the people is hungry, and weary, and thirsty in the wilderness”</b> (II Samuel 17:29). <b>Hunger</b> means <b>from</b> lack of <b>bread</b> to eat, <b>and thirst</b> means <b>from</b> lack of <b>water</b> to drink. The word <b>weary</b> means lack <b>from what? Is it not from bathing?</b> The comparison of the verses suggests that that too is affliction. The Gemara challenges: <b>And perhaps</b> “weary” means from lack of <b>wearing shoes?</b> Therefore, this does not teach us that refraining from bathing is considered an affliction.
<b>Rather,</b> another source needs to be found. <b>Rav Yitzḥak said:</b> It can be derived <b>from here: “As cold water on a weary soul,</b> so is good news from a far country” (Proverbs 25:25). This implies that the word weary is used to describe someone who has not bathed. The Gemara asks: <b>But perhaps</b> the verse is referring to weariness <b>from</b> not <b>drinking?</b> The Gemara rejects this: <b>Is it written: As cold water in a weary soul?</b> That would mean that it entered one like a drink. Rather, <b>“on a weary soul” is written,</b> which implies bathing.
§ The Gemara clarifies the next point in the mishna: The fact that not <b>wearing shoes</b> is considered an affliction, <b>from where do we</b> derive this? <b>As it is written: “And David went up by the ascent of the Mount of Olives, and wept as he went up, and he had his head covered, and was walking barefoot”</b> (II Samuel 15:30). <b>Barefoot</b> implies a lack <b>of what? Is it not</b> a lack <b>of wearing shoes?</b> All these deprivations are described as affliction. The Gemara rejects this: No, <b>perhaps</b> he was barefoot <b>from a horse and whip.</b> Even if he was wearing shoes, a king without a horse and whip was considered as if he were going barefoot.
<b>Rather, Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> We learn it <b>from here,</b> as it states: <b>“Go and loose the sackcloth from your loins, and remove your shoe from your foot”</b> (Isaiah 20:2). <b>And it is written: “And he did so, walking naked and barefoot”</b> (Isaiah 20:2). <b>Barefoot</b> implies a lack <b>of what? Is it not</b> a lack of <b>wearing shoes?</b> The Gemara challenges: <b>And say</b> that perhaps the meaning of barefoot is that Isaiah walked <b>with patched shoes. Because if you do not say this,</b> but you claim that the verse is to be understood literally, does “naked” mean <b>actually naked? Rather,</b> the meaning is that Isaiah walked in <b>ragged garments. Here too,</b> the meaning is that he walked <b>in patched shoes.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> a different source must be found. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said</b> that we derive it <b>from here:</b> It states: <b>“Withhold your foot from being barefoot, and your throat from thirst”</b> (Jeremiah 2:25), meaning: <b>Keep yourself from sin, so that your feet will not come to be barefoot; keep your tongue from idle talk, so that your throat will not come to be thirsty.</b> Consequently, we learn that being barefoot is considered an affliction.
§ The Gemara continues to clarify another of the afflictions of Yom Kippur: <b>From where do we</b> derive the <i>halakha</i> that refraining from <b>conjugal relations is called affliction? As it is written,</b> Laban said to Jacob: <b>“If you shall afflict my daughters, and if you shall take</b> other <b>wives</b> beside my daughters” (Genesis 31:50).

Daf 77b

This can be explained as: <b>“If you shall afflict</b> my daughters” by refraining <b>from conjugal relations, “and if you shall take</b> other wives” causing them to suffer <b>from</b> additional <b>rival</b> wives. The Gemara objects: <b>And say that this</b> phrase <b>and that</b> phrase are both referring to taking <b>rival</b> wives. The Gemara rejects this: <b>Is it written: If you take? “And if you shall take” is written.</b> Therefore, the clauses must be referring to two different kinds of affliction.
The Gemara challenges further: <b>And say that this</b> phrase <b>and that</b> phrase <b>are referring to</b> taking <b>rival</b> wives. <b>One</b> phrase is referring to <b>his</b> wives’ current <b>rivals.</b> “If you shall afflict” means that Jacob should not elevate the position of the two maidservants, Bilhah and Zilpah, to the status of wife, which would make them co-wives with Laban’s daughters. <b>And one</b> phrase is referring to <b>rivals who</b> might <b>come to him from the world</b> at large, which would be <b>similar</b> in meaning to <b>“if you shall take.”</b> The Gemara rejects this: <b>Is it written: If you take and if you afflict?</b> It is logical to first state the more severe warning and then the less severe one. But according to this proposed reading that “take” refers to rivals from the world at large and “afflict” refers to elevating the status of maidservants, the text would have first mentioned the less painful affliction of elevating the maidservants and then followed it with a warning about taking new rival wives, as <b>“if you shall afflict and if you shall take” is written.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said to Abaye: But conjugal relations themselves are called affliction, as it is written:</b> “And Shechem the son of Hamor the Hivite, the prince of the land, saw her; and he took her, <b>and he lay with her and afflicted her”</b> (Genesis 34:2). If so, how can it be said that the affliction is in withholding conjugal relations? <b>He said to him: There,</b> Shechem <b>afflicted her from different relations,</b> meaning he slept with her in an unnatural way. That type of relations is clearly an affliction.
§ The Gemara clarifies some of the prohibitions relating to Yom Kippur. <b>The Sages taught: It is prohibited to bathe part of the body</b> just as it is prohibited to bathe <b>the whole body. But if one is dirty from mud or excrement, he</b> may <b>bathe in his</b> usual <b>manner, and he</b> need <b>not be concerned</b> about transgressing, since his goal is not pleasure. Similarly, <b>it is prohibited to</b> smear oil on <b>part of the body just as</b> it is prohibited to smear oil on <b>the whole body. But if one was sick</b> and needed to smear oil on his body for medicinal purposes, <b>or if one had scabs on his head</b> that would hurt if he did not smear oil on himself, <b>he</b> may <b>smear</b> oil <b>in his</b> usual <b>manner, and he</b> need <b>not be concerned</b> about transgressing.
<b>The school of Menashe taught</b> that <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: A woman</b> may <b>rinse one hand in water,</b> so that she does not touch food before she has washed her hands in the morning, <b>and give bread to her child, and she</b> need <b>not be concerned</b> about violating the prohibition of bathing on Yom Kippur.
<b>They said about Shammai the Elder that he did not want to feed</b> his children <b>with one hand,</b> to avoid having to wash it. This prevented the children from eating during all of Yom Kippur. Due to concerns about the health and the suffering of his children, <b>they decreed that he must feed</b> them <b>with two hands,</b> forcing him to wash both hands. <b>What is the reason</b> that they also said in general that one must wash his hands before touching food? <b>Abaye said: Due to</b> an evil spirit named <b>Shivta,</b> who resides on hands that have not been washed in the morning.
§ <b>The Sages taught: One who goes to greet his father or his teacher, or to greet one who is greater than him</b> in wisdom, and has to cross a river on the way, may <b>cross</b> the water <b>until his neck is in the water, and he</b> need <b>not be concerned</b> that he is violating the prohibition against bathing on Yom Kippur.
<b>A dilemma was raised before them,</b> i.e., the students discussing this question: <b>What</b> is the law concerning <b>a teacher</b> going <b>to</b> visit his <b>student?</b> May he enter the water in order to teach his student? The Gemara tries to bring a proof: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> from what <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar bar Ḥana said: I saw Ze’iri, who went</b> through a river on his way <b>to Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi, his student. Rav Ashi said:</b> This was not the case. Rather, in <b>that</b> case, it was the student <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi who went to Ze’iri, his teacher.</b> Therefore, this incident does not answer the question.
<b>Rava permitted those</b> who lived on the <b>right side</b> of the Euphrates <b>to pass through the water to guard the fruit</b> in their fields on Yom Kippur. <b>Abaye said to Rava:</b> A <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught that supports your</b> opinion. We learned: <b>Guards of fruit</b> may <b>cross</b> the river <b>until their necks are in the water, and they</b> need <b>not be concerned</b> that they are violating the prohibition against bathing on Yom Kippur.
<b>Rav Yosef permitted</b> the <b>people</b> of the village of <b>Bei Tarbu to cross in the water to come to the lecture</b> he delivered <b>on</b> Yom Kippur. <b>He did not,</b> however, <b>permit them to go</b> back home through the water. <b>Abaye said to him: If so, you are obstructing them</b> from coming <b>in the future.</b> They will not come to the lecture knowing they will be prohibited from returning home. <b>Some say</b> the incident happened differently: Rav Yosef <b>permitted them to come and permitted them to go</b> back through the water. <b>Abaye said to him: Granted,</b> you allow them <b>to come, that is well. But what is the reason</b> you allow them <b>to go</b> back? He said to him: <b>So as not to obstruct them</b> from coming <b>in the future.</b>
It is told: <b>Rav Yehuda and Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yehuda were standing on the bank of the Pappa River next to the Ḥatzdad crossing, and Rami bar Pappa was standing on the other side</b> of the river. <b>He raised his voice to them</b> and asked: <b>What is</b> the ruling with regard to <b>crossing over to come to you to ask a <i>halakha</i>? Rav Yehuda said to him:</b> It is <b>Rav and Shmuel who both say: One</b> may <b>cross</b> in the water, <b>provided that he does not remove his hand from under the hem of his cloak.</b> One may not raise the hems of his cloak to his shoulders to keep them dry, since this form of carrying renders one liable to bring a sin-offering. Rather, one should walk normally and get his clothes wet in the water. <b>Some say</b> this is not how the incident happened. Rather, <b>Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yehuda said to him: We learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One may <b>cross over, provided</b> that <b>he does not remove his hand from the hem of his cloak.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef strongly objects to this: And on a weekday is it permitted</b> to walk <b>in such</b> deep water that it presents a danger of drowning? <b>But isn’t it written</b> with regard to the river that, in the future, will issue forth from the Holy of Holies: <b>“He measured a thousand cubits, and he led me through the water; the water was ankle deep”</b> (Ezekiel 47:3); from <b>here</b> it is derived that one <b>is permitted to pass through</b> water that reaches <b>up to the ankles.</b>
Rav Yosef continues explaining the verse: <b>“Again he measured a thousand and he led me through the water, the water was knee deep”</b> (Ezekiel 47:4); from <b>here</b> it is derived that one <b>is permitted to pass through</b> water that reaches <b>up</b> to <b>the knees. “He measured a thousand and led me through the water up to the waist”</b> (Ezekiel 47:4); from <b>here</b> it is derived that one <b>is permitted to pass through</b> water that reaches <b>up to the waist. From this</b> point <b>forward: “And he measured a thousand, a river that I could not pass through”</b> (Ezekiel 47:5). This implies that one is never permitted to pass through water that is more than waist high, because it is dangerous.
<b>Abaye said:</b> That is not a proof, because <b>a river</b> with fast <b>flowing water is different.</b> If it is higher than one’s waist, he could drown. However, one is permitted to cross still water even if it is deeper than that.
§ Apropos the river that will flow in the future, the Gemara explains additional verses in Ezekiel. <b>One might think</b> that Ezekiel <b>could cross</b> the river <b>by swimming. The verse states: “For the water had swollen into <i>saḥu</i> waters”</b> (Ezekiel 47:5). <b>What</b> does <b>“<i>saḥu</i> waters”</b> mean? Water that can be traversed only with <b>a boat</b> [<b><i>shiyuta</i>], as sailing [<i>shayta</i>] is</b> sometimes <b>called swimming [<i>sayḥa</i>]. I might have thought</b> Ezekiel <b>could pass across in a small boat [<i>burni</i>].</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “No galley with oars shall go”</b> (Isaiah 33:21). I <b>might have thought he could pass through in a large boat.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Neither shall a fishing boat [<i>tzi adir</i>] be able to cross it”</b> (Isaiah 33:21). The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> can it <b>be inferred</b> that the words <i>tzi adir</i> mean fishing boat? The Gemara explains: This is how <b>Rav Yosef translated</b> this verse: <b>A fishing boat [<i>sfinat tzayyadin</i>] will not travel on it and a large ship will not cross it.</b>
The Gemara continues its discussion of the river that will in the future come out of the Holy of Holies. <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Pazi said: Even the Angel of Death does not have permission to pass through it</b> to the other side of this river, and proof of this is in the verse, <b>as it is written here: “No galley with oars [<i>ani shayt</i>] can travel” and</b> as <b>it was written there:</b> “Then Satan answered the Lord and said: <b>From going to and fro [<i>mishut</i>] the earth</b> and from walking up and down in it” (Job 1:7). Even Satan, who is also the Angel of Death, cannot cross through this river.
The Gemara cites more <i>midrashim</i> about the river that will flow from the Holy of Holies. <b>Rabbi Pineḥas said in the name of Rav Huna of Tzippori: The spring that comes forth from inside the Holy of Holies</b> is <b>at first</b> very narrow <b>and resembles grasshoppers’ antennae</b> in width. <b>Once it reaches the opening of the Sanctuary it becomes</b> as thick <b>as</b> the <b>thread of</b> the <b>warp; once it reaches the Entrance Hall</b> of the Sanctuary, <b>it becomes</b> as thick <b>as</b> the <b>thread of</b> the <b>woof,</b> which is wider than the warp thread. <b>Once it reaches the opening of</b> the Temple <b>courtyard it becomes like the mouth of a small jug. This is as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>Rav Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: Water,</b>

Daf 78a

<b>in the future, will bubble from under the threshold of the Temple. From this</b> point <b>forward,</b> the spring <b>will grow in strength and rise until it reaches the opening of David’s house,</b> i.e., his grave, which is outside of Jerusalem. <b>When it reaches the opening of David’s house, it will become a flowing river in which <i>zavim</i> and <i>zavot</i>, menstruating women, and women after childbirth will bathe</b> to purify themselves. <b>As it is stated: “On that day there shall be a fountain opened for the house of David and to the inhabitants of Jerusalem for purification and for sprinkling”</b> (Zechariah 13:1).
<b>Rav Yosef said: From here, there is an allusion that a menstruating woman must</b> be able to <b>sit up to her neck in water,</b> i.e., that this is the appropriate depth for waters of a ritual bath to purify. The Gemara comments: <b>But the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with his</b> opinion. Rather, the depth of the water is irrelevant. As long as the water can cover an entire adult body, the ritual bath is kosher.
§ The Gemara investigates the permissibility of crossing water in order to fulfill a mitzva: It works out <b>well</b> that on <b>Yom Kippur</b> it is permitted because <b>there are no shoes,</b> and there is no problem going through water barefoot. However, on <b>Shabbat, when there are shoes, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Is one permitted to cross water wearing shoes? Is there a concern that his shoe might come off and he may pick it up, thereby violating the prohibition of carrying out? <b>Neḥemya, the son-in-law of the <i>Nasi</i>, said: I saw Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi come to a pool of water</b> that they had to cross on Shabbat, <b>and they crossed it while wearing</b> their shoes without removing them first.
The Gemara asks: It works out <b>well</b> that <b>shoes</b> are permitted, since one can tie them tightly, but <b>what is there to say</b> about <b>sandals?</b> Since they do not fit tightly on the foot, they might come off in the water. <b>Rav Riḥumi said: I saw Ravina cross</b> a river while <b>wearing</b> sandals on his feet. <b>Rav Ashi said: If he is</b> wearing <b>sandals,</b> he should <b>not</b> cross the water <b><i>ab initio</i>,</b> lest the sandal fall off his foot and he violate the prohibition of carrying on Shabbat by picking it up.
Incidental to this, the Gemara reports: <b>The Exilarch came to</b> deliver a lecture in <b>Rav Natan’s study hall in Hagronya. Rafram and all the Sages came to the lecture,</b> but <b>Ravina did not come. The next day,</b> when he came, <b>Rafram wanted to remove</b> any anger towards <b>Ravina from the mind</b> of <b>the Exilarch,</b> for missing the lecture. Rafram therefore asked Ravina: <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>the Master did not come to the lecture? He said to him: My foot hurt.</b> He said to him: <b>You should have put shoes on.</b> Ravina answered him: <b>It was the back of the foot</b> that hurt, so wearing shoes would have been hard for me.
Rafram said to Ravina: <b>You should have worn sandals,</b> which leave the heel exposed. <b>He said to him: There was a pool of water on the way</b> that I would have had to cross. <b>He said to him: You should have crossed it wearing</b> the sandals. <b>He said to him: Does the Master not hold</b> with that which <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> One should <b>not</b> wear <b>sandals</b> when crossing a river on Shabbat, <b><i>ab initio</i>?</b> From this conversation, the Exilarch understood that Ravina meant no disrespect in not attending the lecture.
§ The Gemara continues to discuss the laws of Yom Kippur: <b>Yehuda bar Gerogarot taught: It is prohibited to sit on</b> damp <b>clay on Yom Kippur. Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said:</b> This prohibition applies only when the <b>clay</b> is <b>dripping wet,</b> when one feels its wetness when touching it. <b>Abaye said</b> in clarification: It must be <b>dripping wet enough to make something else wet. Rav Yehuda said:</b> One is <b>permitted to cool off with fruit</b> on Yom Kippur, and it is not considered bathing. Similarly, when <b>Rav Yehuda</b> suffered from the heat on Yom Kippur he <b>cooled off</b> by putting <b>a squash</b> on himself.
<b>Rabba cooled off by</b> placing <b>a baby [<i>yanuka</i>]</b> next to him, because a baby’s body is cold. <b>Rava cooled off with a silver cup. Rav Pappa said:</b> If the <b>silver cup</b> is <b>full, it is prohibited;</b> however, if it is <b>not full, it is permitted.</b> With regard to <b>a ceramic</b> cup, both <b>this and that are prohibited, since</b> the water <b>seeps through</b> the cup, causing a violation of the prohibition of bathing. <b>Rav</b> Ashi <b>said: A silver cup that is not full is also prohibited because it can slip [<i>mizderiv</i>]</b> from his hand and spill.
<b>Ze’eira bar Ḥama,</b> the <b>host</b> of the home where <b>Rabbi Ami, and Rabbi Asi, and Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, and all the Sages of Caesarea</b> stayed, <b>said to Rav Yosef, son of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi: Son of a lion, come, I will tell you</b> about <b>a wonderful custom that your father used to perform. He had a cloth that</b> he would prepare <b>on the day before Yom Kippur by soaking it in water and</b> wringing it out, <b>making it</b> almost <b>like a dried cloth. And the next day he wiped his face, hands, and feet with it.</b> On <b>the day before the Ninth of Av,</b> on which the prohibition of bathing is by rabbinic law and not Torah law, he would <b>soak the</b> cloth <b>in water and the next day pass it over his eyes.</b>
<b>Similarly, when Rabba bar Mari came</b> from Eretz Yisrael <b>he said: The day before the Ninth of Av they bring one a cloth, and he</b> may <b>soak it in water and place it under his head. The next day,</b> when only some moisture remains, <b>he</b> may <b>wipe his face, hands, and feet</b> with it. <b>On the day before Yom Kippur, they bring one a cloth, and he</b> may <b>soak it in water and</b> wring it out to <b>make it like a dried cloth. The next day, he</b> may <b>pass it over his eyes. Rabbi Ya’akov said to Rabbi Yirmeya bar Taḥlifa: You told us the opposite.</b> What you told us about Yom Kippur was really what he did on the Ninth of Av, <b>and we objected to you</b> with regard to the prohibition of <b>wringing,</b> since Yom Kippur has the same prohibition of wringing that Shabbat has.
§ <b>Rav Menashya bar Taḥalifa said</b> that <b>Rav Amram said</b> that <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said: They asked Rabbi Elazar</b> ben Pedat: Must <b>an Elder who sits</b> and studies Torah <b>in a yeshiva receive permission</b> from the <i>Nasi</i> <b>to permit</b> him to render <b>firstborn animals permitted,</b> like others who must get permission from the <i>Nasi</i> <b>to</b> render <b>firstborn animals permitted, or not?</b> A firstborn animal may not be eaten until it has a blemish. Knowing which blemishes are permanent and permit the animal to be eaten and which are temporary is specialized knowledge.
The Gemara asks: <b>What are they asking?</b> What is the basis of the question? The Gemara explains: <b>This is what they are asking, like this</b> statement of <b>Rav Idi bar Avin,</b> who <b>said: This matter,</b> the authority of the <i>Nasi</i> to grant permission, <b>was given to the house of the <i>Nasi</i> to raise its stature.</b> Therefore, <b>must permission be received,</b> since the request itself honors the <i>Nasi</i>? <b>Or, perhaps because</b> the individual in question <b>is an Elder who sits</b> and studies Torah <b>in a yeshiva, there is no need. Rav Tzadok ben Ḥaluka rose to his feet and said: I saw Rabbi Yosei ben Zimra, who was an Elder who sat in the yeshiva and who stood before the grandfather of this</b> current <i>Nasi</i>, <b>ask permission</b> from him <b>to permit firstborn animals.</b>
<b>Rabbi Abba said to him:</b> The way you described it <b>was not how the incident was. Rather this was the incident: Rabbi Yosei ben Zimra was a priest, and he raised the following dilemma: Is the <i>halakha</i> in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who <b>said: One who is suspect in</b> a certain <b>area</b> may <b>not judge it and</b> may <b>not testify</b> about <b>it?</b> Priests are suspected of inflicting blemishes on firstborn animals because after the destruction of the Temple, even priests may not benefit from a firstborn animal until it becomes blemished. The question was not one of seeking permission from the <i>Nasi</i>, but it was a question of <i>halakha</i>. Are priests who are Torah scholars also suspected of inflicting blemishes? <b>Or perhaps the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel,</b> who <b>said:</b> One who is suspect <b>is believed about his fellow but is not believed about himself. He resolved</b> the question for <b>him:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.</b>
§ <b>They raised</b> another <b>dilemma</b> before <b>them,</b> the same Sages mentioned: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>going out in sandals made of</b>

Daf 78b

<b>cork on Yom Kippur?</b> Is it considered a shoe, and therefore it may not be worn on Yom Kippur, or not? <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Naḥmani stood on his feet</b> to testify <b>and said: I saw that Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi went out on Yom Kippur in cork sandals, and I said to him: What</b> is the law <b>on a communal fast</b> that is decreed in a time of drought, when shoes are similarly prohibited? Are reed sandals permitted? <b>He said to me:</b> It is <b>no different,</b> and such sandals are permitted even on a communal fast day. <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said: I saw Rabbi Elazar from Nineveh go out in cork sandals on a communal fast day, and I said to him: What</b> is the law <b>on Yom Kippur? He said to me:</b> It is <b>no different,</b> and it is permitted. The Gemara reports: <b>Rav Yehuda went out</b> on Yom Kippur <b>in reed sandals. Abaye went out in</b> sandals made of <b>palm fiber. Rava went out in</b> sandals braided with <b>reeds.</b> None of these sandals are considered to be shoes. <b>Rabba bar Rav Huna wrapped a scarf around his feet and went out.</b>
<b>Rami bar Ḥama raised an objection:</b> We learned that <b>an amputee</b> may <b>go out with his</b> wooden <b>prosthetic leg</b> on Shabbat, since it is like a shoe; <b>these are the words of Rabbi Meir. But Rabbi Yosei prohibits it. And</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught in that regard</b> as an addendum to that mishna: <b>And they agree that it is prohibited to go out wearing it on Yom Kippur.</b> As this indicates that even wooden shoes are prohibited, the materials worn by the aforementioned <i>amora’im</i> should also be prohibited. <b>Abaye said: There,</b> in the case of Yom Kippur, it is prohibited because <b>there are rags</b> in the prosthesis. The prohibition is not due to the shoes but <b>due</b> to the <b>pleasure</b> of the comfort, which is prohibited on Yom Kippur.
<b>Rava said to him: And if</b> the prosthetic leg <b>is not a garment,</b> meaning that it is not a shoe, do the <b>rags make it into a garment?</b> Only shoes are forbidden, not other garments. <b>And furthermore, any</b> other kind of <b>pleasure that is not</b> the pleasure of wearing <b>shoes, is it prohibited on Yom Kippur?</b> Only certain afflictions are mandated on Yom Kippur; activities that are not specifically restricted by those afflictions are permitted. <b>And Rabba bar Rav Huna would wrap a scarf on his feet and go out,</b> demonstrating that the comfort provided by rags is permitted on Yom Kippur. <b>Furthermore,</b> the continuation of the <i>baraita</i> contradicts your explanation that the prohibition is due to the comfort provided by the rags. <b>From</b> the fact <b>that it teaches in the latter clause: If</b> the prosthetic leg <b>has a receptacle</b> designed <b>for rags it</b> is susceptible to <b>ritual impurity</b> like all wooden utensils which have receptacles, <b>it may be inferred that in the first clause we are not dealing with</b> a prosthetic leg that <b>has</b> a hollow space designed for <b>rags.</b> Abaye’s position is thereby rejected.
<b>Rather, Rava said: Actually, according to everyone,</b> a prosthetic leg <b>is</b> considered to be <b>a shoe, and with regard to Shabbat this is what they disagree about: One Sage,</b> Rabbi Yosei <b>holds that we decree</b> a prohibition of wearing a prosthetic leg on Shabbat <b>lest</b> the leg <b>slip off and one come to carry it four cubits</b> in the public domain; <b>and one Sage,</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>holds that we do not decree</b> such a rule.
§ <b>The Sages taught: Young children are permitted</b> to perform <b>all of</b> the prohibited activities on Yom Kippur, <b>except for wearing shoes.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about <b>wearing shoes?</b> It is <b>because</b> observers who see a child wearing shoes <b>will say</b> that <b>adults did this for him,</b> i.e., put them on for him, since he cannot do it for himself. But if that is the reason, with regard to <b>those</b> other prohibitions <b>also,</b> like bathing and smearing oil, <b>they will say</b> that <b>adults did this for him,</b> and children should be prohibited from those activities as well. The Gemara explains: With regard to bathing and smearing oil, <b>they</b> could <b>say that they did this for him yesterday,</b> since one cannot be certain when the child was bathed.
The Gemara asks: If so, we could <b>say</b> this with regard to <b>shoes as well. They</b> could <b>say that they did this for him yesterday.</b> The Gemara answers: In the case of <b>shoes, it is impossible</b> to say an adult <b>did it for him yesterday,</b> since the child would not have worn shoes at night. <b>As Shmuel said: He who desires a taste of death should put on shoes and go to sleep.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> the mishna <b>is teaching</b> that <b>they are permitted</b> to wear shoes <b><i>ab initio</i>.</b> If so, it is permitted for an adult to perform these acts for a child even on the day of Yom Kippur, and the observer will not think that the adult has done anything wrong. <b>Rather,</b> we must explain the mishna as follows: <b>The Sages decreed</b> against performing <b>those</b> actions <b>that are not</b> necessary <b>for</b> the child’s <b>growth,</b> but <b>the Sages did not decree</b> against performing <b>those</b> actions <b>that are</b> necessary <b>for</b> the child’s <b>growth.</b> As <b>Abaye said:</b> My <b>mother told me: A child’s growth</b> requires <b>hot water and oil</b> for smearing. When <b>he grows a little,</b> he must eat <b>egg with <i>kutaḥa</i>,</b> a pickled dip made with milk. <b>When he grows a little</b> more, he must have <b>vessels to break,</b> since he will enjoy breaking them. This is like <b>Rabba</b> who <b>bought cracked ceramic vessels for his children, and they broke them</b> for their enjoyment.
§ We learned in the mishna that according to Rabbi Eliezer, <b>the king and the bride</b> may <b>wash their faces</b> on Yom Kippur. The Gemara asks: <b>Who is</b> the <i>tanna</i> of <b>the mishna?</b> The Gemara answers: It is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥananya ben Teradyon, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The king and the bride</b> may <b>not wash their faces</b> on Yom Kippur. <b>Rabbi Ḥananya ben Teradyon says in the name of Rabbi Eliezer: A king and a bride</b> may <b>wash their faces.</b> The Rabbis said: <b>A new mother</b> may <b>not wear shoes</b> on Yom Kippur. <b>Rabbi Ḥananya ben Teradyon says in the name of Rabbi Eliezer: A new mother</b> may <b>wear shoes.</b>
The Gemara asks: According to Rabbi Eliezer’s opinion, <b>what is the reason</b> that <b>the king</b> may wash his face? <b>Because it is written: “Your eyes shall see the king in his beauty”</b> (Isaiah 33:17). A king should always look regal before his nation. <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>a bride</b> may wash her face? <b>So that she should not</b> appear <b>repulsive to her husband.</b> Since it is only the beginning of their marriage, her husband may be disgusted at seeing her otherwise. <b>Rav said to Rabbi Ḥiyya: For how long</b> after her wedding is a woman considered <b>a bride? He said to him: As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If she becomes a mourner, <b>we do not prevent the bride from wearing perfumes</b> during <b>the entire</b> first <b>thirty days</b> of her marriage. This shows that for the first thirty days, her appearance is most critical.
<b>A new mother</b> may <b>wear shoes.</b> What is the reason for this? <b>Due to the cold</b> there is concern that she will become ill, as she is weak from the birth.
<b>Shmuel said: If</b> a man is worried about walking barefoot on Yom Kippur <b>due to the danger of scorpions, he is permitted</b> to wear shoes, since one need not put himself in danger.
§ We learned in the mishna: On Yom Kippur, <b>one who eats</b> food the <b>volume of a large date</b> is liable. <b>Rav Pappa asked:</b>

Daf 79a

<b>The large date-bulk that they said</b> is the measure that determines liability for eating on Yom Kippur, does this refer to the volume of a large date <b>with its pit or without its pit? Rav Ashi asked</b> a similar question: The mishna that states that <b>a bone</b> that is <b>a barley-grain-bulk</b> imparts ritual impurity, does this refer to the volume of a barley grain <b>with its husk or without its husk?</b> And is that referring to <b>a wet</b> kernel <b>or a dry</b> one? The Gemara clarifies: <b>Rav Ashi did not ask</b> the question <b>that Rav Pappa</b> asked, regarding the size of the date-bulk on Yom Kippur because the answer was clear to him. Since <b>it is stated</b> in the mishna: <b>Large,</b> it means <b>as large as possible,</b> which must include the pit. Conversely, <b>Rav Pappa did not ask</b> the question <b>that Rav Ashi</b> asked regarding the size of the barley-grain-bulk because the answer was clear to him. <b>Wet</b> barley <b>is called <i>shibbolet</i></b> and not barley; <b>without its shell</b> it is no longer called barley but <b>is called <i>ushla</i>.</b> Therefore, the mishna must be referring to dry barley within its shell.
<b>Rava said</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda said: The volume of a large date that they said</b> is <b>larger than an egg-bulk. The Sages have an</b> accepted <b>tradition that with this</b> amount of food, the <b>mind</b> of the one who eats <b>is settled,</b> and he is not afflicted. <b>Less than this</b> amount, <b>the mind is not settled.</b> The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from what we have learned: <b>An incident</b> happened on the festival of <i>Sukkot</i>. <b>They brought a cooked dish to Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai to taste, and</b> they brought <b>to Rabban Gamliel two dates and a tankard of water.</b> Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai and Rabban Gamliel <b>said</b> to them: <b>Bring them up to the <i>sukka</i>,</b> and we will eat there. <b>And</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught in that regard:</b> They <b>did not</b> act this way <b>because that is the <i>halakha</i>,</b> that such food must be eaten in the <i>sukka</i>. <b>Rather, they wished to be stringent upon themselves</b> and not eat anything outside of the <i>sukka</i>.
On the other hand, the Gemara reports: <b>And when they gave Rabbi Tzadok food</b> that was <b>less than an egg-bulk</b> to eat, <b>he held it in a cloth</b> and did not wash his hands. <b>And he ate it outside of the <i>sukka</i> and did not recite</b> Grace after Meals <b>afterward.</b>

Daf 79b

The Gemara clarifies: Food that has the volume of <b>an egg-bulk is required</b> to be eaten in <b>a <i>sukka</i>. If it should enter your mind</b> to say that the <b>volume of the large date that they spoke of is larger than</b> the volume of <b>an egg-bulk,</b> there is a contradiction. <b>Now,</b> comparing the two episodes, it seems that <b>two dates without their pits are not</b> the volume of <b>an egg.</b> If so, <b>can the volume of a large date and its pit</b> be <b>greater than that of an egg-bulk? Rav Yirmeya said: Yes,</b> although <b>two dates without their pits are not equal</b> to <b>an egg-bulk, the volume of a large date and its pit are larger than an egg-bulk,</b> since date pits are very large. <b>Rav Pappa said: This</b> explains the folk saying <b>that people say:</b> In <b>two <i>kav</i> of dates</b> there is <b>one <i>kav</i> and more of pits,</b> meaning that the volume of the pit is larger than that of the fruit itself.
<b>Rava said:</b> This entire line of questioning has no basis: <b>There,</b> in the incident of the <i>sukka</i>, <b>this is the reasoning</b> that the <i>halakha</i> permits eating the dates outside of the <i>sukka</i>, <b>due to</b> the fact that dates <b>are fruit, and fruit need not</b> be eaten in <b>a <i>sukka</i></b> but may be eaten outside of a <i>sukka</i>. The Gemara <b>raises an objection. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: When we would learn Torah with Rabbi Elazar ben Shamua, they brought before us figs and grapes, and we ate them as a casual meal outside of the <i>sukka</i>.</b> The Gemara analyzes this: This implies that in the case of <b>a casual meal, yes,</b> it may be eaten outside of a <i>sukka</i>; but <b>a fixed meal</b> may <b>not</b> be eaten outside of a <i>sukka</i>. Therefore, a meal consisting of fruit must be eaten in a <i>sukka</i>. The Gemara rejects this: That is the wrong inference. Instead, <b>say we ate them as if</b> they were <b>a casual meal,</b> which may be eaten <b>outside of the <i>sukka</i>,</b> meaning that eating fruit is always considered a snack.
<b>If you wish, say</b> instead that it can be understood in this way: <b>We ate</b> that fruit <b>as a fixed meal, and we ate bread as a casual meal with</b> the fruit, to temper their sweetness, <b>outside of the <i>sukka</i>.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say that</b> this <i>baraita</i> <b>supports</b> Rava. It teaches: <b>Therefore, if one completed</b> consuming the amount that one is required to eat in the <i>sukka</i> <b>with types of sweets, he has fulfilled</b> his obligation of sitting in the <i>sukka</i>. <b>If it should enter your mind</b> to say that <b>fruit</b> is <b>required</b> to be eaten in <b>a <i>sukka</i>,</b> then it should not say sweets; <b>let it teach fruit.</b> The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>What</b> do the words <b>types of sweets</b> mean? It means <b>fruit.</b> Therefore, this <i>baraita</i> is not a support for Rava’s opinion. <b>And if you wish, say</b> that this <i>baraita</i> is referring to <b>a place where fruits are uncommon,</b> and therefore other sweet foods are eaten, but fruit can similarly complete the requirement. Consequently, no support can be brought from here.
Until now, the Gemara has assumed that the volume of a large date is more than that of an egg. <b>Rav Zevid</b> disagreed with what was mentioned earlier and <b>said:</b> This is not so. Rather, <b>the volume of a large date that they spoke</b> of <b>is less than an egg-bulk, as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>Beit Shammai say:</b> With regard to <b>leaven,</b> the sourdough used to make dough rise, ownership of <b>the volume of an olive-bulk</b> violates the prohibitions in the following verses stated regarding Passover: “And no leavened bread shall be seen with you” (Exodus 13:7) and “Seven days shall there be no leaven found in your houses” (Exodus 12:19). However, the amount of <b>leavened bread</b> that must be owned to violate the prohibition <b>is the volume of a large date.</b>
The Gemara continues. <b>And we discussed it: What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Beit Shammai?</b> If both leaven and leavened bread had the same measure that determines liability, <b>let the Merciful One write</b> only: <b>“Leavened bread,” and</b> He would <b>not need</b> to write: <b>“Leaven.” I would say,</b> based on logic: <b>If leavened bread, whose leavening ability is</b> not as <b>strong, is prohibited</b> at <b>an olive-bulk, all the more so</b> should <b>not leaven, whose leavening ability is strong</b> because it causes dough to rise, be also prohibited at an olive-bulk? Since <b>the Merciful One distinguishes</b> between <b>them</b> and states both “leaven” and “leavened bread,” this <b>taught you</b> that <b>the measure for one is not</b> the same as <b>the measure for the other.</b> The measure that determines liability for <b>leaven</b> is <b>an olive-bulk,</b> like in the case of most prohibitions from the Torah, and the measure that determines liability for <b>leavened bread,</b> whose leavening ability is weaker, is the <b>volume of a large date.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>And if it should enter your mind</b> to say: <b>The volume of the large date that they spoke</b> of <b>is greater than an egg-bulk, since Beit Shammai are searching for the measure</b> one size <b>larger than an olive-bulk,</b> as they proved that leavened bread must have a larger measure than an olive-bulk, and if the measure one size larger than an olive-bulk is an egg-bulk, then <b>let them teach an egg-bulk</b> and not a date. <b>Alternatively, if they are</b> exactly <b>the same</b> volume, and the volume of a large date has the same volume as an egg-bulk, <b>they should have taught an egg-bulk,</b> which is the more commonly used measure. <b>Rather,</b> must one <b>not conclude from here that the volume of a large date is less than an egg-bulk?</b>
The Gemara rejects this: <b>From where</b> is your proof? <b>Perhaps I could actually say to you</b> that the measure of <b>the volume of a large date that they said is larger than an egg-bulk;</b> however, the volume of a date of <b>normal</b> size is the same as <b>an egg-bulk,</b> and Beit Shammai were referring to a normal-sized date. <b>Alternatively,</b> say <b>that</b> the volume of a large date and an egg-bulk <b>are equal, and</b> the mishna <b>chose</b> to use <b>one of them.</b> Either way, there is no proof from here that the volume of a large date is greater than an egg-bulk.
<b>Rather,</b> it cannot be proven from here. Proof can be found <b>from here: How much</b> must one eat <b>to obligate</b> those with whom he ate in <b>an invitation</b> [<b><i>zimmun</i>]</b> for Grace After Meals? <b>An olive-bulk</b> of food suffices to obligate those with whom they ate in a <i>zimmun</i>; these are <b>the words of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: An egg-bulk</b> is the minimum measure to obligate those with whom they ate in a <i>zimmun</i>. The Gemara clarifies: <b>With regard to what do they disagree? Rabbi Meir holds</b> that the verse “And you shall eat and be satisfied and bless the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 8:10) should be understood as follows: <b>“And you shall eat”; this</b> is referring to <b>eating. “And be satisfied”; this</b> is referring to <b>drinking.</b> The definition of <b>eating</b> throughout the Torah is consuming <b>an olive-bulk. Rabbi Yehuda holds: “And you shall eat and be satisfied”</b> is referring to <b>eating that causes satisfaction, and what is that?</b> The volume of <b>an egg-bulk.</b> Less than that amount of food is not satisfying.
<b>And if it should enter your mind</b> to say that <b>the volume of the large date that they spoke</b> of <b>is larger than an egg-bulk,</b> the following question can be asked: <b>Now</b> that we have said that the volume of <b>an egg-bulk satisfies,</b> can we say that <b>it does not settle the mind,</b> and thereby remove the affliction of Yom Kippur? <b>Rather,</b> must one <b>not conclude from</b> this that <b>the volume of a large date that they said is less than the size of an egg-bulk?</b> Eating the larger amount <b>of an egg-bulk satisfies</b> a person, but eating <b>the volume of a large date</b> only <b>settles his mind.</b>
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b>

Daf 80a

<b>All the measures</b> in the Torah connected to eating are the volume of <b>an olive-bulk, except for</b> the amount of <b>food</b> that renders objects <b>impure, because the verse changed its expression</b> in this case, <b>and the Sages altered the measure</b> accordingly. <b>The proof of this,</b> that the Sages gave it a different measure because the verse used different language for it, is from <b>Yom Kippur.</b> Also in the case of Yom Kippur the Sages assigned a different measure because the verse used a different phrase. The Gemara asks: <b>How did the</b> Sages learn that the <b>verse changed its expression?</b> They learned <b>from:</b> “Any soul which <b>shall not be afflicted”</b> (Leviticus 23:29). The verse does not state: Any soul that shall eat, but rather: “Any soul which shall not be afflicted.” <b>How did the Sages change its measure?</b> One does not violate the prohibition unless he has eaten <b>the volume of a large date-bulk,</b> as opposed to the usual olive-bulk.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what</b> does the <i>baraita</i> mean when it says: <b>A proof for this</b> is from <b>Yom Kippur?</b> Why is the verse pertaining to ritual impurity not sufficient to show that the Sages changed the measure based on the different words in the verse? The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> we learned it only from <b>there,</b> the case of impurity, <b>I would have said that that is the style of the verse,</b> and no <i>halakha</i> can be derived from it. Therefore, the verse pertaining to Yom Kippur teaches that whenever a verse deviates from the usual language, it implies a change in the <i>halakha</i> as well.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that the measure for <b>impure foods</b> is <b>the volume of an egg-bulk? Rabbi Abbahu said that Rabbi Elazar said that the verse states: “Of all food [<i>okhel</i>] which may be eaten [<i>ye’akhel</i>],</b> on which water comes shall be ritually impure” (Leviticus 11:34). The double usage of the root <i>akhal</i> teaches that the ritual impurity of food applies even to the amount which can be described as <b>food that comes on account of food,</b> i.e., food that comes from another food. <b>And which</b> food <b>is that? A chicken egg.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And say</b> it is referring to <b>a kid,</b> which comes from a mother goat, and is therefore also food that comes from another food. The Gemara answers: <b>It lacks ritual slaughter.</b> The young goat is not yet food, since it is not edible until it has been slaughtered. The Gemara asks further: <b>And say</b> it is referring to <b>a <i>ben pekua</i>.</b> Since the slaughter of its mother made it fit to eat, the fetus itself need not be slaughtered, even if it survives and continues to live independently of its mother. The Gemara answers: The calf still <b>requires cutting,</b> since it cannot be eaten live, but it does not require ritual slaughter.
The Gemara asks: Even if we claim that the measure for impure foods is an egg-bulk, one could <b>say</b> it is referring to the giant <b>egg</b>-<b>bulk</b> of the bird called <b><i>bar yokhani</i>.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>If you grasped many, you did not grasp anything; if you grasped few, you grasped something.</b> This means that in a case of doubt, take the smaller number, as it is included in the larger number. Therefore, the correct measure is the volume of a chicken egg. The Gemara questions this: If so, <b>say</b> it is referring to <b>a very small bird’s egg.</b> Consequently, no proof can be brought from the verse that the volume of a chicken egg is the measure for ritual impurity.
<b>Rabbi Abbahu himself said:</b> The verse states: <b>“Of all food which may be eaten.”</b> This is referring to <b>food that you</b> can <b>eat at one time. The Sages estimated: The esophagus cannot hold more</b> than the volume of <b>a chicken’s egg,</b> and therefore this is the measure used for the ritual impurity of foods.
Incidental to the discussion on Torah measures, <b>Rabbi Elazar said: One who</b> unwittingly <b>eats</b> forbidden <b>fat</b> even <b>today must write down the</b> exact <b>measure</b> that he ate, <b>lest another court come</b> in the future <b>and increase the measure.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What does</b> it mean to <b>increase the measure? If we say</b> that a future court <b>will obligate</b> him to bring <b>an offering</b> even for the <b>bulk</b> of <b>a small olive,</b> which is less than what is considered an olive-bulk today, he would not be liable to bring a guilt<b>-</b>offering. <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: It was said with regard to guilt-offerings: “And if any one of the common people sin through error, in doing any of the things which the Lord has commanded <b>not to be done, and be guilty”</b> (Leviticus 4:27)? This teaches that <b>one who repents due to his awareness,</b> i.e., one who repents following becoming aware that he performed a transgression, <b>brings an offering for his unwitting</b> transgression.
However, <b>one who does not repent due to his awareness</b> that he sinned <b>does not bring an offering for his unwitting</b> action. Similarly, if one eats less than an olive-bulk, based on the current measures, he will not be obligated to bring a guilt-offering in the future if the measures change, even if the amount that he ate equals the volume of a revised olive-bulk. This is because the individual would not be bringing his offering because he became aware he had sinned, but because the Torah measures had been changed.
<b>Rather,</b> it should be explained as follows: It is possible that in the future a court <b>will not obligate</b> one to bring <b>an offering until he has</b> eaten the bulk <b>of a large olive,</b> which is more than today’s amount. One should write down how much he ate, since in the future a court might rule that the amount he ate is less than the size of an olive, and therefore he will not be obligated to bring an offering.
The Gemara returns to its first suggestion: <b>According to what entered his mind initially,</b> that in the future a court might <b>obligate</b> him to bring <b>an offering</b> for the bulk of a <b>small olive, what</b> is the meaning of <b>increase the measure?</b> Rabbi Elazar should have said decrease the measure. The Gemara answers: The statement may have meant that <b>perhaps there will be an increase in offerings</b> that are brought <b>due to</b> the smaller <b>measure</b> for liability.
With regard to this topic, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Measures and punishments are <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted <b>to Moses from Sinai.</b> The Gemara expresses surprise at this: <b>The punishments</b> for all transgressions <b>are written</b> explicitly in the Torah, and therefore are not part of an oral transmission from Moses. <b>Rather, this is</b> what was <b>said: Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Measures</b> that determine liability <b>for punishments are <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted <b>to Moses from Sinai.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>This was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Measures of punishments are <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted <b>to Moses from Sinai. Others say:</b> These measures <b>were instituted by the court of Jabez.</b> The Gemara questions this: How can this be? <b>Isn’t it written: “These are the mitzvot which the Lord commanded Moses for the children of Israel at Mount Sinai”</b> (Leviticus 27:34). The word “these” underscores <b>that a prophet is not permitted to introduce</b> any new <b>element</b> related to the Torah and its mitzvot <b>from here on. Rather,</b> over the course of time, the people <b>forgot</b> the measures; subsequently the prophets <b>reestablished</b> the measures and taught them to the masses.
§ We learned in the mishna that <b>one who drinks a cheekful</b> on Yom Kippur is liable. <b>Rabbi Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: This does not</b> mean two <b>cheeks actually full. Rather,</b> the measure that determines liability is the volume of liquid <b>if one pushes</b> the drink <b>to one side</b> of his mouth, <b>and it appears as though his cheek were full.</b> The Gemara questions this: <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: <b>A cheekful,</b> in the plural form, meaning two cheeks full? The Gemara answers: <b>Say: Like</b> two <b>cheeks full</b> in appearance. If viewed from only one side, one whose cheek is full appears as if his entire mouth is full.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to this from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>How much</b> does one need to <b>drink</b> on Yom Kippur <b>to be liable? Beit Shammai say: A quarter-</b><i>log</i>, <b>and Beit Hillel say:</b> Two <b>cheeks full. Rabbi Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Eliezer: Like</b> two <b>cheeks full</b> in appearance from the side, i.e. a single cheekful. <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira says:</b> The <b>amount</b> that one can <b>swallow</b> in one gulp. In this <i>baraita</i>, Beit Hillel’s opinion is that the measure for drinking on Yom Kippur is a cheekful. This implies that a cheekful means an actual cheekful.
The Gemara expresses surprise: <b>Is</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>preferable to the mishna? Since it was established</b> that the measure in the mishna is <b>so that it appears</b> like a cheekful, <b>so too,</b> the <i>baraita</i> can be explained as meaning an amount <b>that looks like</b> two cheeks full. The Gemara questions further: <b>If so,</b> Beit Hillel require an amount that appears like two cheeks full; <b>this is</b> identical with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who says: Like two cheeks full. The Gemara answers: We could say that the practical difference <b>between them</b> is evident in the case of <b>a paltry cheekful,</b> which is not a complete mouthful but slightly less. According to Beit Hillel, one is not liable unless he drinks a full cheekful; but according to Rabbi Eliezer, one is liable even for a paltry mouthful.
<b>Rav Hoshaya strongly objects to this</b> understanding: <b>If so,</b> if Beit Hillel’s measure is a single cheekful, then <b>this is</b> an instance of <b>Beit Shammai’s leniencies and Beit Hillel’s stringencies,</b> since the measure of a quarter-<i>log</i> is larger than a single cheekful. If so, why isn’t this debate listed in tractate <i>Eduyyot</i>, which lists all the cases where Beit Shammai are more lenient than Beit Hillel? <b>He said to him:</b>

Daf 80b

<b>When</b> this question with regard to the measure of liquid <b>was asked,</b> it was not asked about an average-sized person, for whom a mouthful is smaller than a quarter-<i>log</i>. Rather, <b>the question was asked</b> even <b>about Og, king of Bashan,</b> in which case, <b>it is Beit Shammai</b> who are <b>stringent,</b> for Og’s cheekful is much more than a quarter-<i>log</i>.
<b>Rabbi Zeira strongly objects to this</b> <i>halakha</i> with regard to the measure for liability for drinking: <b>What is different</b> with regard to <b>eating,</b> in <b>that all people</b> have the same measure, the <b>volume of a large date; and what is different</b> with regard to <b>drinking, where each and every</b> person is liable <b>according to his own measure,</b> i.e., every individual’s measure depends on the size of his own mouth? <b>Abaye said to him: The Sages have</b> an accepted <b>tradition</b> with regard to <b>the volume of the large date, that</b> eating <b>this</b> amount <b>settles his mind,</b> but <b>less than this</b> amount <b>does not settle</b> his mind. However, with regard to <b>drinking, his mind is settled with</b> the amount of <b>his own</b> cheekful, <b>but his mind is not settled</b> with the cheekful <b>of his fellow</b> who is smaller than him.
<b>Rabbi Zeira strongly objects to this</b> for a different reason: <b>Is everyone</b> of average size satisfied <b>with</b> eating <b>the volume of a large date, and</b> even <b>Og, king of Bashan,</b> is also satisfied <b>with the volume of a large date?</b> If not, there should also be relative measures for eating. <b>Abaye said to him: The Sages have</b> an accepted <b>tradition that this</b> amount <b>settles his mind,</b> but <b>less than this</b> amount <b>does not settle his mind. However, everyone</b> of average size has his mind <b>greatly</b> settled, whereas <b>Og, king of Bashan,</b> has his mind only <b>a little</b> settled. But even so, this measure settles the mind of any person and relieves his affliction.
<b>Rabbi Zeira strongly objects to this</b> further: If it is on account of settling one’s mind, the following question can be raised: If one ate <b>fatty meat,</b> his mind would be settled with the <b>volume of a large date,</b> but if he ate edible <b>grapevine shoots,</b> would his mind similarly be settled <b>with the volume of a large date? Abaye said to him: The Sages have</b> an accepted <b>tradition that with this</b> measure <b>one’s mind is settled,</b> but <b>with less than this</b> measure <b>his mind is not settled. However,</b> with <b>fatty meat,</b> his mind is <b>greatly</b> settled; if one ate the same measure of <b>grapevine shoots,</b> his mind is only <b>a little</b> settled.
